Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>elderly</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is an <vocabulary>old person</vocabulary> (or an <vocabulary>elderly person</vocabulary>). Don't call a person a <jp>古い人</jp>, though. <jp>古い</jp> is used for things, not people. Be nice, they're your elders.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: In Japan, more and more elderly people are living alone or in pairs.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本では、老人の一人ぐらしや二人ぐらしがふえています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Did you patch things up with that elderly person?
Context 3-EN: Wow! That old man is such a hunky beefcake.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うわ！あの老人めちゃくちゃイケメンでマッチョなんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I have <kanji>certain</kanji> <kanji>demand</kanji>s for <kanji>goods</kanji> to take on this trip. Don't worry, it's just the <vocabulary>necessities</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>essentials</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I wonder what the necessities for a newborn baby are.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新生児にとっての必需品って何だろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sweep</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to sweep</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: While you <vocabulary>sweep</vocabulary> you laugh. "<reading>HA</reading> (<jp>は</jp>) HA HA!" Just imagine yourself doing this, or do it for real if you want to clean up a bit.
Context 1-EN: Could you sweep the meeting room before the meeting starts?
Context 1-JP: <jp>会議が始まる前に、会議室をちょっと掃いておいてもらっていいかな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is put on the end of numbers to show how old someone is.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Ever since I turned thirty, my whole body has been itchy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>三十歳を過ぎてから、全身がすごく痒いんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>consolation</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to console</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going <vocabulary>to console</vocabulary> you for what happened to you. The <reading>nag saw</reading> (<jp>なぐさ</jp>) was turned on and buzzed through your leg. What a nagging feeling. You need some consoling.
Context 1-EN: Our dog consoles us whenever we get depressed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>落ち込んでいると、いつもうちのワン子が慰めてくれます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>song</kanji> <kanji>dance</kanji> <kanji>deed</kanji> is a deed you do that involves singing and dancing. This is the traditional form of stage deeds, known as <vocabulary>kabuki</vocabulary>. Watch it on YouTube if you want a taste.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My kabuki ticket is missing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>歌舞伎のチケットが見当たらないんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who has experience (<jp>経験</jp>) is an <vocabulary>experienced person</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Do you think Koichi would hire an experienced criminal at Tofugu?
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチはTofuguに犯罪経験者を雇うと思いますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>white</kanji> <kanji>chrysanthemum</kanji> is a <vocabulary>white chrysanthemum</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading of <jp>白</jp> is a bit different from normal. It's <reading><jp>しら</jp></reading> instead of <jp>しろ</jp>, so do your best to keep that in mind. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: Placing a bunch of white chrysanthemums in front of a house is more than just a nuisance because they are used to mourn the dead in Japan. Do you get what I’m saying?
Context 1-JP: <jp>家の前に大量の白菊を並べるなんて、迷惑行為以上のことだよ。だって、白菊は日本では死者を弔う花だからね。言ってる意味が分かりますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If something <kanji>sticky</kanji> <kanji>wears</kanji> something else on it, it will stick together and form a <vocabulary>cohesion</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>adhesion</vocabulary> onto that thing. It's sticky after all.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why do you keep the adhesive tape in your jewelry box?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして粘着テープを宝石箱に仕舞っているの？</jp>

Meaning: To Heat Up,To Warm Something Up
Meaning Mnemonic: You know that the kanji <jp>温</jp> means <kanji>warm</kanji>, and this verb is related. It means <vocabulary>to heat up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to warm something up</vocabulary>. It's all about you doing something to another object to make it hot, like putting it in the microwave.
Reading Mnemonic: The kanji reading is the same as <jp>温かい</jp>. As long as you know that word, you should be able to associate that reading with this word.
Context 1-EN: Please don't heat that bowl in the microwave.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その器は電子レンジで温めないでください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Before I go to bed, I like to heat up milk and drink it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>夜ねる前に牛乳を温めてホットミルクにして飲むのが好きです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Kombu seaweed releases its sweet flavor when it’s soaked in water and heated up.
Context 3-JP: <jp>水に入れて温めると、昆布のうまみ成分がしみ出てきます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Things you end up <kanji>doing</kanji> in the <kanji>grass</kanji> and not inside probably take a lot of big <vocabulary>action</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>gesture</vocabulary>s. You have to do them outside on the grass because if you did them anywhere else you might break something.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this. Just watch out because rendaku makes <jp>くさ</jp> become <jp>ぐさ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I love to see her picking flowers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かの女が花をつむ仕草が大すきです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What kinds of female gestures do men usually like?
Context 2-JP: <jp>男せいがすきな女せいの仕草はなんですか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was appalled by the smoking adults’ behavior.
Context 3-JP: <jp>煙草を吸う大人の仕草にドキッとした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>escape</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to escape</vocabulary>. Also, it can be <vocabulary>to flee</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to run away</vocabulary>. Basically, if you're trying to get away from someone or something, you could be doing this.
Reading Mnemonic: You are trying <vocabulary>to escape</vocabulary> from something chasing you, but you can't run fast because of your <reading>knee</reading> (<jp>に</jp>). You try to run, but it keeps holding you back. Feel the fear and pain of running with a hurt knee, and curse that knee of yours for holding you back.
Context 1-EN: While running away from my furious wife, my suit got really torn up.
Context 1-JP: <jp>怒り狂った妻から逃げ回っているうちに、スーツがボロボロに痛んでしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If there are <kanji>lie</kanji>s and <kanji>deceit</kanji> in your interactions with people, you're committing <vocabulary>fraud</vocabulary>, you're carrying out a <vocabulary>scam</vocabulary>, you're <vocabulary>swindling</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If you want to know various swindling tricks, you should ask Jenny.
Context 1-JP: <jp>色々な詐欺の手口について知りたいなら、ジェニーに聞いたらいいよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My grandmother was cheated out of one million yen in an imposter scam.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うちのお婆ちゃん、オレオレ詐欺にあって、百万円を騙し取られたんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Have you ever been accused of committing fraud?
Context 3-JP: <jp>詐欺を働いて告訴された経験はおありですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>scent</kanji> or <kanji>fragrance</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to be fragrant</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to smell good</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
Context 1-EN: This perfume doesn't smell at all.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この香水は、全く匂わない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It smells like chocolate from the factory.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その工場からは、チョコレートの香りが匂います。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In spring, different kinds of tulips are fragrant at the flower garden and people visit to enjoy the smells.
Context 3-JP: <jp>春の花畑では、色んな種類のチューリップが匂い、人がたくさん訪れて香りを楽しみます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as this one.
Context 1-EN: That temple stands at the top of this hill.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その寺なら、この坂を上ったところにありますよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet likes going down gentle slopes on his bicycle.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトは自転車でゆるやかな坂を下るのが好きです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The Tofugu baseball team has been on a downward slope since it lost its star player, Fugu.
Context 3-JP: <jp>スター選手であったフグを失ってから、Tofugu野球チームの調子は下り坂となってしまった。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Absorbed In,To Grow Stiff,To Be Devoted To
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>congeal</kanji> or <kanji>freeze</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to grow stiff</vocabulary>. But it's also used to mean what happens when your emotions or interests freeze on one thing. You start <vocabulary>to be absorbed in</vocabulary> whatever that thing is. Try to remember both meanings.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What have all your friends started to be absorbed in? Their 子s (こ). They all keep having kids and now that's all they seem to care about. Damn kids.
Context 1-EN: I’m always absorbed in the arrangement of my wife’s food.
Context 1-JP: <jp>妻の料理の盛り付けは、いつも凝っています。</jp>

Meaning: To Commit A Crime,To Make A Mistake,To Rape
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>crime</kanji> and the verb vocab version can mean <vocabulary>to commit a crime</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to make a mistake</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to rape</vocabulary>, depending on the context.
Reading Mnemonic: You go <vocabulary>to commit a crime</vocabulary>. How did it go, you think? Well, I thought it went <reading>oka</reading>y (<jp>おか</jp>). Imagine yourself committing a crime and it going just okay. Not great, not bad... meh. Okay.
Context 1-EN: I'm going to confess to the sin I committed during the war.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これから戦時中に犯した罪を告白します。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I don't think it's worth doing if we have to break the law.
Context 2-JP: <jp>法律を犯してまでするような事じゃないよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Viet is incapable of making mistakes. For Viet, nothing is impossible.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビエトがミスを犯すことなどない。ビエトに不可能は無い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I will <kanji>inherit</kanji> at your <kanji>consent</kanji>. It's not just given straight to me at birth, though it kind of is. I get <vocabulary>succession</vocabulary>, but only if people say it's okay.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: There is a rumor that someone is plotting the assassination of the successor to the throne.
Context 1-JP: <jp>王位継承者の暗殺を企てている者がいるとの噂があります。</jp>

Meaning: To Look After,To Take Care Of,To Hold On To
Meaning Mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means deposit, and you already learned a similar word that means the same thing as the kanji, 預ける. With this verb, someone is depositing something (or someone) with you, because they want you to look after, to take care of, or to hold on to it.

To differentiate it with 預ける, think of the か in 預かる. The only thing you're willing to look after is your car (か), and nothing else! Someone asks you to look after their kids? Sorry, nothing doing, you're busy taking care of your car. Can you hold on to someone's luggage for them? Nope, your car takes priority.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this before with the pair verb 預ける, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case:

You need someone to look after your kids for the day. Hey I have an idea! Leave them with the monkeys at a zoo (あず)! Monkeys love kids, and kids love monkeys. Now you can zoom off in your cars (か) for the day!
Context 1-EN: It's been decided I'll take care of my sister's child on Sunday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日曜日に妹の子供を預かることになった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The job of a bank isn't only to take care of money.
Context 2-JP: <jp>銀行の仕事はお金を預かるだけではありません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want you to hold onto this for me in case I need it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>必要になった時のために預かっておいてほしい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you go to (<jp>ごと</jp>) a <kanji>circle</kanji>, you need to go to it <vocabulary>in its entirety</vocabulary>. That means you have to circle around the <vocabulary>whole</vocabulary> thing. Otherwise, it isn't even a circle. It's like a line or a squiggle or something.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading, so you should be able to read this too!
Context 1-EN: I’m memorizing the whole song.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは、そのうたを丸ごとあんきしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please give me the whole cow, not half.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その牛、半分だけじゃなくて丸ごと一とう下さい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This cake is filled entirely with apples.
Context 3-JP: <jp>このケーキには林檎が丸ごと入っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <jp>頼む</jp> is "to ask for" or "to request." The noun version of that is <vocabulary>a favor</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a request</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>頼む</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Koichi asked Viet to open the window, but Viet turned down Koichi's request.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチはビエトに窓を開けるよう頼みましたが、ビエトはコウイチの頼みを拒絶しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>gate</kanji>'s <kanji>front door</kanji> is the <vocabulary>doors of a gate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>gate doors</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: When I was waiting in front of the gate doors someone cut in front of me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私が門扉の前で待っていると、誰かが割り込んできました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: So <kanji>luxurious</kanji>! So <kanji>showy</kanji>! Whatever this thing is, it is <vocabulary>luxurious</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>splendid</vocabulary> and I want one.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Wow! That’s splendid. They look delicious. (Kansai-ben)
Context 1-JP: <jp>うわっ！めっちゃ豪華やん。美味しそう。（関西弁）</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: While words that are made up of a single kanji usually take the kun'yomi reading, this one takes the on'yomi reading. Luckily, this is the same reading you learned with the kanji, so it shouldn't be too hard to remember.
Context 1-EN: Please look at the diagram below.
Context 1-JP: <jp>下の図を見てください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you click it, an enlarged view will appear.
Context 2-JP: <jp>クリックすると、かく大図がひょうじされます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Your brother drew a simple diagram of the relationship between him and his girlfriend.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたのお兄さんは、自分と彼女の関係を簡単な図に表しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>remainder</kanji>, but you can't really "to remainder." What is something that's similar that would make sense? How about <vocabulary>to leave behind</vocabulary>. This is when you're actually doing the leaving behind too. For example, you eat some food and you leave behind your rice because you're a bad child. You can remember this because of <jp>す</jp>. Every time you leave some food behind your mom would <reading>sue</reading> you, because she was a terrible mom. Imagine this.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word can come from level 14 item <jp>残る</jp>. Associate the two in your mind and you'll be able to read both.
Context 1-EN: Why don't we leave this creamy chicken pot pie for tomorrow?
Context 1-JP: <jp>このクリーミーチキンポットパイ、明日に残しておかない？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi passed away and left a huge amount of debt behind for Viet.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、ビエトに多がくのしゃっ金を残して死んでしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Thieves broke into the Tofugu office and stole some of our stickers last night, but they were so stupid that they made the elementary mistake of leaving behind their fingerprints.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昨夜Tofuguオフィスに泥棒が入り、Tofuguステッカーを何枚か盗んで行ったのですが、馬鹿な泥棒たちは、指紋を残すという初歩的な過ちも犯しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>vermillion</kanji> colored <kanji>seal</kanji> is a <vocabulary>red seal</vocabulary>. Just look up the (Japanese) word in Google Image search and you'll see what this is.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Could I get the red seal of the shogun on this paper?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この紙に御朱印を押してもらえますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bribe</kanji>, but when you pay a bribe, you are going <vocabulary>to pay</vocabulary> something or <vocabulary>to cover</vocabulary> something, like a meal, or something like that.
Reading Mnemonic: You need to make a payment, <reading>make a</reading> payment <reading>now</reading> (<jp>まかなう</jp>) <vocabulary>to cover</vocabulary> the cost of this room.
Context 1-EN: I don’t think my income would be enough to feed my family if we had a baby now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし今赤ちゃんができたら、俺の収入だけで家族を賄うのは無理だと思うんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Paper</kanji> <kanji>cash</kanji> is <vocabulary>paper money</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for <jp>紙</jp> even though you went through all that trouble to learn the kun'yomi reading. Did you know <vocabulary>paper money</vocabulary> is made of <reading>shee</reading>p (<jp>し</jp>)? Well, part sheep, but there's sheep in there for sure. That's why you can wash your paper money with your t-shirts in the washing machine.
Context 1-EN: Whenever I go to America I feel like I’m rich with all the money in my wallet. Though, they are all one dollar bills.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アメリカに行くと、お財布に紙幣がギッシリ入るのでお金持ちになった気がするんですよね。まあ、それは全部一ドル札なんですが。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>turtle shell</kanji> that is <kanji>patterned</kanji> has much more <vocabulary>effect</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>result</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>worth</vocabulary> than a non-patterned turtle shell.
Reading Mnemonic:
You haven't learned this reading for 甲 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you want to know how much you're worth, just take a look at your car (か). Cars are the result of money and hard work. So basically, they say how much you're worth!
Context 1-EN: Thanks to his efforts, the newsletter was able to avoid being discontinued.
Context 1-JP: <jp>努力の甲斐があって、そのニュースレターは廃刊になるのを免れた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>sigh</kanji>, you feel a certain type of emotion. A type that makes you feel sad and causes you <vocabulary>to lament</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to grieve</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: For the reading, just think about this feeling you're having (this lamenting grieving one). Then, decide you're done with it. <reading>Throw</reading> (<reading><jp>投げ</jp></reading>) it out the window. You don't want these feels anymore!
Context 1-EN: No amount of grieving can bring the dead back to life, so forget about her quickly and marry me instead.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どんなにくよくよ嘆いても、死んだ人はもう戻っては来ないんだから、彼女のことはさっさと忘れて、代わりに私と結婚してよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sacrifice</kanji> <kanji>hit</kanji> is one you do in baseball, when you hit the ball in the air, and then the person on third tags up and scores. In baseball, this can either be a <vocabulary>sacrifice bunt</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sacrifice fly</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned the readings for both of these kanji, so you should be able to read this word already!
Context 1-EN: I can’t help but worry about the sacrifice fly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>犠打にならないか心配です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is used to refer to your own wife, though, for the most part.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your <kanji>wife</kanji> does everything for you. She feeds you, she bathes you, she cleans up after you and even wipes your butt when you poop. Really, she is doing <reading>too mu</reading>ch (<jp>つま</jp>), and you should stop being a baby.
Context 1-EN: For my wife's birthday, I got her a seaplane.
Context 1-JP: <jp>妻のたん生日に、水上飛行機をプレゼントしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My wife went to Koichi's concert and she said it was fantastic, though her seat was in the last row.
Context 2-JP: <jp>妻がコウイチのコンサートに行ってきたんですが、最後尾の席だったけど、すごく良かったと言ってましたよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My ex-wife says, "You’ll never find someone like me." Well exactly! That’s the plan!
Context 3-JP: <jp>元妻が、「私みたいな女にはもう巡り合わないわよ」とか言うんだけどさ…っていうか、それが俺の計画なんですけど、みたいな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>馬鹿</jp> means "idiot?" Well put two idiots together and everything they say and do is absolutely <vocabulary>absurd</vocabulary>. Remember how <vocabulary>ridiculous</vocabulary> that "Dumb and Dumber" movie was? Yeah. Like that.
Reading Mnemonic: You already learned <jp>馬鹿</jp>, so as long as you can remember it twice in a row, you should be able to read this too!
Context 1-EN: Don’t say stupid things.
Context 1-JP: <jp>馬鹿馬鹿しいこと言わないでよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To take a <kanji>supplement</kanji> and <kanji>allocate</kanji> it to where it needs to be is to <vocabulary>resupply</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>refill </vocabulary> something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Could you refill the printer paper before you leave?
Context 1-JP: <jp>帰る前にプリンタの紙を補充しておいてもらえるかな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>及ぶ</jp> is "to reach" then this is something similar. Now you're doing the reaching, and to reach something you have <vocabulary>to exert</vocabulary> yourself to do it. Also, you have <vocabulary>to reach to</vocabulary> the goal you're trying to reach.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>及ぶ</jp>, so if you know that, you'll reach the ability to know this word's reading as well.
Context 1-EN: What effect do people think radioactive contamination has on the human body?
Context 1-JP: <jp>放射能汚染は人体にどのような影響を及ぼすと考えられているのでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>bad</kanji> is <vocabulary>the worst</vocabulary>. At least all there is is up now, right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Today was the worst day ever.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は最悪な一日だったよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The worst case scenario is that I just have to sleep less and work, but it'll be okay.
Context 2-JP: <jp>最悪、すいみん時間をけずって仕事をしなければならないですが、まぁなんとかなるでしょう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "My car was stolen last night." "Oh, no! That’s the worst!"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「昨夜、自動車を盗まれちゃったんだよ。」「げっ、最悪じゃん。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>strange</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is <vocabulary>an eccentric</vocabulary>. They are also an <vocabulary>oddball</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Did you see what's in that weirdo's closet?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの変人のクローゼット、見た？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I challenged myself to set a new world record for acting like an oddball, but I was ten minutes shy.
Context 2-JP: <jp>変人的なふるまいをしつづける世界記ろくにちょう戦したが、おしくも世界記ろくにはあと十分足りなかった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Your boss is a little eccentric but I think you’re going to fit right in.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたの上司はちょっと変人ですが、すぐに馴染めると思いますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're doing a <kanji>prevent</kanji>ion. When you prevent something, what are you really doing? You're trying <vocabulary>to defend</vocabulary> against something from happening. That's why this verb is a little weird and means <vocabulary>to defend</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to protect against</vocabulary>. It can also be <vocabulary>to prevent</vocabulary>, too, but just make sure you're thinking of it more like you're defending something with your prevention.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want <vocabulary>to defend</vocabulary> yourself? You should probably put out that <reading>fuse</reading> (<jp>ふせ</jp>) attached to that giant bomb first then.
Context 1-EN: We need to discuss how to prevent accidents.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうやって事こを防ぐかについて、議論する必要があります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: While Viet and the others were defending themselves against the enemy, Kristen had Prince Koichi escape to Japan.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエト達がてきを防いでいる間に、クリステンはコウイチ王子を日本へにがしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This down jacket will really protect you from the cold.
Context 3-JP: <jp>このダウンジャケットは、寒さをとってもよく防いでくれますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
The kanji 達 pluralizes things sometimes. So, when you have a plural amount of a person you have more than one person, you have people.

Take note! When using this word, you want to attach it to the type of "people" you are talking about. For example, あの人達 (those people over there). Other examples: 男の人達, その人達, 向こうの人達, etc. You don't use this by itself, instead you use it with something describing what kind of people you're talking about.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi readings of the kanji. The readings come from the word <jp>人</jp> and the <jp>だち</jp> of <jp>友達</jp>, though now it's <jp>たち</jp> because it hasn't been rendaku'd. You like to <reading>touch</reading> (<jp>たち</jp>) people, you perv.
Context 1-EN: These people are really talkative, eh?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この人達、みんな本当によく舌が回るよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: People in Texas are very friendly, aren't they!
Context 2-JP: <jp>テキサスの人達ってとっても親切だね！</jp>
Context 3-EN: There are some people who make fun of my dad for being a pizza delivery man, but I’m very proud of him.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お父さんがピザの配達人であることを笑う人達もいますが、僕はお父さんのことをとても誇りに思っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>生まれる</jp> means "to be born?" Well once you're born that place where it happened becomes your <vocabulary>birthplace</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned <jp>生まれる</jp>. Just drop the <jp>る</jp> off the end and you have your reading!
Context 1-EN: I’m Japanese, but I was born in San Francisco.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは日本人ですが、生まれはサンフランシスコです。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>つまは、アメリカ生まれの日本人なんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My birthplace is Osaka, but I was raised in Nara.
Context 3-JP: <jp>生まれは大阪ですが、育ちは奈良です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>大学院</jp> means "graduate school" and <jp>大学生</jp> means "college student?" Well smush them together and you have a  <vocabulary>graduate student</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This graduate student has a green thumb.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この大学院生は、えんげいが上手だ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That player who hit a grand slam is apparently an actual grad student.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あのまんるいホームランを打ったせん手、げん役の大学院生らしいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What kinds of things do graduate students do?
Context 3-JP: <jp>大学院生ってどんなことをするんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: A <vocabulary>diagonal</vocabulary> is anything that's not a right angle. Even if something is at a <jp>七</jp> (<jp>なな</jp>) percent angle is a diagonal, <vocabulary>slanting</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>tilted</vocabulary> angle.
Context 1-EN: I told him to draw a horizontal line, but it’s slightly diagonal.
Context 1-JP: <jp>水平な横線を引くように言ったのに、ちょっと斜めになっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Only <kanji>accept</kanji> new people moving in <kanji>nearby</kanji> once you've finished properly <vocabulary>monitoring</vocabulary> them! <vocabulary>Tapping</vocabulary> into their phones will probably help too, but don't tell anyone I told you to do that.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The police may perform correspondence monitoring for the sake of the criminal investigation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>警察は、犯罪捜査のために、通信の傍受を行うことがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One sided</kanji> <kanji>say</kanji>ing things means you don't know both sides of the language, causing you to speak in <vocabulary>broken language</vocabulary>, for example <vocabulary>broken Japanese</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>broken English</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned for <jp>片</jp> and the <jp>こと</jp> of <jp>言葉</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I managed to get my passport reissued with my broken Japanese.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は片言の日本語でなんとかパスポートの再発行をしてもらいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I can only speak broken English. I'm wondering if I can do things like interpretation.
Context 2-JP: <jp>片言の英語しか話せないんですが、通訳なんてできるんでしょうか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Our daughter is still little, so she can only speak baby talk.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うちの娘はまだ小さいので、片言ぐらいしかしゃべることができません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a noun version of the kanji <kanji>feeling</kanji>. What is that? It's a <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for both on'yomi and kun'yomi of this kanji are the same, actually. So long as you learned the reading that was with the kanji, you can't go wrong. Feel good?
Context 1-EN: That person is nasty, isn't she?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの人感じ悪いよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I went to the office yesterday, I didn't get the impression that Koichiko was pregnant.
Context 2-JP: <jp>きのうオフィスに行った時にはコウイチ子がにんしんしている感じはしませんでしたよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What’s it feel like to be a company president, Mr. Koichi?
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチさん、社長になるって、どんな感じですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that 運転 has to do with driving, right? And you know that 手 often has to do with a person doing something in words like these. So, a person who does driving is what? A driver.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is all on'yomi, because it's jukugo. You should know the on'yomi reading of <jp>手</jp> by now just by seeing similar word patterns to this one.
Context 1-EN: When I took the taxi, the driver happened to be Tofugu's Koichi.
Context 1-JP: <jp>タクシーに乗ったら運転手がトーフグのコウイチだった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I ended up getting in an argument with the bus driver.
Context 2-JP: <jp>バスの運転手と言い争いになってしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The driver seemed okay but his car was totaled in the accident.
Context 3-JP: <jp>運転手は大丈夫だったみたいだけど、車は事故でめちゃくちゃになっていたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
The England country is where England is. This word can refer to Britain, the United Kingdom and England!

Note that イギリス is more common for "England" - but, since this is a kanji learning website you should learn this word.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It was very tough work persuading the stubborn British prime minister, wasn't it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの頑固な英国首相をせっとくするのはとても大変だったでしょう？</jp>
Context 2-EN: A great number of people visit United Kingdom to golf every year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>毎年、大変な数の人たちが、ゴルフをしに英国をおとずれます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The UK has an antagonistic relationship with the US.
Context 3-JP: <jp>英国と米国は敵対関係にある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>five</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji>s that you have are what? Sight, sound, taste, touch, and smell (don't count the sixth one where you see dead people). These are <vocabulary>the five senses</vocabulary> that you probably have.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If you had to lose one of your five senses, which one would you give up and why?
Context 1-JP: <jp>五感のうちどれか一つを失ってしまうとしたら、どれを選びますか？また、その理由も教えてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In my dream last night, there was a smell I didn't notice before... do all five senses work in dreams?
Context 2-JP: <jp>さく夜のゆめで、今までにかいだことのないにおいを感じました。五感ってねている間も働いているんでしょうか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Please study Japanese words and verbs related to the five senses, as well as some Japanese vocabulary related to the sixth sense.
Context 3-JP: <jp>五感に関する日本語の単語と動詞の他に、第六感に関する語彙も学習してください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You need to go through a <kanji>paragraph</kanji> in chunks that you can easily see with your <kanji>eye</kanji> so you break it up by <vocabulary>item</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you out with <jp>目</jp>. If you can't see this <vocabulary>item</vocabulary> in the paragraph with your eye, someone will <reading>mock</reading> (<jp>もく</jp>) you for sure.
Context 1-EN: "Okay! Let’s move on to the next item on the agenda." "Wait! Why don’t we take a ten-minute break before moving on instead?"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「それでは、アジェンダの次の項目へ進みましょう。」「ちょっと待って下さい。次へ進む前に、10分間の休憩を取りませんか？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>member</kanji> of a <kanji>boat</kanji> is called a <vocabulary>sailor</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A seaman will come pick you up this evening, okay?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は夕方に船員さんがおむかえに来てくれるからね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My grandfather was a sailor in the navy.
Context 2-JP: <jp>そ父は海ぐんの船員でした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Could I move into the room where that mariner checked out of today?
Context 3-JP: <jp>今日、あの船員がチェックアウトした部屋に、部屋を変えてもらえませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>kill</kanji> a <kanji>person</kanji> that's <vocabulary>murder</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, if you know <jp>人</jp>'s reading as a vocab word and <jp>殺す</jp>'s reading, you should be able to read this word. Just note that <jp>ころし</jp> goes to <jp>ごろし</jp> due to rendaku.
Context 1-EN: If you commit murder, you must go to prison.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人殺しをしたら、刑務所に行かなければなりません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard there was a murder in this neighborhood yesterday.
Context 2-JP: <jp>昨日、この近所で人殺しがあったそうです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I thought it wouldn't be fun to lead a calculating life, so I'd just do whatever I please, but I ended up becoming a murderer before I knew it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>計算ずくの人生なんてつまらないと思って好き勝手していたら、いつの間にか人殺しになってたんだ。</jp>

Meaning: Japanese Inn,Japanese Hotel,Inn,Ryokan,Japanese Style Inn,Japanese Style Hotel
Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>public building</kanji> for taking <kanji>trip</kanji>s is a place you stay when you are taking a trip. Back in the day that would just be an inn or something. Now, this specifies that the inn is a <vocabulary>Japanese inn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Japanese hotel</vocabulary>. A lot of people even just call it by its Japanese name: <vocabulary>ryokan</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When I travel to Japan, I would like to stay at a Japanese-style hotel.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本に旅行に行ったら旅館にとまってみたいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm traveling to Japan next month. Where do you think I should stay: a Japanese-style inn or a hotel?
Context 2-JP: <jp>来月日本に旅行に行くんだけど、旅館とホテルとどっちにとまった方がいいと思う？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Why are there so many cockroaches in this Japanese inn?" "I think it’s because of all the rain we’ve been getting."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「なんでこの旅館、こんなにゴキブリが出るの？」「最近雨ばっかり降ってるからじゃない？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>pleasant</kanji> <kanji>pleasant</kanji> person is super <vocabulary>pleasant</vocabulary>! They're <vocabulary>happy</vocabulary> and nice to everybody all the time!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A long time ago, a young murderer said, "I can’t help but find murder pleasant."
Context 1-JP: <jp>昔、「僕は殺しが愉快でたまらない」と言った少年殺人犯がいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>recommend</kanji> this to you, so I'd like to <kanji>invite</kanji> you to try it. This is a <vocabulary>solicitation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>invitation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I got a lot of invitations to participate in club activities at the beginning of the university year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大学生活の最初は、部活の勧誘をたくさん受けました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Reason</kanji> is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>exhaust</kanji>ed... but what you're asking is <vocabulary>unreasonable</vocabulary>. Soon my reason will be exhausted, though.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My dream job turned into a nightmare all at once because I had to deal with such an unreasonable boss.
Context 1-JP: <jp>超理不尽な上司とやっていかなくちゃいけなくて、理想の仕事が一気に悪夢になったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you ask me to tell the <kanji>truth</kanji> I'll say your <kanji>face</kanji> is shaped like a <kanji>melon</kanji>. No no, it's not a bad thing! You just have a really <vocabulary>oval face</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic:
This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for 瓜 and 顔, but in the middle there, 実 has a bit of an exceptional reading. You certainly haven't learned this weirdness before, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You know who has an oval face? Zayn (ざね) formerly from One Direction. When you think of handsome oval faces, picture Zayn's.
Context 1-EN: I’m looking for a woman who has an atmosphere with classic features.
Context 1-JP: <jp>瓜実顔で雰囲気のある女優を探しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>doubt</kanji> <kanji>problem</kanji> is caused by having too much <vocabulary>doubt</vocabulary>. Just think about it. Don't doubt yourself, it's why you're getting those vocab words wrong! :P
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It's doubtful whether Koichi actually can't eat meat.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチが本当に肉を食べられないかは疑問です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Mr. Tashiro's behavior on that day is questionable.
Context 2-JP: <jp>田代さんのあの日の行動には疑問がのこります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I like Mayor Fugu but if I was asked what he could do for our community, I still have my doubts.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグ市長は好きですが、私たちの地域に何をしてくれたかって聞かれると、まだ疑問です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Erase</kanji> <kanji>one</kanji> part of your feelings and you'll only feel <vocabulary>a little</vocabulary> bit of them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: For a moment I felt a little anxious.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一抹の不安が胸をよぎった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If all you can see is a <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji> of a person, then you'll only have a <vocabulary>general</vocabulary> idea of what they look like. You know their <vocabulary>outline</vocabulary> is quite big, but you don't know anything else.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That’s about right.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大体あっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We are about the same height.
Context 3-EN: I generally get up at 6 o’clock.

Meaning Mnemonic: When things are put in a <kanji>row</kanji> they end up forming a <vocabulary>line</vocabulary>. This can be a line of people or a line of random stuff.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: "Is this the end of the line? " "No. I'm at the front of the line."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「列の最後びはここですか？」「いいえ、私は列の先頭です。」</jp>
Context 2-EN: My seat was in the second row.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私のせきは、前から二列目でした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There was a long line in front of the bacon shop.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ベーコンショップの前には長い列ができていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>rope</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> people are known as the <vocabulary>Jomon People</vocabulary>, which are the <vocabulary>ancient Japanese</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I wonder if there was the equivalent of teething rings in the Jomon era.
Context 1-JP: <jp>縄文時代にもおしゃぶりみたいなものはあったのかな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>random</kanji> <kanji>boil</kanji> isn't all that random. It's specifically the <vocabulary>new year's dish</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mochi soup</vocabulary>, eaten on new years. Old people and children tend to die every year from this (choking on the mochi), so be  careful if you eat it! Maybe the reason it's called "random boil" is because someone decided to boil a bunch of random things (like mochi) and then it became a new years dish later on. Who knows. That information isn't even known by the ancients.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned the reading for <jp>煮</jp> on the kanji page, but the reading for <jp>雑</jp> is an exceptional one. You did learn this reading with <jp>雑巾</jp>, though. Just imagine yourself with a dust cloth in your new year's dish.
Context 1-EN: The New Year’s mochi soup should be ready by now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お雑煮そろそろ煮えたんじゃないかな。</jp>

Meaning: To Knock Over,To Knock Down,To Bring Down
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means overthrow or collapse, and this verb is transitive, like most verbs ending in す, so you are doing those things to something else. So, this verb means things like to knock over, to knock down, and to bring down.

This word can be used to talk about physically knocking something over, as well as bringing something or someone down, like a government.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You use the power of the <reading>Tao</reading> (<jp>たお</jp>) to do all of your knocking down. Imagine yourself contemplating Tao philosophy, then using those pleasant thoughts to knock everything over around you. BLAM!
Context 1-EN: Who knocked over the perforated ladle?
Context 1-JP: <jp>穴じゃく子、倒したのだれ？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm gonna bring him down, so don't worry too much.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あいつの事はおれが倒してみせるから、余計な心配はするな。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My dad and I knocked down some trees and chopped them up for logs this Sunday.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日曜日、僕は父と一緒に木を何本か切り倒した後、それを叩き切って薪にしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Previous</kanji> from <kanji>now</kanji> are the times around now. They're <vocabulary>these days</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>nowadays</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that <jp>さく</jp> changes to <jp>さっ</jp> as many K-column sounds do in situations like this.
Context 1-EN: Nowadays it is very rare to meet somebody big like you, Mr. Koichi.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨今はあなたの様な大物にお目にかかれることはめったになくなりましたよ、コウイチさん。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Owing to recent trends, Koichi decided to have a Shiba-inu and a Jindo in our office.
Context 2-JP: <jp>昨今の流行りにあやかって、コウイチはオフィスでしば犬とチンド犬をかうことに決めました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: They say it's been a hard time for job seekers these days, but I'm sure you should be able to find a job if you're not picky about the company you work for.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昨今は就職氷河期だと言われているが、会社を選ばなければどこかには就職できるはずである。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also, you can call this a <vocabulary>bowl</vocabulary>, too, if you want.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

You have this container. It's upside down with a stick holding it up and a string on the stick. You're going to catch some U2s (like, the band). You put some food under it and wait. Then, out of the bushes comes Bono. He sniffs around for a bit and then goes under the container. You pull! U2 walked (うつわ) right into the trap! Haha!

Context 1-JP: <jp>この器は母の形見なんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What should I do? I accidentally broke the container of blowfish that Koichi cherishes.
Context 2-JP: <jp>どうしよう？コウイチが大切にしていたフグの器をわってしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: First you put some rice in a bowl, then you put a hamburger patty on the rice, followed by some gravy, and then an egg on top. Then, ta-da! Now, your Loco-moco is done!
Context 3-JP: <jp>まず最初にごはんを器に入れて、次にハンバーグをのせて、それからグレービーソースをかけて、最後に卵をのせたら…ジャーン！ロコモコの出来上がり！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Take the <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>route</kanji>, <kanji>half</kanji> to the <kanji>edge</kanji>. You don't do anything the full way. Just to the middle. Just to the half. The <jp>ぱ</jp> at the end is the only tricky part here since that isn't a common reading (or the one you learned before) for the kanji. Just think of your ol' <reading>Pa</reading> (<jp>ぱ</jp>), who is the biggest half-asser you know.

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>visit</kanji> and the verb vocab version is also <vocabulary>to visit</vocabulary>. What makes it different from <jp>訪ねる</jp>, though? With <jp>訪れる</jp>, you tend to be doing something for fun but with a purpose. So, if you were visiting Tokyo for sightseeing, you could say <jp>訪れる</jp>. If you were going to visit Tokyo for no real reason, you could say <jp>訪ねる</jp>. That being said, they are almost exactly the same, just the nuance is different.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading isn't the same as <jp>訪ねる</jp>, though, I'm afraid. It's <jp>おとず</jp>, so think how this verb is the one where you do have a (fun) purpose to visit wherever you're visiting. That being said, you forgot what you were visiting as well. When you finally remember, it's because you were looking down to think. It's to look at the toes of the giant Buddha statue. "<reading>Oh Toes</reading>!" (<jp>おとず</jp>) you exclaim.
Context 1-EN: If you want to visit the ramen factory you should make your reservations as far in advance as possible.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もしあのラーメン工場に訪れたいのであれば、できるだけ早くに予約を入れる方がいいですよ。</jp>

Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji.

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pull and the verb version vocab means to pull.

This word has another meaning! When you pull numbers away from other numbers, what you're really doing is subtracting them. That's why this word also means to subtract.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading (<jp>ひ</jp>) is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!

Context 3-JP: <jp>引きがねを引いて、フライパンをうった。</jp>

Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning: To Be In Surplus,To Remain Left Over,To Be In Excess
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>surplus</kanji> so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to be in surplus</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to remain left over</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be in excess</vocabulary>. Too much!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "I have a surplus of kittens from that last batch we made, Reddit. <reading>AMA</reading> (ask me anything, <jp>あま</jp>)."
Context 1-EN: We caught more than enough fish ice fishing, so please take some if you'd like.
Context 1-JP: <jp>穴づりでつった魚が余っているので、良かったら少しいかがですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: From the way they live, they seem to have quite an excess of money, don't you think?
Context 2-JP: <jp>くらしぶりからして、あの夫妻、相当お金が余ってそうだと思いませんか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There is an abundance of apples in our orchard.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私達の果樹園にはあり余るほどの林檎があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>遣う</jp> is something along the lines of "to consider" then a "<kanji>small</kanji> consider" is what I'll give you for your <vocabulary>spending money</vocabulary>. Can I have some money? $50? No, how about a smaller consideration on that, maybe something that's more along the lines of an <vocabulary>allowance</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the alternate reading of <jp>小</jp> and <jp>遣う</jp>'s reading. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: How much spending money do you give your kid a month?
Context 1-JP: <jp>お子さんには月々お小遣いはいくら渡しているんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know the word <jp>皿</jp> (plate) and the word <jp>洗う</jp> (to wash), right? You can probably guess dish washing is happening here, but this is a noun, so it's the idea of <vocabulary>dishwashing</vocabulary>, AKA <vocabulary>doing dishes</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>washing dishes</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the individual vocab words (you can tell because there's a bit of hiragana stuck on there). It's the reading for <jp>皿</jp> and <jp>洗う</jp> combined.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>I</kanji> with a <jp>ら</jp> on it makes it plural. It's less formal than <jp>俺たち</jp> (if you've seen that word yet), but has the same meaning. It's <vocabulary>we</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji's reading.
Context 1-EN: I’m sorry. It’s obviously way too early for us to be having this conversation, but I just wanted to tell you that I want to marry you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ごめん。 俺らがこの会話をするのは明らかにすごく早すぎたよな。でも、ただ、俺はお前と結婚したいと思ってるってこと、言いたかったんだ。</jp>

Meaning: To Play A Stringed Instrument,To Play
Meaning Mnemonic: You'd think that this means "to bullet" but it does not. It means <vocabulary>to play a stringed instrument</vocabulary>. It's actually used for all stringed instruments, and all instruments with a keyboard, like pianos and electric keyboards. Just imagine taking a bullet and using it as a pick for a guitar, then using it to press down the keys of a piano and play a tune.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>引く</jp>, which is "to pull." When you play a stringed instrument, you are pulling the string in a direction to make it vibrate and create a sound. So, "to pull" and "to play a stringed instrument" share a reading. It's a bit more of a stretch for instruments with keyboards, but pianos do at least have strings...
Context 1-EN: Mika said that she feels relaxed when she plays the ukulele.
Context 1-JP: <jp>美香ちゃんは、ウクレレを弾くと心が休まると言っていたよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I tried to play an old guitar, one of the strings broke.
Context 2-JP: <jp>古いギターを弾こうとしたら、げんが切れてしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was thrilled by the news that he started playing piano again.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼がまたピアノを弾き始めたというニュースに、私は胸を躍らせました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You want to talk about the <kanji>origin</kanji> where something <kanji>come</kanji>s from. That's where it is from <vocabulary>originally</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This site was originally used as a turtle habitat.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このサイトは本来かめのせいそくちとしてつかわれていた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do you know the original meaning of that word?
Context 2-JP: <jp>その言ばの本来のいみをしっていますか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Kanji in and of itself isn’t a bad thing.
Context 3-JP: <jp>本来漢字は悪いものではない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>feeling</kanji> of the <kanji>action</kanji>s going on around you are the <vocabulary>circumstances</vocabulary>. For example: you feel like things are going pretty poorly right now, which is why the circumstances are looking pretty dire for you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Adults have adult circumstances.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大人には大人の事情があるんですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The police must take all circumstances into account.
Context 2-JP: <jp>警察はすべての事情を考慮しなければならない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Samantha explained the circumstances behind her inability to pay for using Wanikani.
Context 3-JP: <jp>サマンサはワニカニのサービス利用代金がはらえない事情を説明しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>結婚</jp> is <kanji>marriage</kanji>, so the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to marry</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get married</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know <jp>結婚</jp> first, though.
Context 1-EN: You’ve gotta stop thinking about your ex-girlfriend, especially because you asked Salmon’s dad if you could marry her and he said yes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お前、もう元カノについて考えるのはよした方がいいぞ。特に、サーモンのお父さんに彼女と結婚していいかどうか聞いて、許しも得ちまったんだからな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Shift</kanji> and <kanji>move</kanji> to create <vocabulary>movement</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You get worn out when you migrate long-distance by bus.
Context 1-JP: <jp>バスで長距離の移動は疲れる。</jp>

Meaning: To Cover,To Hide,To Lay Upside Down,To Turn Over
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bow</kanji> or <kanji>lay</kanji>, so the verb version is what when you try <vocabulary>to cover</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hide</vocabulary> something. You're doing the action to something, you're not the one hiding.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who's that you're trying to cover up? It's your fool (ふ) brother. He keeps doing embarrassing things and trying to get you in trouble. So you're trying to hide him with your jacket. Well we see him, we know he's a fool, so you can stop now.
Context 1-EN: Why would I cover up my younger brother being a criminal?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして弟が犯罪者であることを伏せていたんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>天気</jp>, meaning "weather," and <jp>予報</jp> meaning "forecast." Put them together and you get the <vocabulary>weather forecast</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I just felt that it was troublesome to check the weather forecast beforehand.
Context 1-JP: <jp>天気予報を事前にチェックするのが面倒くさかったんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The weather forecast said it would rain this afternoon.
Context 2-JP: <jp>天気予報では午後から雨になってたよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The weather forecast was crazy off.

Meaning: Entrance Exam,Entrance Examination,Admission Test,Admission Exam,Admission Examination,Entrance Test
Meaning Mnemonic: For <kanji>school admission</kanji> (<jp>入学</jp>) you're taking an <kanji>examination</kanji> (<jp>試験</jp>). What exams do you have to take to get into a school? How about <vocabulary>entrance exam</vocabulary>s? The Japanese ones are pretty hard. Another word for them is "hell tests."
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It'll also help if you know the two separate words that make up this longer word.
Context 1-EN: My son flew back home smiling after finishing the entrance exam.
Context 1-JP: <jp>入学試験を終えた息子が、ニコニコしながら飛んで帰ってきました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What? The entrance examination fees are that expensive? I'm gonna go bankrupt!
Context 2-JP: <jp>えーっ！入学試験代ってこんなにかかるの？は産しちゃうよ〜。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What! She’s failed the entrance exam?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ええっ！入学試験に落ちちゃったの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>pluck</kanji> and then <kanji>exit</kanji> those plucked items is to do an <vocabulary>extraction</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Could you sort out the extracted data by 5 o’clock?
Context 1-JP: <jp>五時までに抽出データを整理してもらうことはできますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>ancestor</kanji> <kanji>mother</kanji> isn't your mother, it's the mother before your mother, your <vocabulary>grandmother</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>祖</jp> is known to you, but the <jp>母</jp> part is not. To remember the on'yomi reading for <jp>母</jp> in <jp>祖母</jp>, just think about how your <vocabulary>grandmother</vocabulary> had a <reading>bo</reading>at (<jp>ぼ</jp>), even if she didn't... and what an amazing boat it was. If you want, you can imagine your grandma is a boat too, but that might not be very nice.
Context 1-EN: My grandmother always has flashy jewelry on her fingers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の祖母はいつも指にド派手な指輪を嵌めています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that <kanji>invade</kanji>s and <kanji>eat</kanji>s away at something is something that causes <vocabulary>erosion</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>corrosion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Chopping down trees can cause soil erosion.
Context 1-JP: <jp>木々を切り倒すことで、土壌の侵食が引き起こされることがあります。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Anxious,To Worry About,To Lament,To Grieve,To Be Distressed
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>grieve</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to grieve</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be anxious</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your aunt starts to grieve really loudly at your Uncle Ray's funeral. "Ooh, Ray (うれ)! OOoh, Ray why did you have to leave me!" It's really sad. You even hear it in your head after you've left and gone home. You've never seen someone start to be distressed like that in public.
Context 1-EN: It’s natural for parents to be anxious about their children’s’ futures.
Context 1-JP: <jp>親が子供の将来を憂えるのは当然のことだ。</jp>

Meaning: To Keep A Pet,To Raise A Pet,To Own A Pet
Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>domesticate</kanji>. When you domesticate an animal, you get <vocabulary>to keep a pet</vocabulary> of some kind. You'd use this to describe when you are keeping a dog or cat or something.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. The <jp>か</jp> of <reading>ca</reading>t!
Context 1-EN: I want to keep some reptiles as pets.
Context 1-JP: <jp>何か爬虫類をペットに飼いたいな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Shift</kanji> your <kanji>dwelling</kanji>s! Everyone shift! Somewhere else, please. Time for a <vocabulary>migration</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That depends on whether or not you will move to this country.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それはあなたがこの国に移住して来るか来ないかによります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>焦げる</jp> is "to be burned" or "to get burned." This word however is when you're doing the burning, making it <vocabulary>to burn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to scorch</vocabulary>. You know this because when it comes to burning, you pull out all the stops. You use lots of <reading>gas</reading> (<jp>がす</jp>) to burn whatever it is you burn.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>焦げる</jp>, so if you know that you know this word as well.
Context 1-EN: I always burn my toast completely black.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いつもトーストを真っ黒に焦がしてしまう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>fly</kanji> and <kanji>go</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji> is some machine you get into that flies and goes places. It's an <vocabulary>airplane</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I've already booked the airplane tickets.
Context 1-JP: <jp>飛行機のチケット、もう取っちゃったんだよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I was super excited when Koichi sat down next to me on the plane.
Context 2-JP: <jp>飛行機でコウイチのとなりの席になった時、めちゃくちゃこうふんしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I dislike airplanes, so I would never be able to go to Japan.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は飛行機が苦手なので、一生日本に行けることはないでしょう。</jp>

Meaning: Bread Loaf Counter,Counter for Loaves of Bread
Meaning Mnemonic: This has the <jp>〜</jp> for counters, so you can bet this shares the <vocabulary>bread loaf counter</vocabulary> meaning with the kanji.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: I ate four loaves of bread in one sitting from stress.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ストレスで4斤のパンを一気に食べてしまった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It'd be cheaper to bake your own bread if you're buying five loaves of white bread at a time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>食パンを五斤買うなら、自分で焼いた方が安いよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Eight loaves of bread will make twenty-three egg sandwiches and twenty-three tuna sandwiches.
Context 3-JP: <jp>8斤のパンで、卵サンドが23個とツナサンドが23個できる予定だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>abstain</kanji> from doing things a lot you'll need a <vocabulary>backup</vocabulary> plan to get you out of things. Someone invites you to the beach? You need a backup. (It's that you are afraid of the sun, say that!)
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You learned this reading already! Good for you!
Context 1-EN: Who’s the reserve player?
Context 1-JP: <jp>控えの選手には誰がいたっけ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Bind</kanji> a <kanji>bundle</kanji> of sticks to a person as a type of <vocabulary>restraint</vocabulary>. They can't get away when they're tied to a bunch of sticks, can they?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>彼氏の束縛が厳しいんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Fix</kanji> your <kanji>control</kanji> over the planet by assuming <vocabulary>direct control</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Well then, is there an agency the government has direct control over here too?
Context 1-JP: <jp>それじゃあ、ここも政府が直轄している機関なんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>戻る</jp> is "to <kanji>return</kanji>" then you return on the <kanji>street</kanji> you came from, you are taking the <vocabulary>way back</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of everything. Think <jp>戻る</jp> for the <jp>戻り</jp> portion.
Context 1-EN: I didn’t know which way was the way back.
Context 1-JP: <jp>戻り道がどれだか分からなかったんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: All you <kanji>leave behind</kanji> are <kanji>traces</kanji> of the past. These are the <vocabulary>ruins</vocabulary> of what happened before. The <vocabulary>historic remains</vocabulary>...
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We found a Fugu-shaped stone statue in the ancient ruins.
Context 1-JP: <jp>古代の遺跡で、フグの形をした石像を見つけました。</jp>

Meaning: To Get Better,To Get Well,To Heal
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji 治 means cure, but this verb refers to the natural process of getting better: to get better, to get well, or simply to heal. This is an intransitive verb, meaning that it happens on its own. Nobody cures you, you just get better.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

When you get sick, your mom calls every day to ask, "Are you better now (なお)?" How about NOW!? How about NOW!? Jeez Mom, just let me rest!
Context 1-EN: Your disease will most definitely be cured.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お前の病気は必ず治る。</jp>
Context 2-EN: His injuries have healed, but the scars remain.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ケガは治ったが、きずあとが残った。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you know the saying "stupidity can never be cured"?
Context 3-JP: <jp>「バカは一生治らない」っていうことわざ知ってる？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>boat</kanji> that <kanji>come</kanji>s from somewhere else is bringing <vocabulary>imported</vocabulary> goods.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My uncle often boasted that it was imported brandy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>舶来のブランデーだと叔父はよく自慢していた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It <kanji>honorable</kanji>(y) becomes (<jp>なる</jp>) that you <kanji>look at</kanji> something. This is a respectful way to say <vocabulary>to look</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to please look</vocabulary> at something. The reading <jp>を御覧になって下さい！</jp>
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Have you been to the third floor and seen the new rooms already?
Context 1-JP: <jp>もう三階へ行かれて新しい部屋を御覧になられましたか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sew</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to sew</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to stitch</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have to sew yourself some clothes because if you don't you'll be completely nude (ぬ). You don't want anyone to see your bits! Sew quickly!
Context 1-EN: We sewed dust cloths in home economics class.
Context 1-JP: <jp>家庭科の授業で、雑巾を縫いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The credible <kanji>resources</kanji> that determine your professional <kanji>status</kanji> are your <vocabulary>qualifications</vocabulary>. You need some good ones if you want to get into a good school or land a sweet job.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You can have the best qualifications and still lose the ability to make a living.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一流の資格を持っていたって、食いっぱぐれることはあるさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <kanji>fire</kanji> <kanji>illuminate</kanji>s your face, you're going <vocabulary>to feel hot</vocabulary>. Sometimes you start <vocabulary>to flush</vocabulary> when you're embarrassed and it just feels like there is fire making your face light up.
Reading Mnemonic:
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 火 yet, but it's easier to remember this with a mnemonic for the whole thing:

When are you going to feel hot? When is your face going to flush? When I ask you to go to a hotel (ほてる) with me!
Context 1-EN: My body feels hot from this high fever.
Context 1-JP: <jp>高熱で体が火照っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Someplace with <kanji>nothing</kanji> amounts of <kanji>bacteria</kanji> is <vocabulary>sterilized</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I just got an email asking whether or not the Tofugu stickers are sterilized.
Context 1-JP: <jp>Tofuguのステッカーが無菌かどうかの問い合わせのメールが来たんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>decrease</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to decrease</vocabulary>. You can differentiate this from <jp>減る</jp> because with this one, you are the one that is going to be doing the decreasing. The <reading>rush</reading> (<jp>らす</jp>) of decreasing something fills your veins.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>減る</jp>, so if you know that reading you should know this one.
Context 1-EN: The plague reduced the number of blowfish to half its previous level.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その疫病は、河豚の数をそれまでの水準の半分に減らした。</jp>

Meaning: Thank You,That's Enough For Today,Good Work
Meaning Mnemonic: You are a <jp>疲れ</jp> (tired) <jp>様</jp> (honorific that kind of refers to whoever's being mentioned with this word). You say this to people after a day of hard work or after a good practice, etc. <jp>お疲れ様でした</jp>! I suppose the assumption here is that everyone worked until they were tired, so it was a good work, and then you thank them for it and mention how tired everyone is.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>疲れ</jp> and <jp>様</jp>, combined together into one word.
Context 1-EN: When my wife puts my jacket on the hanger she always says, "Thank you for working hard again today."
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の妻は私の背広をハンガーに掛る時に、「今日も一日お仕事お疲れ様でした」といつも言ってくれるんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>cape</kanji> <kanji>ball</kanji> <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Saitama Prefecture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of <jp>埼</jp> and <jp>玉</jp>, and the regular reading for <jp>県</jp>.
Context 1-EN: What brings you to Saitama prefecture?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして埼玉県に来たんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>生</jp> can mean <kanji>raw</kanji>? Well, it does now. So, a <kanji>raw</kanji> <kanji>egg</kanji>? First of all, delicious. Second of all, it means <vocabulary>raw egg</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the vocab <jp>生</jp> and <jp>卵</jp> combined into one <reading><jp>生卵</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: "Do you have raw egg allergy?" "Not that I know of."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「生卵アレルギーはありますか？」「私の知る限りではありません。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>duplicate</kanji> <kanji>numbers</kanji> are when you duplicate the numbers into more numbers, representing <vocabulary>multiple</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I have multiple nicknames and accounts.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私には複数のニックネームとアカウントがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>払い</jp> is a "payment" and <jp>戻す</jp> is "to return." If you return a payment, you are going <vocabulary>to repay</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to refund</vocabulary> someone for their payment.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>払い</jp> and <jp>戻す</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I’m afraid that we cannot refund your deposit since you lost the key.
Context 1-JP: <jp>恐れ入りますが、お客様は鍵を失くされたので、保証金の払い戻しは出来かねます。</jp>

Meaning: To Recognize,To Perceive,To Acknowledge,To Approve,To Admit
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>recognize</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to recognize</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reason I was able <vocabulary>to recognize</vocabulary> you is because your face was covered in <reading>meat</reading> (<jp>みと</jp>). Your face was always covered in meat all those years ago too!
Context 1-EN: I hate to admit it, but I think Fugu is doing a great job this time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>認めるのは悔しいけど、今回はフグはいい仕事をしていると思うよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>People</kanji> <kanji>Rights</kanji> are <vocabulary>human rights</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Some people say that dress codes can violate human rights. What do you think about that?
Context 1-JP: <jp>服装規定が人権侵害にあたることがあるという人もいますが、それについてどう思いますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're <kanji>confused</kanji> and you make a <kanji>mistake</kanji>, no matter how much you didn't mean it, it's still a <vocabulary>mistake</vocabulary>. You should ask for help next time you don't know what you're doing and you won't make these <vocabulary>error</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Don’t you think that’s a little anachronistic?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちょっとそれは時代錯誤じゃないか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>explode</kanji>, it means you're blowing up yourself, and probably taking others with you. This is a <vocabulary>suicide bomb</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I have to commit a suicide bombing by the end of this month.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今月末までに、自爆テロを実行しなくてはなりません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>main</kanji> cause behind someone's <kanji>righteousness</kanji> is usually what <vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>s, <vocabulary>principle</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>doctrine</vocabulary>s they believe in. Buddh<vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>, Shinto<vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>, social<vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>, commun<vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>, you name it. If you believe in one of those it's the main driving factor behind what you believe righteousness to be.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Fugu doesn’t eat meat. He’s a vegetarian.
Context 1-JP: <jp>フグは肉を食べないよ。菜食主義者だからさ。</jp>

Meaning: Bitter Enemies In The Same Boat,Classic Rivals,Traditional Rivals
Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>give</kanji> your rival information that will <kanji>go beyond</kanji> what you normally say and you realize the two of you are in the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>boat</kanji> on a lot of personal things. You are <vocabulary>bitter enemies in the same boat</vocabulary>! Or <vocabulary>classic rivals</vocabulary>, like you see in movies and read about. You never would have known if you hadn't gone beyond what you normally give people.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 舟 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What are bitter enemies in the same boat supposed to do? They shoot (しゅう) each other!
Context 1-EN: If we can share mutual interests, I won’t mind being in the same boat as my rivals.
Context 1-JP: <jp>利害が一致すれば、呉越同舟も厭わない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I'd like to <kanji>isolate</kanji> this <kanji>interval of time</kanji>. Take it, make it separate, and then look at it. Now there is a <vocabulary>space</vocabulary> there. An <vocabulary>interval</vocabulary>, if you will.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Mild contractions are starting in 15 to 20 minutes intervals and I called the hospital to see if we should go now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>生理痛程度の陣痛が15分から20分ぐらいの間隔で始まって、今行った方がいいのか病院に電話をしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Sharpen</kanji> your <kanji>discipline</kanji>, whatever that might be. Could be kanji, could be baseball, could be curling. Whatever it is, when you sharpen it, you have to <vocabulary>study</vocabulary>. You have to do <vocabulary>training</vocabulary>. It's the only way to get better.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The training session is set to begin at 3 p.m.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その研修は午後3時に始まる予定です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
You have righteousness and then a reason behind it, at least in your own mind. This is your sense of duty. And it really is a "sense" in a way, too. You just feel it. It's not an actual thing that is tangible. It is your own personal reason for this righteousness.

This word can also mean in-law like your mother-in-law, because they're your mother in the social obligation sense only, not by blood.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I bought an obligatory box of chocolates for my father in law.
Context 1-JP: <jp>義理の父に義理チョコを買いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
