Self nature is nature itself. That is nature, like all those green things and 青葉 outside. Many apologies if someone hundreds of years from now is reading this. It used to be pretty green outside before the robots.

If you call this "natural" then you are using the な adjective 自然な, but I thought it pertinent to add that in here too.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Wait! Except <jp>自</jp> is <jp>し</jp> and not <jp>じ</jp>! That is because when you add the little dakuten you are adding to the <jp>し</jp>. When it has no dakuten, it is in the form that <vocabulary>nature</vocabulary> intended.
Context 1-EN: I love the nature of Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本の自然が大好きです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It was just natural that Koichi and Koichiko fell in love with each other.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチとコウイチ子がこいに落ちるのはとても自然なことでした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The US government told us to release Fugu into the wild.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私達はアメリカ政府から、フグを自然に返すように言われました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>place</kanji> where <kanji>action</kanji>s and <kanji>task</kanji>s happen is the <vocabulary>office</vocabulary>. None of that happens at home. The office is more of an action / task place.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Let me quickly show you around the Tofugu office.
Context 1-JP: <jp>当社トフグの事務所を簡単にご案内させてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Suppose</kanji> that <kanji>life</kanji> is in <vocabulary>existence</vocabulary> on this planet... What would that say about <vocabulary>life</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>survival</vocabulary> in such an unforgiving place?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Our bodies always need water for survival.
Context 1-JP: <jp>われわれの肉体は、生存のためにつねに水分を必要としている。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In that world, titans were threatening the existence of humanity.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その世界では、きょ人たちが人るい生存のきょういとなっていた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The FBI searched all night for the survivor in the Tofugu office.
Context 3-JP: <jp>FBIは、生存者を求めて、夜通しTofuguオフィスの中を捜索した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The meaning of this word is the same as the kanji, except it has an <jp>お</jp> before it, which just makes the thing you're saying elevate the other person more. Basically, it's more polite and awesome.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I wanted to thank you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたにお礼をいいたかったんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I got a beer as thanks.
Context 2-JP: <jp>お礼にビールをもらいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’d like to thank Spider-Man for taking back the streets and making our city safe again.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この町が平和を取り戻したことについて、スパイダーマンにお礼を言いたい。</jp>

Meaning: To Put In Disorder,To Throw Out Of Order,To Disturb
Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>乱れる</jp> is "to be in disorder"? Well, now you're the one causing this. So, by doing this you are going <vocabulary>to put in disorder</vocabulary> things. Just imagine all the people who will try to <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) you for your actions.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>乱れる</jp>, so make sure you know that so you can know this as well.
Context 1-EN: Kids with ADHD typically can’t stand having the rhythm of their lives thrown out of order.
Context 1-JP: <jp>注意欠陥過活動性障害の子どもは、生活のリズムを乱されることに耐えられないことが多いです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>concept</kanji> you <kanji>think</kanji> about is your <vocabulary>thought</vocabulary>s. It is your <vocabulary>idea</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for 思 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

All your thoughts and ideas are about sheep (し) right now. You just can't stop thinking about sheep. Are you thinking about sheep right now? What kind of sheep are they?
Context 1-EN: I can't follow Koichi's thoughts.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチの思想にはついていけません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I was watching the news yesterday, I was so shocked that it said Viet was arrested for thoughtcrimes.
Context 2-JP: <jp>きのう、ニュースを見ていたら、ビエトが思想犯としてたいほされたニュースが出て本当にびっくりしたよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi is the founder of Tofugu and one of the great modern Japanese thinkers.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチはトーフグの創始者であり、近代日本を代表する啓蒙思想家である。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>lodge</kanji> area is <vocabulary>Shinjuku</vocabulary>, a popular district in Tokyo. Perhaps there are many places to stay in Shinjuku. Either way, you should visit, it's fun! It will help if you've heard of Shinjuku before, too. Do some research about Shinjuku if you've never heard of it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be careful of the <jp>しゅく</jp> changing to <jp>じゅく</jp>. Once again, will help if you've heard of Shinjuku.
Context 1-EN: This Shinjuku hotel's shower only has cold or lukewarm water.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この新宿のホテルのシャワーは、水かぬるま湯しか出ない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Shinjuku is always dead last on my personal list of places I want to visit each year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>新宿は毎年、わたしの行ってみたい場所ランキングの中で最下位です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Shinjuku 2-chome is now known as a gay town but it used to be a sketchy red light district.
Context 3-JP: <jp>新宿二丁目は今はゲイタウンとして知られていますが、昔は危険な香りのする赤線地区でした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Okayama (<jp>岡山</jp>) <kanji>Prefecture</kanji> is a prefecture in Japan. Learning the reading will help you to remember the meaning of this word since half of it is in Japanese.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the first two kanji. Luckily you learned them when you learned the kanji. Then, stick <jp>県</jp> on there and you should be good to go!
Context 1-EN: Is there any vernacular architecture in Okayama prefecture?
Context 1-JP: <jp>岡山県には、土地特有の建築物はありますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>detain</kanji> your <kanji>study</kanji> and take it away to a foreign place. That foreign place is having you <vocabulary>study abroad</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for <jp>留</jp> is the <jp>りゅう</jp> version. You can remember this because <reading>Ryu</reading> (<jp>りゅう</jp>) from street fighter is doing a study abroad program to learn more karate.
Context 1-EN: "My older brother didn't obey the orders of our parents and left to study abroad." "Where is his study abroad destination?" "It's in the U.S."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「兄は親の言いつけを守らず、留学してしまいました。」「留学先はどこなんですか？」「アメリカです。」</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I studied abroad, I practiced speaking Japanese naturally a lot.
Context 2-JP: <jp>留学先で、日本語を自然にしゃべる練習をたくさんしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Could you reschedule my appointment for next Sunday? On Saturday I have to go to the Japanese Consulate General to get some study abroad documents.
Context 3-JP: <jp>約束を来週の日曜日に変更していただけませんか？土曜日に、留学の書類を取りに日本総領事館に行かなければならなくなってしまって。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Think back to the old old olden days. Back when decisions were made with swords. A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>cut</kanji> is going to be <vocabulary>important</vocabulary>. Just imagine a couple samurai squaring off, then charging, then making one big cut. It's the most important thing they'll do in their lives (if they live!).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This is the doll that Mary treats with a great deal of care.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは、メアリーが大切にしている人ぎょうです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You should cherish your friends, partner, and family who stand by you.
Context 2-JP: <jp>そばにいてくれる友人やこい人、かぞくを大切にした方がいいですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Whenever I hear that a document is very important, I always want to look at what’s inside.
Context 3-JP: <jp>大切なしょるいときくと、いつも中みをみたくなる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Table</kanji> <kanji>sphere</kanji> is a sport where you have a table and then you use a sphere on it. That's <vocabulary>table tennis</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>ping pong</vocabulary>. Makes sense, right? You use a ping pong ball and you play on a table.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of <jp>たく</jp>'s shortening.
Context 1-EN: That ping pong noise is driving me crazy!
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの卓球の音のせいで気が変になりそうだ！</jp>

Meaning: To Be In Time For,To Make It On Time,To Be On Time For
Meaning Mnemonic: There is an <kanji>interval</kanji> (of time) that you need "to suit" (<jp>合う</jp>). To suit that interval, you need to be there before the time in question. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to be in time for</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to make it on time</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be on time for</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned this reading for <jp>間</jp> when you learned <jp>間もなく</jp>. And the reading for <jp>合う</jp> is just that of the word <jp>合う</jp>. If you remember them both, you'll remember this word!
Context 1-EN: If we get in a taxi right now, we might still make it on time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今すぐタクシーに乗れば、まだ間に合うかもしれません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Sorry! I'm stuck in traffic, so I'm most likely not going to make it to the appointment on time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ごめん！じゅうたいにはまっちゃって、待ち合わせに間に合いそうにない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Do you think we can make it in time?" "Well, it’s almost seven o’clock. Do the math."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「間に合うと思う？」「もうすぐ7時なんだから、後は自分で考えればわかるだろ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <jp>形容詞</jp> is an <kanji>adjective</kanji>. So what about an adjective with a <jp>動詞</jp> (verb) in there? How does that make sense? I'm not entirely sure either, but an adjective with movement in it is a <vocabulary>na adjective</vocabulary>. These are the adjectives that can end with <jp>な</jp> (<jp>便利な</jp>, for example). In fact, they're more like nouns than they are verbs, so what gives? Whatever it is, just decide you don't want to deal with this craziness. Just say <reading>nah</reading>, I don't care about this anymore.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know <jp>形容詞</jp> and <jp>動詞</jp> as well, since they're both parts of this word.
Context 1-EN: Today’s class was on na-adjectives.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日の授業は形容動詞でした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I mixed up na-adjectives with i-adjectives and now I'm really confused.
Context 2-JP: <jp>頭の中で、形容動詞と形容詞が混ぜこぜになってしまっていて、かなり混乱しています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I found it difficult to judge whether it was a na-adjective or just an i-adjective.
Context 3-JP: <jp>それが形容動詞なのかただの形容詞なのか、判断にまよいました。</jp>

Meaning: To Get Tired Of,To Lose Interest In
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bored</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to get tired of</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lose interest in</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you start to get tired of something you can't help but yawn "Ahh (あ)." It doesn't matter how hard you try to hold back. The "A-ah's" keep coming out.
Context 1-EN: I’m at a place where I’m starting to lose interest in my new lover.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新しい恋人に飽きてきたところなの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Let’s meet up at the intersection of the earth’s axis and the celestial sphere in the Arctic.
Context 1-JP: <jp>地軸の延長が北方で天球と交わる点で会いましょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>employment</kanji> (<jp>雇用</jp>) <kanji>someone</kanji> is someone who gives you employment, aka an <vocabulary>employer</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ve told my new phone number to my employer over and over again, but he always calls me at the old number.
Context 1-JP: <jp>雇用者に新しい電話番号を何度も教えてるのに、いっつも古い方の番号に掛けてくるんだよな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: My <kanji>various</kanji> <kanji>buddies</kanji>! Wait, that didn't come out right. <vocabulary>Gentlemen</vocabulary>! <vocabulary>My friends</vocabulary>! There we go, much better.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My friends, do you realize this is probably the last time we’ll all be here in the Tofugu office as ten single people?
Context 1-JP: <jp>諸君、Tofuguオフィスで独身の 10 人がみんな集まるのってこれがたぶん最後だってこと、気がついていたかい？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>say</kanji>, so the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to say</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

To remember the reading い we use the word "eagle."

You're trying to say something, but every time you try to say anything an eagle (い) swoops down and pecks at your face then flies away. Just imagine yourself saying tiny bits of words, then an eagle crashing down on your face. Then, you wait in silence. Nothing happens. You try to say something again, and the eagle swoops down on you again.
Context 1-EN: Please say it slowly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ゆっくり言ってください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: How can I say, "Thank you always," in English?
Context 2-JP: <jp>いつもありがとうってえいごで何て言うの？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Are you going to say sorry to Jake for stepping on his foot?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ジェイクに、足を踏んでごめんって言うつもりなの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>have</kanji> <kanji>benefit</kanji> is to be <vocabulary>beneficial</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Thank you very much for your very useful information.
Context 1-JP: <jp>非常に有益な情報を提供して頂き、誠に有り難うございます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>の</jp> particle makes it so the <jp>人</jp> belongs to the <jp>女</jp>. Basically, this literally means "a woman person" or "a person of woman." It's a more polite way to say plain old woman, though, so all you have to remember is that.
Reading Mnemonic: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). That being said, in level 1 you learned about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.
Context 1-EN: I was bullied by a woman.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは女の人にいじめられた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The cafe was full of women.
Context 2-JP: <jp>そのカフェは女の人だらけでした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m not good at talking to women.
Context 3-JP: <jp>女の人としゃべるのが苦手です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>東京</jp> is <kanji>Tokyo</kanji>, and you know that <jp>弁</jp> is <kanji>dialect</kanji>, so you have yourself <vocabulary>Tokyo dialect</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read <jp>東京</jp> already, which you should.
Context 1-EN: Tokyo dialect is almost the same as standard Japanese.
Context 1-JP: <jp>東京弁は共通語とほとんど同じですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I rejected Koichi's request that I speak in Tokyo dialect.
Context 2-JP: <jp>東京弁でしゃべってほしいというコウイチの要求をしりぞけました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I need to get some free Tokyo dialect lessons." "Ask Koichi. He’ll do anything."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ねえ、無料で東京弁のレッスンを受けたいんだけど。」「コウイチに聞けよ。アイツは何でもするぞ。」</jp>

Meaning: To Put Down,To Set Down,To Place,To Put
Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>put</kanji> something you don't just put it, you have <vocabulary>to put down</vocabulary> this item or even <vocabulary>(to) set down</vocabulary> the item. Basically, you have to put something down with this verb. It's a little different from the kanji meaning you learned but not that different.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just imagine you're putting down <reading>O</reading>reos (<jp>お</jp>). One after another. Each oreo that you try <vocabulary>to put down</vocabulary> say in your head "Hello Mr. Oreo, I'm going to put you down.. ooh yes, you like that don't you?" REPEAT.
Context 1-EN: Fugu and I are putting some distance between us right now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>フグと私は今距離を置いてるの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bind</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to tie</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to bind</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What do you want to tie up? Your Shiba (しば) Inu! She's always running off and getting into trouble. You have to tie her up outside when you leave the house. It's sad, but at least it keeps her safe!
Context 1-EN: I tied my shoelaces tightly so they wouldn't come loose.
Context 1-JP: <jp>靴紐が解けないようにしっかり縛った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>華やか</jp> is "showy." Now we're doubling it, making it doubly showy. If you make something showy enough, it becomes <vocabulary>gorgeous</vocabulary>, but it also becomes pretty <vocabulary>flamboyant</vocabulary>. So, so, so flamboyant.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>華やか</jp>. Note the second <jp>はな</jp> becomes <jp>ばな</jp>, to be <reading><jp>はなばなしい</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: That left‐handed pitcher made a brilliant major league debut.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その左利きの投手は、大リーグで華々しいデビューを飾りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You already learned that <jp>歌謡</jp> means "song," so when you add <kanji>music</kanji> to that it becomes a super <vocabulary>popular song</vocabulary>. It's not just a song anymore. It's in everything you hear!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A list of the 100 best, most unforgettable, popular songs from the Showa Era was announced.
Context 1-JP: <jp>心に残る昭和の歌謡曲ベスト100のリストが公表されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though it adds a few more meanings as well, like <vocabulary>nail</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>talon</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hoof</vocabulary> or really any hard thing on the ends of fingers or feet.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading takes the second <jp>爪</jp> reading, <reading><jp>つめ</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: Her right pinky nail is six meters long.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女の右の小指の爪の長さはなんと六メートルもあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>社長</jp> is the company president? This uses the same <jp>長</jp> meaning (where it means something like "boss"). Since <jp>課</jp> means <kanji>section</kanji>, this is the <vocabulary>section manager</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I got promoted to section manager last month.
Context 1-JP: <jp>先月、課長にしょう進しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm glad I was able to become a section chief, but my pay has actually decreased because I don't get paid for overtime.
Context 2-JP: <jp>課長になれたのはうれしいんだけど、ざん業代が出ないから実はきゅう料が下がったんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My section manager is kind of annoying. He is always trying to impress the other workers.
Context 3-JP: <jp>課長が少しうざいんだよね。他の社員に良い印象を与えようといつも頑張っちゃってさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Since this is a kanji with hiragana attached that ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know that this word is a verb. What's the ultimate verb version of the kanji <jp>生</jp>? That would be <vocabulary>to be born</vocabulary>, the very beginning of life as we know it!
Reading Mnemonic:
You have to remember the う part of this word to read it. To remember that, let's use a mnemonic:

Just imagine someone being born. All they do is scream: UUUUUuuUuuUUUuuuUUUuu (う) the whole time. Go ahead and imagine yourself being born and doing the same thing. Say UUUuuUUuuu out loud to help you to remember.
Context 1-EN: On Sunday, Yang’s child was born.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日よう日、ヤンさんの子どもが生まれました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please watch these home runs produced by the strong swings of a pro player named Michael.
Context 2-JP: <jp>マイケルせん手の、力づよいフルスイングから生まれるホームランのかずかずをごらんください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do not make a newborn baby drink alcohol.
Context 3-JP: <jp>生まれたばかりの子どもに、さけをのませるな。</jp>

Meaning: In A Row,Arrange In A Row
Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Line up</kanji> everything in a <kanji>row</kanji>. When you do that, they're all <vocabulary>in a row</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If my boyfriend was bad at reverse parallel parking I’d be disappointed in him.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし自分の彼氏が後ろ向きで入る並列駐車が上手くできなかったら、がっかりしちゃうと思う。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>populous</kanji> place sounds like a place with a lot of people but it's more like a big part of the populace. It's most of the populace, sure, making it the <vocabulary>general public</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It depends on how people feel.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大衆の感じ方次第です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Take things apart into <kanji>part</kanji>s. Then, do <kanji>analysis</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>analysis</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That’s the result of the teacher’s breath quality analysis.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それは先生の息の質の分析結果です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Enter</kanji> into a <kanji>squad</kanji>... an army squad. When you do this, you <vocabulary>enlist in the army</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Can a Japanese man enlist in the U.S. army?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本人男性がアメリカ軍に入隊することはできますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>purification</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is the place where you perform purification on people. Who needs the most purification? The dead. Where do you purify them? In a <vocabulary>funeral hall</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi for <jp>場</jp> when you learned <jp>入場</jp> ages ago.
Context 1-EN: We’re about to arrive at the funeral hall.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちょうど斎場に到着するところです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Temporarily</kanji> <kanji>determine</kanji> something. That makes it <vocabulary>tentative</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>temporary</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Please bear in mind that these prices are temporary.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こちらの料金設定は暫定的ですのでご留意下さいませ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>manage</kanji>d by the <kanji>city</kanji> is <vocabulary>run by the city</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>city-run</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Osaka City built a very unique, city-run incineration plant in Maishima.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大阪市は、舞州にすごくユニークな市営のゴミ焼却炉を建設しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
You're so glad, you get glad again. Wow, you're just happily going through life, aren't you? Joyfully accept that gladness into your life!

This word is pretty old, and it's used like a noun with と(して) added to make it an adverb or たる added to make it an adjective. Make sure to check out the context sentences to get more familiar with this classical word.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses on'yomi readings of the kanji you learned... twice! You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: As soon as they get pregnant, they will happily let us know.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子供ができればすぐ、嬉々として報告してくれるだろう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My father saw his old friend for the first time in a long time and they happily caught up with each other.
Context 2-JP: <jp>父は、久しぶりに旧友に会い、嬉々として近況を語り合った。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi returned safely and the village was filled with joyful voices.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチが無事に帰ってきて、村には嬉々たる声が響いた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Inside</kanji> <kanji>internal organs</kanji> are your <vocabulary>internal organs</vocabulary>, though you'd think the second kanji would give a hint to that without the <jp>内</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: They take the internal organs out of deer in my neighbor’s garage.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ご近所さんのガレージで鹿の内臓を取り出すんです。</jp>

Meaning: To Send Someone Back,To Send Someone Home
Meaning Mnemonic:
The hiragana ends with an う sound, so you know this is a verb. The kanji itself means return, and this verb is transitive, meaning it takes a direct object. You send someone back. You send them home. And tell them to never come near you again. So this means to send someone back or to send someone home.

In fact, most verbs ending in す are transitive. To help you remember that, think of suing (す) someone to make sure they go home!
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Yay! But since this word has a pair verb, let's think of a way to remember the ending:

What's the most surefire way to send someone home? Threaten to sue (す) them if they don't!
Context 1-EN: I sent my driver home a little early today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は少し早く運転手を帰した。</jp>
Context 2-EN: They won't send you home unless you finish all the work.
Context 2-JP: <jp>作業が全部終わらないと帰してもらえないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want to send this fish back to the ocean quickly.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この魚を早く海に帰してあげたいんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have a <kanji>flavor</kanji> of <kanji>dislike</kanji>. If someone gives you "flavor" and you dislike it, what might that "flavor" be? How about <vocabulary>hurtful words</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>味</jp> is the on'yomi you learned with the kanji, but the reading for <jp>嫌</jp> is the kun'yomi, <jp>いや</jp>. Just imagine someone saying words so hurtful that you have to scream, "<reading>Iya</reading>aaaa!" <jp>いや</jp>.
Context 1-EN: He’s kind of an idiot, really. Why didn’t he realize that it was sarcastic?
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼はちょっと頭が悪いよね。どうしてあれが嫌味だってことに気づかないのかしら。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Look in the sea and you'll see what looks like a <kanji>crow</kanji> moving under the water and it's a <kanji>thief</kanji>! It's stealing from all the fish. As it comes closer you see that it isn't a crow, it's a <vocabulary>squid</vocabulary>. Or a <vocabulary>cuttlefish</vocabulary>? One or the other.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this word is completely irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

You call the fish police to arrest that thieving squid, but it jumps into it's eagle car (いか) and makes a swift getaway. In case you didn't know, an eagle car is an eagle moonlighting as a car. The eagle car is zooming up into the sky, so there's no way the fish police can catch it now.
Context 1-EN: Squid sashimi is my favorite food.
Context 1-JP: <jp>烏賊の刺し身が大好物です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm thinking about making stewed cuttlefish this evening.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今夜は烏賊の煮物を作ろうと思っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>value</kanji> <kanji>status</kanji> you really care about how much the <vocabulary>price</vocabulary> of things are. The more things <vocabulary>cost</vocabulary>, the more you <vocabulary>value</vocabulary> them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The cost is a little too high.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この価格はちょっと高すぎやしないかい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Are you visiting a neat place? Grab some <kanji>dirt</kanji> and bring it back with you. Then pretend to <kanji>give birth</kanji> to it in front of your friends. That dirt is now a special <vocabulary>souvenir</vocabulary>! It's the best <vocabulary>present</vocabulary> you could ever give someone!
Reading Mnemonic:
These readings are exceptions, sorry! Here's a mnemonic to help you:

When someone asks you who gave you a souvenir, just say "Miya gave (みやげ) it to me." Who's Miya? No idea. But neither do they. You never have to remember who gave you anything ever again! Miya gave you everything you own. She's probably a great person.
Context 1-EN: I haven’t picked out a souvenir yet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まだお土産を選んでいません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>appearance</kanji> of <kanji>fault</kanji> is a huge <vocabulary>blunder</vocabulary> on our family. At least do not have the appearance of fault.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>しつ</jp> gets shortened to <jp>しっ</jp>, though, so make that <vocabulary>blunder</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: The president made a huge blunder and he tried to cover it up, but it backfired.
Context 1-JP: <jp>社長は大失態を犯し、それを隠蔽しようとしたが、さらにその隠蔽工作が裏目に出てしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You already know that <jp>神社</jp> means "shinto shrine," so add <kanji>peaceful</kanji> and <kanji>country</kanji> to it and you get a shrine that calls for the peace of the entire country. It's Yasukuni Shrine. If you watch the news you know that this name and everything it stands for is always a topic of current debates.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of two words. The first two kanji take the kun'yomi readings and the second two are the jukugo word <jp>神社</jp>. You already learned all of these readings, so you should already be able to read this word!
Context 1-EN: Have you ever visited Yasukuni Shrine?
Context 1-JP: <jp>靖国神社に参拝したことはありますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Accept</kanji> a child into your <kanji>womb</kanji> with <vocabulary>conception</vocabulary>. Now there's a baby in there!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The last child a horse named Elaine conceived was Stay Gold.
Context 1-JP: <jp>エレインという馬が、ステイゴールドの最後の子を受胎しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Holy</kanji> <kanji>ground</kanji> is <vocabulary>holy land</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This road leads to the holy land.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この道は聖地に続いています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Climb</kanji> up and <kanji>record</kanji> your information here. This is <vocabulary>registration</vocabulary>. It's work to get yourself registered (from the climbing) and even if you get your name recorded on there, you may not get in. So record your information, wait, and hope you get in.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This is Yuka Miyake. I’ve changed my phone, so could you register my new number and email address in your address book, please? Thank you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>三宅結花です。携帯電話を変えたので、新しい電話番号とメールアドレスの登録をお願いします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen <jp>技</jp> as a vocab word meaning "technique." This is sort of using that meaning. So, a <kanji>technique</kanji> of <kanji>art</kanji> is still <vocabulary>art</vocabulary>, but it's also your <vocabulary>craft</vocabulary>, your <vocabulary>technique</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I'm not a doctor but I learned heart transplant techniques from a doctor.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は医者ではありませんが、ある医者から、心ぞういしょくの技術を学びました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I learned the art of selling from the company I used to work for.
Context 2-JP: <jp>以前に働いていた会社で、えい業技術を身につけました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I married a technically brilliant boxer.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は技術的に優れたボクサーと結婚した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>appearance</kanji> is <kanji>strange</kanji>. You're <vocabulary>abnormal</vocabulary>. Oh, and you're a <vocabulary>pervert</vocabulary> because you look so abnormal. Though you could just be a caterpillar going through your <vocabulary>metamorphosis</vocabulary> to become a butterfly. You just look really weird while the changing is going on.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Actually, it’s sort of an embarrassing story, but my father is so perverted that he was caught in a massive child porn ring.
Context 1-JP: <jp>実は、ちょっと恥ずかしい話なんだけど、俺の親父めちゃくちゃ変態で、児童ポルノの一斉捜査で捕まっちゃったんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>doing</kanji> <kanji>way</kanji> is basically a "way of doing" something. More simply put, this is the <vocabulary>method</vocabulary>. "What's your way of doing this?" No no no. "What's your METHOD." There we go.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji <jp>仕</jp>, and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji <jp>方</jp>. You've learned both of these readings already, so you should be able to read this already!
Context 1-EN: Please teach me how to bow.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おじぎの仕方をおしえてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My French friend taught me how to greet people in the French way.
Context 2-JP: <jp>フランス人の友人にフランスしきのあいさつの仕方をおしえてもらいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "How to Drive" became a best-selling book this year.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「運転の仕方」という本は今年のベストセラーとなった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>不足</jp> is a physical shortage? Well, now you have a physical shortage of <kanji>sleep</kanji>. That's a <vocabulary>lack of sleep</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. However, the first kanji <jp>寝</jp> actually uses its kun'yomi <jp>ね</jp>. <jp>不足</jp> is on'yomi as you'd expect, but the <jp>ふ</jp> in <jp>不</jp> changes to <jp>ぶ</jp>, so hopefully you've been getting enough sleep.
Context 1-EN: "So are you going to work overtime again today?" "Well actually, I was kind of hoping to get off work early today because I’ve been missing out on a lot of sleep."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「今日も残業するつもりなの？」「えっと…ですね、今日は寝不足なのでどちらかというと早くあがりたいと思っています。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Prefecture</kanji> <kanji>manage</kanji>d things are <vocabulary>run by the prefecture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Fugu was scolded for making out with Salmon in the prefectural library by a librarian.
Context 1-JP: <jp>フグは県営図書館でサーモンといちゃついていて、図書館司書さんに怒られた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>過ぎる</jp> is <vocabulary>to surpass</vocabulary>. When you surpass what is needed, what are you left with? Just this word: <vocabulary>too much</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>過ぎる</jp>. Know that and you know <vocabulary>too much</vocabulary>. Dial it down to get <jp>過ぎ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: You get paid way too well for working such short hours.
Context 1-JP: <jp>短時間の仕事で良い給料をもらい過ぎだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: These <kanji>view</kanji>s that have <kanji>merit</kanji> (<jp>価値</jp>) are your <vocabulary>values</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I think it’s quite important to share similar values with your spouse.
Context 1-JP: <jp>結婚相手と価値観が近いことって結構大切だと思うんだよねー。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>比較</jp> is <vocabulary>comparison</vocabulary>. So, verb version of that? It's <vocabulary>to compare</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help a lot to know the word <jp>比較</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: My daughter lacks physical strength compared to the other girls at her age.
Context 1-JP: <jp>同じ年齢の女の子と比較すると、私の娘は体力があまりありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have a <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>plate</kanji>. Wait, is that it? Yep, that's it.
Reading Mnemonic: <jp>さら</jp> uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji, except it's <jp>ざら</jp> this time because of the rendaku. <jp>小</jp> uses an alternate kun'yomi reading. You can remember it by thinking "What are small? Kids (<jp>子</jp>) are small. Bwahaha."
Context 1-EN: Please set the small plates on the table.
Context 1-JP: <jp>小皿をテーブルにならべてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why don't we just serve foods into small plates by ourselves and eat at our own pace?
Context 2-JP: <jp>かくじ、小皿にとり分けてたべましょう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s impossible to put this huge steak on that tiny dish.
Context 3-JP: <jp>このどでかいステーキを、その小皿に載せるのは無理だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>飲む</jp> is drink, so this has to do with <kanji>drink</kanji>ing. Also, <jp>会</jp> means <kanji>meet</kanji>, so when you meet to drink you're getting together with others to drink. It's a <vocabulary>drinking party</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from the <jp>飲む</jp> vocabulary word and the regular kanji reading for <jp>会</jp>. Hopefully you know both of those by now so you can apply them to the reading of this word, too!
Context 1-EN: Drinking parties hosted by Tofugu are so fun!
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグ主さいの飲み会はとても楽しいですよ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: These days there seems to be an increase in the number of students who are forced to chug drinks at parties and die of acute alcohol poisoning.
Context 2-JP: <jp>最近、飲み会で一気飲みを強要されて急せいアルコール中どくで死ぼうする学生がふえているようです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My mom says that I can’t go to the drinking party. Your parents are really chill about stuff like alcohol. I’m jealous.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お袋が飲み会には行っちゃダメだって言うんだよね。お前んとこの親がアルコールとかに対して厳しくないの、羨ましいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you do <kanji>not</kanji> have <kanji>happiness</kanji>, you have <vocabulary>unhappiness</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>misfortune</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>misery</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>death</vocabulary>, usually of a family member.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: You look as if you're in the depths of misfortune. Are you okay?
Context 1-JP: <jp>まるで不幸のどん底のようにいるような顔をしてるけど、大丈夫？</jp>
Context 2-EN: There was a death in my family. Can I take tomorrow and the day after off?
Context 2-JP: <jp>家族に不幸があったので、明日、明後日会社を休ませてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: They say misery loves company, which explains why I’m dating you.
Context 3-JP: <jp>不幸は仲間を好むってよく言うけど、それって私があなたと付き合っている理由をうまく説明しているよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mountain</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mountain road</vocabulary>! Or a <vocabulary>mountain trail</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>mountain path</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Both the kanji in this word use the kun'yomi, which you learned when you learned the vocabulary. When it uses this reading, it sounds casual, and is common in conversation. It can also be read using the on'yomi, though, in which case it has a more formal feel to it. That's typical of on'yomi, which tends to add formality to a word!
Context 1-EN: I walked the mountain trail with my puppy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子犬と山道を歩きました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: From there on, it becomes a mountain path.
Context 3-EN: Beyond that point, the road enters the mountains.

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>比較</jp> is a comparison. Add <jp>的</jp> to it and you have <vocabulary> comparatively</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know the word <jp>比較</jp>.
Context 1-EN: He learns new programming codes relatively quickly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は新しいプログラミング言語を比較的速く修得します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>dispatch</kanji> but this word is <vocabulary>to consider</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to make use of</vocabulary>. Just think about how if you have people that are on dispatch for you, you can send them information <vocabulary>to consider</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to make use of</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This has a similar meaning to <jp>使う</jp>, and has the same reading too. If you remember that, you can remember this word's reading.
Context 1-EN: I think living with my in-laws would mean I’d have to take care of them every day, and I’d get worn out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>義理の両親と暮らすのって、毎日気を遣うだろうし、疲れちゃうと思うのよね。</jp>

Meaning: To Do A Favor,To Bless,To Give Out Of Pity,To Donate Out Of Charity
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>favor</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to do a favor</vocabulary> for.
Reading Mnemonic: If you are going <vocabulary>to do a favor</vocabulary> for anyone, it's going to be for your good buddy <reading>meg</reading> (<jp>めぐ</jp>). Imagine a Meg you know (or know of) and imagine yourself doing a favor for her. Meg Ryan is so happy you're in her life.
Context 1-EN: All of Tofugu’s proceeds from today will be donated to underprivileged children.
Context 1-JP: <jp>本日のTofuguの収益の全額が、恵まれない子どもたちに寄付されます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Rainbow</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji>ed things are <vocabulary>rainbow colored</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kanji readings for both <jp>虹</jp> and <jp>色</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I purchased rainbow colored wasabi but it tastes just like regular wasabi.
Context 1-JP: <jp>虹色の山葵を購入してみたんですが、味はまんま山葵ですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>込む</jp> is "to be crowded." This, however, is when you make something crowded. How do you make something crowded? You have <vocabulary>to put in</vocabulary> more and more into the thing you want crowded until it is crowded. To do this act (which you are doing), you <reading>mail</reading> (<jp>める</jp>) things in over and over again. This will crowd the post office if I include all this mail in this mail box! Ha ha! What a rebel!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>込む</jp>. No reading too crowded to include here.
Context 1-EN: I didn’t have enough time to load rounds into the shotgun.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ショットガンに弾を込める時間がなかったんだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Put more emotion in your performance! Are you really a professional theatrical actor?
Context 2-JP: <jp>もっと気持ちを込めて演技しろよ！それでもプロの劇団員か？</jp>

Meaning: To Shoot,To Attack,To Fire A Gun
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>to attack</kanji>, though it usually means <vocabulary>to shoot</vocabulary>, because that's a very common way in which to attack someone. Pow!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who are you going <vocabulary>to shoot</vocabulary>? You are going to shoot <reading>You</reading> (<jp>う</jp>). Why? Because there's another version of you in front of you, so if you don't shoot that version of you who is you, amirite?
Context 1-EN: Don’t move. Hold still or you’ll be shot!
Context 1-JP: <jp>動くな。じっとしていないと、撃つぞ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Fell</kanji> trees and <kanji>gather</kanji> them up. That's called <vocabulary>lumbering</vocabulary>. Or if you cut them all down and take every last one, it's <vocabulary>deforestation</vocabulary> and you should be ashamed!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Notification is necessary before felling a forest.
Context 1-JP: <jp>森林を伐採する際は、事前に届け出が必要です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>army base</kanji> is <kanji>manage</kanji>d from the <vocabulary>camp</vocabulary>. This is where all the bigwigs get together, talk, and manage things, right over the open fire.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Once the enemy camp came into view, I started to feel afraid.
Context 1-JP: <jp>敵の陣営が見えてくると、恐怖を感じ始めました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
Normally a single kanji alone like this would mean the same thing as its parent kanji, but in the case of 生 it's a little different (but still related). When you think of something that has life, it's fresh or raw. Think sashimi or sushi, for example. You want that to be as close as possible to life as you can, so you eat it when it's fresh and raw. This word can also be used to describe a live event, like a concert or sporting event.

You'll see this word at the beginning of other words. For example, 生たまご is "raw egg."
Reading Mnemonic:
This uses one of the kun'yomi readings. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

After eating raw fish, my yoga teacher and I say namaste (なま) to the sushi chef, bowing low to show our appreciation.
Context 1-EN: I don't like raw veggies.
Context 1-JP: <jp>生のやさいはにが手です。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>生ビール一ちょう、下さーい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If only I could have seen the Beatles live!
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビートルズは生でみれたらいいな〜。</jp>

Meaning: To Long For,To Yearn After,To Admire,To Be Attracted By
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>long for</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to long for</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to yearn after</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: I have a crush on that senpai.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの先輩に憧れているんです。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Employed At,To Work For
Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>work</kanji> which means this verb has something to do with working. It's not straight up "to work," instead it's "<vocabulary>to work for</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>to be employed at</vocabulary>."
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the other word that means "to work for" (<jp>務める</jp>). Remember this and you'll be able to remember the reading for this word too.
Context 1-EN: I started working at a library ever since my daughter got into primary school.
Context 1-JP: <jp>娘が小学校に上がったので、私は図書館に勤め始めました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>pressure</kanji> used easily <kanji>collapse</kanji>s whatever it's pushing against. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to overwhelm</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the <jp>あつ</jp> goes to <jp>あっ</jp>, as you'd probably expect.
Context 1-EN: This new site will overwhelm other Japanese language sites.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この新しいサイトは他社の日本語学習サイトを圧倒するだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I can <kanji>deal with</kanji> it, no matter what the <kanji>reason</kanji>. I can <vocabulary>take care of</vocabulary> this problem, <vocabulary>process</vocabulary> it, and <vocabulary>deal with</vocabulary> it on my own.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He complains that his boss doesn’t deal with clients’ complaints.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は、上司が顧客のクレーム処理をしないことについてぶつぶつ文句を言っている。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My computer couldn't process the data and froze.
Context 2-JP: <jp>パソコンがデータを処理しきれずにフリーズしてしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That player is good at taking care of ground balls.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの選手はゴロを処理するのが上手い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Here's a weird one for you. You have a <kanji>red</kanji> <kanji>monk</kanji>. What is this? It's a <vocabulary>baby</vocabulary>. Think about it. Babies, when they come out, are all red. Also, they have a shaved head, just like a monk would. So, a "red monk" is really just a baby. I wonder who's getting the shorter end of the stick here, the monk or the baby? Probably the monk.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of <jp>赤</jp> (you learned this with the kanji) and the reading you learned for <jp>坊</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: Well, how can we get this baby to stop crying? We already tried feeding him, changing him, and burping him. Oh, here is something! It says to try holding the baby close to your body and then rocking it quickly from side to side.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あーどうしたら赤ん坊を泣き止ませることができるんだろう。ミルクもあげてみたし、オムツもかえてみたでしょ。それに、げっぷもさせてみた。あ、これはどうかな？赤ちゃんを体に引き寄せて抱っこして、左右に素早く揺らしてみるって書いてあるわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're only <kanji>nearby</kanji> <vocabulary>while</vocabulary> you are nearby, that's it.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

While you live as a normal human citizen you also have another life as a cutter walrus (かたわ)! That's a walrus that cuts fish up while eating. It's your secret double life. You do it at night while you are a human by day!
Context 1-EN: While working at the newspaper office, I’ve been attending night classes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新聞局で働く傍ら、夜間学校に通っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is the polite and humble form of <vocabulary>mother</vocabulary>. You use this when you're talking about your own mother to other people, especially if you aren't very close to them.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but this is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just remember, your <vocabulary>mother</vocabulary> is a terrible person and won't stop laughing at you: "<reading>HA HA</reading> HA HA HA!"
Context 1-EN: My mother got in a taxi.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母はタクシーにのりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My younger sister is getting to look like our mother more and more.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いもうとは、どんどん母ににてきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My mother likes tofu and fugu.
Context 3-JP: <jp>母はとうふとふぐがすきだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>oil</kanji> <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> is really more like an <vocabulary>oil field</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for <jp>田</jp> yet. Just think about how you walk into the <vocabulary>oil field</vocabulary> and you see a bear <reading>den</reading> (<jp>でん</jp>), filled with oil.
Context 1-EN: Unfortunately, none of those oil fields are mine.
Context 1-JP: <jp>残念ですが、どの油田も私のものではありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>extent</kanji> <kanji>degree</kanji>s show to what <vocabulary>degree</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>extent</vocabulary> you're willing to take something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He is actually 35 years old, but has no more intelligence than a three year old kid.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は実際は35歳だが、3歳児と同程度の知能水準しかない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>respond</kanji> <kanji>versus</kanji> someone else to have an <vocabulary>interaction</vocabulary> with them. If one of you stops responding, so does the <vocabulary>correspondence</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Interacting with that doctor was wonderful.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの医者の対応は素晴らしかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>rotation</kanji> of <kanji>wind</kanji> forms a <vocabulary>whirlwind</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because <jp>ふう</jp> becomes <jp>ぷう</jp> here (hehe).
Context 1-EN: Tofugu is creating a whirlwind in the Japanese learning industry.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トフグは、日本語学習業界に旋風を巻き起こしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You can <kanji>infer</kanji> and <kanji>measure</kanji> all you want. If you do enough, you'll get some good <vocabulary>conjecture</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>speculation</vocabulary> off that inferring and measuring.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My guess is that he won the lottery and moved to the Bahamas.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の推測では、彼は宝くじが当たって、バハマに引っ越した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>完全</jp> means "complete" or "perfect." So, a <kanji>not</kanji> "complete" or "perfect" is something that is <vocabulary>incomplete</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>imperfect</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It also will help if you can read <jp>完全</jp>.
Context 1-EN: What kind of love is imperfect?
Context 1-JP: <jp>不完全な形のあいってどんなものですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Aren't incomplete things better than complete things, since they have a humanness about them?
Context 2-JP: <jp>完全なものよりも不完全なものの方が人情味があってよくない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: The Tofugu softball team had an incomplete end to their season when the game they were winning was suspended due to rain.
Context 3-JP: <jp>勝ち試合が雨で中止になり、Tofuguソフトボールチームのシーズンが不完全に終わった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji, though it's kind of like an add-on for other words in a sense, which makes it behave like jukugo, I think. Don't confuse this with <jp>各々</jp> though. That one does use the kun'yomi reading, which is strange when you consider this one doesn't. Every kanji has its own "perks" I suppose.
Context 1-EN: First, choose a representative for each team.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まず始めに、各チームの代表者を決めて下さい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>大腸</jp> means "large intestines?" Well when you get <kanji>bacteria</kanji> in there you end up with <vocabulary>E. Coli</vocabulary>. Go to a doctor right away! You're gonna be stuck in the bathroom for a while. Sorry...
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: There’s a card app game that personifies E. Coli as a beautiful woman.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大腸菌を美少女に擬人化させたカードアプリ・ゲームがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Lucky for you, even though this word is a single kanji, it uses the same reading you learned, meaning you know how to read it already. Time to plan and scheme for your next vocab/kanji.
Context 1-EN: In my presentation today, I will cover three main plans.
Context 1-JP: <jp>本日のプレゼンでは、主に3つの策を取り上げます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It doesn't matter how many <kanji>times</kanji> a <kanji>rotation</kanji> goes around, it's still a <vocabulary>rotation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I practiced a figure eight turn in the garage.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ガレージで八の字旋回の練習をしてみました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>tank</kanji> you <kanji>bathe</kanji> in is a <vocabulary>bathtub</vocabulary>. Unless you're bathing in like... the town's water supply. If you are, please stop. I don't want to drink your bathwater.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When I don’t clean it everyday, the bathtub accumulates grime.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎日掃除をしないと、浴槽には垢がたまります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have a <kanji>thought</kanji> on a particular <kanji>view</kanji>. This is your <vocabulary>idea</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>notion</vocabulary> on it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: She has a keen sense of beauty for art, so I don’t understand how she’s dating such an ugly guy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は芸術においては素晴らしい美の観念を持っているのに、どうしてあんなに不細工な男性と付き合っているのかが理解できない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If can you read this word, you may well know what it means. It's everybody's second favorite noodle dish, <vocabulary>somen</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>somen noodles</vocabulary>, which are <vocabulary>fine white noodles</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The first kanji has a slightly irregular reading because it's prolonged. That's because <vocabulary>somen</vocabulary> are your <reading>sou</reading>l (<jp>そう</jp>) food.
Context 1-EN: Everyone started slurping down the cold somen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>みんな冷たい素麺をツルツル食べ始めました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The taste of the soup is lighter because the somen noodles are added at the end.
Context 2-JP: <jp>最後に素麺を入れるのでスープの味は薄めになっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Mami made us somen that she'd brought from Japan.
Context 3-JP: <jp>マミさんが日本から持ってきた素麺を作ってくれた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>instant</kanji> <kanji>sit</kanji> is <vocabulary>immediate</vocabulary>. It's also <vocabulary>instantaneous</vocabulary>. Just imagine yourself sitting instantly. No time passes between when you were standing and sitting. The instantaneous nature of your sit is definitely... troubling.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Please don’t expect immediate results.
Context 1-JP: <jp>即座の結果は期待しないでください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Membrane</kanji>s that wrap around at an <kanji>angle</kanji> are in your eye. Eyes are round and the membranes have to bend around the front part at an angle. It's called your <vocabulary>cornea</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: In Lasik surgery your cornea is shaved with a laser.
Context 1-JP: <jp>レーシック手術では、角膜をレーザーで削るんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Know how <jp>非難</jp> is a criticism? Make it a verb and you have the word <vocabulary>to criticize</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, it will be really helpful to know the word <jp>非難</jp> to start.
Context 1-EN: The kids criticized their parents for hiding the scandal.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子どもたちは両親が不祥事を隠したことを非難した。</jp>

Meaning: Articles Of Incorporation,Company Statute,Articles Of The Company Laws
Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Article</kanji>s that <kanji>determine</kanji> the rules and regulations of your job or a company are called <vocabulary>articles of incorporation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If I make this sample I can easily draw up a company statute.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この雛形を作れば簡単に定款が作成できます。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Transmitted,To Be Told,To Be Handed Down
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something is transmitted. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to be transmitted.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 伝える.
Context 1-EN: Various legends of Viet before working for Tofugu have been told to the employees.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグに入社する前のビエトの様々な伝せつが社員に伝わっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Even though you can't speak Japanese well, if you try to speak with your heart, people will understand.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本語が上手に話せなくても心で話せばきっと相手に伝わりますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A message about how the Tofugu ninjas crept towards the castle during the night was transmitted to Shogun Koichi.
Context 3-JP: <jp>忍者トーフグ組が夜に城へ忍び寄ったということが、コウイチ将軍に伝わった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>否定</jp> is denial. Remember how <jp>形</jp> sometimes refers to grammar tense / type? Well, with a denial type grammar, you have a <vocabulary>negative form</vocabulary>, making it a <vocabulary>negative sentence</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Can you change this sentence into a negative sentence?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この文章を否定形にすることができますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>ferment</kanji> something it makes a <kanji>departure</kanji> from what it originally was and transforms during <vocabulary>fermentation</vocabulary> into something new.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Please teach me how to keep the sweetness in wine and stop fermentation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ワインの甘みを残して発酵を止める方法を教えてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Create</kanji> a <kanji>brew</kanji> of beer by <vocabulary>brewing</vocabulary> it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I toured the scotch distillery.
Context 1-JP: <jp>スコッチの醸造所を見学してきました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>folding fan</kanji> and since you don't "to folding fan" something, this word means <vocabulary>to fan</vocabulary> instead.
Reading Mnemonic: Imagine yourself trying <vocabulary>to fan</vocabulary> yourself with an <reading><jp>青</jp></reading> (<jp>あお</jp>) fan. For some reason blue fans feel cooler. Maybe it's because they're the color of ice/water?
Context 1-EN: I’m wearing too many layers and it’s so hot. Could you fan me?
Context 1-JP: <jp>重ね着しすぎてすごく暑いんだけど、ちょっと私に向かって扇いでくれない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>problem</kanji> <kanji>topic</kanji> is the <vocabulary>problem</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>question</vocabulary> you have to answer. If you think about it, topics as problems tends to be a school-related thing. So, when you have to answer a problem in school, that's <jp>問題</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It would be a big problem for Tofugu if WaniKani's revenue were to drop.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ワニカニの売り上げが落ちるのはトーフグにとって大きな問題です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I tried to solve this math question for thirty seconds and I couldn't figure it out, can you do it for me?
Context 2-JP: <jp>この数学の問題、三十秒間どう考えても分からなかったからわたしの代わりにちょっとやっておいてくれない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Can you do me a favor?" "Sure, what is it?" "Can you look after my dog for the weekend?" "No problem. You can count on me."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「お願いがあるんだけど。」「いいけど、何？」「週末、私の犬の世話をしてもらえないかな？」「問題ないよ。任せといて。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>image</kanji> is <kanji>reflect</kanji>ing in the mirror. You're looking at the mirror, confused. Don't worry, it is only a <vocabulary>picture</vocabulary>, an <vocabulary>image</vocabulary>, or maybe a <vocabulary>video</vocabulary>. It's not real.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I heard that if you watch Michael's video on YouTube 4444 times, you'll be cursed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>YouTubeでマイケルの映像を四千四百四十四回見ると、のろいにかかるらしいよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Since I watched Ringu, I can't get the image of Sadako coming out of that old well out of my head.
Context 2-JP: <jp>映画リングを見てからというもの、古い戸からさだ子が出てくる映像が頭からはなれない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Did you see that new Japanese movie? The movie itself wasn’t very good, but the shots they captured were beautiful.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの新しい日本映画見た？映画自体はいまいちだったんだけど、映像が物凄く美しかったよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Get Fat,To Gain Weight,To Grow Fat,To Become Fat
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fat</kanji> so the verb form of that is <vocabulary>to get fat</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You have to learn the ふと portion of this word to be able to read it. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're getting fat so quickly that you can see your body expanding. You look down - at first you can see your foot (ふと) but then a second later you can't. You can't see your foot because you're getting fat, even when you stick your foot way out. What's going on?
Context 1-EN: I’ve gotten a little fat from overeating lately.
Context 1-JP: <jp>さいきん、たべすぎで少し太りました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I envy people who don't get fat even though they eat a lot.
Context 2-JP: <jp>たべても太らない人がうらやましい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The fatter I get, the hungrier I become.
Context 3-JP: <jp>太れば太るほど、わたしはおなかがすく。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Time to <kanji>go</kanji> get your <kanji>silver</kanji> from the <vocabulary>bank</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I have to go to the bank to withdraw some cash.
Context 1-JP: <jp>銀行にお金を下ろしに行かないといけないんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There is a proverb that says someone who laughs over one yen will eventually cry over one yen, so I decided to go to the bank to put one yen in my account.
Context 2-JP: <jp>一円を笑う者は一円に泣くということわざがあるので、銀行に一円をあずけに行くことにしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When people rob banks they go to prison. When banks rob people they get bonuses. It’s so unfair, isn’t it?
Context 3-JP: <jp>銀行を強盗した人は牢屋行きなのに、銀行が人々からお金を奪ったら、ボーナスがもらえるんだよ。それってすごく不公平じゃない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Feeling</kanji> + <kanji>feeling</kanji> = <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary>! It can also mean <vocabulary>emotion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I can't control my emotions well when I get mad.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おこると感情のコントロールがうまく出来ません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is important, so please judge it in good spirits rather than relying on your feelings.
Context 2-JP: <jp>これは大事なことですから、感情に左右されずにれいせいにはんだんしてくださいね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do not give in too much to your feelings. There’s no point in letting your emotions get the better of you, right?
Context 3-JP: <jp>感情に流されすぎてはいけないよ。自分の感情に負けることには何の価値もないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>signpost</kanji> you have your <kanji>eye</kanji> on is your <vocabulary>goal</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>target</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>objective</vocabulary>. Just imagine looking at this signpost in the distance. You know you have to get to it from where you are. That is the goal of your journey.
Reading Mnemonic: You've had the on'yomi reading of <jp>目</jp> with <jp>目次</jp> way back in level 6. For this vocab, you're trying to get to your <vocabulary>goal</vocabulary>, that signpost in the distance. As you're trekking towards it there are people standing to the side <reading>mock</reading>ing you, telling you you'll never make it to your goal. Imagine this happening.
Context 1-EN: Mr. Kawamura, what is your life's goal?
Context 1-JP: <jp>川村さんの人生の目標はなんですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I fired an arrow toward the target 50m ahead of me.
Context 2-JP: <jp>五十メートル先の目標に向かって矢を放ちました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Could you be a little more specific about Tofugu’s goals, please?
Context 3-JP: <jp>トーフグの目標について、もう少し具体的に話をして頂けませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you go to <kanji>attire</kanji> yourself, you're covering up who you are and trying to be someone else. You are trying <vocabulary>to feign</vocabulary>. You are trying <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary> a lie. You are trying <vocabulary>to pretend</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: While you go <vocabulary>to feign</vocabulary> that you're someone or something else, someone calls you out on it: "<reading>you so</reading> (<jp>よそお</jp>) much a liar!"
Context 1-EN: Although he didn’t get the promotion he had been expecting, he put on a good face and congratulated the people who did.
Context 1-JP: <jp>予想していた昇進が無かったが、彼は平気を装って昇進した社員たちにおめでとうと言った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>article</kanji> you write a <kanji>promise</kanji> on is an <vocabulary>agreement</vocabulary>. Make sure you read them thoroughly before you sign them!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Did you read the agreement thoroughly?
Context 1-JP: <jp>きちんと約款を読みましたか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>practice</kanji> something to <kanji>learn</kanji> it. That's still called <vocabulary>practice</vocabulary>! The important part about this is that you're learning while you practice too. It's right in the word. So, when you practice kanji and Japanese vocab, make sure you're learning as well as practicing. If you're not learning, you're not really practicing, are you?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: After practicing for one year, was finally able to distinguish between aspirated and unaspirated sounds.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一年間練習して、ようやく有気音とむ気音を聞き分けられるようになりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My daily practice bore fruit and now I can improvise on the guitar.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日々の練習が実をむすび、アドリブでギターがひけるようになりました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I believe the reason I continue being ranked number one in the world is that I devote seven hours a day to practicing Japanese.
Context 3-JP: <jp>僕が世界ランキング一位を維持し続けているのは、日本語を毎日七時間練習しているからだと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I was raised by wolves.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は狼に育てられました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The baby wolves are doing well.
Context 2-JP: <jp>狼の赤ちゃんたちは元気にしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can hear the sound of wolves in the distance.
Context 3-JP: <jp>遠くから狼の鳴き声が聞こえる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>like</kanji> <kanji>alcohol</kanji> a lot, you're probably a heavy <vocabulary>drinker</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading here as you can probably guess from the hiragana sticking out on the end. You should know the readings of these as separate words already (<jp>酒</jp> and <jp>好き</jp>) which means all you need to pay attention to is the rendaku of <jp>すき</jp> to <jp>ずき</jp>.
Context 1-EN: My boyfriend is a drinker, so I'm worried.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かれ氏は酒好きなんで、心配なんですよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That alcoholic is drinking in the morning again today.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの酒好き、今日も朝から引っかけてやがるぜ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My wife is a drinker and I’m worried about her becoming an alcoholic.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の妻は酒好きなので、アル中にならないか心配だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Beer can only <kanji>become</kanji> <kanji>brew</kanji>ed if you decide to <vocabulary>brew</vocabulary> it. Beer can't make itself, you know.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: They brew sake here.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここで酒を醸成しているんですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Mountain</kanji> <kanji>robber</kanji>s are known as <vocabulary>bandit</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I became friends with the bandits.
Context 1-JP: <jp>山賊たちと友だちになりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sand</kanji> <kanji>hill</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sand dune</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: There are some camels on that sand dune.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その砂丘には駱駝もいるんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>large</kanji> <kanji>force</kanji> is a group of people. Just think about when this word was probably made up... a long time ago, and the biggest force you could have was a huge group of people. This group of people force is also known as a <vocabulary>crowd</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>a large number</vocabulary> of people.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>大</jp> is the <jp>おお</jp> reading (like <jp>大きい</jp>). Nothing you can do about that but remember it. Then, <jp>勢</jp> is rendaku'd to become <jp>ぜい</jp>. Also something you'll just have to remember. Say this word a few times in your head, then you'll be able to come up with an idea of what sounds right and what sounds wrong so that you can figure it out next time this word comes up.
Context 1-EN: I’m not used to speaking in front of crowds, so my hands are already shaking.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大勢の人の前で話す事に慣れていないので、今からもう手が震えています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I take the attendance of a large number of students, I sometimes skip over one or two names.
Context 2-JP: <jp>大勢の生徒の出席を取る時、たまに一人か二人、名前を飛ばしてしまうことがあります。</jp>

Meaning: To Decline,To Decay,To Become Weak,To Wither
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>decline</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to decline</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You're wandering through the jungle exploring, when you come upon a deep pit. Since you're looking for treasure, you decide to go down into the pit to look for some. You take out your handy <reading>auto ro</reading>pe (<jp>おとろ</jp>), made of organic, environment friendly materials, and easily rappel down into the pit. Unfortunately, you get lost down there, and it takes you fifty years to get back to the pit you came in from. But your auto rope is gone! This is the last time you buy an organic rope, made <vocabulary>to decay</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to wither</vocabulary> away when left in the wild.
Context 1-EN: When I had this beef several years ago I was really impressed by how well it was aged and marbled, but the taste seems to have declined a bit and I’m really disappointed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>数年前にこの牛肉を食べた時は、非常に良く熟成されて霜が降っていることに感動したんですが、今はちょっと味が衰えたみたいでとても残念ですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>penalty</kanji> <kanji>game</kanji> (<jp>ゲーム</jp>) is a fun kind of game you see on Japanese television a lot. When you mess up, you are punished. Usually it hurts. You can call this a <vocabulary>batsu game</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>penalty game</vocabulary>. Don't call it anything else, though, or you know what happens...
Reading Whitelist: ばつげーむ,ばつゲーム
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m kind of disappointed about this penalty game, but I’m also a little excited.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この罰ゲームについて、がっかりもしてるんだけど、ワクワクしてもいるんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What I <kanji>leave behind</kanji> and <kanji>transmit</kanji> to you is your <vocabulary>heredity</vocabulary>. You have my genes, even after I'm gone.
Word Type: noun,する verb,な adjective,の adjective
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, which you've already learned.
Context 1-EN: In Japan you are obligated to display whether foods are genetically modified on the package.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本では、遺伝子組み換え食品にはパッケージへの表示が義務づけられています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have a <kanji>concept</kanji> to <kanji>determine</kanji> so you need a <vocabulary>hypothesis</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>supposition</vocabulary>, or an <vocabulary>assumption</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We assume the picture of the many-armed deity will be hung here.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの手がたくさんある神様の絵がここにかざられることを想定しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's not good to act on the assumption that you'll have something before you actually do.
Context 2-JP: <jp>まだ手に入れていないものを、手に入れたとの想定で行動するのは良くない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We will now conduct the disaster drill assuming there is an earthquake.
Context 3-JP: <jp>地震を想定した避難訓練を行います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>green</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is the color <vocabulary>green</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji, combined!
Context 1-EN: This boiled, green egg makes you lose your appetite, doesn't it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この緑色なゆで玉子は、ちょっと食べる気になれませんね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is just my personal preference, but I want Koichi to dye his hair green.
Context 2-JP: <jp>これはかん全にこ人てきな好みなんですけど、コウイチにはかみを緑色にそめてもらいたいんですよねー。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A: How do you like this tie? B: Hmm... Here. Try this green one. A: Okay. How’s this? B: Yeah. That’s more like it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>A:「このネクタイ、どうかな？」 B:「そうねぇ。こっちの緑色のをしてみてよ。」 A:「わかったよ。これでどう？」 B:「うん。そっちの方がいいわね。」</jp>
