Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji for <kanji>person</kanji> and <kanji>life</kanji> combined makes you think about human life. What is your <vocabulary>human life</vocabulary> like?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Life is wonderful.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人生ってすばらしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Life is like a banana, you never know how long it will be.
Context 3-JP: <jp>人生はバナナのようなものさ。どれだけながいのかだれもしらないのさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You put on the <vocabulary>ring</vocabulary> you found, hoping it will be the one ring to rule them all (invisibility!). Instead, it turns out it's a special <reading>Wa</reading>lken ring, made out of Christopher Walken's bones. It talks up to you, telling you how he kept this ring in his (*ahem*) butt during the war so he could get it to you. First of all, why is this ring talking? Second, why is it talking like Walken. Third, eww, gross, it was in his anus.
Context 1-EN: Please throw this Quoits ring quickly!
Context 1-JP: <jp>早くこの輪投げの輪をなげてくださいよ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: If I go to parties, my circle of friends expands.
Context 2-JP: <jp>パーティーに行くと、友だちの輪が広がります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Ew! Why are you wearing gold hoop earrings, Koichi?
Context 3-JP: <jp>うわっ！コウイチ、なんで金の輪っかのイヤリングなんて付けてるの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>article</kanji> that proves that you're only <kanji>borrow</kanji>ing money or stuffed animals is called a <vocabulary>loan</vocabulary>. You have to pay that person back for those fluffy critters.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Did you know that Japan offers international yen loans to many countries?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本が多くの国に円借款を提供しているのはご存知ですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>澄む</jp> is "to become clear" - this is when you make something clear, because you <reading>mus</reading>t (<jp>ます</jp>) make it clear. You have to. That's why this is <vocabulary>to clear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to make clear</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji, so if you know that this answer will become clear too.
Context 1-EN: I strained my ears to hear the faint but constant screeching coming from upstairs.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は、一つ上の階からコンスタントに聞こえてくる気味の悪い金切り声を聞くために、耳を澄ましました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>change</kanji> something then <kanji>exchange</kanji> it, you are making a <vocabulary>conversion</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>change</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I'd love to meet the person who developed the technology to convert solar energy into electricity.
Context 1-JP: <jp>太陽エネルギーを電気に変換する技術を開発した人に会ってみたいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I bought a conversion plug so that I can use my computer overseas.
Context 2-JP: <jp>海外でもパソコンを使えるように変換プラグを買ってきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If you can't convert your hiragana to kanji properly, it's probably because there's a typo.
Context 3-JP: <jp>平仮名がうまく漢字に変換できない時は、大体タイプミスが原因です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If something is the <kanji>latter</kanji>, it can't be first, it has to be at least <vocabulary>second</vocabulary>. This works for lists too. So if you have A through D, it's going to be <vocabulary>B</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Hey, thanks for the report.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どーも、報告乙です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We agree with the contract as outlined below with regards to the subcontract of the first company, Tofugu, and the second company, WaniKani.
Context 2-JP: <jp>合同会社Tofuguを甲とし、Wanikaniを乙として、甲の業務の委託に関して、次の通り契約を締結する。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s very neat to look over my hometown from the top of the mountain.
Context 3-JP: <jp>こうして山頂から生まれ故郷を見渡すのも、また乙なものですねぇ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something is a trouble (<jp>面倒</jp>) and it is smelly (<jp>臭い</jp>). So what is something that's smelly and a trouble? Well, something that's <vocabulary>troublesome</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a bother</vocabulary>, I suppose. Basically you can ignore the smelly part. For some reason someone threw that back in, but smelly things are a bother, I suppose.
Reading: <reading><jp>めんどうくさい</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>めんどくさい</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: めんどうくさい,めんどくさい
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the words <jp>面倒</jp> plus <jp>臭い</jp> added together. Just make sure you know those words and you'll know this one too!
Context 1-EN: I've started going gray, but it's too much bother to color it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>白がが出てきちゃったんだけど、白が染めをするのは面倒臭いんだよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There's nothing more annoying than listening to people complain.
Context 2-JP: <jp>人のぐちを聞くことほど面倒臭いことは無い。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Cutting the grass with a sickle every day is such a bother.
Context 3-JP: <jp>毎日鎌で草を刈るのは本当に面倒くさい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>call</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to call</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to call out</vocabulary>. As in "HEY, YOU!"
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji, so you should be good here. Just imagine yourself  calling out to someone: "<reading>YO</reading> (<jp>よ</jp>)! You!"
Context 1-EN: He saved your life so you should invite him to your birthday party.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼はあなたの命の恩人なんだから、誕生日会に呼んだ方がいいわよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Cow</kanji> <kanji>milk</kanji> is <vocabulary>cow's milk</vocabulary>, though most people just call cow's milk <vocabulary>milk</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: "Good morning. Here’s your milk." "Oh, thanks. That hits the spot. There’s nothing like a great glass of milk to start the day."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「おはよう。はい、牛乳よ。」「ああ、ありがとう。やっぱりこれだよね。一日の始まりに、美味しい牛乳に勝るものはないね。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>halt</kanji> <kanji>electricity</kanji> you experience a <vocabulary>power outage</vocabulary>. Makes sense. When the electricity stops you don't have any more power.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Why do I keep flipping light switches on and off if I know that there is still a power outage.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうしてまだ停電してるって分かってるのに、電気のスイッチを何度も付けたり消したりしちゃうんだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>place</kanji> you do your <kanji>farming</kanji> is a <vocabulary>farm</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I went to a farm on Sunday to experience the wheat harvest.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日よう日、小麦のしゅうかくを体験しに、農場へ行ってきました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I was asked if I'd like to keep working at the farm.
Context 2-JP: <jp>農場で、引きつづきはたらかないかと聞かれました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m planning to start an organic farm.
Context 3-JP: <jp>オーガニック農場を始めるつもりです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is what day? Oh, it's <vocabulary>today</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this word is a complete exception, though the word itself is incredibly common and useful. When you think of "today" think about what you have to do today for work.

You have to work in one of those mall kiosks (きょう). Just think about how sad you are that you have to do this today. What a crummy day. It's sunny outside and you're stuck in a mall manning this hermit crab kiosk.

Note: This reading mnemonic is pretty far away from the actual reading, as far as reading mnemonics go. Use this to get yourself close, and then use your own brain grapes to get the rest of the way there. This one won't be as easy as most of the others, but do some good old fashioned memorization and you should be okay. I won't ask you to do this much, fortunately. :)
Context 1-EN: Today’s homework is question two on page twenty-one.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日のしゅくだいは、二十一ページの二ばんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Today's sales are less than usual.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日はいつもよりうり上げが少ない。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>あら、今日が私のたん生日だったんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>task</kanji> is to open this pickle <kanji>container</kanji>. Why you? Because you are so <vocabulary>dextrous</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>skillful</vocabulary> when it comes to opening pickles.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi is very dextrous with his fingers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは手先がとても器用です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet skillfully drank a coca cola while wearing a WaniKani mascot outfit.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトはワニカニの着ぐるみを着たまま、器用にコカ・コーラを飲んだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: She is always a cheerful and agreeable girl but she’s not very skilled with her hands, so I’m wondering if I should fire her.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼女はいつも明るくて良い子なんだけど、あまり器用じゃないので、首にしようか迷ってるんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>obsolete</kanji> will end in <kanji>extinction</kanji>. Join in the calls for its <vocabulary>abolition</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>elimination</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>extinction</vocabulary>, whatever it is.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The anti-nuclear movement believes that the abolition of nuclear weapons is feasible.
Context 1-JP: <jp>核廃絶運動家たちは、核兵器を廃絶することは実現可能だと信じている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>麺</jp> means "noodles", and <jp>つゆ</jp> is another word for "soup" or "broth". Put the two together and you have the delicious <vocabulary>mentsuyu </vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>noodle soup base</vocabulary>. It's usually made of dashi, soy sauce, mirin and sugar​. Yum!
Reading Mnemonic: You learned the reading for <jp>麺</jp> when you learned the kanji.
Context 1-EN: This mentsuyu is the best!
Context 1-JP: <jp>この麺つゆが最高においしいよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: With just three ingredients you can easily make homemade noodle soup base.
Context 2-JP: <jp>三つの材料で簡単に手作り麺つゆができます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This noodle broth can be used in stews and other dishes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この麺つゆは煮物などの料理にも使えます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Go ahead and <kanji>carry out</kanji> the task and <kanji>establish</kanji> the <vocabulary>institution</vocabulary>. To carry out and establish something is to institute it too. What do you institute? An institution.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’d like to quit my job at the children’s home because it’s too hard, but, at the same time, I don’t want to go burning any bridges.
Context 1-JP: <jp>児童養護施設の仕事がきついので辞めたいんですが、一方で今まで築き上げてきた関係も壊したくはないんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s... these are the feelings humans have. When you ask someone to have feelings (Have feelings, <reading>KAY</reading>?? (<jp>け</jp> at the end)), you are asking them to <vocabulary>pity</vocabulary> or have <vocabulary>mercy</vocabulary> on you. Please! Have those human feelings that people have, like <vocabulary>sympathy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pity</vocabulary>. Don't kill me, man!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who are you begging to have pity on you? It's <reading>NASA</reading>. They have you hanging outside of the space station and they're going to push you towards earth where you'll burn up in the atmosphere. You don't want that, so you beg mission control for some <vocabulary>pity</vocabulary>. What will they do? You decide.
Context 1-EN: Koichiko broke up with Koichi after she learned Koichi is a man without even a shred of sympathy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチ子は、コウイチが情けのかけらもない男だと知って、別れました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In Japanese there is a proverb, "It is important for us to be compassionate toward each other as we travel through this world."
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本語には、「旅は道づれ世は情け」ということわざがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I needed a 70 to pass the test, and even though I got a 69, I was given a pity pass.
Context 3-JP: <jp>テストは70点が合格点だったが、私は69点だったのにも関わらずお情けで合格させてもらえた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Election</kanji> is <jp>選挙</jp> so when you make that word into a verb, you have <vocabulary>to elect</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, the reading just comes from <jp>選挙</jp> so if you know that you know this as well.
Context 1-EN: We elect a Tofugu Chairman every year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>Tofuguの会長を毎年選挙しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>judge</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to judge</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go <vocabulary>to judge</vocabulary> people, there are different types. The one you truly hate the most, however, is the <reading>sobber</reading> (<jp>さば</jp>). "The Sobber" is the worst kind. They just sob and sob and sob and it's really hard to move on to your next judging.
Context 1-EN: It came out that the man is a murderer, but the statute of limitations already ran out, so no one is legally able to place judgement on him.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その男が殺人犯であることがわかったが、時効を迎えているので法的には誰も彼を裁く事ができない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're going to get <kanji>judge</kanji>d times two. <kanji>Judge</kanji> and <kanji>judge</kanji> again. Once by the judge and another time by the jury. This is a whole <vocabulary>trial</vocabulary> here.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>はん</jp> goes to <jp>ばん</jp> though, so be careful.
Context 1-EN: This piggy bank contains the eighty dollars I’ve saved from my allowance, but I guess it is not close to enough to file a lawsuit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この貯金箱には小遣いからためた80ドルが入っているんだけど、裁判を起こすには到底足りないと思うんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: So, you're <kanji>send</kanji>ing something that <kanji>revolve</kanji>s. It's a little <vocabulary>transfer</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>transmission</vocabulary>, going through the wires. Little messages that revolve around as they zip through the lines to get to their destination. Try to imagine this happening in slow motion, getting to the other end.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Could you forward that email to me?
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのメール、私にも転送してくれない？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Japanese people who reside overseas often buy things from Japanese websites and have them forwarded to the foreign addresses.
Context 2-JP: <jp>海外に住んでいる日本人は、よく日本のウェブサイトから物を買って、海外の住所に転送しています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Could you please forward my mail to this address?
Context 3-JP: <jp>郵便物をこちら住所の方へ転送して頂きたいんですが。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>express</kanji> something that's of the <kanji>present time</kanji>, you are saying something that only people of the current time understand. These are <vocabulary>expression</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>figure of speech</vocabulary>. You say these things during the present time, not the future, not the past, the present time. Otherwise nobody would understand.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Last night in my dream, our baby told me that it’s time for her baby teeth to come out and she can’t express in words how itchy they are.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨夜の夢で、私たちの赤ちゃんに「乳歯が抜けそうだった時、言葉では表現できないほど痒かった」って言われたの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>illusion</kanji> you have when you're <kanji>awake</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hallucination</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi sometimes has hallucinations while recording podcasts.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは時々、ポッドキャストをレコーディングしている時に幻覚を起こしてしまうんだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When you watch this video, you have to watch in a well-lit place, not too close to the screen, otherwise I heard you'll have hallucinations.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この映像を見る時は、部屋を明るくしてはなれて見ないと、幻覚が見えてくるらしいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Fugu must have been hallucinating from the hallucinogenic mushrooms he ate.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグは幻覚作用のあるキノコを食べたせいで、幻覚に襲われていたに違いない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>member</kanji>s of <kanji>employment</kanji> in your business are your <vocabulary>personnel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>staff</vocabulary>. You employed them, so they're your personnel!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m not a teacher, but I am part of the school staff.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は教師ではありませんが、学校職員です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>pull</kanji> something and <kanji>separate</kanji> it, you are making everything even. In a game, this would be a <vocabulary>tie</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>draw</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: See the hiragana stuck in there? That's hinting that these use the kun'yomi readings. You learned the kun'yomi readings of these two kanji separately in the previous level, so if you know those you should know this word's reading as well.
Context 1-EN: The basketball game was a tie.
Context 1-JP: <jp>バスケのしあいは、引き分けでした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The battle to determine the best pickup truck in America is currently a draw between Toyota and Ford.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アメリカのベストピックアップトラックをきめるたたかいは、今のところトヨタとフォードの引き分けのじょうたいがつづいている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was so upset that our rock-paper-scissors game ended in a three way tie.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は、じゃんけんが三対三の引き分けに終わったことにとても腹を立てた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cut off</kanji>. What happens when you do the action of cutting someone off? You're going <vocabulary>to refuse</vocabulary> them of whatever it is they want.
Reading Mnemonic: By trying to refuse this person, you're going to start a 事 (a war of actions). They will do one war-like action, then you will do a war-like action until it escalates into a 事 (ことわる).
Context 1-EN: I'm still trying to decide whether I should refuse the job or not.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その仕事を断るべきかどうか、判断にまよっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I was asked to be the chief umpire for a baseball game, but I rejected the offer. I would have done it if it was for the chief referee of a soccer game though.
Context 2-JP: <jp>野球の試合の主審をたのまれたけど、断りました。サッカーの試合の主審だったら引き受けたんだけどね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: President Koichi appointed Viet as the next Secretary of State, but he refused.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチ大統領はビエトを次期国務長官に任命したが、ビエトはそれを断った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bite</kanji> or <kanji>chew</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to bite</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to chew</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I was bitten on the groin by a werewolf!
Context 1-JP: <jp>狼男に股を噛まれた！</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>私は机を噛むのが好きです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I have a habit of biting my nails.

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>present time</kanji>, but when something "does present time" it is making itself known in the present time. It is showing itself. When it does present time, it causes it <vocabulary>to appear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to emerge</vocabulary> (as in right now, during the present time).
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It looks like something is going <vocabulary>to appear</vocabulary> in front of you. You are so scared and surprised you can't even speak properly: "<reading>Are wha</reading>t??" (<jp>あらわ</jp>) you ask, trying to figure out what's appearing in front of you.
Context 1-EN: My cat will probably appear around mealtime.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の猫はおそらく夕飯時頃に現れるでしょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lead</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to lead</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this one is a bit difficult, but there's a hint in the kanji. See the <jp>道</jp> in there on the top? What's the reading for the vocab version of that kanji? It's <jp>みち</jp>. That's the first part. Now, who are you leading? Let's say you're leading a bee back to its nest, via the road. It's a <reading>道 Bee</reading> (<jp>みちび</jp>)!
Context 1-EN: I think you misunderstand my father. He’s not the type of person who would lead someone into committing a heinous crime.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたは父のことを誤解していると思います。彼は決して誰かを凶悪犯罪へと導くような人ではありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You already know that 中華 means Chinese, and 麺 means noodles. Put them together and what have you got? That's right, Chinese noodles! Yum!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I've been craving Chinese noodles all day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一日中、中華麺が食べたくて仕方がない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My mom's Chinese noodles are the best in the world.
Context 2-JP: <jp>母の作る中華麺は世界で一番おいしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We became rich exporting instant Chinese noodles to Europe.
Context 3-JP: <jp>インスタント中華麺をヨーロッパに輸出してお金持ちになりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>pluck</kanji> off someone's mask and <kanji>departure</kanji> it off somewhere away from their face, that is <vocabulary>to unmask</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to expose</vocabulary> someone.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m a policeman but I’ve never had the chance to bust a drug trafficking ring.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は警察官ですが、麻薬の密売組織を摘発するような機会に出くわしたことがありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading first. Technically this is the "New Tree Trunk Line" but you wouldn't realize this is the Japanese <vocabulary>bullet train</vocabulary> aka <vocabulary>Shinkansen</vocabulary> from that, would you? Maybe going to the reading will help you after all.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Read this to be able to remember the meaning, too, which is <vocabulary>Shinkansen</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: I could hear nothing, save for the rolling thunder of a Shinkansen passing by.
Context 1-JP: <jp>走りすぎる新幹線の鈍い轟を除いては物音一つ聞こえなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>glad</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>glad</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: Whenever you're really <vocabulary>glad</vocabulary> to be alive, you look up at the sun's rays and sing, "<reading>Ooh, ray</reading>s (<jp>うれ</jp>), I'm so glad you're here!" Then your Uncle Ray comes dancing into the room and sings back, "Ooh, Ray is <vocabulary>happy</vocabulary> you're happy!" The sun's rays and Uncle Ray both make you really happy.
Context 1-EN: You look happy today, for some reason.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は何だか嬉しそうですね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When you were born one hundred years ago today, I was happy. Happy birthday.
Context 2-JP: <jp>百年前の今日、あなたが生まれてくれて嬉しかった。お誕生日おめでとう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Nothing happy has happened to me lately.
Context 3-JP: <jp>最近、嬉しいことが全然ない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>feeling</kanji>s of <kanji>apologizing</kanji>. Strangely, this word means <vocabulary>thanks</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>gratitude</vocabulary>, though. Perhaps someone did something so nice for you that you want to apologize for how many nice things they're doing for you. You are this grateful to them!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Let's show our gratitude to everyone on Thanksgiving Day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>感謝祭の日にはみんなに感謝しましょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Although I don't say it, I always appreciate my wife.
Context 2-JP: <jp>言葉には出さないけど、つまにはいつも感謝しているんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I would like to express my gratitude to all our clients. Without you, we would not be here.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私達のお客様全員に感謝したいと思います。私達は、皆さん無しには、ここには居られません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Swamp</kanji>s and <kanji>mountain</kanji>s happen <vocabulary>a lot</vocabulary> in Japan. That's why we use this to mean <vocabulary>many</vocabulary>! Because there are many of them!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. This word is usually written in kana though, so keep that in mind when you're writing it to use kana and not these kanji!
Context 1-EN: I got a lot of money this month.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今月は沢山の金を手に入れた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>責任</jp> is <kanji>responsibility</kanji>. If you add <jp>感</jp> you get a "feeling of responsibility." That's not really a thing people say. What people do say, however, is <vocabulary>sense of responsibility</vocabulary>. Do you have one?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He may have a strong sense of responsibility, but to me he seemed a little rude and selfish.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は責任感が強いのかもしれないけど、私には少し失礼で自分勝手な気がしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>person</kanji> (people) <kanji>feeling</kanji>s are <vocabulary>human feelings</vocabulary>. That is what <vocabulary>humanity</vocabulary> is all about.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I survive on the warmth of humanity.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人情のあたたかさに生かされています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi-sama is such a wonderful person with deep empathy, but Viet is such a devilish yakuza with not one atom of humanity.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチ様は人情味にあふれているすばらしいお方ですが、ビエト様はひとかけらの人情もないごく悪ヤクザです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Our goal with the daily Tofugu articles is to depict human nature, emotions, and the everyday lives of Japanese individuals.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私達はTofuguの毎日のブログ記事を通して、日本人の生き方や人情を描き出すことを目指しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: My waist is in intense pain. I can’t take another step.
Context 1-JP: <jp>腰に激痛が走ってるんだ。もう一歩も歩けないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This has the same meaning as the kanji. Stick this onto another word and you have "ultra _____."
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I’m super broke right now. I’ve run out of sugar and I can’t even buy more.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今超貧乏でさ〜。砂糖も切らしてるんだけど、それすら新しいの買えないんだわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>horse</kanji> <kanji>deer</kanji> is a <vocabulary>stupid</vocabulary> idea. You're an <vocabulary>idiot</vocabulary> for thinking about it, really. It's quite <vocabulary>dumb</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned both of these readings when you learned the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If you weren’t so stupid, I could explain to you how stupid you are!
Context 1-JP: <jp>お前がそこまで馬鹿じゃなければ、お前がどれだけ馬鹿なのか説明することができるんだけどなあ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Skewer</kanji>s you grill (<jp>焼く</jp>) turn into <vocabulary>grilled skewers</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of the kun'yomi readings you already learned. You should be able to read it already!
Context 1-EN: Lately, I've been into grilled kale skewers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>最近、ケールの串焼きにはまっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I had dinner at a grilled skewer place Friday night.
Context 2-JP: <jp>金曜日の夜は、串焼き屋さんで夕飯を食べました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Our parakeet's catchphrase is, "Don't turn me into grilled skewers!"
Context 3-JP: <jp>うちのインコは「串焼きにしないで！」が口癖です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When your <kanji>heart</kanji> is <kanji>fever</kanji>ish and hot about something, it is obviously something you have a lot of <vocabulary>enthusiasm</vocabulary> about. Think about the things you've enthusiasm for. Then, imagine your heart beating and getting all hot from thinking about it. Why else would people get so upset when talking about religion and politics. It's their feverish heart! Their enthusiasm!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful of the <jp>ねっ</jp> portion (normally is <jp>ねつ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: The child was practicing hiragana with zeal.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子どもは熱心に平仮名をかいていた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My heart was struck by how he practiced skipping enthusiastically every morning in front of the station.
Context 2-JP: <jp>かれが毎朝駅前でスキップの練習をしている熱心なすがたに心打たれました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Tofugu’s new employees were all keen to show their enthusiasm and worked even when they could have been sleeping.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トーフグの新入社員はみんな、仕事にやる気を見せることに熱心で、寝てもいい時間でさえも、仕事をしていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Add this onto the end of someone's name. It's probably too polite, to be honest, unless you're talking to one of your customers or something. It's good to know, but you're probably not going to use it much, despite seeing and hearing it fairly often.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Koichi-sama can't stand it if everything isn't exactly the way he wants.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチ様は、何もかもが自分の思い通りにならないと気がすまないんですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It would be rude if you don't attach the formal name ender, sama, to the recipient's name when you send letters in Japan.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本で手紙を送る時には相手の名前に様をつけないと失礼になります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Mr. Koichi from Tofugu, party of nine. Your table is ready.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トーフグのコウイチ様御一行九名様ですね。お席のご用意ができましたのでどうぞ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
Everything that happened to you previously is just the tip of the iceberg, and the important stuff is ahead of you, in your future. So make sure you put that stuff first!

The original meaning of this word is the tip of something, like a pen or a finger. From that meaning, it's expanded into all sorts of meanings, like ahead, first, and future, depending on the context and where it is in the sentence. It can also mean "previous" in formal contexts (and we'll accept that meaning too, but we're not teaching it here because it's more advanced).
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Just ahead of you are the tips of a saw and a key(さき). You have no idea what they're doing there, but both saws and keys have very sharp tips, so watch out you don't hurt yourself. Imagine yourself edging carefully past those saw and key tips.

You can differentiate this from 先ず (まず) because it doesn't have any hiragana on the end.
Context 1-EN: The tip of the pen got crushed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ペンの先がつぶれた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There's a restaurant just ahead of us.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この先にレストランがある。</jp>
Context 4-EN: Nobody knows what the future holds.
Context 4-JP: <jp>先のことはだれにも分かりません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>discipline</kanji> in which you <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>word</kanji>s so that you can out talk anyone is called <vocabulary>rhetoric</vocabulary>. Get the rhetoric right and you can be a boss in any word related situation or discipline, yo!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I have a crush on the rhetoric teacher.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は修辞学の先生に恋をしています。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Published,To Be Reported,To Be Printed
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>publish</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be published</vocabulary>. Books can be published, magazines can be published, and I guess even your gross blog posts get published too.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

"Hey, were you able to be published yet?" someone asks, and the answer is always NO (の)! It's never your time to get published. The answer is always no... because no one likes (sniff) what you write (sob).
Context 1-EN: My interview as the representative of the entry-level employees was published in the spring edition of the company newsletter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新入社員の代表として受けた私のインタビュー記事が、社内報の春季号に載りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <jp>磁場</jp> is a "magnetic field." An <kanji>electricity</kanji> version of this is an <vocabulary>electromagnetic field</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings for the first two kanji and the kun'yomi reading of the third. You should be able to read this on your own. Will of course help to know <jp>磁場</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: My father has a patent for an electromagnetic field generator, but I’m not sure what it’s for.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の父は、電磁場発生装置の特許を持っているんですが、私はそれが何のためのものなのかよく分かりません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>放射</jp> is "radiation." Add the <kanji>ability</kanji> of radiation and you have <vocabulary>radioactivity</vocabulary>, for some reason. I guess things don't have radioactivity until you have given them the ability of radiation, right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Before calling the meeting about the radioactivity, we should decide who should attend.
Context 1-JP: <jp>放射能に関する会議を招集する前に、出席者を決める方がいいだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>look at</kanji> things and <kanji>memorize</kanji> them via your sight, using your <vocabulary>sense of sight</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My superior was fired for discrimination against a visually disabled worker.
Context 1-JP: <jp>視覚障害のある社員を差別したとの理由から、上司が解雇された。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>frugal</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>regrettable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>precious</vocabulary>. If you're too frugal to buy something your actions are regrettable later when you realize you wanted that thing. If you're so frugal you only buy one single thing, it's very precious to you.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You made a regrettable decision. You didn't buy that clock you wanted and now it's been discontinued. The salesperson tells you this and all you can say is, "Oh..." (お) really really quietly. How disappointing.
Context 1-EN: I lost a precious person.
Context 1-JP: <jp>惜しい人を亡くしたものだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Everyone</kanji> (<kanji>formal name title</kanji>). This is just a polite way to say <vocabulary>everyone</vocabulary> (and you want to be polite to everyone, because everyone > you).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for both kanji here are the same as the ones you learned with their kanji. Everyone can breathe easier now.
Context 1-EN: Okay everyone, the airplane will be landing in Los Angeles Airport soon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>皆様、間もなく当ひ行きはロサンゼルス空港に着りくします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I wish everyone the best of luck and continued good health.
Context 2-JP: <jp>皆様のごけんこうとご多こうをおいのり申し上げます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Could everyone take their seats, please?" "With all due respect, I don’t think that's a good idea. There is super glue on our chairs for some reason."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「皆様、ご着席いただけますか？」「お言葉ですが、それは良い考えではないと思います。何故だか分かりませんが、我々の椅子に接着剤が付いているのです。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>luck</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji> wasn't actually too lucky. This is <vocabulary>Fukushima</vocabulary> where the nuclear meltdown happened after the 2011 earthquake. So, when you think of "luck island" this is where you should think.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. If one thing is lucky, it's probably that.
Context 1-EN: This band's vocalist is from Fukushima.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このバンドのボーカルは、福島の出身です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Look at the silver, starry sky in this drawing from a kid in Fukushima.
Context 2-JP: <jp>福島の子どもたちがかいた絵の中の、この銀色の星空を見て下さい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Please CC me on all emails concerning the problems of Fukushima.
Context 3-JP: <jp>福島問題に関するメールは、全て私をCCに入れてもらえますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You previously learned this kanji with three different meanings. In vocabulary form, it just has one of these meanings, <vocabulary>Framed Picture</vocabulary>! Similarly, it can just mean <vocabulary>Picture</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Frame</vocabulary> too.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: I’m searching for a frame to match this picture.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この絵に合う額を探しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The place where your <kanji>company</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>s is your <vocabulary>company</vocabulary>. Sony is a company. Nintendo is a company. Etc.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: How do you go to your company?
Context 1-JP: <jp>会社へは、何で行っていますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu is a company that deals with things like developing Japanese language learning materials and delivering Japanese-related information.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグは日本ごの学しゅうきょうざいをつくったり、日本についてのじょうほうをはいしんしたりする会社です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The president of the company I work for looks like a hamster.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私が働く会社の社長は、ハムスターのような容貌をしている。</jp>

Meaning: Place To Put Something,Place To Put Down,Location To Put Something,Location To Put Down
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>置く</jp> is <kanji>to put down</kanji> something. So a <kanji>location</kanji> where you put something down is a <vocabulary>place to put something</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the readings of <jp>置く</jp> and <jp>場</jp> put together.
Context 1-EN: We have a place for the towels under the sink, so help yourself after your shower.
Context 1-JP: <jp>洗面台の下にタオル置き場があるから、シャワーの後勝手に取って使ってね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>container</kanji> used by the <kanji>military</kanji> is probably going to be used as a <vocabulary>weapon</vocabulary>. After all, that's what the military does... weapons.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Is it true that not all police officers are qualified to use their weapons?
Context 1-JP: <jp>全ての警察官に武器を使う資格があるわけではないというのは本当ですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>郵便</jp> is the <kanji>mail</kanji>. A <kanji>box</kanji> that's used with said mail is a <vocabulary>mailbox</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: How could this book fit in my small mailbox?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうやって私の小さな郵便箱にこの本が入ったんだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>burn</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to burn something</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to burn</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: This is when you're burning something. To remember this meaning, you have to remember the <jp>も</jp> part. So, just think of your friend <reading>Mo</reading>e (<jp>も</jp>), and how you're going to burn him... uh... just a little bit.
Context 1-EN: I really like burning things until they’re reduced to ashes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>何かを完全に灰になるまで燃やすことが大好きだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>listen</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to listen to</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hear</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The meaning is really similar to <jp>聞く</jp>, right? The reading is the same.
Context 1-EN: I’m listening to this relaxing song and I’m getting sleepy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その癒し系の曲を聴いてると、眠くなってきたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>romance</kanji> you also have <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>! The romantic kind of mushy, gushy love. Be careful though. This word doesn't share its meaning with its kanji. But, that's how romance is. It gets all crazy and turns to love really fast.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your <vocabulary>love</vocabulary> isn't toward a person, it's toward this giant <reading>Koi</reading> (<jp>こい</jp>) fish you met the other day. The fish is just so... so... handsome! You get hearts popping above your head every time you think about this koi!
Context 1-EN: I wanted to fall in love, but I'd never actually fallen for anyone until now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今まで、恋に恋したことはあっても、本当にだれかに恋したことは無かったんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Don't you think Salmon got prettier? I think it's because she's a woman in love, don't you?
Context 2-JP: <jp>サーモンちゃん、なんかかわいくなったよな。恋する女って感じじゃない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t get Fugu out of my head! Is there love in the air?
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグのことが頭から離れないの。これって恋の始まりなのかな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>thin</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>thin</vocabulary>, though it can be <vocabulary>slender</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: If your garden is too <vocabulary>thin</vocabulary>, just get out the <reading>hose</reading> (<jp>ほそ</jp>)! How about if your hair is thin? Point the hose at your head! Hoses can cure any thin issues you may have.
Context 1-EN: I think this thread is a bit too thin.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この糸はちょっと細すぎますね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Your fingers are slender and long like a pianist's.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ピアニストみたいに細くて長い指だね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My dietary plan is basically to make all of my friends cupcakes. The fatter they get, the skinnier I look.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私のダイエット計画は、基本的に友達全員にカップケーキを作ることです。つまり、みんなを太らせれば太らせるほど、私が細く見えるってわけ。</jp>

Meaning: To Brew,To Cause,To Give Rise To,To Distill
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>brew</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to brew</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to distill</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You want to brew up some beer but not the regular boring stuff. You're going to make it from the water in the hump of a camel (かも). Camel beer is definitely not a horrible idea, right?
Context 1-EN: The idol’s bold statement is giving rise to public criticism.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アイドルの大胆な発言が物議を醸している。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Transport</kanji> of <kanji>blood</kanji>. Only time you do this is during a <vocabulary>blood transfusion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: She was in a car accident when she was just about to head off to Tokyo, and now she is getting a blood transfusion in the hospital.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女はちょうど東京に向かおうとしていた矢先に交通事故に巻き込まれ、現在病院で輸血を受けている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>look to</kanji> something, you are facing it, taking it head on. That's why this verb vocab is <vocabulary>to face</vocabulary>, as in "to face terrorism," etc.
Reading Mnemonic: The reason you must <vocabulary>(to) face</vocabulary> terrorism is because the terrorists have threatened to take everyone's <reading>nose</reading>s (<jp>のぞ</jp>) away. We must face them head on if we are to save our noses!
Context 1-EN: The Tofugu headquarters is located in Oregon, which is a state in the northwestern United States facing the Pacific.
Context 1-JP: <jp>Tofuguの本社は、オレゴン州という、太平洋に臨むアメリカ北西部の州に位置しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>aim</kanji> is your <vocabulary>aim</vocabulary>. What are you aiming for? Despite looking like an adjective, this is a noun, so be careful!
Reading Mnemonic: My <vocabulary>aim</vocabulary> is <reading>near</reading> (<jp>ねら</jp>) to here. Right there, in fact.
Context 1-EN: The aim of this textbook is as mentioned above.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この教科書の狙いは上述の通りです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Any problem has objectives and aims.
Context 2-JP: <jp>どんな問題にも目的と狙いがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It must be a clickbait article aimed at affiliate programs or stealth marketing.
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうせアフィ狙いかステマの釣り記事だろ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I'm going to <kanji>diagnose</kanji> you and then make a <kanji>guess</kanji> as to what's wrong with you during this <vocabulary>medical exam</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The doctor has a jam-packed medical exam schedule.
Context 1-JP: <jp>先生は診察の予定がみっちり詰まっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have to <kanji>aim</kanji> with your <kanji>attack</kanji>, you're probably <vocabulary>shooting</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sniping</vocabulary> something with a projectile (like a gun, or something).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He positioned himself in view of the hotel room to snipe the politician.
Context 1-JP: <jp>男は政治家を狙撃するために、そのホテルの部屋が見える場所までやってきた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>hundred million</kanji> is <vocabulary>one hundred million</vocabulary>. That's a lot of zeros.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi has a one-hundred-million yen condo in Tokyo.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは東京に一億円のマンションを持っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I can't believe that Japan, a tiny island country, has one hundred million people living on it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本という小さな島国に一億もの人が住んでいることがしんじられない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I won a hundred million dollars in the lottery, but I donated it all to charity because I’m a trillionaire.
Context 3-JP: <jp>宝くじで一億ドル当たったけど、私は既に兆万長者なので全部慈善活動に寄付したよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Tree</kanji> <kanji>manufacture</kanji>d items are <vocabulary>wooden</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>made from wood</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My wooden bat was broken by an inside fastball thrown by that guy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺の木製バットは、あいつの内角速球によって折れてしまったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>bottom</kanji> <kanji>lip</kanji> is your <vocabulary>lower lip</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bottom lip</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
したくちびる is the vocab reading for 下 and the reading you learned with the kanji for 唇. This is how you'd usually read this word.

かしん is very technical and it's rarely used outside of scientific writing. If you don't plan to read science papers in Japanese, you can ignore this reading!
Context 1-EN: Even though the baby was wearing cotton mittens, he still scratched his lower lip.
Context 1-JP: <jp>赤ちゃんは、木綿のミトンをしていたにも関わらず、下唇を引っ掻いてしまった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: "I can’t eat out this week because I’m broke." Hitomi said, biting her bottom lip.
Context 2-JP: <jp>「お金が無いから、今週は外食出来ないの。」と言って、瞳は下唇をかんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The bottom lip of the ancient shark Helicoprion is just amazing. You should Google it!
Context 3-JP: <jp>古代鮫ヘリコプリオン、とにかく下唇がすごいから、一度ググってみて！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>meet</kanji> so the verb form of that is <vocabulary>to meet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to encounter</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have to remember the あ part but let's include the う as well for this one. Who do you want to meet more than anyone? Think about it. Then, imagine meeting them. The first thing they do is grab your arm and pinch it. You yell out "OW!" (あう) and they laugh and run away.
Context 1-EN: We’re meeting on Sunday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日よう日に会う。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I ran into Koichi at the Portland airport.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ポートランドくうこうでばったりコウイチに会いました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I get to meet my favorite actor tomorrow afternoon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>明日の午後、大好きな俳優に会えるんです！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word starts with an お to make it more polite. Then it has the kanji 兄 which you already know. Lastly, it has さん which is an honorific to elevate people and be polite. This is basically the formal way of saying older brother (versus plain old 兄). It can also be used to refer to a guy that you don't know who has a youthful appearance.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this one is pretty tricky, and I'd consider it an exception. To remember it, you have to learn the 兄 part, and everything else will fall into place. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your (kind) older brother pushes you down on the ground. You stand up and look at your knee (にい), which is all bloody. "Why'd you do that to my knee!?" you ask. "You're supposed to be a nice older brother, that's why I call you お兄さん!"
Context 1-EN: Which one is Takashi’s older brother?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どれがたかしのお兄さんですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The delivery guy today had exactly the type of face I go for.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日のたっきゅうびんのお兄さんのかおがタイプすぎた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t help thinking about my older brother’s nose hair.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お兄さんのはなげがきになってしかたがない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Everyone</kanji> + <jp>さん</jp> (normal name ender). This is the normal way to say <vocabulary>everyone</vocabulary>
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: That is up to all of you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それは皆さんが決めてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I just want to get along with everybody. I absolutely do not have any ulterior motives.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしは皆さんと仲良くなりたいだけなんです。決して下心なんてありません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hello everyone. I am hoping we can nail down some of the dates for the Tofugu seminars this week. I’ll talk to Viet in the next few days and then I will announce everyone’s schedule.
Context 3-JP: <jp>皆さん、こんにちは。今週中には、トーフグセミナーの日程を確定させたいと思っています。数日中にビエトと話しをして、その後で皆さんに日程をお伝えさせて頂きます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>初</jp> means "first" This word means <vocabulary>for the first time</vocabulary>. Think of <jp>めて</jp> as "meet." Then think "when we met <vocabulary>for the first time</vocabulary> ____ happened."
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. What are you beginning? You are beginning <reading>Haj</reading> (<jp>はじ</jp>). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja).
Context 1-EN: Since the first time we met, President Obama and I have gotten along very well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>初めてオバマ大とうりょうと会ったしゅんかんから意気投合した。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is my first time dealing with banking and I'm really struggling.
Context 2-JP: <jp>初めての銀行業むに四苦八苦しています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Is it possible this is your first time in Japan?" "Yes, it is." "Oh really? How do you like it?” "I really like it!"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「もしかして、日本はこれが初めて？」「はい。そうなんです。」「そうなんだ。日本はどう？」「かなり気に入ってるわ。」</jp>

Meaning: To Distinguish,To Tell Apart,To Differentiate,To Recognize
Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>see</kanji> something, then you <kanji>separate</kanji> (<jp>分ける</jp>) it. This is the same thing as <vocabulary>to distinguish</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You should know the reading of <jp>見</jp> already. The second part, <jp>分ける</jp> is a word you should have learned in the previous level. Combine that knowledge together and you get the reading for this word.
Context 1-EN: I can’t tell whether it’s real or fake.
Context 1-JP: <jp>本ものかにせものか見分けられない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Is there a way to find out if my significant other is a psychopath?
Context 2-JP: <jp>こい人がサイコパスかどうか見分ける方ほうはありますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: We should have put collars on our dogs, because now it's difficult to tell which one is mine and which one is yours.
Context 3-JP: <jp>首輪をつけておくべきだったよね。だって、どっちの犬がどっちの犬か見分けるのが難しくなっちゃったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Candy</kanji> made into a <kanji>thin</kanji> <kanji>construction</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sugar sculpture</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>candy sculpture</vocabulary>. It's usually a <vocabulary>sugar animal</vocabulary>, but it can be anything, really.
Reading Mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi reading for the first kanji and the on'yomi readings for the second two. You haven't learned this reading for 工 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You want your sugar sculptures to be made into cookies (く)! Cookies are your other favorite snack, so having a cookie that's really just entirely made of sugar is the absolute best.

Also, watch out for the rendaku on 細, it's easy to miss if you're focusing on remembering this new on'yomi reading.
Context 1-EN: My father is a master of sugar sculptures.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の父は飴細工の名人です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Have you ever made sugar sculptures?
Context 3-EN: Apparently, the sugar goldfish is similar to real goldfish in shape and taste.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その金魚の飴細工は、形も味も本物の金魚にそっくりなんだって。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>country</kanji> <kanji>boundary</kanji> is that country's <vocabulary>national border</vocabulary>. Be careful about crossing it if you're carrying bananas. The border police seem to hate when you tell them you're carrying a banana in your pants when they ask you if you're bringing any fruits back. No idea why.
Reading Whitelist: こっきょう,くにざかい
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>こく</jp> gets shortened to a nice little <jp>こっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: It is common for Border Patrol agents to find foreigners who have entered the U.S. illegally in the bushes near the border.
Context 1-JP: <jp>国境警備隊の隊員がアメリカに不法入国した外国人を国境のそばの茂みで見つけることはよくあることです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>expand</kanji> and <kanji>open</kanji>. Just imagine something happening like this. This is when something is <vocabulary>unfolding</vocabulary> or in <vocabulary>development</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What are the advantages of small businesses expanding overseas?
Context 1-JP: <jp>中小企業が海外展開をする利点とは何でしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>religion</kanji> <kanji>sect</kanji> is a sect within religion, most likely, but it can be simply referred to as a <vocabulary>sect</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>denomination</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: There are some rules for acting as chairman of meetings in this religious sect.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この宗派には、会議で議長を務めるための規則があります。</jp>

Meaning: To Mourn For,To Hold A Memorial Service For,To Condole
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>condolence</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to mourn for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to condole</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You seem to mourn for things you really care about. Well then you would mourn for your toe mural (とむら). You had a mural made for your favorite toe so if anything were to happen to it, you would want to mourn for it.
Context 1-EN: We’re building a stone memorial for the souls of soldiers who died in battle.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここには、殉職者の魂を弔う石碑が建てられています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>celebrate</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is a day you get off to celebrate something awesome. More specifically, this is known as a <vocabulary>national holiday</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>public holiday</vocabulary>. Festivus for the restivus!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi always wears the most showy clothes on holidays.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは祝日はいつもかなり派手な格好をしている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Transmit</kanji>s the feeling of wanting to <kanji>unite</kanji> behind something. What do people unite behind, if they're all part of a similar people? Tradition. Add <jp>的</jp> on there and you have <vocabulary>traditional</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Fundoshi is traditional Japanese underwear for guys.
Context 1-JP: <jp>褌は、伝統的な日本の男性用下着です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: You only learned one reading for the kanji that makes up this word, and it's the same as the reading for this word (of course). That means you should already know the reading.
Context 1-EN: Please write the character more carefully.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もっとていねいに字をかいてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I married a man whose eyebrows are shaped like the character for eight.
Context 2-JP: <jp>八の字まゆ毛の男せいとけっこんしました。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>この字は何という意味ですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Weird that this kanji means <kanji>bullet</kanji> but the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to bounce</vocabulary>. Just imagine someone shooting a bullet. What does it do when it hits the right materials? It's going <vocabulary>to bounce</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you're going <vocabulary>to bounce</vocabulary> something off that wall, it <reading>has</reading> (<jp>はず</jp>) to be made of rubber, otherwise it will just go right through. It <reading>has</reading> to.
Context 1-EN: I never expected such a lively conversation between the two of us.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼との会話がこんなに弾むなんて、思ってもみなかったわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>explode</kanji> <kanji>bullet</kanji> is when an explode shoots out of something like a bullet, but much bigger, like from a <vocabulary>bomb</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I knew taking apart the bomb could be very dangerous, but I was really interested.
Context 1-JP: <jp>爆弾を分解することは危険だってことは分かってたんだけど、すごく興味があったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Imperial</kanji> <kanji>tea</kanji> the color of a <kanji>crow</kanji>'s feathers can only be the famous, delicious <vocabulary>Oolong tea</vocabulary>. It came from the imperial people of China to Japan (probably) and there are lots of different variants. But the leaves are all that blackish/grey crow feather color.
Reading: <reading><jp>うーろんちゃ</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>ウーロンちゃ</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: うーろんちゃ,ウーロンちゃ
Reading Mnemonic:
This word takes the on'yomi readings except for 龍 which is an exception (sorry). You haven't learned the on'yomi for 烏 yet either, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who loves Oolong tea more than anyone else? Oooo Ron (うーろん) Weasley from Harry Potter. He's British, so of course you'd think he loves tea, but Oolong is his jam. Just picture him and think, oooooh it's Ron, when you drink this kind of tea.

And make sure you remember that, because this is also a written in katakana when the kanji isn't used, to type out the long mark ー when you enter your answer.
Context 1-EN: Oolong tea without ice, please.
Context 1-JP: <jp>烏龍茶を氷抜きでください。</jp>

Meaning: Nonburnable Garbage,Unburnable Garbage,Nonburnable Trash,Unburnable Trash,Nonburnable Rubbish,Unburnable Rubbish
Meaning Mnemonic: These are <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>burn</kanji>able garbages (<jp>ごみ</jp>). Pay attention to this on signs when you throw things away. You want to put the right things into <vocabulary>nonburnable garbage</vocabulary>.
Reading Whitelist: ふねんごみ,ふねんゴミ
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please take out the nonburnable garbage on Tuesday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>不燃ゴミは火曜日に出してください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>rule</kanji> <kanji>model</kanji> is the model that follows all the rules. It's the normal model. It is <vocabulary>typical</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Why do you call him a typical Japanese person?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして彼のことを典型的な日本人だっていうの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>announce</kanji> something <kanji>beforehand</kanji> you will have <vocabulary>advance notice</vocabulary>. Advance notice is always nice to give.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: You'll be alright. Koichi won't fire you without prior notice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大丈夫だよ、コウイチは予告なしにかいこしたりしないよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I left my rent unpaid for three months and then I was given an eviction notice.
Context 2-JP: <jp>三ヶ月家ちんをたいのうしてしまい、立ちのきを予告されました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A letter giving advance notice for a murder arrived at the Tofugu office.
Context 3-JP: <jp>殺人予告を告げる手紙が、Tofuguオフィスに届けられた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: We are ready to <kanji>confront</kanji> <kanji>war</kanji>, if we have to. We are going to start the <vocabulary>resistance</vocabulary> against your regime, confront you, and even make war.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The students were forced to resist to the bitter end against authority.
Context 1-JP: <jp>学生たちは、権威に対して徹底抗戦を強いられました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>listen</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is your <vocabulary>hearing ability</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m going to submit my report about blind people’s hearing abilities this afternoon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日の午後に、盲目の人の聴力に関するレポートを提出するつもりです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>intercept</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to intercept</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to interrupt</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The thing you want to interrupt and to intercept is your roommate's sighing guitar (さえぎ). He keeps playing it and all it does is make these horrible, long sighing sounds. You want to interrupt it any cost.
Context 1-EN: It’s rude to interrupt a person.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人の話を遮るのは失礼です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>radiance</kanji>. Imagine if something is radiating on something else. That would cause it <vocabulary>to shine</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to glitter</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to sparkle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The <reading>cog yak</reading> is so shiny. It so shiny it starts <vocabulary>to shine</vocabulary> and glitter. I don't know what a cog yak is, but imagine it in your head and imagine it being super shiny, shining off shines and glitter.
Context 1-EN: Under the bright, shining moon, I was caught in the sobriety checkpoint and promptly arrested for driving under the influence.
Context 1-JP: <jp>明るく輝く月の下で、飲酒運転取締り検問所にひっかかり、飲酒運転の罪で速攻逮捕されてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: "What do you think of Fugu?" "To be honest, I don’t like him. I prefer a guy with muscular arms like Kinnikuma."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「フグのこと、どう思う？」「正直に言うと、私の好みじゃないわ。私はキンニクマみたいに筋肉モリモリの腕の男が好きなの。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Confront</kanji> your <kanji>body</kanji>? Sounds like it's something that's against bodies... perhaps, something that's <vocabulary>antibody</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why do you defy your boss and try to build up antibodies to the virus? Get a vaccination!
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうしてボスに逆らって、そのウィルスへの抗体を作り出そうとするのですか？予防接種を受ける！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>America</kanji> <kanji>manufacture</kanji>d is something that is <vocabulary>made in USA</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>made in America</vocabulary>.
Reading: <reading><jp>あめりかせい</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>アメリカせい</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: あめりかせい,アメリカせい
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: You really won’t eat sushi that was made in USA? You’re too picky.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アメリカ製の寿司は食べられないだって？好き嫌いするんじゃないよ！</jp>

Meaning: To Amass,To Store,To Lay In Stock,To Have A Beard,To Grow A Beard
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>amass</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to amass</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to store</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This shares the same reading as <jp>貯える</jp>, and the meanings are very close too!
Context 1-EN: He’s growing such a splendid mustache.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼はとても立派な口髭を蓄えています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>serve</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to serve</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pour</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What do you decide to serve your guests? Cookies (く)! But not just any cookies. Cookie smoothies! They're delicious and you won't pour anyone anything else. They must drink your delicious cookie drinks.
Context 1-EN: Please pour water into this bucket quickly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>急いでバケツに水を酌んできてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have something that's <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>sufficient</kanji>. When something isn't sufficient, you have a <vocabulary>shortage</vocabulary>. Keep in mind that this is a physical shortage, not a shortage of mental ability or something like that. To remember this, just think about how <jp>足</jp> also means "foot." What is a foot? Something physical. That's why this is a physical shortage.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I don’t have enough change.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おつりが不足しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Due to the lack of funds, the project that the central government planned was suspended.
Context 2-JP: <jp>しきん不足で中央せいふのきかくしたプロジェクトが中止になった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You are fired because you lack experience and are always sleep deprived.
Context 3-JP: <jp>経験が不足しているうえにいつも寝不足なので、あなたは首です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>celebrate</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to celebrate</vocabulary>. When you burn this word, you should <jp>祝う</jp>!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you celebrate something, you have to yell out your celebrations. Yell out <reading><jp>いわう</jp></reading> three times! It's kind of like a combination of the word <jp>いい</jp> (good) and "wow." <jp>いい</jp>wow! <jp>いい</jp>wow! Just make sure the <jp>いい</jp> gets shortened, because it's getting combined.
Context 1-EN: We are going to a Chinese restaurant to celebrate grandpa’s 60th birthday on Sunday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日曜日におじいちゃんの還暦を祝うために、中華を食べに行きます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Isolate</kanji> this <kanji>week</kanji> from next week, and do that over and over. That way we have <vocabulary>every other week</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This anime airs every other week and I like its opening and ending songs.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このアニメは隔週で放送されていて、私はそのオープニング曲とエンディング曲が好きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Elderly</kanji> people start to <kanji>decay</kanji> and they get all <vocabulary>decrepit</vocabulary> and gross. Like a corpse. Bleh. Good thing I'll never be <vocabulary>too old</vocabulary>. Ho ho ho!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That building is pretty decrepit so you shouldn’t go in it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その建物はかなり老朽しているので、立ち入らない方がいい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>pipe</kanji> of <kanji>reason</kanji>. Imagine someone holding this pipe. It always leads to the correct decision because it is the pipe of reason. Those who have this pipe are in a higher rank than you. They are the <vocabulary>management</vocabulary>, and by using this pipe of reason they're able to make good management decisions.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I can’t believe the lecturer of the time management strategy class is actually late.
Context 1-JP: <jp>時間管理法の授業の講師が遅刻しているなんて、信じられない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>narrow</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>narrow</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji, so you're good to go here. It may be a <vocabulary>narrow</vocabulary> way of thinking about this kanji, but it will help you out the most.
Context 1-EN: Koichi, put your toys away! If you don’t I’ll put you in the dark, narrow closet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチ、おもちゃを片付けなさい！さもないと、暗くて狭いクローゼットに閉じ込めるわよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>long time</kanji>? Well, it's <vocabulary>long ago</vocabulary>, or can mean <vocabulary>for a long time</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Long ago, in a galaxy far away, a bunch of prequel movies were ruined by a single character. "Heesa (ひさ) the best character!" you hear. Oh no. Heesa here. Get out before Jar Jar Binks gets you! Keep him in the past!
Context 1-EN: It’s been long since I stopped eating bacon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしがベーコンをたべなくなって久しい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Japanese people have taken peace for granted for so long that they probably can't understand it anymore.
Context 2-JP: <jp>へいわボケして久しい日本人には、おそらくりかいできないだろう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He ate a raw goldfish and has been dead for a long time now.
Context 3-JP: <jp>かれが生のきんぎょをたべてしんでから久しい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: My <kanji>dialect</kanji> has offended you? I will make <kanji>reparation</kanji> by giving you a <vocabulary>reimbursement</vocabulary> and some <vocabulary>compensation</vocabulary>. I'm sorry my dialect was so bad you couldn't understand the speech. Here's your money back.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I ripped a fisherman’s nets by mistake while taking pictures, so I had to reimburse him.
Context 1-JP: <jp>撮影中に漁師さんの網を誤って破いてしまったため、弁償しなくてはならなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means catch so the verb version is to catch.

Try to remember the mnemonic from the kanji with this one, because this word isn't used for physically catching things, but for ideas or meanings that you are able to grasp, metaphorically speaking.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
Context 1-EN: A glass filled halfway with water can be perceived as "half empty" or "half full," depending on the person.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コップの半分まで入れられた水は、人によって「半分しかない」とも「半分もある」とも捉えられます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's hard to grasp what Japanese clients are really thinking.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本人のクライアントの本音を捉えるのは難しい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Immediately after the show started, the circus troupe captivated the audience's hearts.
Context 3-JP: <jp>そのサーカス団は、開演してすぐに観客の心を捉えた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>carry</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to carry</vocabulary>. This has to do with carrying something literal, unlike <jp>担う</jp> which is not necessarily literal (you'll learn it later). And in this case, you carry it on your shoulder(s). You can remember that it's literal from the reading mnemonic, which has you carrying literal cats on your shoulders.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You love to carry things, especially cats (かつ). You hoist them up onto your shoulders and carry them all around town.
Context 1-EN: If I go to Japan, I’d like to carry a portable shrine in a parade.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本に行ったら、お祭りで神輿を担いでみたい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>material</kanji> you can <kanji>burn</kanji> is called <vocabulary>fuel</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was simply running out of fuel.
Context 1-JP: <jp>単なる燃料切れだったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Display</kanji> and <kanji>publish</kanji> your writing into a <vocabulary>publication</vocabulary> or form of <vocabulary>print</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Do you mind if I reproduce some copies of articles published on Tofugu and distribute them to my students who are studying Japanese?
Context 1-JP: <jp>Tofuguに掲載されているブログ記事を何部かコピーして、日本語を学習している私の生徒たちに配っても構いませんか？</jp>

Meaning: To Assume A Stance,To Get Ready To Fight
Meaning Mnemonic: You know <jp>構え</jp>, which is a stance? This is the verb version, making it <vocabulary>to assume a stance</vocabulary>, or most often, <vocabulary>to get ready to fight</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>構え</jp>, so if you know that you'll be ready for this fight.
Context 1-EN: When you play poker it’s important to prepare patiently.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ポーカーをする時は、気長に構えることが大切です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>urge</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Someone with a weird accent is trying <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary> you to eat "Unagah" (<jp>うなが</jp>).
