This person really means "unagi," and this person also doesn't realize how delicious unagi is (and thinks he's tricking you). You ask him what "Unagah" is. Go ahead and say it out loud.
Context 1-EN: The weather lady urged viewers to take their umbrellas with them.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お天気のお姉さんが、視聴者に傘を持って行くよう促した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>縛る</jp> means "to bind?" Well, in Japanese being bound by <kanji>gold</kanji> means you're experiencing <vocabulary>sleep paralysis</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>temporary paralysis</vocabulary>. Just imagine that you're waking from a dream where you're bound up in gold thread, and it's stopping you from moving.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>金</jp> and <jp>縛る</jp>. Both use the kun'yomi readings, but <jp>金</jp> becomes <jp>かな</jp> instead of <jp>かね</jp>. If you can remember that exception, this should be easy!
Context 1-EN: Have you ever had sleep paralysis before?
Context 1-JP: <jp>金縛りにあったことはありますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>foster</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to foster</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're offering <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary> some girl as your own. After the paperwork is over, you can finally say: "<reading>Yah, she now</reading> (<jp>やしな</jp>) is my kid!"
Context 1-EN: Does WaniKani foster Tofugu or does Tofugu foster WaniKani?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ワニカニがトーフグを養っているの？それともトーフグがワニカニを養っているの？</jp>
Context 2-EN: We need to keep our eyes peeled so we won't be deceived by Koichi's ninjutsu.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチのにんじゅつにだまされない目を養う必要があります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You should thank your husband sometimes. He has done a good job raising your family, hasn’t he?
Context 3-JP: <jp>たまにはご主人にも感謝しろよ。あいつだって、立派に家族を養ってきたじゃないか。</jp>

Meaning: To Help,To Assist,To Lend A Hand,To Give A Hand
Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>transmit</kanji> your <kanji>hand</kanji> to something or someone, you're putting out your hand <vocabulary>to help</vocabulary> them or <vocabulary>to assist</vocabulary> them.
Reading Mnemonic: Both of these are the kun'yomi readings that you've already learned! The thing is, the <jp>た</jp> from <jp>伝</jp>'s <jp>つた</jp> changes into <jp>だ</jp> for who knows what reason. Perhaps you can ask for someone <vocabulary>to help</vocabulary> you to understand this dumb reading change.
Context 1-EN: Can you give me a hand in cleaning up the fridge?
Context 1-JP: <jp>れいぞうこをかた付けるの、手伝ってくれない？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet asked me to help him assassinate Koichi because he purchased a 100 million dollar insurance policy for him.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトに、コウイチに一億ドルのほけん金をかけたので、やつを暗殺するのを手伝ってほしいとたのまれたんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m sorry. I’d like to help but my hands are tied.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ごめんなさい。お手伝いしてあげたいんだけど、私にはどうにもできないんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>consume</kanji> <kanji>smoke</kanji> you are <vocabulary>smoking</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: None of Tofugu's employees smoke.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグの社員には、喫煙する人が一人もいません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do you know where the smoking room is?
Context 2-JP: <jp>喫煙室はどこにあるかご存知ですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh my gosh! That was just way too funny! Why did you think you could smoke with your nose? I am laughing so hard right now.
Context 3-JP: <jp>やばーい！ちょっと面白すぎっしょ〜！何で鼻で喫煙できるなんて思っちゃったわけ？爆笑してるんですけど。</jp>

Meaning: To Cross,To Cross Over,To Go Across
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>transit</kanji>, but when you think about "to transit" this doesn't make too much sense. When you "transit" something, though, you're going across it. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to cross</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cross over</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: After crossing the bridge, please turn right.
Context 1-JP: <jp>橋を渡り終わったところで、右に曲がって下さい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>bake</kanji>d <kanji>bird</kanji> isn't just any bird, it's <vocabulary>roast chicken</vocabulary>. You may also know it by its romanized Japanese name: <vocabulary>yakitori</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings. With <jp>焼き</jp>, you can use the reading you learned with the kanji. With <jp>鳥</jp> just remember back to the vocab word, <jp>とり</jp>. Combine and eat.
Context 1-EN: Yakitori is essential for my life.
Context 1-JP: <jp>焼き鳥は私の生活に不可欠です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My husband was too busy running his yakitori restaurant and he totally forgot about our wedding anniversary.
Context 2-JP: <jp>主人は焼き鳥屋のけいえいが忙しすぎて、けっこん記念日のことはすっかり忘れていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t blame me! I didn’t eat your yakitori.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私のせいにしないで。あなたの焼き鳥なんか食べてないわよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: These people are kind of like a <kanji>type</kanji> of <kanji>parents</kanji>. Not quite parents, but kind of, in a pinch anyways. These are your <vocabulary>relatives</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I'll start by consulting elderly relatives.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まずは年配の親類に相談してみます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Actually, President Obama is a distant relative of Koichi.
Context 2-JP: <jp>実は、コウイチとオバマ大とうりょうは遠い親類なんですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He’s a really isolated guy who cut off all contact with his relatives.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼は全親類と縁を切った孤独な男だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>limit</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji>. What? No limit? That means it will never stop! It is <vocabulary>infinite</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Young people have infinite possibilities.
Context 1-JP: <jp>若者には、無限の可能性がある。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Is anything infinite in this world?
Context 2-JP: <jp>この世に無限なものなんてある？</jp>
Context 3-EN: The situation looks bright at the moment, but the demand won’t increase indefinitely, right?
Context 3-JP: <jp>今は絶好調のように思えるが、需要は無限には増加しないだろう？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>Buddha</kanji> <kanji>priest</kanji> is a <vocabulary>Buddhist Priest</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That Buddhist priest will reach the age of ninety-nine in one month.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの仏僧は、あと一ヶ月で九十九才に達します。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi's pun was so lame that the Buddhist priest looked like a deer in headlights.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチのダジャレがつまらなさすぎて、仏僧ははとがまめ鉄っぽうを食ったような顔をしていた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The witch set even the Buddhist priest’s heart on fire.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その魔女は仏僧の心をも燃え上がらせた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>imitation</kanji> <kanji>model</kanji> is obviously not the real thing. It's (usually) a <vocabulary>plastic model</vocabulary> or just a <vocabulary>model</vocabulary> figure or something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My grandfather started his business out as a small one person plastic model retail shop.
Context 1-JP: <jp>祖父は、最初は従業員一人の小売模型店からこのビジネスを始めました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>place</kanji> where something <kanji>belong</kanji>s is where it is attached. It's where it's <vocabulary>attached to</vocabulary>. It <vocabulary>belong(s) to</vocabulary> that place.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: You should turn in doctor’s notes for sick days to your own department.
Context 1-JP: <jp>所属部署に病欠のための診断書を提出しておいた方がいいよ。</jp>

Meaning: To See Through,To Get To The Bottom Of
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>極める</jp> is "to carry to extremes." If you carry something to the extremes (aka the end), and then you <kanji>see</kanji> it to the extremes while doing it, you're going <vocabulary>to see through</vocabulary> whatever you're doing.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from the words <jp>見</jp>る and <jp>極める</jp> put together. See through this word and learn it.
Context 1-EN: I want to see the truth with my own eyes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分のこの目で真実を見極めたいんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>resist</kanji> is something he <vocabulary>generally</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>usually</vocabulary> does... at least <vocabulary>in most cases</vocabulary>. He's usually a big resistor, that one.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I think most foreigners usually don’t like natto and I’m one of them.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大抵の外国人は納豆が苦手かと思いますが、私もその一人です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>search</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to search for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to seek</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're searching all around for a "<reading>sagger</reading>" (<jp>さが</jp>) on your body. This is a flap of skin that is sagging on your body really far, and you probably should get it removed.
Context 1-EN: I’m searching for my grandmother. She has Alzheimer's and hasn’t come home since yesterday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>祖母を捜しているんです。アルツハイマーがあって、昨日から家に帰ってないんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Full</kanji> of <kanji>member</kanji>s, so sorry, no more room. This place is a <vocabulary>full house</vocabulary>. That means there is <vocabulary>no vacancy</vocabulary> here.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I hate that I have to stand in a packed train until I arrive at Shinjuku station every morning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎朝、新宿駅に着くまで、満員電車の中に立っていなくてはいけないのが苦痛です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>comrade</kanji> who's <kanji>behind</kanji> you is your <vocabulary>junior</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for <jp>後</jp> is the long <jp>こう</jp> reading, though. Just think of your junior being <reading><jp>こう</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: I’ll take care of you, no matter what happens because you’re my favorite underclassmen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お前は俺のお気に入りの後輩だから、どんなことがあってもちゃんと面倒みてやるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Do you remember <jp>関西</jp>, which is the Kansai region of Japan? Well, they have their own <kanji>dialect</kanji>, and it is <vocabulary>Kansai Dialect</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the vocab <jp>関西</jp>'s reading and the kanji reading of <jp>弁</jp>, combined.
Context 1-EN: I heard poop is called baba in Kansai dialect.
Context 1-JP: <jp>関西弁で、ウンチのことをババというらしいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's really scary when people complain in Kansai dialect, isn't it?
Context 2-JP: <jp>関西弁で文句を言われると、かなりこわいよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He said things to me like, “I hate you” and “go home” and it sounds awful, doesn’t it? But I actually thought it was pretty cool because he said it all using Kansai dialect. It was really hot.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼、私に向かって、「お前のこと嫌いやねん」とか「帰れや」とか言ったのよ。ひどいでしょ？でもさ、実は関西弁で言われたもんだから、ちょっと格好いいなんて思っちゃったんだよね。何か、すごいセクシーだったの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you can see <kanji>all</kanji> the <kanji>scene</kanji> you have a <vocabulary>complete view</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I was expecting a breathtaking panorama of Mt. Fuji, but the reality of it was pretty pathetic.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は息を飲むような富士の全景を期待していたが、実際はかなりお粗末なものだった。</jp>

Meaning: To Bring Up,To Raise,To Bring Something Up,To Raise Something
Meaning Mnemonic: This is similar to <jp>育つ</jp>, except now you're doing the raising of someone. This word means <vocabulary>to bring up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary>. You can remember this because of the <jp>てる</jp>. Your version of bringing a child up involves <reading>tear</reading>ing (<jp>てる</jp>) all their clothes to make them look poor so they can get the cheaper lunch at school. You're rich because of all the tax breaks you get from all the children you're raising, but you could always use more money to fuel your StarCraft addiction (we've all been there).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>育つ</jp>. So long as you know that one, you know how to read this one as well.
Context 1-EN: Viet and Koichi love growing vegetables in their office.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトとコウイチは、オフィスで野さいを育てるのが大好きです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Could you raise this puppy instead? I would love to do it, but I need to relocate to Neptune next month.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この子犬をわたしの代わりに育ててくれませんか。わたしが育てたいんですが、来月から海王星に転きんになってしまったんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What did you raise as a class when you were in elementary school? Our class was raising tadpoles, hamsters, and eggplants, but all of the hamsters ran away and got eaten by cats.
Context 3-JP: <jp>小学校の時、クラスで何を育ててた？うちのクラスはおたまじゃくしとハムスターとなすを育ててたんだけど、ハムスターはみんな逃げてねこに食べられちゃった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: In the <kanji>shadow</kanji>s you still <kanji>echo</kanji>. Your echo leaves the shadows and hits people, creating an <vocabulary>influence</vocabulary> on them. You're like the shadow person pulling the strings, making things do what you want... influencing them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: You should consider that working extra hours may have a negative influence on your health.
Context 1-JP: <jp>残業は健康に悪影響を及ぼす可能性があるということを考えた方がいいですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>approximation</kanji> is when I say something <vocabulary>in general</vocabulary>. I'm <vocabulary>mainly</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>mostly</vocabulary> telling everything.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>cut</kanji> and <kanji>take</kanji> something, you are going to cut it right off. So, this verb is <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>切る</jp> and <jp>取る</jp>. So, know those words separately and you can combine them into this word.

Context 2-EN: Today, I'll teach your how to cut a star out of a piece of paper.

Context 3-EN: Why do you bother clipping coupons from newspapers if you never use them?
Context 3-JP: <jp>使わないのにどうしていちいち新聞から割引券を切り取るのさ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>period of time</kanji> <kanji>limit</kanji> is nothing more than a <vocabulary>period</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>term</vocabulary> of time. There's a limit there, and that limit is defined by the <vocabulary>term</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I have to leave Japan next month because my visa will expire.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビザの期限が切れるので、来月日本を出なくてはいけません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What exactly are your <kanji>parent</kanji> <kanji>relatives</kanji>? Your own <vocabulary>relatives</vocabulary>! You're all <vocabulary>kin</vocabulary>, after all.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 2-JP: <jp>あなたの親戚はiPadでは何のブラウザを使っていますか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I barely managed to pick up my relative at the airport.
Context 3-JP: <jp>なんとか飛行場で親戚を拾うことができました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Sleepy</kanji> <kanji>sleep</kanji> <kanji>medicine</kanji> is <vocabulary>sleeping pills</vocabulary>. Don't take too many or you might get addicted.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Context 1-JP: <jp>さっき飲んだ睡眠薬のせいで、手足が思うように動かないんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>float</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to float</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji. <jp>う</jp>!
Context 1-EN: Watermelons and pumpkins float in water.
Context 1-JP: <jp>スイカも南瓜も水に浮く。</jp>

Meaning: Number Of Sheets,Number Of Flat Objects
Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>flat object</kanji>s. You have a <kanji>number</kanji> of them. These flat objects are flat things, right? Flat things like sheets of paper, perhaps (or other sheets of things). So, this word is <vocabulary>number of sheets</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Could you count the number of the origami paper?

Context 2-EN: Can you guess how many credit cards Koichi has in his wallet at the moment?
Context 2-JP: <jp>今コウイチのさいふの中にあるクレジットカードの枚数を当ててみてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m not exactly sure how many stickers I’m going to order yet, but I think it will be at least one hundred.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ステッカーの枚数については、何枚くらい注文できるかはまだはっきり分かりませんが、少なくとも百枚にはなると思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you associate with a certain <kanji>lineage</kanji>, you trace yourself back with a group of people. This group of people is your <vocabulary>tribe</vocabulary>, your <vocabulary>lineage</vocabulary>, your <vocabulary>group</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because this word gets stuck onto other things to describe tribes and groups.
Context 1-EN: Somehow I’m attracted to Akihabara style, nerdy men.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私、アキバ系のオタッキーな男性に何故か魅力を感じるんだよね。</jp>

Meaning: First Ten Days Of The Month,Beginning Of Month,Beginning Of The Month
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>above</kanji> <kanji>time of the month</kanji> Is the top part of the month. The <vocabulary>first ten days of the month</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>beginning of the month</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The Japan Meteorological Agency says the rainy season will start at the beginning of June.
Context 1-JP: <jp>気象庁は六月上旬に梅雨が始まると言っている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Explode</kanji> with <kanji>laugh</kanji>s, what <vocabulary>explosive laughter</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for <jp>笑</jp> with the kanji, here's a mnemonic. Who has come down with explosive laughter? It's the <reading>sho</reading>gun (<jp>しょう</jp>)! The shogun just can't stop laughing.
Context 1-EN: Do you have any good April fool’s ideas to make our parents explode with laughter?
Context 1-JP: <jp>母さんと父さんを爆笑させるような、何かいいエイプリルフールの案はある？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the same as the kanji <jp>豊</jp>, making it <vocabulary>plentiful</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>rich</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wealthy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Don't worry, these resources are <vocabulary>plentiful</vocabulary>. <reading>You ta</reading>ke (<jp>ゆた</jp>) what you want.
Context 1-EN: Compared to 80 years ago, Japan has become really wealthy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>80年前と比べると、日本は本当に豊かになりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Kyushu is a place that's rich in nature.
Context 2-JP: <jp>九州は自然が豊かな所です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Reading books will enrich your mind.
Context 3-JP: <jp>本を読むと心が豊かになりますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Ah yes, <kanji>wet</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> must be wet clothes-NOT! This used to mean "wet clothes" a long, long time ago, but these days it's used for <vocabulary>false accusations</vocabulary>. Think of it this way: if you make false, baseless accusations, it's like you're dumping water all over someone for no reason.
Reading Mnemonic: This word is made up of the reading from <jp>濡れる</jp> and the rendaku version of the <jp>きぬ</jp> reading of <jp>衣</jp>. You learned this reading in the <jp>衣</jp> vocabulary, but here's a mnemonic to remember it. Imagine someone's dumped water on you and you're all wet. You might say "<reading>gi</reading>ve <reading>new</reading> (<jp>ぎぬ</jp>) clothes to me!"
Context 1-EN: Are you saying I farted? That's a baseless accusation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>僕がおならしたって？そんなの濡れ衣だよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi accused me of something he was responsible for.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチに濡れ衣を被せられた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The only one who believed that it was a false accusation was my dog.
Context 3-JP: <jp>濡れ衣だったと信じてくれたのは、飼い犬だけだった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something you <kanji>wear</kanji>, and <kanji>wear</kanji> again, is something you <vocabulary>steadily</vocabulary> wear. You do it so often, it's reliable. Also, if you wear something this much it's steadily wearing away too.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses on'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That office worker always got tasks done steadily.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その会社員は、いつも着々と仕事をこなしていた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It seems like you're making steady progress on the project.
Context 2-JP: <jp>プロジェクトは着々進んでいるようだね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The arrangements for it have been moving along steadily.
Context 3-JP: <jp>手はずは着々と整っていますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has <jp>曜日</jp> in it. But what day of the week is it? The "<kanji>moon</kanji>" day of the week is <vocabulary>monday</vocabulary>. Why? Because "Moon" is pretty much just "Mon," right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word <jp>曜日</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: On Monday, I forgot to turn off the bath, it overflowed, and our place was flooded.
Context 1-JP: <jp>月曜日に、お風ろの水を止めるのを忘れてて、湯船からあふれて、家中水びたしになってしまったんだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please pay the examination fee through your bank by Monday.
Context 2-JP: <jp>受験料は、月曜日までにふりこんでください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: On Monday, I would like to watch some fun movies with you, like a steamy romance or blood-curdling horror film. How does that sound?
Context 3-JP: <jp>月曜日、熱々のロマンスとか、ゾッとするホラーみたいな感じの楽しい映画をあなたと一緒に観たいなって思うんだけど、どうかな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you can't <kanji>wait</kanji> to <kanji>oppress</kanji> people when you grow up, you're the kind of person who's prone to inflicting <vocabulary>abuse</vocabulary> on other people. You should try to correct that right away.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Many children who were abused have extremely lowered self esteem.
Context 1-JP: <jp>虐待を受けた子供は、自己評価が非常に低くなることが多い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Include</kanji> your <kanji>idea</kanji>s here, but think about the <vocabulary>implication</vocabulary>s they will result in too, especially considering you're just including them now. They have implications!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It’s difficult for everyone to understand the implied meaning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰にとっても、含意を汲み取るのは難しいことだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>apprehend</kanji> and <kanji>catch</kanji> someone, that leads to an <vocabulary>arrest</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>capture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I was almost arrested by mistake for molestation on the rush hour train.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ラッシュ時の電車内で痴漢行為を働いたとして、危うく誤認逮捕されるところだった。</jp>

Meaning: Way Of Speaking,Speaking Style,Way Of Talking,Talking Style
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>way</kanji> of <kanji>speak</kanji>ing is your <vocabulary>way of speaking</vocabulary> (or it could be your <vocabulary>speaking style</vocabulary>). This is how someone talks. Some people have an interesting speaking style, after all.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>話す</jp> and <jp>方</jp>. By now you should have seen these words separately and should be able to read this word too.

Context 1-JP: <jp>話し方が本当にイライラするのよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi's style of conversation is very cultured, eh?
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチの話し方って、かなりしぶいよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Wow! The way you talk sounds just like a native Japanese person.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うわぁ！君の話し方、まるで母国語が日本語の人みたいだね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen that <jp>準備</jp> is <kanji>preparations</kanji>. This is the verb version, so you get yourself <vocabulary>to prepare</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>準備</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Finish your breakfast before getting ready.
Context 1-JP: <jp>準備する前に先に朝ご飯食べちゃいなさい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>remainder</kanji> of <kanji>oppress</kanji>ion is <vocabulary>cruelty</vocabulary>. Even when you're done oppressing people the <vocabulary>brutality</vocabulary> you caused will linger in their minds and hearts.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This is an extremely brutal crime.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは非常に残虐な犯行です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>limit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to limit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <vocabulary>to limit</vocabulary> things, you have something called a <reading>ca</reading>r (<jp>か</jp>) <reading>guillotine</reading> (<jp>ぎ</jp>) which you drive around limiting everything with.
Context 1-EN: After all, nothing beats Tofugu when it comes to learning Japanese.
Context 1-JP: <jp>やっぱり、日本語の勉強はTofuguに限るよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Make Muddy,To Make Cloudy,To Speak Ambiguously,To Speak Vaguely
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>muddy</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to make muddy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to make cloudy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you want to make muddy, meaning make yourself muddy, you should have your knees go (にご) first. When you have your knees go first the mud splashes all over you but you don't hurt your hands or your butt doing it.
Context 1-EN: At the heart of the problem, the company president was vague.
Context 1-JP: <jp>核心をついた質問に、社長は言葉を濁した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have an idea of the <kanji>concept</kanji> <kanji>beforehand</kanji>, aka you know what's going to happen, or at least you have an idea. This is an <vocabulary>expectation</vocabulary> of what's going to happen next. But don't let your <vocabulary>anticipation</vocabulary> get the better of you!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I can predict the future.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは未来を予想できるんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My prediction that Koichi would be late again today turned out to be completely wrong.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日もコウイチはちこくするであろうというわたしの予想は見事に外れてしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Due to unforeseen circumstances, the ice boat will not be traveling across the lava pool today.
Context 3-JP: <jp>予想外の出来事が生じているため、今日は氷の舟で溶岩のプールを渡ることはできません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: There's a <kanji>riot</kanji> and everything's getting all <kanji>mix</kanji>ed up! Within that, there is of course a ton of <vocabulary>confusion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The culprit escaped in the confusion.
Context 1-JP: <jp>はん人は、混乱にまぎれてにげてしまった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The wildfire brought utter chaos to the town.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その町は、山火事で大混乱となっていた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m afraid that your half-baked policy may cause confusion among the new employees.
Context 3-JP: <jp>申し訳ないけど、そんな中途半端なやり方じゃ新入社員が混乱しちゃう気がします。</jp>

Meaning: To Become Accustomed To,To Get Used To
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>accustomed</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to become accustomed</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: What have you <vocabulary>become accustomed to</vocabulary>? All the <reading>Na</reading>rwhals (<jp>な</jp>) you hang out with. They take some getting used to.
Context 1-EN: Could you bring the hem up for me? I’m not really used to sewing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>裾上げをお願いできますか？自分ではあまり縫い物に慣れてなくて。</jp>

Meaning: To Wring Out,To Squeeze,To Narrow Down
Meaning Mnemonic: You've learned that the kanji <jp>絞</jp> means <kanji>strangle</kanji>. <jp>絞る</jp>, on the other hand, means <vocabulary>to wring out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to squeeze</vocabulary> something like a towel, or <vocabulary>to narrow down</vocabulary> ideas.
Reading Mnemonic: Your friend wants <vocabulary>to wring out</vocabulary> a towel, but before she does so <reading>she bow</reading>s (<jp>しぼ</jp>) to the towel to show her respect for it.
Context 1-EN: Here is the juice I made from wringing out a dust cloth.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ぞうきんを絞って作ったジュースです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Let's narrow down our ideas at the meeting.
Context 2-JP: <jp>会議でアイデアを絞りましょう。</jp>

Meaning: Please Help Me,Please,If You Would Be So Kind
Meaning Mnemonic: This is a tricky word that doesn't really have a good translation. The best ways I've seen it done in terms of getting a meaning across are <vocabulary>please</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>please help me</vocabulary>. When you say this word you're kind of saying "please help me out and I'm relying on you and you're kind of awesome too." Anyways, <vocabulary>please</vocabulary> is a pretty good way to do it. So, when you see this word you'll notice it has the <kanji>request</kanji> kanji in it. You can guess you're requesting something. What is that thing? It's help (<vocabulary>please help me</vocabulary>) and you're asking very nicely too (<vocabulary>please</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: You ask for help by saying <vocabulary>please help me</vocabulary>, and that person does try to help you... but the amount they do for you is so <reading>neg</reading>ligible that it hardly does anything to help you at all. Please try to help me again, this time better?
Context 1-EN: Please God! I want to be fluent in Japanese.
Context 1-JP: <jp>神様、お願いします！日本語が上手くなりたいんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you aren't an active member, please join!
Context 2-JP: <jp>ゆうれい会員でもかまわないので、お願いします。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Could I have an aisle seat, please? I hate looking out the window.
Context 3-JP: <jp>通路側の席をお願いします。窓から外の景色を眺めるのが嫌いなんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>care</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to care about</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you care a lot about grammar? I don't care, unless it has to do with <reading>comma</reading>s (<jp>かま</jp>). Then I do flip out.
Context 1-EN: "This one will cost about a million yen more." "I still don’t mind. I’ll take it."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「こちらの品は百万円ほどお高くなります。」「それでも構わないよ。それを頂くよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Riot</kanji> and <kanji>violence</kanji>. That sounds terrible! That sounds like a place full of violence, because rioting is <vocabulary>violent</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>violence</vocabulary> is violent too!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I hate violent people!
Context 1-JP: <jp>乱暴なやつは大きらいだ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: That man got arrested for assaulting a girl.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その男は少女に乱暴したつみでたいほされた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Dad, my friend says I’m violent." "So what? Who cares what he thinks? Just beat the stupid guy up!"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「父さん、友達が僕のこと、乱暴だって言うんだ。」「それがどうした。そんな奴の言うことなんかどうでもいいよ。そんな馬鹿たれ、こてんぱにしてやれ！」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I am <kanji>full</kanji> and <kanji>sufficient</kanji>. I am <vocabulary>satisfied</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that the reading for <jp>足</jp> in this one is <jp>ぞく</jp> because of that pesky rendaku.
Context 1-EN: My business is doing well so I finally feel satisfied.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビジネスが順調なので、ようやく満足しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word covers all types of <vocabulary>sword</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>sabre</vocabulary>s, though it was originally used mostly for <vocabulary>double-edged sword</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: How much is this sword?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この剣いくらですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We decided to fight with swords at two in the morning.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私達は午前二時に剣で戦うことにした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was interested in the subject, so I took careful notes during the lecture on the history of sabres.
Context 3-JP: <jp>興味があったので、剣の歴史の講義のノートは念入りに取りました。</jp>

Meaning: To Chase,To Pursue,To Stalk,To Run After,To Follow
Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>追う</jp> is "to follow." So, you're following something or someone, or something similar. Just think of the <jp>かける</jp> as you being all "cocky" about it. You're not just following this person, you're chasing them, with the intent to catch them. So, this word is <vocabulary>to chase</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to pursue</vocabulary>. Scary!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>追う</jp> as well as the kanji reading you learned too.
Context 1-EN: Ms. Tanaka likes Mr. Yamada a lot, so she chases him every day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>田中さんは山田さんのことが大すきで、毎日追いかけています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: OMG! Koichi left for Japan without his passport. Can you run after him and give him this passport?
Context 2-JP: <jp>大へんだ！コウイチったらパスポートを持たずに日本へ出発してしまったよ。今すぐ追いかけてこのパスポートをわたしてあげてくれない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I saw Fugu following a pod of killer whales.
Context 3-JP: <jp>シャチの群れを追いかけてるフグを見たよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fragrance</kanji> of <kanji>water</kanji> is a <vocabulary>perfume</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Even though wearing perfume is banned at school, that guy always wears a fragrant perfume and he told the teachers that it was his natural armpit smell.
Context 1-JP: <jp>学校では香水が禁止されているにもかかわらず、その男子生徒はいつも甘い香りの香水を付けていて、教師たちには自然な脇の臭いだと言っていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>belong</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to belong to</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. This kanji is going <vocabulary>to belong to</vocabulary> you.
Context 1-EN: Whose group were you in when you were in grade four?
Context 1-JP: <jp>四年生の時は誰のグループに属していたの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>echo</kanji> so the verb is <vocabulary>to echo</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <reading>He be</reading> (<jp>ひび</jp>) echoing... <reading>He be</reading> (<jp>ひび</jp>) echoing... <reading>He be</reading> (<jp>ひび</jp>) echoing... <reading>He be</reading> (<jp>ひび</jp>) echoing... <reading>He be</reading> (<jp>ひび</jp>) echoing...
Context 1-EN: To win a major contract, we’ll need a great business proposition that resonates in our customers’ hearts.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大きな契約を勝ち取るには、顧客の心に響く素晴らしい提案書が必要だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Someone who's of the <kanji>woman</kanji> <kanji>gender</kanji> is probably going to be <vocabulary>female</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: In recent years, there's been a gradual increase in the number of female politicians in Japan as well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>近年、日本でも女性のせいじ家の数が少しずつふえています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This woman can squeeze onigiri very firmly with both hands, so Tofugu should hire her.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この女性はりょう手でしっかりオニギリをにぎれるので、トーフグはかの女をやとうべきだと思うんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I am not a girl. I’m a lady.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は女の子なんかじゃないよ。私はれっきとした女性だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>wealth</kanji> <kanji>clan</kanji> is a group of people who do whatever they can to get their money. These are the <vocabulary>plutocrats</vocabulary> of the world, but you can also call them <vocabulary>financial clique</vocabulary> or even the <vocabulary>Zaibatsu</vocabulary> (sometimes brought up in English language history / economic books regarding Japan).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He is the heir of this zaibatsu.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼はこの財閥のあと取りです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu will reign over the business world in Japan as a zaibatsu sooner or later.
Context 2-JP: <jp>おそかれ早かれ、Tofuguは財閥として日本のビジネス界に君りんするでしょう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In Japan, there were several financial cliques prior to World War II, including Mitsui Zaibatsu, Mitsubishi Zaibatsu, Sumitomo Zaibatsu and Yasuda Zaibatsu.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本には、第二次世界大戦前に三井財閥、三菱財閥、住友財閥、安田財閥などの財閥がありました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
Bind and set up everything so it is fairly fine and alright. This word is used like this:

"That's fine, no more" 結構です "It's fairly big" 結構大きい "It's alright" 結構です

etc.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>けつ</jp> shortens to <jp>けっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: "Would you like anything else today?" "No, that’s alright."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「今日は他には何か、ございませんか？」「いいえ。それだけで結構です。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word is a single kanji with hiragana attached, though there is no specific clue as to what type of word it is. That means you can usually guess it's a noun, adverb or na-adjective (in this case it's a noun / adverb). The meaning of this word is pretty much the same as the kanji, though, making it fairly easy. The kanji meaning for 少 is few, and the meaning of the vocab form is a little or a few.
Reading Mnemonic: Did you know that this word created an English word you probably already know? Have you ever heard someone say "just a skosh"? That's 少し! Hopefully you know this English word and therefore know this Japanese word as well.
Context 1-EN: There is only little milk.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ぎゅうにゅうは、少ししかありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are only a few left.
Context 3-EN: His proposal was a little vague.
Context 3-JP: <jp>かれのプロポーズは少しあいまいだった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hit</kanji> so the vocab is <vocabulary>to hit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pound</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you haven't learned yet, but never fear! A mnemonic is here:

Something is coming toward your face. It's black and spiky and it's definitely going to hit you right in the eye. It's an uni (う). Have you ever seen one of those things before? You definitely aren't going to be happy with whoever is trying to hit you with an uni.
Context 1-EN: Cabrera hit a home run.
Context 1-JP: <jp>カブレラがホームランを打ちました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My teacher is the world's fastest keyboard typer.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ぼくの先生は、キーボードを打つのが世かいで一ばんはやい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My mom went crazy and pounded my butt with a carrot.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ママは狂って、人参で僕のおしりを何度もひどく打った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>incur</kanji> <kanji>damage</kanji> you are doing <vocabulary>damage</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>harm</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Tofugu suffered a great loss from an office burglary.
Context 1-JP: <jp>オフィスにどろぼうが入ってしまい、トーフグは大きな被害を受けました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This town wasn't damaged by the wildfire.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この町は、山火事の被害は受けませんでした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We are going to send our profits from today's business to the area with flood damage.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私達は、洪水の被害があった地域に、今日の利益を募金としてお送りします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>obtain</kanji> something you need to keep it safe, so you decide <vocabulary>to store</vocabulary> it somewhere. Then you can always go back and look at the thing you managed <vocabulary>to achieve</vocabulary>,  <vocabulary>to score</vocabulary>, or at least <vocabulary>to finish</vocabulary>, and no one can take it from you.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with 収まる, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case:

You need to store all of the old saws (おさ). You were able to finish and to achieve everything you wanted with them, so it's time to put them away so they'll be safe.
Context 1-EN: I stored the evidence regarding Viet's political crime in the file.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトの政治犯罪に関する証こをファイルに収めました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi scored a landslide victory at this election.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは今回の選挙で圧倒的に勝利を収めた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What should I do to finish the fight?
Context 3-JP: <jp>争いを収めるにはどうすればいいのだろう。</jp>

Meaning: To Anger Someone,To Anger,To Provoke,To Offend Someone
Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>怒る</jp> means "to get angry?" Well this is when someone else gets angry and it's because YOU made them angry. It means "to anger someone."
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned <jp>怒る</jp>, so you should know this one too!
Context 1-EN: You’ll be in trouble after making dad mad.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父さんを怒らせると後が面倒よ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>silver</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is just <vocabulary>silver</vocabulary> (the color).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please repaint this silver like I told you the first time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>初めにお伝えしていたように、これを銀色にぬり直してください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Could you sell Koichi's silver mustache to me, please?
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチの銀色のヒゲをわたしに売ってくれませんか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: My dance partner is that guy in the silver costume. His name is Fugu.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私のダンスの相手は、あの銀色のコスチュームを着たフグって男よ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Time to <kanji>pay</kanji> over your <kanji>drunk</kanji>edness. You try, but you can't pay over drunkedness. You must be super <vocabulary>drunk</vocabulary> to think that.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of <jp>酔う</jp> and <jp>払い</jp>, put together with some small <jp>っ</jp> and a rendaku added in because you're drunk.
Context 1-EN: My heart was pounding while I was hassled by a drunk last night.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨日の夜酔っ払いに絡まれた時、心臓がドキドキしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>power</kanji> of <kanji>violence</kanji> is more <vocabulary>violence</vocabulary>, and it is a <vocabulary>force</vocabulary> to be reckoned with.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi took away my tamagotchi by force.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチに暴力でたまごっちを取られました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I couldn't stand the domestic violence, so I left home.
Context 2-JP: <jp>家庭内暴力にたえかねて、家を出ました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you really think that parents should limit their children's exposure to violent movies and video games?
Context 3-JP: <jp>親は本当に、暴力的な映画やビデオゲームが子供の目に触れる事を制限すべきなのでしょうか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I'm so <kanji>bored</kanji>. On top of my boredom is <jp>くまでも</jp>. If you took this separately, it would mean "even as a bear." So it's like you're saying I'm so <kanji>bored</kanji>, even if I was a bear. If you're so bored that you'd be bored even as a bear, you're going to be bored <vocabulary>to the last</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to the end</vocabulary>. Nothing will please you, you bored bear person.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned <jp>飽きる</jp> so you should be able to read this one too!
Context 1-EN: This is a stubbornly self-centered opinion.
Context 1-JP: <jp>飽くまでも、これは個人的な見解です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>supplement</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to supplement</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: <reading>Oh, gee, now</reading> (<jp>おぎな</jp>) you're going <vocabulary>to supplement</vocabulary> it? That would have been helpful earlier. Might help to say "oh gee now" with a <jp>ぎ</jp> sound instead of "ji" sound out loud, too. This is a tricky reading, won't be learned too easily, so think about it a bit now.
Context 1-EN: To compensate for the empty spot, I joined the bowling game.
Context 1-JP: <jp>欠員を補うために、ボーリングゲームに参加しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have a <kanji>hope</kanji> and you turn it into a verb, you'd think it would be "to hope." But what is really behind a hope? It's a desire or wish, right? That's why this word means <vocabulary>to wish</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to desire</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your one wish that you have is to have a bigger <reading>nose</reading> (<jp>のぞ</jp>). Feel your nose, it's too small. You wish it was two or three inches longer. Of course, if it helps to imagine you want a smaller nose or a nose at all, that's fine too. Just make sure you wish you have something nose-related.
Context 1-EN: Koichi had a strong desire to lick his toenails.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは自分の足のつめをなめたいと強く望んでいた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: These days it seems like you can watch anything you wish on YouTube.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今はYoutubeで何でも望むものが見られていいよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I got a haircut but it just made me look even more childish. I was hoping to look like a stylish 35-year-old woman. Boohoo.
Context 3-JP: <jp>髪切ったんだけど、逆に童顔に磨きがかかっちゃってさあ。年相応のお洒落な三十五歳の女性になることを望んでたのに。。。とほほ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>inside</kanji> <kanji>cause</kanji> is an <vocabulary>internal cause</vocabulary>. Internal causes are usually the nastiest causes, if you ask me.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I was diagnosed with intrinsic asthma.
Context 1-JP: <jp>内因性ぜんそくだとしんだんされました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When a traumatic thing happens, endogenous opioids, which are morphine-like substances, will be secreted.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トラウマになる出来事が起きると、その苦しみを和らげるために、内因性オピオイドというのう内ま薬が分ぴつされます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: For a long time the actual reason I’ve been suffering was a mental disorder.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は長い間内因性精神疾患に悩まされています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You take a <kanji>dose</kanji> of medicine but it gets <kanji>lock</kanji>ed in your throat because it's the kind of <vocabulary>pill</vocabulary> you chew, not swallow! You need to pay attention to which one is which or it won't help at all.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I can’t swallow pills, so I smash and drink them.
Context 1-JP: <jp>錠剤を飲み込むことができないので、砕いて飲んでいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>change</kanji> <kanji>again</kanji>. This is more along the lines of an <vocabulary>alteration</vocabulary>, because you changed once in order to get to where you are, and then you get changed again to become altered, which is why it's an <vocabulary>alteration</vocabulary> (though <vocabulary>change</vocabulary> works too).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My boss told me to alter the business proposal so that it emphasized the mutual benefits more.
Context 1-JP: <jp>上司に、もっとお互いのメリットを強調するような企画書に変更するように言われました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the verb version of the kanji <kanji>superior</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>to surpass</vocabulary>. Someone who is superior is always going to surpass and <vocabulary>to excel</vocabulary> beyond others. That's what makes them so superior in the first place!
Reading Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>今すぐ</jp> means "at once"? Well that's the key <vocabulary>to surpass</vocabulary>ing others. You have to do everything <jp>今</jp>!!!
Context 1-EN: Nobody outstripped Keiko senpai back then.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あのころは、景子先輩より優れている人はだれもいなかったの。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu surpasses the other Japanese learning materials in terms of uniqueness.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグはユニークさにおいて、他の日本語学習教材より優れています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi is excellent at making plastic natto models.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは納豆の模型を作るのに優れている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: And <kanji>again</kanji> it has become <kanji>new</kanji>! It was old, but now it's all nice. This is quite the <vocabulary>renewal</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: They are proposing an updated contract with several alterations, but I’m still reluctant.
Context 1-JP: <jp>先方は、いくつかの修正を伴う契約更新を提案してきているんだが、あまり気が進まないんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>家庭</jp> and <jp>教師</jp>. A "teacher" who only teaches when you're with your "family" is known as a <vocabulary>tutor</vocabulary>. They don't teach you at school, they're a <vocabulary>private teacher</vocabulary> that comes to your home to help you learn.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I work part time as a tutor.
Context 1-JP: <jp>家庭教師のアルバイトをしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: For as long as you can remember, your family and another family has had a bloody <reading>feud</reading> (<jp>ふで</jp>) over this one <vocabulary>writing brush</vocabulary>. Just think of all the people killed over this brush. This feud has to end.
Context 1-EN: Put the cursor over the brush icon and click the left mouse button twice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>筆マークのアイコンの上にカーソルを合わせて、マウスの左のボタンをカチカチッと２回クリックしてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Again</kanji> you have <kanji>life</kanji>! Either this is a <vocabulary>rebirth</vocabulary> of some kind, or you have received <vocabulary>resuscitation</vocabulary> and another shot at life. Whatever it is, you have life again, so that's great!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: She believes that there is hope of rehabilitation for her son.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は自分の息子は更生の見込みがあると信じている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>thin</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to get thin</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you want to get thin, just join the Yankees (や). They run their players around those four bases so much they all get thin quicker than you can throw a ball.
Context 1-EN: It's been a couple years since I started saying, "I want to lose weight."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「痩せたい」と、言い始めてから二年が経ちます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Most stray dogs in my village are skinny.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私の村にいる野良犬のほとんどは痩せていますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When it gets silent and awkward during conversations, I make it a rule to just say, "Have you lost weight lately?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>会話が途切れて気まずくなった時は、とりあえず「最近、痩せた？」と言うことにしている。</jp>

Meaning: To Disappear,To Go Out,To Turn Off
Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen that <jp>消す</jp> is "to extinguish." So, this is another verb version of that. This time, you're not doing the extinguishing, it's just happening. Something is going <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary> on its own. How can you differentiate this from <jp>消す</jp>? Well, <jp>える</jp> allows you to notice how the object disappeared into thin <reading>air</reading> (<jp>える</jp>). You know you didn't do it, so it disappeared on its own, making it <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is different from <jp>消す</jp>, unfortunately, so you can't use that. Just think about how after the object in front of you disappears you use a <reading>key</reading> (<jp>き</jp>) to open an invisible door. That's where everything's disappearing to! You see all your disappeared stuff on the other side of this invisible door which you opened with a magical <reading>key</reading>.
Context 1-EN: WaniKani makes most of my income disappear.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ワニカニにしゅう入の大半が消えます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My eyebrows have worn off from my sweat.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あせでまゆ毛が消えてしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He waved goodbye until she completely disappeared from view.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼は、彼女が視界から完全に消えるまで、さようならと手を振り続けた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. This word means <vocabulary>mark</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You see a beautiful woman in front of you. She shows you a <vocabulary>mark</vocabulary> on a piece of paper. It's a mark that tells you she's Russian (<jp>しるし</jp>)!
Context 1-EN: I like putting a heart mark at the end of letters.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は手紙の最後にハートの印を付けるのが好きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Sell</kanji>, <kanji>sell</kanji>, sell. This is the attitude you need if you want to work in <vocabulary>sales</vocabulary> or do <vocabulary>sales</vocabulary>. You have to work on your <vocabulary>selling</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which means you need to know the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know them both, hurray!
Context 1-EN: Many of the salespeople at our company are taking time off work in August.
Context 1-JP: <jp>我が社の販売員の多くは、八月に休暇を取ります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a <kanji>car</kanji> has <kanji>sky</kanji> in it (and not, say, a bunch of people) it is free to give you a ride. If you see this sign lit up on a taxi feel free to hail it down, it will be able to take you somewhere. It is an <vocabulary>open taxi</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When a taxi is displaying "Open Taxi," there are no customers aboard.
Context 1-JP: <jp>タクシーのひょうじが「空車」となっているときは、おきゃくさんはだれものっていません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm really curious why the parking lots around here are always empty.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この辺りのコインパーキングがいつも空車なのがふしぎでしょうがない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: No empty taxis have passed us.
Context 3-JP: <jp>空車のタクシーが全然通らない。</jp>

Meaning: To Get Burned,To Be Burned,To Burn,To Get Burnt,To Be Burnt
Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen how <jp>燃やす</jp> is to burn something. Now something is just getting burned but you're not doing the actual action yourself. You know this because of the <jp>える</jp> part which refers to the letter "L" which is getting burned. You like L okay because it stands for "love," but others don't like it so they burn it.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word <jp>燃やす</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The castle seemed to be full of the smell of burning wood.
Context 1-JP: <jp>城は燃える木のにおいで充満しているようでした。</jp>

Meaning: To Feel,To Touch,To Touch On,To Refer To,To Mention
Meaning Mnemonic:
触る means "to touch." This means to feel. It's kind of similar but somewhat different and also uses a different reading, making this word very hard in some ways. Just think how it's rare (れる) for you to feel anything at all, but this time you are, so that's nice, I guess.

The word also means to touch on, not in the physical sense, but when you touch on a subject. That's why it also means to refer to or to mention.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is totally different from <jp>触る</jp> so don't let that fool you. In this case, you feel some <reading>fur</reading> (<jp>ふれ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: I felt somebody touch my shoulder and I looked back, but nobody was there.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰かが肩に触れるのを感じて振り返ったが、そこには誰もいなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>decay</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to decay</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to die out</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The entire world would start to die out if there were no cookies (く) left! Can you imagine your life without cookies? The trees and animals would all die too. Because they love cookies. Not just us humans.
Context 1-EN: In the end, I didn’t succeed, never had a girlfriend, and now I’m going to die out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>結局成功もせず、女もできずに朽ちていくはめになった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: There is <kanji>fault</kanji> in your <kanji>hope</kanji>. It breaks, and everything falls apart. You feel massive <vocabulary>disappointment</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>despair</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I'm disappointed that there isn't a lot of whipped cream in this even though I asked for extra.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ホイップクリームたっぷりでって言ったのに、全然たっぷりじゃなくて失望しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That teacher isn't good at speaking English like I thought they'd be, so I'm disappointed.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの先生は、期待していたよりも英語が上手じゃなくて失望しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m really disappointed. I want to wear sleeveless shirts, but my chubby arms bother me a lot. My waist is getting flabby, too. My boyfriend tells me that he likes my pudgy fingers, but it doesn’t make me happy at all, you know?
Context 3-JP: <jp>マジ、自分に超失望中だよ〜。ノースリーブのシャツが着たいんだけど、ポッチャリ二の腕が気になってさ。しかも、腰まわりもたるんできたし。彼氏は私のポッチャリした指が好きだとか言うんだけど、そんなの全然嬉しくないってのさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>flavor</kanji> of an <kanji>idea</kanji>, what is that? Imagine yourself licking an idea to figure out what it tastes like. What do you think you'll be tasting? Probably the <vocabulary>meaning</vocabulary> of said idea.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Look at Koichi's meaningful look!
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチのあの意味あり気なかおを見て。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do you understand what these eyes imply?
Context 2-JP: <jp>この目が何を意味するかは分かりますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I thought you were smarter than that." "Hey what’s that supposed to mean?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「あなたって、もっと賢いと思っていたわ。」「おい、それってどういう意味だよ!?」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>flat objects</kanji> that make up your <kanji>tongue</kanji>. What kind of tongue is made up of two of anything? That's a tongue that's split, that's a <vocabulary>forked tongue</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. That's the case for the first two kanji, but <jp>舌</jp> actually uses the kun'yomi. Not only that, it's read here as <jp>じた</jp>, and not <jp>した</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I'm totally fed up with politicians' duplicitous policies.
Context 1-JP: <jp>政治家達の二枚舌の政さくにはもううんざりだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: He has a forked tongue, so you should be careful.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あいつは二枚舌だから気をつけた方がいいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: True or False Quiz: In order to get the money for a life-sized Hatsune Miku doll, Viet used his forked tongue to cheat Koichi. True or false?
Context 3-JP: <jp>○×クイズ: ビエトは等身大の初音ミク人形を買うお金を儲けるために、二枚舌を使ってコウイチを騙しました。○か×か？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>frustration</kanji>. What do frustrated people do? They tend <vocabulary>to bully</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to pick on</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to tease</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to torment</vocabulary> other people.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Kyoko picks on me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日子ちゃんが私を苛めるの。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My elder sister always sticks up for other children if they're being bullied.
Context 3-JP: <jp>姉は、他の子が苛められていたら、いつも助けてあげるんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>promise</kanji> <kanji>bundle</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>promise</vocabulary> no matter how many you have wrapped up there. One promise is just another promise which is just another promise.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I can't make it because I have an appointment with Koichi on Saturday. How about Sunday?
Context 1-JP: <jp>土よう日は、コウイチとの約束があるからむりなのよね。日よう日はどう？</jp>
Context 2-EN: He chickened out on our suicide pact.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの男には、心中の約束をうら切られたの。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m really sorry to cause so much scheduling trouble. I can free up the fourth. I promise I will never cancel at the last minute like this again.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日程の件で色々と振り回しちゃって本当にごめんね。四日なら都合がつきそうです。次は今回みたいなドタキャンは絶対しないって約束します!</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You are going on your <vocabulary>trip</vocabulary> but you need to bring your little <reading>tabby</reading> (<jp>たび</jp>) cat with you to keep you company. This cat keeps you calm and lets you leave your house, but the airlines won't let you take it on this trip. What to do?
Context 1-EN: My dream is to travel around the world.
Context 1-JP: <jp>世界中を旅するのがゆめです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My wallet and passport were stolen and I missed the plane. It was the worst trip ever.
Context 2-JP: <jp>さいふとパスポートをぬすまれるは、ひ行きに乗りおくれるは、マジで最悪の旅だったよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m already prepared for our trip.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私はもうすっかり旅支度ができているよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>savings</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> is your <vocabulary>savings</vocabulary>. You'd be good to have gold right now in your savings, actually. Melt it down into bars, manngggg.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If your retirement money was paid to you in one lump sum, would you be able to not use it and put it in your savings?
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし退職金が一括で支払われることになったら、それを使い切ってしまわずにちゃんと貯金することができますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It can <kanji>hinder</kanji> a <kanji>child</kanji>, but that's about it. This is a <vocabulary>Japanese Sliding Door</vocabulary>. They're often made of rice paper after all, so, you know, an adult can go through it but a child would be hindered by it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>子</jp> is changed from <jp>し</jp> to <jp>じ</jp>, though, so be careful.
Context 1-EN: I like being woken up by the sunlight filtering gently through shoji screen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>障子から差し込む光で、朝目を覚ますのが好きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>celebrate</kanji>, so when you put a <jp>お</jp> before it to raise it up, it means <vocabulary>congratulations</vocabulary>! When someone has something to celebrate you should congratulate them.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: You have to bring a moving gift.
Context 1-JP: <jp>引っ越しお祝いを渡さなくちゃいけないわね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>gender</kanji> and <kanji>status</kanji> are part of your <vocabulary>personality</vocabulary>. Think about what gender you identify as, and what your current status is (in relationships, residency, employment...). Now think about how all that affects your <vocabulary>personality</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi has a level-headed personality, but he is quick-witted and talks a lot.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは性格はおっとりとしているが、頭の回転が速いだけに、よくしたが回る。</jp>
Context 2-EN: His personality isn't that bad, but it's hard to have deeper conversations.
Context 2-JP: <jp>かれ、性格はそんなに悪くないんだけど、一しょにいても会話が広がらないんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My husband is really easy going, but forgetful and indecisive. I love him but sometimes it drives me nuts.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の旦那さんの性格はのんびり屋で、忘れっぽくて、優柔不断です。彼のことは大好きだけど、たまにイラッとくるんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>float</kanji>ing <kanji>world</kanji> <kanji>painting</kanji> is what you call an <vocabulary>ukiyo-e woodblock print</vocabulary> in Japan. The "floating world" refers to an evanescent world that is impermanent (floating), just as beauty and entertainment is. Back in the day, this type of art was made into woodblock prints and paintings. Unfortunately, we don't have a name for these in English because they're so unique and special, but they come up more than you'd think, so get used to ukiyo-e!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings don't really line up perfectly, but they're close (although mixed in terms of what has what reading). Take a look at the word and break everything down. <jp>浮</jp> takes the kun'yomi <jp>うき</jp> (from <jp>浮く</jp>), <jp>世</jp> also takes the kun'yomi <jp>よ</jp>, and then <jp>絵</jp> takes the on'yomi <jp>え</jp>. Put that all together and you have <jp>うきよえ</jp>! Or if you already know the word ukiyo-e, that works too!
Context 1-EN: Why don’t we talk about the ukiyo-e?
Context 1-JP: <jp>その浮世絵についてお話をしませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you take the <kanji>whole</kanji> and <kanji>join</kanji> it together, you get a good <vocabulary>overall</vocabulary> picture of things.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Overall, WaniKani is a well-built website.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ワニカニは、総合すると良くできたサイトです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Our class got the highest overall score on sports day.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うちのクラスは、体育大会の総合の部でゆう勝しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: America got first place in overall total medals in the Olympics.
Context 3-JP: <jp>オリンピックの総合メダル獲得数では、アメリカが一位だった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: With the <kanji>whole</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji>. Do it <vocabulary>as a whole</vocabulary> instead of as a part, or something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We are concentrating on the overall satisfaction of our customers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>我々は、お客様に総体的に満足して頂けるよう努力しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>stab</kanji> <kanji>nature</kanji> <vocabulary>suddenly</vocabulary>... why you do that? So suddenly, too... Now nature is going to die for sure!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Suddenly the ghost of a cat showed up in my kitchen and started singing the mew-mew song.
Context 1-JP: <jp>突然、猫のお化けが台所に現れて、「ニャーニャーソング」を歌い始めたんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
When you pull yourself back and retreat, you're retiring. At some point in everyone's lives you just can't do it anymore and it's time to take your retirement.

This word focuses on the moment of retiring. It's often used to mean withdrawing from public life, when someone ends their career in a particular field, like when celebrities or pro athletes retire. It can also be used for students who stop extracurricular activities like clubs and sports teams ahead of graduation, often to study for their exams.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 引 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Now that you're retiring, you decide to go and spend your retirement at an inn (いん). Inns are great places to spend your retirement because everything is done for you, and you can just sit back and relax!
Context 1-EN: That celebrity doesn't mention retirement at all.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのタレントは引退を全く口にしない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that boxers tend to gain weight after retiring.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ボクサーは引退後太ることが多いらしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I intend to retire from the Youtube world soon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>そろそろYoutube界を引退しようと考えてるんだ。</jp>
Context 4-EN: Tomorrow a senior member of my basketball team is retiring from the team.
Context 4-JP: <jp>明日はバスケ部の先輩が引退する日だ.</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>猶予</jp> means "extension?" Well you <kanji>wake up</kanji> ready to <kanji>sue</kanji> people when you're told there has been an extension, meaning there was a <vocabulary>suspension of indictment </vocabulary>on your case. What the heck, you woke up ready for this! Now you have to wait to try and sue them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The suspension of indictment punishment was passed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>起訴猶予処分がくだされました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Automatic</kanji> (<jp>自動</jp>) <kanji>sell</kanji> <kanji>sell</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji>. The machine sells things by itself, basically. This is a <vocabulary>vending machine</vocabulary>. There is a shorter version of this, but good to learn the long one first :)
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Remember those, and you'll be fine here.
Context 1-EN: The October twenty-third meeting about the vending machines has been rescheduled for October twenty-fourth due to Koichi’s birthday party.
Context 1-JP: <jp>10月23日の自動販売機に関する会議は、コウイチの誕生日会のため、10月24日に変更されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>surround</kanji>ing <kanji>energy</kanji> in the <kanji>atmosphere</kanji> is what makes up the <vocabulary>atmosphere</vocabulary>. I love it when it takes three kanji to represent what one of the three kanji already represents.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The Tofugu office has a very relaxed atmosphere, doesn't it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグオフィスの雰囲気ってかなりくつろげるって感じだよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Michael is good at enhancing the mood of the Tofugu office.
Context 2-JP: <jp>マイケルは、トーフグオフィスの雰囲気をもり上げるのが上手です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Well, the meeting ended with an awkward atmosphere, didn’t it? I can’t believe our president farted at the end. It was funny, though.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あーっ、なんかさっきの会議、煙たい雰囲気で終わったよね。まさか最後に社長が屁をこくなんてね。まぁ、おもしろかったけどさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>created</kanji> item is <vocabulary>artificial</vocabulary>, not "real."
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The diplomat was stabbed by Android No.18.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その外交官は人造人間十八号に刺された。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

A beast... what do you think of when you think of a beast? How about a thing (物, もの) full of fur (毛, け), aka a けもの (fur thing)? A beast is a fur thing, and in Japanese that's けもの. Punnnns.
Context 1-EN: That guy has eyes like a beast. He’s scary.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの男の人、獣のような目をしていて、恐いわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>obey</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to obey</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

I am going to obey you. I think your order is a bit of shit (したが), I'll do it and obey you.

(Little side note, did you know が in the middle of a sentence can mean "but" in Japanese? Think of it as that meaning here.)
Context 1-EN: What do you think what would happen if I didn’t obey his orders?
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし彼の命令に従わなければ、どうなると思う？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, presumably because it's normally attached onto other numbers to signify how many hundred millions of ____ there are.
Context 1-EN: We sold five hundred million yen worth of this reach toothbrush this year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このおく歯までしっかりとどく歯ブラシで、今年は五億円を売り上げました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I really can't believe that little kid has gotten so big and now earns three hundred million dollars every year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あんなに小さかった子がこんなに大きくなって、今や毎年三億ドルをかせぐ大物になっているなんて、本当にしんじられないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Please keep all the receipts from your business trip. You will be reimbursed for your business expenses later, as long as they’re under two hundred million yen.
Context 3-JP: <jp>出張の領収書は全部とっておいてください。経費は二億円までなら後で精算されますので。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen the word <jp>消す</jp>, I hope. This comes from that. You're extinguishing something with <jp>ゴム</jp>. <jp>ゴム</jp> is a word for either gummy or rubbery things. So, this is a gummy thing that extinguishes something. This is an <vocabulary>eraser</vocabulary> that extinguishes pencil markings.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>消す</jp>, so make sure you know that word so you can read this one!
Context 1-EN: I miss Japanese erasers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本の消しゴムがこいしいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The Tofugu team got one hundred pencils with rubbers on the end for Koichi's birthday present.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグチームは、コウイチのたん生日に、消しゴム付きのえんぴつを百本分プレゼントしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I could give you a chance to apologize to me, Koichi." "For what, Viet? For letting you throw me out of Tofugu office?" "It only happened because you stole my eraser! I need an apology!"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「コウイチ、お前に謝るチャンスをあげてもいいよ。」「何に謝れっていうんだよ、ビエト？ お前が俺をトーフグのオフィスから追放したことに対して謝れってか？」「そもそもお前が俺の消しゴムを盗んだからそうなったんだろ？いいから謝れよ！」</jp>

Meaning: To Get Torn,To Get Broken,To Get Ripped
Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>破る</jp> is "to tear" or "to rip," then this is <vocabulary>to get torn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get broken</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get ripped</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>破る</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Why do my pants always start wearing out in the butt area first?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ズボンのお尻の部分がいつも最初に破れるんだけど、どうしてだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>恥</jp> is a "disgrace." If you <jp>知らず</jp> then you don't know something. In this case, you don't know disgrace, and a person who doesn't know disgrace is a <vocabulary>shameless person</vocabulary>, because they don't care what disgraces them and what doesn't.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>恥</jp> and <jp>知る</jp> put together.
