Context 1-EN: My brother is such a shameless liar. He told me he had no idea what happened, but he was the one who ate all my bacon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの俺の兄貴は恥知らずの嘘つきだ。何の事だかサッパリ分からないなんて言ってたくせに、俺のベーコンを平らげたのはアイツだったんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Again</kanji> you <kanji>build</kanji> it. This is <vocabulary>rebuilding</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just don't forget that extra <jp>い</jp>!
Context 1-EN: To rehabilitate his almost-bankrupt company, he worked longer hours than he was supposed to every day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>潰れかかった会社を再建するまで、彼は毎日規定よりも長い時間働いた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>教育</jp> means "education?" Well, the <jp>育</jp> here is referring to the education word, but this time it's a <kanji>body</kanji> education. What do you call the body education at school? <vocabulary>Physical education</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>PE</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I hated that time in elementary school when we had to do long-distance running in gym.
Context 1-JP: <jp>小学校の時、体育のマラソンが大きらいでした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Before the next PE class, please clip your fingernails.
Context 2-JP: <jp>次の体育のじゅ業の前に、つめを切ってください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Do you want to play volleyball with us on Physical Education Day?" "Oh, it’s a national holiday, right? Isn’t it October 10th or something?" "Yes, it’s a holiday, but is not October 10th anymore. Now it’s the second Monday of October because of the Happy Monday system."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「体育の日に、一緒にバレーボールしない？」「ああ、確か祝日だったよね。十月十日とかだっけ？」「そうそう。祝日。でも、もう十月十日じゃないよ。ハッピー・マンデー制度ができてから、十月の第二月曜日になったんだよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Alone</kanji> I <kanji>stand</kanji>. I have <vocabulary>independence</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If you say not many people who left the company and went independent succeeded, show me the data, their plans, and how they failed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>会社を辞めて独立した人で成功した人は多くないって言うなら、そのデータやその人たちの計画、そしてどうしてそれが失敗したのかを示してくださいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with hiragana that ends in an <jp>い</jp>, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>envy</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>envious</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 羨む, but here's a reminder just in case:

Those uranium Yankees (うらや) are making you more envious and jealous by the day. They're the new Yankees team that was manufactured in a lab and fed uranium. Their skills are unparalleled because of their metallic strength. Go ahead and feel envious, they'll definitely be #1 this year.
Context 1-EN: I'm jealous of people who can speak Japanese fluently.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本語がペラペラと話せる人が羨ましい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm envious of you for being successful in business and looking good in sunglasses.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビジネスで成功した上に、サングラスが似合うなんて、私はあなたが羨ましいですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If I told my little sister that I got a boyfriend I think she would be jealous.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私に彼氏ができたって言ったら、妹が羨ましがると思うの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>distinction</kanji> <kanji>finger</kanji> is the finger you use to point at people to distinguish them from other people. This is your <vocabulary>pointer finger</vocabulary>... your <vocabulary>index finger</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are all the kun'yomi readings of everything. The word <jp>人</jp>, the word <jp>差す</jp>, and the word <jp>指</jp>. Take your time with this one, it's kind of weird.
Context 1-EN: I cut my index finger when I tripped over the electrical cords.
Context 1-JP: <jp>電気コードに躓いた時に、人差し指を切っちゃったんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Although this has a <jp>い</jp> on the end it's tricky and not an adjective. The kanji is <kanji>fortune</kanji>, and the vocab word is <vocabulary>fortune telling</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: I'm going to do some <vocabulary>fortune telling</vocabulary> on you... hmmm... I see... ohhhh... Looks like you'll be living on <reading>Uranu</reading>s (<jp>うらな</jp>) in your near future, that will be $50. What a dumb fortune telling for $50, you definitely won't be living there, unless he meant your butt, then maybe.
Context 1-EN: According to the stars, Fugu and I aren’t supposed to have so much chemistry between us.
Context 1-JP: <jp>星占いによると、フグと私ってあまり相性が良くないみたいなんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I'm going to <kanji> chastise</kanji> you about this <kanji>theory</kanji>. When I do this, this is a <vocabulary>debate</vocabulary>. Doesn't it feel like you're being chastised when people are debating with you sometimes, especially with your own theories? I think so.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I participated in the discussion about salary cuts and the reduction of pensions.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は給与削減と年金減額に関する討論に加わった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you want to know <kanji>what</kanji> the <kanji>circumstances</kanji> are around you, you have to ask <vocabulary>why</vocabulary>. Why do things happen around you? Asking why is very important if you want to understand the world.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this is an exception. The reading for 何 is just the first な from なに. You can remember the second part this way:

No one knows quite how or why that big zeppelin (ぜ) crashed in the 1930s. People are still asking today and no one has any answers. We have to keep asking until we get some.
Context 1-EN: How do you think you’ll get your revenge?
Context 1-JP: <jp>何故復讐しようと思ったんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>judge</kanji> to <kanji>cut off</kanji> your head. That is my <vocabulary>judgement</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My mom always told me not to judge people by their appearance, but she divorced my father just because he went bald.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の母はいつも人を見た目で判断してはいけないと言っていたのに、父が禿げたことだけを理由に父と離婚しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>攻撃</jp> is an <kanji>attack</kanji>. Make that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know <jp>攻撃</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: "Koichi! There’s a pride of raging lions charging toward our town! They are going to attack us very soon. What do we do?" "Don’t worry. Leave it to me."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「コウイチ！怒り狂ったライオンの群れが俺たちの町に向かって突撃してくるよ。俺たち、もうすぐ攻撃されちまうよ。どうしたらいいんだ？」「心配するな。俺に任せとけ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>主</jp> means <kanji>main</kanji> so when you add <jp>に</jp> it becomes the adverb <vocabulary>mainly</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You mainly spend your time talking to your master Moe. But you mainly address him like, "Oh Moe The Great!" (おも). That's because he's above you. Imagine yourself saying "OH MOE THE GREAT!" as you walk into his room, bowing low.
Context 1-EN: I’m mainly studying Japanese.
Context 1-JP: <jp>主に日本ごをべんきょうしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Primarily red and white cars are sold in Portland.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ポートランドでは、赤い車と白い車が主にうれています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He is a researcher who is mainly interested in bananas.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼は研究者で、主にバナナに興味があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: First we have a katakana word, so it's safe to assume that it's a loan word. Like many loan words, it comes from English. Say it out loud and what do you have? That's right, "table". Then comes the particle <jp>の</jp>, which joins two nouns together. Finally we have <jp>上</jp>, which you learned means "up" or "above". Put all of these pieces together and we have a phrase meaning <vocabulary>on the table</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>tabletop</vocabulary>!
Reading: <reading><jp>てーぶるのうえ</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>テーブルのうえ</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: てーぶるのうえ,テーブルのうえ
Reading Mnemonic: In this phrase, <jp>上</jp> is a standalone word, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary. Easy to stay on top of that one, right?
Context 1-EN: The book is on the table.
Context 1-JP: <jp>本はテーブルの上にあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please put three glasses on the table.
Context 2-JP: <jp>テーブルの上にグラスを三つおいてください。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>さっき、テーブルの上をきれいにしたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
Your energy is ... well ... different. That's the nice way to put it. You're crazy, actually.

WARNING: We're teaching you this word because it's used quite a bit still (especially online) and we want you to be able to understand it if you see it. But please keep in mind that this is considered to be a discriminatory word against people with mental illnesses, so we strongly recommend you do not use or direct this word toward anyone. Think of it like a really inappropriate swear word that makes you really uncool if you say it. Please!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>気</jp> plus <jp>違い</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Dancing around in a snow storm in nothing but your underpants is just too crazy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この吹雪の中、パンツ一丁で踊るなんて、気違いにも程がある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>circumference</kanji> is <vocabulary>one time around</vocabulary>. How many times will you go around the moon? Just <jp>一周</jp>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the <jp>いち</jp> becomes <jp>いっ</jp> as it often does when being used in a counter (<jp>一階</jp>, <jp>一回</jp>, etc.).
Context 1-EN: Koichi passed ten runners on the final lap.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、最後の一周で十人のランナーをゴボウぬきした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi can run one lap of the track in three to four minutes.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチはグラウンド一周を三分台で走ります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The Tofugu team is going to make a trip around the world, so the office will be closed for about a year.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トーフグチームは世界一周旅行に出かけるので、オフィスは約一年間不在となります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>ultra</kanji> or <kanji>super</kanji> so the verb version is what happens when you do something ultra or super much. You start <vocabulary>to exceed</vocabulary> the amount you were meant to do it. If you ultra drive a car, you exceed the speed limit. If you ultra study, you exceed your brain capacity. Get it?
Reading Mnemonic: Who likes <vocabulary>to exceed</vocabulary> everything? Your <reading><jp>子</jp></reading> (<jp>こ</jp>)! Or you, when you were a <jp>子</jp>. No bedtimes, parents, or other limitations could stop you! You were able to go over them all!
Context 1-EN: He’s not really the kind of person who talks about their own feelings, so he hid that he was excessively obsessed with me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼はあまり自分の気持ちを言葉で表さない人なので、度を超す程私に執着していることを隠していました。</jp>

Meaning: Under The Bed,Below The Bed,Beneath The Bed
Meaning Mnemonic: This starts with another katakana word, so you can assume that it's a loan word. This one also comes from English. Can you figure out what it means? That's right, "bed". Then comes the particle <jp>の</jp>, which joins two nouns together. Finally, we have <jp>下</jp>, which you learned means "down" or "below". Put these elements together and you get <vocabulary>below the bed</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>under the bed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>beneath the bed</vocabulary>. What's under your bed?
Reading: <reading><jp>べっどのした</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>ベッドのした</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: べっどのした,ベッドのした
Reading Mnemonic: <jp>下</jp> is a standalone word here, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.
Context 1-EN: There are 2000 manga under my bed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ベッドの下には2000さつのマンガがある。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You never clean under your bed, do you?
Context 2-JP: <jp>ベッドの下はまったくそうじしないでしょう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'm going to hide under the bed and never come out.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ベッドの下にかくれてぜんぜん出てこない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>meet</kanji> for <kanji>cooperation</kanji>, you're coming together to help each other. One form of this is when people form <vocabulary>union</vocabulary>s. They're all cooperating and coming together to help each other and themselves.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: All the money my son worked so hard to slowly save up was used to pay his union membership fees.
Context 1-JP: <jp>息子が折角コツコツためたお金は、協会ひの支はらいに消えてしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I have to attend an organization meeting tomorrow, so please wake me up at six.
Context 2-JP: <jp>明日は協会の集まりがあるので、六時に起こしてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hello. My name is Koichi and I am the events manager for the Portland Kendo Association here in Portland, Oregon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>こんにちは。僕はコウイチといいます。オレゴン州ポートランド市のポートランド剣道協会で、イベントマネージャーをしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>child</kanji> of musical <kanji>beat</kanji>s is the <vocabulary>tempo</vocabulary>. You can only keep <vocabulary>time</vocabulary> if you have a good beat to guide you, like a father.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 拍 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You get the tempo and the rhythm going in your body. You can't help but sing out loud, "Heyo (ひょう), heyo!" Feel that rhythm and sing with me! HEYO HEYO!
Context 1-EN: It's difficult to match the tempo of this tune.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この曲は、拍子を取るのが難しい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I was embarrassed that when I fell my false tooth fell out.
Context 2-JP: <jp>転んだ拍子に差し歯が抜けてしまい、恥ずかしい思いをした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>誕生日</jp> is <kanji>birthday</kanji>. <jp>おめでとう</jp> is like "congratulations." So, congratulations for your birthday is like <vocabulary>happy birthday</vocabulary>!
Reading: <reading><jp>おたんじょうびおめでとう</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: おたんじょうびおめでとう
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>誕生日</jp>, so if you know that you know this!
Reading Audio Male: [sound:Vocab-おたんじょうびおめでとう-Male.mp3]
Reading Audio Female: [sound:Vocab-おたんじょうびおめでとう-Female.mp3]
Context 1-EN: Better late than never with saying happy birthday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>遅れたとしても、「お誕生日おめでとう」って言う方が言わないよりもいいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>精神</jp> is your <kanji>spirit</kanji>, both religiously and spiritually. When those are <kanji>sick</kanji>, you have a problem. Back in the day, a <vocabulary>mental illness</vocabulary> was thought to be a sickness with your spirit. Nowadays you can just call it a <vocabulary>mental illness</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mental disorder</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know <jp>精神</jp> already, though.
Context 1-EN: My friend is kind of messed up in the head from some type of mental illness, but he’s a nice guy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>僕の友達は精神病で頭が少しイッちゃてるけど、良い人だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>foundation</kanji> <kanji>tray</kanji> is a flat thing that is your foundation. It holds everything up. It is the <vocabulary>base</vocabulary> of everything that goes above it. It is the <vocabulary>foundation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We are going to build a fund base for the bacon business first.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ベーコン事業に先立ち、まずは資金基盤を築くつもりです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>narrow</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to narrow</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have to narrow the gap between yourself and your enemy so that you can sabotage (せば) them. You're trying to get through this already narrow air vent, so you can sabotage all of their plans! (But because your windpipe is so narrow in this air vent, it comes out more like sebatage.)
Context 1-EN: Can you narrow the width a little more here?
Context 1-JP: <jp>もう少しここの幅を狭めることはできますか？</jp>

Meaning: To Take A Picture,To Take A Photograph,To Take A Photo,To Photograph,To Take Video,To Film
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>photograph</kanji>. When you make that into a verb, you are doing a photograph, aka making it become <vocabulary>to take a picture</vocabulary>. It can also be <vocabulary>to film</vocabulary> as well. Really anything to do with a camera.
Reading Mnemonic: Think of the reading like you do the meaning <vocabulary>to take a photograph</vocabulary>. You "take" all these things, and how do you say "to take" in Japanese? It's <jp>取る</jp>, aka <reading><jp>とる</jp></reading>, which happens to be the same reading!
Context 1-EN: He put his baseball cap on backwards to take the picture.
Context 1-JP: <jp>写真を撮るために、彼は野球帽を後ろ向きに被り直した。</jp>

Meaning: First Anniversary Of Death,First Death Anniversary
Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>一周</jp> means "one time around?" Well if you're <kanji>mourning</kanji> one time like this a year, then it's because it's the <vocabulary>first anniversary of death</vocabulary> for a family member. Maybe it was the death of your mom, your grandad or your goldfish, this is the first year since they died.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: In July we’re having the ceremony for my wife’s father’s first death anniversary.
Context 1-JP: <jp>七月には、妻の父の一周忌の法事があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>temporary</kanji> <kanji>title</kanji> is what you give something when you don't have a final title for it. it's a <vocabulary>working name</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>tentative name</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The title is just a temporary name for now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>タイトルはまだ単なる仮称です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>perform</kanji> and <kanji>play music</kanji> you are doing a <vocabulary>musical performance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The light bulb burned out while the band was performing on stage.
Context 1-JP: <jp>バンドが舞台で演奏をしている最中に、電球が切れてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning: To Encourage Someone,To Cheer Up Someone,To Encourage
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>encourage</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to encourage someone</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to encourage</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: Think about encouraging a <reading>hag</reading> (<jp>はげ</jp>). She needs encouragement because she's a hag, and nobody likes her much because of that.
Context 1-EN: It’s hard to cheer up someone who’s depressed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>落ち込んでいる人を励ますのは難しい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
You know that 嫌 means dislike and this vocab word means the same thing: dislike or hate!

Though this word is an adjective in Japanese, it usually makes sense to translate it as a verb in English, because of the difference in sentence structure. However, a more literal translation would be dislikable or detestable.
Reading Mnemonic: Of all the things out there to <vocabulary>dislike</vocabulary> the thing I dislike the most is the <reading>killer</reading> (<jp>きら</jp>) of people. People should never kill people.
Context 1-EN: There were fill in the blank questions on the test, which I hate.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の嫌いな穴うめ問題がテストに出ました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I don't like busy work. I think we should have it done by machines.
Context 2-JP: <jp>単じゅん作業は嫌いです。そんなものは機械にまかせるべきだと思います。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m sorry to cause so many problems. You may think I’m unpleasant, but please don’t hate me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>色々と振り回してごめんなさい。嫌なやつと思ってるかもしれないけど、嫌いにならないで。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>世界</jp> means "world" and <jp>恐慌</jp> means "panic" or "scare," so when you put them together you get a scare that made the entire world panic. This is how we refer to <vocabulary>The Great Depression</vocabulary>. It was caused by and subsequently resulted in everybody in the whole world panicking together about money.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
Context 1-EN: My grandfather was born the year the Great Depression occurred.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の祖父は世界恐慌が起きた年に生まれました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The Great Depression affected many countries.
Context 2-JP: <jp>世界恐慌は様々な国に影響を与えた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The Great Depression raised unemployment and even suicide rates.
Context 3-JP: <jp>世界恐慌は失業率と共に自殺率までも上げた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>savings</kanji>, so the verb vocab version would become <vocabulary>to save</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put something aside</vocabulary>. Basically, you're saving up, which is good to do, I'm told.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need <vocabulary>to save</vocabulary>, so you <reading>take one</reading> (<jp>たくわ</jp>) and put it aside, then take another and use it. This way you will have saved at least half.
Context 1-EN: We need to save up some funds before we can start a big business.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大きなビジネスを始める前に、元手を貯える必要がある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>round</kanji> <kanji>tray</kanji> is a <vocabulary>disk</vocabulary>, though if it goes through the air it becomes a <vocabulary>flying saucer</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: After a while, James came back with a disk under his arm and told us he found a UFO.
Context 1-JP: <jp>しばらくすると、ジェームズは円盤を脇に抱えて戻ってきて、UFOを見つけたんだと言いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>day</kanji>'s <kanji>edition</kanji> is the <vocabulary>daily edition</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The <jp>にち</jp> goes to <jp>にっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Aya’s illustration of the cute pug was selected as a daily newspaper’s mascot character.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アヤが描いたパグのイラストが、ある日刊紙のマスコットキャラクターに選ばれました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Someone who's <kanji>shock</kanji>ed at everything all the time will seem like an <vocabulary>idiot</vocabulary>. At this point, putting your drinks in a glass shouldn't be surprising. I mean, come on. Only a <vocabulary>fool</vocabulary> lets himself be shocked by everything he sees.
Reading Mnemonic: Remember when you learned <jp>呆ける</jp>? Well just cut the <jp>る</jp> part off the end and it's exactly the same! If you can remember that, you'll remember this reading as well.
Context 1-EN: You, idiot! Look straight ahead and walk.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この呆け！ちゃんと前見て歩け。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That is what a fool would say.

Meaning Mnemonic: You wouldn't put your <kanji>idea</kanji> in a <kanji>diagram</kanji> <kanji>~like</kanji> format if it wasn't <vocabulary>intentional</vocabulary>. Doing that takes a lot of work. So you can only make diagram like things <vocabulary>on purpose</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 図 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You intentionally stub your toe (と) all the time! If you hurt your toe on purpose you can get out of class and work! It's a really simple injury, but you can't do other stuff while it's hurt, so you always do it on purpose to get out of things.
Context 1-EN: Koichi intentionally raised the base pay for Tofugu employees.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、トーフグ社員の基本給を、意図的に引き上げた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: But don't you think it sounds a little like an intentionally made-up story?
Context 2-JP: <jp>でもそれちょっと、意図的な作り話っぽくない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: There’s a guy manipulating the news on purpose.
Context 3-JP: <jp>意図的に情報を操作している奴がいる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
You know that 好 means like and this vocab word means the same thing: like or love!

This word is an adjective in Japanese, so a more literal translation is likable or lovable. Still, it usually sounds more natural to translate it as a verb in English.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who do you like more than anyone? Your friend Sue. If you know someone named Sue, pretend you like her. If you don't, think of a famous person you know named Sue and use her, pretending you're good friends that like each other a lot.
Context 1-EN: I like Tofugu, but I looove WaniKani.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグのことが好きです。でも、ワニカニはもっと好きです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I love just staying home and doing nothing with someone I love.
Context 2-JP: <jp>好きな人と家でゴロゴロするのが大好きです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I like you just the way you are. So please don’t try to change yourself for anyone.
Context 3-JP: <jp>そのままの君が好きなんだ。だから、他のやつのために自分をかえようなんてしないでくれよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
You've come and you've obeyed the whole way up to now. I guess it's time for you to know my secret. So far I've really been a...

*ahem*

This word can also mean usual or traditional when it's modifying a noun or phrase with の. It makes sense if you try to think about it: a "so far" book is just a weird way of saying a "traditional" book.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: So far, first year employees are given zero paid holidays in this company.
Context 1-JP: <jp>従来、一年目の新入社員はこの会社では有給休暇は一日ももらえません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>指摘</jp> is "pointing out" then the verb version is <vocabulary>to point out</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading comes from <jp>指摘</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Some pedestrians pointed out that the driver ignored the stoplight.
Context 1-JP: <jp>何名かの歩行者が、運転者が赤信号を無視したことを指摘しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Choose</kanji> and <kanji>select</kanji> your choice. This is your <vocabulary>selection</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: In my university, we can freely choose our second language and I’m at a loss as to which language to choose.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の大学では、第二外国語は自由に選べるんですが、どの言語を選択するか迷いに迷っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>mourning</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>unpleasant</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>disgusting</vocabulary>. Nobody said mourning was fun.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your mourning is especially unpleasant because it's your pet eagle (い) you're mourning for. Your parents wouldn't let you bury him so you're just staring at his week old, dead eagle body. It's super disgusting, actually.
Context 1-EN: Please erase this disgusting memory somehow.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この忌まわしい記憶をどうか消し去ってください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you're <kanji>request</kanji>ing <kanji>people</kanji> you're <vocabulary>seeking workers</vocabulary>. "<vocabulary>Help wanted</vocabulary>!" is what this word is basically saying.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We will explain the job offer later.
Context 1-JP: <jp>求人については、後ほどあらためてせつ明をいたします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Nowadays, almost all companies use the Internet for recruiting.
Context 2-JP: <jp>近年は、ほぼ全てのき業が求人にインターネットを使います。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m calling regarding the position advertised in the Tofugu blog. I’d like to apply for the programmer position, but is Mr. Viet still alive? I sent an assassin after him this morning.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トーフグのブログで拝見した求人の件でお電話しました。プログラマー職に応募したいのですが、ビエトさんはまだ生きていらっしゃいますか？今朝方刺客を送り込んでおいたのですが。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>fierce</kanji> and <kanji>violent</kanji>? <vocabulary>Fierce</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>violent</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: What is <vocabulary>fierce</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>violent</vocabulary>? That old <reading>hag</reading> (<jp>はげ</jp>). Imagine her coming at you attacking you violently!
Context 1-EN: Sometimes at night I feel an intense anxiety.
Context 1-JP: <jp>時々、夜になると激しい不安を感じるの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If your <kanji>sweat</kanji> is <kanji>smelly</kanji> (<jp>臭い</jp>) you are <vocabulary>sweaty-smelling</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>smelling of sweat</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>smelling like sweat</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I liked his sweaty-smelling pillow.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は彼の汗臭い枕が好きだった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

In your spare time you like to drink hima (ひま), an off brand version of Zima.
Context 1-EN: We sell home electronic appliances like air purifiers, but not many customers come in and honestly, I have a lot of free time at the store.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私達は空気洗浄機とか家電を販売してるんですが、お客さんがあまりこないので、お店では正直暇してます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lend</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to lend</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Allow me <vocabulary>to lend</vocabulary> you some advice. The reading you learned from the kanji can be used here.
Context 1-EN: "Can you lend me your car?" "Absolutely not. You don’t have a license yet."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「君の車を貸してくれない？」「絶対にだめだよ。まだ免許持ってないじゃないか。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>groin</kanji> <kanji>interval</kanji> is simply the <vocabulary>groin</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crotch</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My crotch is really itchy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>股間がすごく痒い。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why does that dancer always put his hand on his crotch?
Context 2-JP: <jp>あのダンサーはどうしていつも股間を押さえるの？</jp>
Context 3-EN: It might be embarrassing, but I think you should have your groin looked at by a doctor.
Context 3-JP: <jp>恥ずかしいかもしれないけど、お医者さんに股間を見てもらったほうがいいと思うよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This meaning is a little weird, but I'm going to try my best to help you remember.

Every person has to participate in eating carrots. I don't care if you don't like them, if you don't eat at least one carrot in your life you'll die. So if you're a person you better participate in the eating of at least a single carrot.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 参 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're craving a carrot, but you can't seem to find any. You look in your fridge, in your garden, and even in the trash. Finally you give up your carrot search and sit down when... ouch! The carrot was in your jeans (じん) the whole time!
Context 1-EN: I was disappointed with this carrot soup.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この人参スープには失望しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I gifted some carrot liqueur to the King, who loves alcohol, but he didn't like it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>酒好きの王様に、人参リキュールをプレゼントしたが、よろこばれなかった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Please. I'll eat anything else, just not the carrot. Please.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お願いします。何でも食べるので、人参だけは勘弁してください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This <kanji>company</kanji> (<jp>会社</jp>) has done the <kanji>ritual</kanji> required to create <kanji>stock</kanji>s for their company. When a company has stocks, they become a <vocabulary>corporation</vocabulary>.
Reading: <reading><jp>かぶしきがいしゃ</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>かぶしきかいしゃ</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: かぶしきがいしゃ,かぶしきかいしゃ
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for everything here are the readings you learned with the individual kanji, though not all are on'yomi. This word is usually rendaku'd too, but sometimes you'll see the non-rendaku version when it comes to English language legal stuff, so keep that in mind.
Reading Audio Male: [sound:Vocab-かぶしきがいしゃ-Male.mp3],[sound:Vocab-かぶしきかいしゃ-Male.mp3]
Reading Audio Female: [sound:Vocab-かぶしきがいしゃ-Female.mp3],[sound:Vocab-かぶしきかいしゃ-Female.mp3]
Context 1-EN: Can you call Tofugu Corporation to make sure the fax went through alright?
Context 1-JP: <jp>Tofugu株式会社に電話を入れて、ファックスの送信がきちんと完了しているかどうか確認してくれる？</jp>

Meaning: To Make Noise,To Be Boisterous,To Make A Fuss
Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>boisterous</kanji>. The verb version is <vocabulary>to make noise</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be boisterous</vocabulary>. Basically, you're being boisterous when you make a lot of noise, so that's where it comes from.
Reading Mnemonic: When you go <vocabulary>to make noise</vocabulary> and be boisterous, you go to the local <jp>沢</jp> (<reading><jp>さわ</jp></reading>) swamp. It's an awesome place, and people don't complain about the noise.
Context 1-EN: Don’t make so much noise! Do you wanna be killed? If not, just shut up.
Context 1-JP: <jp>騒ぐな！死にたいのか？死にたくなけりゃ黙ってろ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It's a <kanji>prize</kanji> where you are <kanji>give</kanji>n <kanji>gold</kanji>. In business, this is called a <vocabulary>bonus</vocabulary>. You didn't expect it (not your salary) and it is given to you (and is gold, if you're lucky).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Our paydays are the fifth and the twentieth of every month and a bonus may be paid at the end of the year depending on how well the company has done.
Context 1-JP: <jp>給料日は毎月5日と20日で、会社の業績次第で賞与金が年末に支払われます。</jp>

Meaning: To Take Down,To Launch,To Drop,To Lower,To Bring Down
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that <jp>降りる</jp> means "to get off." This is when you're helping something else descend down from something, not when you yourself are getting down. So it means <vocabulary>to take down</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lower</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you already learned. Go you!
Context 1-EN: Could you help me take down my luggage?
Context 1-JP: <jp>荷物を降ろすのを手伝ってくれ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>morning</kanji> <kanji>edition</kanji> is the <vocabulary>morning edition</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You may have seen this reading for 朝 before, but here's a mnemonic to help you:

You pick up your copy of the morning edition and Mrs. Chou (ちょう) is on the front cover. Oh no, what has she done now? Before you can find out, the morning edition is ripped from your hands. You look up and see Mrs. Chou running away, cackling, with other copies stuffed into her arms.
Context 1-EN: I’d say every one of us is more or less interested in the headline from this morning’s newspaper.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日の朝刊の大ニュースには、誰もが多かれ少なかれ興味を抱いているんじゃないかな。</jp>

Meaning: To Transfer,To Change Trains,To Transfer Trains
Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>ride</kanji> and <kanji>exchange</kanji>, so you take your ride (bus, train, whatever) and exchange to another bus, train, or whatever. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to transfer</vocabulary> (or more commonly) <vocabulary>to change trains</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>乗る</jp> and <jp>換える</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I’m worried about how well I’ll be able to transfer planes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>飛行機をうまく乗り換えることができるかどうか心配しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Evidence</kanji> <kanji>traces</kanji> are little bits of <vocabulary>evidence</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>proof</vocabulary>, left behind. They're the <vocabulary>traces</vocabulary> that show that something happened.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Although there was no evidence of crime in the room, the police thought that it was a murder case.
Context 1-JP: <jp>部屋には犯罪の証跡はなかったが、警察は殺人事件ではないかと考えていた。</jp>

Meaning: Front Of Station,In Front Of Station,Front Of The Station,In Front Of The Station,Station Front
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>station</kanji> <kanji>front</kanji> is the <vocabulary>front of station</vocabulary>. This word is great for telling people where you want to meet, by the way.
Reading Mnemonic: This is like two separate words put together into one, so you can imagine it's the kun'yomi readings. You learned the right reading for <jp>駅</jp> in the kanji, and you should know the vocab word <jp>前</jp> by now. Combine the two together and you have yourself <vocabulary>front of station</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: I'm looking for an apartment in front of the station.
Context 1-JP: <jp>駅前のマンションをさがしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: During the election period, lots of politicians make speeches in front of stations.
Context 2-JP: <jp>せんきょの期間は多くのせいじ家が駅前でスピーチをする。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Why did you just send that weird looking selfie taken in front of the station to me?
Context 3-JP: <jp>なんで私に、駅前で撮ったこんな変な自撮り写メを送ってきたの？</jp>

Meaning: To Stoop,To Lean Over,To Bend Down,To Crouch,To Bend Forward,To Bow,To Bend Over
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>yield</kanji>, and when you do that to someone else you tend <vocabulary>to lean over</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to bow</vocabulary> to show them respect.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who do you need to stoop and to bow before? Takeshi Kaga (かが), that's Chairman Kaga to you! Before you can start cooking for him in Iron Chef, you must bow! Otherwise you'll be disqualified for being rude.
Context 1-EN: I get a pain in my lower back when I bend down.
Context 1-JP: <jp>屈むと腰が痛いんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>moon</kanji> <kanji>edition</kanji> is the <vocabulary>monthly edition</vocabulary>, since <jp>月</jp> also means "month."
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A monthly magazine named "The Bacon" reported that the Nobel prize for bacon was awarded to Mami as an April Fool’s joke.
Context 1-JP: <jp>月刊誌『ベーコン』は、エープリルフールのジョークとして、「ノーベルベーコン賞はマミに授与された。」と報じた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Reason</kanji> <kanji>yield</kanji>s to <vocabulary>theory</vocabulary> and more <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The only reason you argue is because you’re really a disagreeable person.
Context 1-JP: <jp>理屈ばっかりこねて、本当に嫌味な人ね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give birth so the verb vocab version is to give birth.

You know another 産む as well (生む). This 産む is more sciency, but both are good to know.
Reading Mnemonic: You know another "to give birth" word (<jp>生む</jp>). Guess what!? They share readings!
Context 1-EN: I heard that person just gave birth to a baby last winter and that she'll have another one this fall.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの人、去年の冬に赤ちゃんを産んだばかりなのに今年の秋にもまた赤ちゃんを産むんですって。</jp>
Context 2-EN: A lot of baby mantises came out of the egg that the mantis laid.
Context 2-JP: <jp>カマキリが産んだたまごの中からたくさんの赤ちゃんカマキリが出てきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Dr. Koichi: Okay. You ready to push again? You are going to have twins! Salmon: I already gave birth to one baby. Leave me alone. Fugu: Okay, okay, come on, you can do it. You can do it!
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチ先生：よし、もう一度いきむ準備はいいかい？君は双子の赤ちゃんを産むんだよ！ サーモン：もう一人生んだじゃない。放っておいてよ。 フグ：大丈夫、大丈夫。頑張れ、サーモン！君ならできるよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Honey is good for coughs.
Context 1-JP: <jp>咳にはハチミツがいいですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm going to go and buy cough syrup.
Context 2-JP: <jp>咳止めシロップを買いに行ってきます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <jp>旅行</jp> by this point. This is the verb version of that. Instead of "trip" it's <vocabulary>to travel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take a trip</vocabulary>. These are fun to do. You should do them!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>旅行</jp>, but it also happens to use the reading you learned with the kanji anyways, so you should be able to read it.
Context 1-EN: Not only is Aya traveling to South Korea, but she's also traveling to Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アヤはかん国を旅行するだけでなく、日本にも旅行する予定です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I went to a hair salon before taking my trip, but it ended up shorter than I'd wanted.
Context 2-JP: <jp>旅行する前に美よう院に行ったんだけど、思ってたより短く切られちゃったんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Seriously, it’s already been a week since our trip together and he hasn’t called me back. I must have farted too many times while I was sleeping.
Context 3-JP: <jp>マジ、終わってる。一緒に旅行をした後、彼が一週間も電話を折り返してこないの。きっと、私寝っ屁をこきまくってたんだわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Please <kanji>indicate</kanji> this in a <kanji>public</kanji> way. How about a <vocabulary>public announcement</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Could you tell me when Japanese land prices are announced each year?
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎年いつ頃日本の地価公示価格が公表されるのか教えて頂けませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>hermit</kanji>, for some reason, is a <vocabulary>daffodil</vocabulary>. Just imagine a water hermit dancing around picking <vocabulary>daffodil</vocabulary>s, because he loves 'em! Yayyy daffodils!!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: There were some daffodils in bloom just behind the grave.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お墓の真後ろに、水仙の花々が咲いていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you think of a <kanji>fur</kanji> <kanji>insect</kanji> what do you think of? My mind immediately goes to a <vocabulary>caterpillar</vocabulary>. Imagine the furriest caterpillar you can and touch it. How does it feel? Furry?
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are strange. Both use the kun'yomi readings - <jp>虫</jp> uses the reading you learned with the kanji, so that's easy. The <jp>毛</jp> part is like the vocab word <jp>毛</jp> you learned in the previous lesson.
Context 1-EN: There was a caterpillar on the cabbage.
Context 1-JP: <jp>キャベツに毛虫がついていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I thought it was a caterpillar, but it was actually my sister's fake eyelashes.
Context 2-JP: <jp>毛虫かと思ったら妹のつけまだった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I videotaped a giant caterpillar fighting a giant centipede.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は巨大な毛虫と巨大なムカデが戦っているところをビデオに収めた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>action</kanji>s and <kanji>things</kanji> you have to <jp>心配</jp> about are your <vocabulary>cares</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>worries</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the reading of <jp>心配</jp> (which you've hopefully gotten down okay by now) and <jp>事</jp> using the (<jp>こと</jp>) reading. It is rendaku'd, as well, so beware of the <jp>ごと</jp> (just another <jp>心配事</jp>, ammiright?).
Context 1-EN: Thank you for laughing my cares away.
Context 1-JP: <jp>心配事をわらいとばしてくれてありがとう。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>なんだか心配事があるみたいだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My biggest worry is volcanic ash falling over the city.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の一番の心配事は、町に降り落ちる火山灰です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Allocate</kanji> <kanji>electricity</kanji> back to the battery with a <vocabulary>recharge</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You can charge your phone in my car, if you’d like.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もしよければ俺の車で携帯の充電ができるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>alive</kanji> <kanji>alcohol</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is a place that does a lot of alcohol. In Japan, these places are often <vocabulary>izakaya</vocabulary>, or, if you don't know Izakaya already from English, you can consider it to be a <vocabulary>Japanese Style Bar</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The readings here are all kun'yomi, but this is the first time you've seen the さか reading for 酒, which rendaku then turns into ざか in this word! If you know what an izakaya is already, it will help you to remember the reading, but if not here's a mnemonic to help you:

After soccer (さか) practice, you always go to your favorite izakaya!
Context 1-EN: The door opened and an old woman walked into the izakaya restaurant by herself.
Context 1-JP: <jp>扉が開き、居酒屋の中に老婆が一人ぼっちで入ってきた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>extreme</kanji> <kanji>south</kanji> is the extreme of south. It's about as south as you can go. That place is known as <vocabulary>Antarctica</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My parents have decided to go to Antarctica this summer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の両親は、この夏に南極に行ってみることを決心しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You'd think that <kanji>someone</kanji> who does <kanji>acting</kanji> is an actor or something... but think about the reading for this kanji. What is it? Do you recognize the word? It's <vocabulary>geisha</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That geisha and I have nothing in common.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの芸者とわたしの間には、何一つ共通点がありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I travel to Japan, I would certainly like to dress like a geisha and parade around Kyoto.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本に旅行に行ったらぜひ芸者のかっ好をして京都の町を練り歩いてみたいです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi, I just wanted to say thank you again for taking care of Fugu and my kid yesterday while we were drinking with geisha.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチ、昨日は私達が芸者遊びをしている間、フグと私の子どもを見ててくれてありがとう。再度お礼が言いたくて。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>hole</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> isn't some kind of creepy hole child (not sure how else to describe it). It's a <vocabulary>conger eel</vocabulary>, a type of tasty eel eaten in Japan. It might be easier to learn the reading first, though, and use that, because the second meaning option is <vocabulary>anago</vocabulary>, the Japanese word for it (also used in English).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the two kun'yomi vocab readings combined. So, <jp>穴</jp> and <jp>子</jp> to combine make <jp>あなご</jp>. Just watch out for rendaku, which changes the reading of <jp>子</jp> from <jp>こ</jp> to <jp>ご</jp>.
Context 1-EN: We are running short on conger eel, so we need to place an order for them soon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>穴子が減ってきたから、そろそろ注文しないといけないな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Since it is difficult to get conger eel in America, freshwater eel is used instead.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アメリカでは穴子は手に入りにくいので、代わりにウナギが使われています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Do you want another piece of conger eel nigiri?" "Sure. Why not?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「穴子の握り、もう一貫頼む？」「うん！あたり前田のクラッカーだよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This has a similar meaning to <jp>主人</jp> (<vocabulary>head of household</vocabulary>). You can remember it also as the meaning you learned with the kanji <jp>主</jp>, which is <vocabulary>master</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading is of course different from what you learned with the kanji. Think of this:

The person who was your head of household was very strict. Anytime you did anything that was incorrect or bad, he/she would pull out the noose (ぬし), but would call it a "noosey" to be cute, since you were just a kid.
Context 1-EN: What is the name of the head of this household?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この家の主の名前は何ですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that the master of that castle doesn't have any heirs.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの城の主にはあとつぎがいないらしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s said that in this pond there is a huge leopard frog called the master of the old pond.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この池には、古池の主と呼ばれる大きな殿様蛙がいると言われています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
You've hopefully seen 好き by now, which is "to like." So, what happens when you have a 大 (big) like? You really like, like a lot, or love something.

This is the same as 好き in that a more literal translation would be lovable, but it's generally tranlsated as a verb in English.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>好き</jp> which you've hopefully seen. Then, <jp>大</jp> is the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I love you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大好きです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: No matter what he says, Fugu still likes WaniKani a lot.
Context 2-JP: <jp>なんだかんだ言っても、フグはワニカニのことが大好きなんですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You’re kind of goofy and that makes you fun to hang out with. I really like you.
Context 3-JP: <jp>天然ボケで、一緒にいていつも楽しいなって思うんだ。お前のこと大好きだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mutual</kanji> <kanji>change</kanji> you make with other people will go so smoothly that it will seem like everything is working <vocabulary>as usual</vocabulary>. It will be like everything is <vocabulary>the same</vocabulary> as it was before because the change was mutual.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: As usual, you've got a cool nose ring, but I can see your nose hairs today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>相変わらずかっこいい鼻輪をつけてるね。でも、今日は鼻毛が出てるよ。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>相変わらず面白いことをしてるね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Viet is muttering an oath under his breath as usual, yeah?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビエトは相変わらず、つぶやくような小声で、ヒドイことを言いまくってるね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're being <kanji>invited</kanji>, but you're also being <kanji>misguided</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>temptation</vocabulary> that's talking. A misguided invitation is never a good thing, like temptation.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Fugu could not resist the temptation to kiss Salmon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>フグは、サーモンの唇を奪いたいという誘惑に抗うことはできなかった。</jp>

Meaning: To Apply For,To Enlist,To Answer An Ad
Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>応募</jp> is "application" then the verb version is <vocabulary>to apply for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to enlist</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>応募</jp>'s reading, though knowing the readings of the kanji will take care of things too.
Context 1-EN: He applied for a job as a lifeguard at the community pool only to see girls in bikinis.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつ、ビキニ姿のギャルが見れるからっていう理由だけで、市民プールの監視員の仕事に応募したんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Ascend</kanji> and <kanji>advance</kanji>! Congratulations, you ascend and advance by getting a new <vocabulary>job promotion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: "Guess what? I got a promotion at work!" "Really? That’s awesome! Congrats!"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「聞いて聞いて、昇進したんだ！」「本当？すごいね！おめでとう！」</jp>

Meaning: Finding Employment,Finding A Job,Getting A Job,Accepting A Job
Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Settle in</kanji> for <kanji>employment</kanji>, well, that is, if you can even find a job at all, you lazy bum. <vocabulary>Finding Employment</vocabulary> is what you need to do to settle in for employment.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: "I’ve had several job interviews, but I haven’t received any job offers yet.” “Join the club.”
Context 1-JP: <jp>「いくつか就職の面接をしたんだけど、まだどこからも内定が出ないんだ。」「お互い大変だな。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>紳士</jp> means "gentleman?" Well when two men <kanji>determine</kanji> that the best thing to do is <kanji>cooperate</kanji> they form a <vocabulary>gentlemen's agreement</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: They’re supposed to be tied to a gentlemen’s agreement.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつらとは紳士協定を結んでいるはずだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is in the <kanji>interior</kanji> of something else is inside of it, deep, and <vocabulary>far back</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>in the back</vocabulary>. Just imagine something interior to something else, it's probably in the back.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: We have ones in smaller sizes in the back.
Context 1-JP: <jp>奥にもっと小さいサイズのものも置いてますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is going to <kanji>suppress</kanji> and <kanji>stop</kanji> what's coming at you. It's a <vocabulary>deterrent</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Which country do you think has the best crime prevention model?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どの国が一番素晴らしい犯罪抑止モデルを有していると思われますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji, making it <vocabulary>flock</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: A <vocabulary>flock</vocabulary>? A flock of <reading>cows</reading> (<jp>む</jp>)! Imagine a flock of cows, probably flying like birds, because flocks usually have something to do with birds.
Context 1-EN: When I I traveled to Europe during the spring, I saw a flock of white sheep for the first time in my life.
Context 1-JP: <jp>春にヨーロッパ旅行をした時に、生まれて初めて真っ白な羊の群れを見ました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Just imagine the <vocabulary>shadow</vocabulary> of a <reading>cage</reading> (<jp>かげ</jp>). Lots of long bars. Looks good.
Context 1-EN: "I haven’t seen Fugu for weeks." "Oh, look. Here comes Fugu right now." "Well, speak of the devil. Hi, there. We were just talking about you."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「私、もう何週間もフグを見てないわ。」「ほら、見て。ちょうど今フグが来たわよ。」「あら、噂をすれば影がさす、ね。こんにちは。私たち、今ちょうどあなたのことを話していたのよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>お</jp> is an honorific that makes this word a bit more fancy. When you're talking about money you gotta be fancy, after all. So, you're basically saying "gold" in a nicer way. What was gold back in the day? It was <vocabulary>money</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for 金 is different from the one you learned with the kanji. Makes sense since this is a single kanji with hiragana attached. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

You've saved up a ton of money. With it you're going to buy something awesome. Then, suddenly someone hits you in the knees with a bat. Now you have to spend all your money buying a cane (かね). Sucks for you :(
Context 1-EN: This photo is more important than money.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この写しんは、お金よりも大切です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you're careless with money, it's going to bite you in the butt.
Context 2-JP: <jp>お金をなめているとバチが当たるよ！</jp>
Context 3-EN: You should be aware that this machine takes your money and gives you nothing in return.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この機械は、お金を取りあげるけどなんの見返りもくれないから、気をつけた方がいいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>冷たい</jp> is "cold." This is the verb version, so you're making something cold. This word is <vocabulary>to chill something</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: <vocabulary>To chill something</vocabulary>, you need to apply cold, not <reading>hea</reading>t (<jp>ひ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: My finger got caught in the door and I’m chilling it with ice now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>指をドアで挟んじゃって、今氷で冷やしてるの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have <kanji>humility</kanji> you will try <vocabulary>to be discreet</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Why are you going <vocabulary>to be discreet</vocabulary>? Because that <reading>tutu she</reading> (<jp>つつし</jp>) wears is really embarrassing.
Context 1-EN: People on the train should refrain from having cell phone conversations.
Context 1-JP: <jp>電車の乗客は、携帯での会話を慎むべきだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>plan</kanji> made by the <kanji>government</kanji> is usually known as a <vocabulary>policy</vocabulary>. "The government passed a policy prohibiting the use of guns on zombies, dooming us all."
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for the opportunity to make this presentation about our policies today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お集まりの皆さん、本日は我々の諸政策についてのプレゼンテーションの機会をいただき、有難うございます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I can <kanji>replace</kanji> <kanji>both</kanji> of your moneys for other moneys at this <vocabulary>money exchange</vocabulary>. I can also <vocabulary>make change</vocabulary> for you too, if you'd like. You'll probably see this word the most in Arcades where you can go to the <jp>両替</jp> machine and get coins to feed your UFO catcher addiction.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading here is a bit weird. Instead of just being <jp>か</jp> (it changes to <jp>が</jp> for the rendaku), it is <jp>がえ</jp>. Just think that if you want change exchanged, I'm your <reading>guy</reading> (<jp>がえ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: I’ll review today’s lesson about how to exchange money in Japanese later.
Context 1-JP: <jp>後で、今日習った日本語での両替の仕方について復習したいと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>隠す</jp> is "to hide." <jp>隠れる</jp> is <vocabulary>to be hidden</vocabulary>. You know that this is the version where something is hidden (and you're not doing the hiding) because it is <reading>rare</reading> (<jp>れる</jp>) that you ever find something that has been hidden (not by you).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>隠す</jp>. So as long as you know that you know this as well.
Context 1-EN: "Oh no. I think I just saw my ex. Quick, hide!" "What? You mean Fugu?" "No. Shark." "Shark? Who’s Shark? You have way too many exes!"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「やばい。多分あれ元彼だ。速く隠れなきゃ。」「まじで？フグってこと？」「違うよ。サメだよ。」「 サメ？サメって誰のこと？てか、あんた元カレ多すぎだっつーの！」</jp>

Meaning: To Toy With,To Play With,To Flirt,To Kid
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>play</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to play with</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to toy with</vocabulary> someone.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Everyone always seems to yell at you when you start to toy with your towel and your towel moves (たわむ). Just because you don't have anything on under it doesn't mean you can't play with it! Right?!
Context 1-EN: I took a picture of the puppy and the girl playing with it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子犬と戯れている少女の写真を撮りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>scarce</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>scarce</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When things are <vocabulary>scarce</vocabulary>, you have <reading>to bo</reading>at (<jp>とぼ</jp>) all the way across the lake to find any resources or food, as your side of the lake is picked dry.
Context 1-EN: Not only are my Japanese abilities lacking, but my personal abilities are too.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本語能力だけじゃなく、対人能力も乏しいんです。</jp>

Meaning: To Settle In,To Take A Seat,To Take A Position
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>settle in</kanji>. The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to settle in</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Try <vocabulary>to settle in</vocabulary> to this life. Wow, you are <reading>too</reading> (<jp>つ</jp>) settled in now, don't get too comfortable.
Context 1-EN: Why do you want to take a position at a company that pays you per diem?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして日当で給与を支払う会社に就きたいの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>English</kanji> <kanji>range</kanji> is the areas where people speak English, aka the <vocabulary>English Speaking World</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ve never thought that Singapore was an English-speaking country.
Context 1-JP: <jp>シンガポールが英語圏だとは思ってもみなかったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have <kanji>guilt</kanji> then you have committed a <vocabulary>sin</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crime</vocabulary>. Come here and confess to Father Koichi.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: When you come to confess your <vocabulary>sin</vocabulary> to me, you start claiming it wasn't you. You say it was some other version of you! What? How could this be? Well, you say "there are <reading>two me</reading>s (<jp>つみ</jp>) out there!" One is doing the bad stuff, and the other is you, and you haven't done any sins!
Context 1-EN: Mami's crime of eating Koichi's bacon is more serious than she thinks.
Context 1-JP: <jp>マミがコウイチのベーコンを食べた罪は思っている以上に重い。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My company president has been found guilty of accounting fraud crimes.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私の会社の社長は会計さぎの罪で有罪になった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I don’t think Koichi would hire anyone who has committed the crime of murdering innocent civilians.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは罪なき一般市民を殺害した人は雇わないと思うよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have your <kanji>wife</kanji> and you have your <kanji>child</kanji>. These are your <vocabulary>wife and kids</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My hungry wife and children are waiting for me at home.
Context 1-JP: <jp>家では妻子がおなかをすらせて待っているんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Even though Koichi has a wife and kids, he visits his favorite hostess every night. Don't you think he's terrible?
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは妻子ある身なのに毎晩行きつけのホステスのところに通っているんだよ。ひどいと思わない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Now that I’ve been transferred to the new branch store, I’m feeling really motivated. Working hard to find a good man has become one of my daily routines. I don’t care whether he has a wife and kids, you know? lol
Context 3-JP: <jp>新しい支店に転勤になって、やる気満々だよ〜。イイ男探しを日課に頑張ってます。妻子持ちだろうが関係ないかんね。笑</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>tighten</kanji> things up and <kanji>bind</kanji> things together, it's hard to separate them again. That's why this word is used <vocabulary>To ratify</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to bind</vocabulary> important things like treaties and contracts.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It’s strange, I wonder why those countries entered into a peace treaty so suddenly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうしてあの国が突然平和友好条約を締結したのか不思議に思うよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We spent a considerable amount of time to ratify this treaty.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この条約を締結するのにかなり長い時間を費やした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We decided to sign a partnership agreement with the supplier.
Context 3-JP: <jp>供給元とパートナーシップ協定を締結することにしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>flock</kanji> of <kanji>horse</kanji>s <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is the part of Japan known as <vocabulary>Gunma Prefecture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird. <jp>群</jp> is okay, but <jp>馬</jp> is just <jp>ま</jp>, which is an exception. It's like the <jp>ま</jp> of <jp>うま</jp>. Then there's prefecture which is the same too.
Context 1-EN: Let me know when you come back from your parents’ house in Gunma prefecture.
Context 1-JP: <jp>群馬県の実家から帰ってきたら、知らせてくれよな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have an <kanji>other</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>, you really have <vocabulary>another person</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Don’t rely on other people’s money.
Context 1-JP: <jp>他人のかねにたよるな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Being that you are someone other than myself, you may not understand, but this onion is my lifesaver.
Context 2-JP: <jp>他人のあなたには分からないでしょうが、この玉ねぎはわたしのいのちのおん人なんです！</jp>
Context 3-EN: He was kinder to me than I could have ever expected from a stranger, but it was just because he thought that I was his aunt.
Context 3-JP: <jp>他人とは思えないほど親切にしてくれたんだけど、単に自分の叔母さんと私を間違えていただけみたい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>gentle</kanji> <kanji>cooperation</kanji> nobody has their way. You're very gently coming towards the middle, coming to a <vocabulary>compromise</vocabulary>. (Whether you like it or not.)
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I don't want to give in.
Context 1-JP: <jp>妥協したくないの。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I couldn't compromise very well and everything came apart at the seams.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うまく妥協することができなくて、ちょっとせい神的に参っちゃったんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: At this job, compromise is not allowed.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この仕事に、妥協は許されないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Grief</kanji> shows in your <kanji>eye</kanji>s by making them look like you've gone through a lot of <vocabulary>bitterness</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>hardship</vocabulary>. You can always see it in someone else if you look them in the eyes too.
Reading Mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi readings for the kanji. You kind of learned this reading for 憂, but not exactly. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

The bitterness that shows in your eyes takes the rays (れ) of light out of them, leaving you with just the う part of the reading that you know. That's why this reading is just う and not うれ like the others.
Context 1-EN: I met with the misery of a broken heart.
Context 1-JP: <jp>失恋の憂き目に遭いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>salary</kanji> I <kanji>give</kanji> you is your <vocabulary>allowance</vocabulary>. It is the <vocabulary>wages</vocabulary> you earn.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We transfer your monthly allowance to your appointed bank account.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎月の給与は、指定の銀行口座にお振り込み致します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a weird word, sorry ahead of time. You have the <kanji>formal name title</kanji> plus another <kanji>formal name title</kanji> (thanks to the <jp>々</jp>). When you have several different kinds of formal name titles you have all kinds of fancy people that you're talking to. Each one of them is different. There are <vocabulary>many</vocabulary> <vocabulary>various</vocabulary> people!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just the reading you learned with the kanji. The second one is <jp>ざま</jp> however, which plays right into the "various" meaning of the word. There's even various ways to read <jp>さま</jp> in this word!
Context 1-EN: My university is big and famous, so foreign exchange students come here from many different countries.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしの大学は大きくて有名なので、様々な国からりゅう学生が集まっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think there are various ways to interpret that remark.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その発言に対しては様々な受けとり方ができると思います。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Tofugu workers vary in size, shape, and color, depending on where they come from. They all have unique characteristics.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トーフグの社員は、どこの出身かによって、肌の色も体型も大きさも様々で、みんなそれぞれユニークな個性をもっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>know</kanji> <kanji>nothing</kanji> (Jon Snow), you know nothing. This is <vocabulary>ignorance</vocabulary>, it's being <vocabulary>ignorant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I'm worried people think of me as an ignorant know-it-all.
Context 1-JP: <jp>周りの人から、無知なくせに知ったかぶりをするやつだと思われていたらどうしようと心配です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I made a mistake due to ignorance.
Context 2-JP: <jp>無知が原因で、間ちがいをおかしてしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You shouldn’t be ashamed of yourself after admitting your ignorance. They should be ashamed of themselves for hiding their own ignorance.
Context 3-JP: <jp>無知をさらけ出したからって恥ずかしがることなんか無いよ。あいつらこそ、自分たちの無知を隠していることを恥じるべきさ。</jp>

Meaning: To Get Irritated,To Get Annoyed,To Get Impatient
Meaning Mnemonic: Double <kanji>frustration</kanji> would cause anyone <vocabulary>to get irritated</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to get annoyed</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to grow impatient</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
This isn’t the reading you learned with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You don’t just get irritated, you get ira-ira-tated (いらいら). That's the next level up from irritated.

This word is often written in katakana or hiragana, but you'll sometimes see it in kanji too, so it's worth knowing!
Context 1-EN: That person is always irritated, huh?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの人、いつも苛々しているね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Don't get impatient while you're driving.
Context 2-JP: <jp>運転しながら苛々しないでよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It's not like I’m trying to get annoyed.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私だって苛々したくてしてる訳じゃないよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Deposit,To Entrust,To Leave Something With Someone
Meaning Mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means deposit so the verb vocab version is to deposit or to entrust. You use this word when you are leaving something with someone else.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

In terms of places where you want to deposit your money, the last place on your list should be a zoo (あず). I mean seriously, you know the animals are just gonna munch up all your dolla bills.
Context 1-EN: What? You deposited how much?
Context 1-JP: <jp>え？今、いくら預けたって言った？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>thick</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>thick</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: What is <vocabulary>thick</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>dense</vocabulary>? A <reading><jp>子</jp></reading> is thick and dense. You poke the child and you see how thick he is.
Context 1-EN: I’m thinking of dyeing his hair a deep purple.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は彼の髪は濃い紫色にしようかなって思ってるんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>discerning</kanji> you do with your <kanji>idea</kanji>s shows your <vocabulary>awareness</vocabulary>. It shows you're <vocabulary>consciously</vocabulary> thinking, because you not only know that you have ideas, but you think about them and discern them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please make it a habit to check that there aren't any cars coming before you cross.
Context 1-JP: <jp>道をわたる前に、車が来てないことをかくにんするよう意識してください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I consciously eat fruits and vegetables since they are good for your health.
Context 2-JP: <jp>果物や野さいはけんこうに良いので、意識して食べるようにしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: As soon as Fugu shows any attention to other girls, Salmon loses consciousness.
Context 3-JP: <jp>サーモンは、フグが他の女の子に興味を示そうものなら、意識を失う。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>die out</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to die out</vocabulary>. You know that this one is "to die out" because you're up in the <reading>air</reading> (<jp>える</jp>), looking down at the dinosaurs, who are all dying out. Thank goodness you're up in the air, because the ground is all on fire.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading can come from <jp>絶つ</jp>, so as long as you know that word you know this one as well.
Context 1-EN: Since Tofugu members ate a mushroom called "panaeolus papilionaceus," there has been no end to the laughter in the Tofugu office.
Context 1-JP: <jp>Tofuguメンバーが笑い茸と呼ばれるキノコを食べてからというもの、Tofuguのオフィスでは、笑いが絶えることはない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>front</kanji> <kanji>scene</kanji> is the <vocabulary>foreground</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: How can I focus on something in the foreground with this camera?
Context 1-JP: <jp>このカメラでは、どうすれば前景の被写体にピントを合わせることができるんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>hope</kanji> is really a <vocabulary>wish</vocabulary> that you have inside of you (though it can still be a <vocabulary>hope</vocabulary> too).
Reading Mnemonic: What's your one big <vocabulary>wish</vocabulary>? It's to have a different <reading>nose</reading> (<jp>のぞ</jp>). Alternatively, you could think "<reading>nose on me</reading>" for <jp>のぞみ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: What are your desires?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたの望みは何ですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My mom told me that the more time and effort you can put into it, the closer you will get to making your wish come true.
Context 2-JP: <jp>時間をかけて努力すればするほど、望みをかなえることに近づくのよって母に教えられました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Just as Salmon had hoped, Fugu proposed to her.
Context 3-JP: <jp>サーモンの望み通り、フグは彼女にプロポーズをした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>結構</jp> is something like "fine" or "alright." This is just a little more polite. You can use this to say <vocabulary>no thank you</vocabulary> to someone trying to offer you something.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>結構</jp>.
Context 1-EN: No, that’s okay. I don’t want dinner. Sorry, but I’m so stressed that I have no appetite.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いいえ、結構です。夕食はいりません。申し訳ありませんが、ストレスで食欲がないんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're <kanji>discerning</kanji> about what you <kanji>know</kanji>. You choose what to keep and what not to keep in your brain. This is the sum of your <vocabulary>knowledge</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi is like a gold mine of information, isn't he?
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチって、知識のほうこみたいなやつだよな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu employees are all very thirsty for knowledge.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグの社員は、みんな知識よくがおうせいです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you want to acquire a good knowledge of Japanese? Don’t be afraid. It’s easy. You just need to learn how to express information in another language.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本語の知識を身に付けたいですか？恐がらなくてもいいですよ。簡単です。あなたの知識を別の言語で表現する方法を学べばいいだけなんですから。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
A perfect disc is flawless. It's just perfect.

As you may already know, in Japan the symbol ⭕ is used to mark correct answers. See how it looks like a perfect disc?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that rendaku turns <jp>へき</jp> into <jp>ぺき</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I can sing the Japanese national anthem perfectly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は日本の国歌を完璧に歌えます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I going to delete these files, then I'll be completely ready.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このファイルを削除したら、これで準備は完璧です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want my Japanese to be flawless.

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>流行</jp> means "trend", so "trend" <kanji>language</kanji> means a <vocabulary>popular phrase</vocabulary>. Yolo! It could also be a <vocabulary>catchphrase</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>popular word</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>buzzword</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Which popular phrase do you think will be chosen for this year's buzzword of the year?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どの流行語が、今年の流行語大賞にえらばれると思う？</jp>
Context 2-EN: A lot of new catchphrases are born every year, huh?
Context 2-JP: <jp>毎年ほんとに色んな流行語が生まれるよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In the past few years, "meme" has become a popular word on the internet.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ここ数年の間に、「ミーム」はインターネットでの流行語となりました。</jp>

Meaning: To Feel Embarrassed,To Be Shy,To Be Embarrassed,To Feel Shy
Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>illuminate</kanji> the things I've done, I start <vocabulary>to feel embarrassed</vocabulary>. Please don't embarrass me. :(
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.
