You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you feel the most embarrassed about is your <reading><jp>手</jp></reading> (<jp>て</jp>). It's all blue and scary looking.
Context 1-EN: Oh, thank you. I’m blushing!
Context 1-JP: <jp>えっ、有り難う。照れるなぁ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Things that are <kanji>beautiful</kanji> and <kanji>lovely</kanji> are very <vocabulary>beautiful</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>pretty</vocabulary>, and often <vocabulary>clean</vocabulary>, too. You can call someone <jp>綺麗</jp>. You can also mention how clean something is with <jp>綺麗</jp>. Gives you some insight as to what "beauty" is in Japan, I suppose. Take your baths, folks.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: "Salmon, you’re the most beautiful woman I’ve ever met." "Fugu, that’s such a lie."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「君みたいに綺麗な女性に会ったのは初めてだよ、サーモン。」「フグったら、嘘ばっかり。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen how <jp>登る</jp> means "to climb." So, if you're <kanji>climb</kanji>ing a <kanji>mountain</kanji> what is that? It's <vocabulary>mountain climbing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from combining <jp>山</jp> and <jp>登る</jp> together to form one word, <jp>山登り</jp>. If you know the readings of those two words you know the reading of this word too.
Context 1-EN: Is mountain climbing your hobby?
Context 1-JP: <jp>山登りがしゅ味なんですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I went to climb a mountain with my quiet friend.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ものしずかな友人と、山登りに行ってきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Both of us have been through a lot, but we had a long talk while climbing a mountain and decided to get back together.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お互い色々あったんだけど、山登りをしながらじっくり話し合ってさ。なんと復縁することになったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>road</kanji> where you're <kanji>astray</kanji> is a road that goes all around in different ways, tricking you and making you lost. This is a <vocabulary>maze</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Nobody found their way out of the maze.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰一人としてその迷路の出口を見つけることができませんでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Example</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is a piece of writing that is an example for maybe a word or a kanji or something like that. This is an <vocabulary>example sentence</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I can't come up with a good sample sentence that uses the word "sample sentence."
Context 1-JP: <jp>例文という語いを使ったいい例文が思いつきません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please let us know which WaniKani example sentence is your favorite.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ワニカニの例文の中で一番好きな文章を教えてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: For some reason my teacher always uses my name when she makes model sentences.
Context 3-JP: <jp>何故だか分からないんだけど、僕の先生は例文を作る時にいつも僕の名前を使うんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lean</kanji>, and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to be leaned</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be tilted</vocabulary>. You aren't doing the leaning or the tilting, though, you're just watching, which is why you say "cool" (<jp>く</jp>) when you see it, because it's already done.
Reading Mnemonic: You <reading>cut a moo</reading> (<jp>かたむ</jp>), that is, a cow, in half. Then you request it is leaned up against the fence so you can start harvesting its meat for sustenance.
Context 1-EN: That pine tree leans a bit toward the south.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その松の木は、少し南の方向へ傾いています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You are counting your <vocabulary>bundle</vocabulary>s. There are a lot of them, so you have to create <reading>tab</reading>s (<jp>たば</jp>) in your notebook to properly categorize everything. Imagine yourself doing this (physically creating the tabs in your notebook, even though your notebook didn't come with tabs).
Context 1-EN: Koichi has so much money that he can swim in it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは札束にうもれるほど金を持っている。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If I remember correctly, I think they sell broccoli in bunches.
Context 2-JP: <jp>記おくが正しければ、たしかブロッコリーは束で売ってたと思うよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I have to get some copy paper. Could you exchange a bundle of copy paper for this bouquet of flowers?
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうしてもコピー用紙がいるんだけど、この花束とそのコピー用紙一束を交換してもらえないかな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What do you get when you <kanji>roast</kanji> <kanji>mochi</kanji>? <vocabulary>Senbei</vocabulary>, a crispy Japanese <vocabulary>rice cracker</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for the second kanji, but if you remember the meaning of the word, that will get you to the reading. In case you're having trouble, here's a mnemonic to help:

You sit eating senbei next to a bay (べい), looking out over the water as you crunch.
Context 1-EN: These are rice crackers, a souvenir from Tokyo.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは東京土産の煎餅です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Green tea always goes well with senbei.
Context 2-JP: <jp>やっぱり煎餅には煎茶が合うよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Viet got annoyed and threw the rice crackers.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビエトは苛々して煎餅を投げた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>pleasant</kanji>? It is also <vocabulary>pleasant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word's reading is pretty weird. We're going to think back to a couple different words to put this one together. The word for heart (<jp>心</jp>), is <jp>こころ</jp>. The word for good is <jp>よい</jp> (or <jp>いい</jp>, but for this word's sake, <jp>よい</jp>). A "good heart (feeling)" is one where your heart feels nice and warm and fuzzy (figuratively, not literally. If it's literal, go to the hospital please). That is a <vocabulary>pleasant</vocabulary> feeling. A <jp>こころよい</jp> feeling.
Context 1-EN: Her voice is very pleasing to the ear, like the babbling of a brook.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女の声は小川のせせらぎのように耳にとても快い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What is a <kanji>sprout</kanji> doing? It's <vocabulary>sprouting</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>budding</vocabulary>. A <vocabulary>crush</vocabulary> you have on someone can sprout too.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Think about that newly sprouting moe (もえ) character you have a crush on. Yes, this is the same moe. Congrats, you already know it!
Context 1-EN: This blog introduces me to the moe characters in my favorite anime and manga.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このブログでは、萌え系を中心に、僕の好きなアニメや漫画を紹介していきます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>salary</kanji> <kanji>fee</kanji> are the moneys you get for your salary. These are your <vocabulary>wages</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>pay</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: "I heard your boss is going to give you a raise." "Really? That’ll be the day."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「君の上司が、君の給料を上げるつもりだって聞いたよ。」「まさか！そんなことあり得ないよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen <jp>美味しい</jp> by this point. This is the opposite of that. Instead of <jp>美</jp> you have <jp>不</jp> (not), so something that does <kanji>not</kanji> have <kanji>flavor</kanji> is something that doesn't taste good. i.e. something <vocabulary>bad tasting</vocabulary>. This can also refer to someone who's <vocabulary>unskillful</vocabulary> at something as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading doesn't follow any of the rules you've run into. It's <jp>まずい</jp>. Think about how you're going through this really long <reading>maze</reading> (<jp>まず</jp>) and how you're promised a really tasty wonderful treat at the end for getting through it (you're a lab rat or something). When you get to the end, there's your treat! What joy! You eat it and... oh man... it is so <vocabulary>bad tasting</vocabulary> you can't even believe it. Be sure to imagine the terrible taste and the terrible disappointment after going through that difficult maze only to get this... this... terribly <vocabulary>unappetizing</vocabulary> cheese.
Context 1-EN: Those sandwiches look a bit unappetizing, don't they?
Context 1-JP: <jp>なんか不味そうなサンドイッチだね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: His handwriting is kinda bad, don't you think?
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの字はちょっと不味いんじゃない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ve never eaten such disgusting miso soup.
Context 3-JP: <jp>こんなに不味い味噌汁を飲んだことはありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
If you preserve and don't hinder, you're providing security, you're safeguarding something.

This word is used in contexts where the emphasis is on protecting from harm. For example, you'll see it in compound words like 社会保障 (social security) 安全保障 (security) and 人権保障 (safeguarding human rights).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What kind of social security is there in Japan?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本にはどんな社会保障がありますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tomorrow, I will attend the National Security Council.
Context 2-JP: <jp>明日は、国家安全保障会議に出席する予定です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: At school, I learned about safeguarding basic human rights.
Context 3-JP: <jp>学校で、基本的人権の保障について学びました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Someone who has <kanji>territory</kanji> under their <kanji>sleeve</kanji> is the <vocabulary>leader</vocabulary>. They're the <vocabulary>boss</vocabulary> of all this territory because they say so, and because they shoved it all into their big sleeves.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
Context 1-EN: What a boss says is absolute.
Context 1-JP: <jp>領袖の言うことは絶対だ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That politician is the leader of the party.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その政治家こそが、党の領袖だ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: These days, the word "leader" tends to be used in the political sense.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「領袖」と言う言葉は、現代では、政治的な使われることが多い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>言葉</jp> means "language?" Well when you add <jp>つき</jp> to the end of it you end up talking the whole time the moon (<jp>つき</jp>) is out and paying more attention to your own <vocabulary>speech</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>wording</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The fairy had a kid's voice, but its wording was as if it was an adult.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのようせいの声は子どもの声だったが、言葉つきはまるで大人だった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That worker's clear diction gives me a good impression.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの社員は言葉つきがハキハキしていて好感がもてますね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was surprised by how much my friend's language had changed in the time since I'd seen him.
Context 3-JP: <jp>しばらくぶりに会った友達の言葉つきが随分変わっていてびっくりした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Sweep</kanji> and <kanji>exclude</kanji> all that dirt from the floor, please. When you do this a lot, it becomes <vocabulary>cleaning</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. For this one though, you have to remember to read the <jp>除</jp> part as <jp>じ</jp>. Just keep in mind that <kanji>cleaning</kanji> (cleanliness) is next to godliness and so is <reading>Je</reading>sus (<jp>じ</jp>). So, Jesus is like cleaning. Easy.
Context 1-EN: First things first. Let’s start by cleaning your room.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まずやるべきことをやらなくてはね。部屋の掃除から始めようか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>uncle</kanji> on your <kanji>father</kanji>'s side is still your <vocabulary>uncle</vocabulary>. This uncle always has to be younger than him though.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the <jp>伯父</jp> which means uncle too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one uncle, you know them all!
Context 1-EN: My uncle is the principle of this school.
Context 1-JP: <jp>叔父はこの学校の校長です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, but it can be either that or the on'yomi reading, depending on the context. You haven't learned the kun'yomi reading for 方 yet, so there's a mnemonic to help you:

You need to go a certain direction. How do you get there? By jumping into a catapult (かた) and shooting yourself the right way. Need to get a particular direction fast? Consider the catapult next time.
Context 1-EN: Which one do you prefer?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どちらの方がすきですか。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>あちらの方に行ってください 。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I don’t like the way she laughs.
Context 3-JP: <jp>かの女のわらい方がきらいだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>oversee</kanji> and <kanji>look at</kanji> all that is in your domain. You are keeping an <vocabulary>observation</vocabulary> over everything.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I have a surveillance camera, but I haven’t checked the tape yet. I wonder if it’s working properly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>監視カメラは持ってるんですが、まだテープを確認した事はないんですよね。ちゃんと撮れてるのかな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>example</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bad example</vocabulary> and is something you don't want.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When learning Japanese, it is necessary to learn from good examples as well as bad examples.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本語を学ぶ時には、いい例だけでなく、悪例を学ぶことも必要です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi is a cluster of bad examples.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは悪例のかたまりだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My parents never let me stay up late because they believed it would set a bad precedent for future bedtimes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>僕の両親は、今後の寝る時間に悪例を残すことになるからって、絶対に夜更かしさせてくれないんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Despise</kanji> someone and your <kanji>scorn</kanji> for them just becomes even stronger <vocabulary>scorn</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My aunts speech always has light traces of contempt.
Context 1-JP: <jp>叔母の言葉は、いつも軽い侮蔑を帯びている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>degree</kanji> of human <kanji>thick</kanji>ness in the area will show the amount of people. Higher degrees of human thickness = more people. Lower degrees of human thickness = less people. That is the population <vocabulary>density</vocabulary> of the area, or the <vocabulary>concentration</vocabulary> of people.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’ll get back to you on your blood-alcohol concentration.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたの血中アルコール濃度については追って連絡致します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>逮捕</jp> is an "arrest" or "capture"? This is the verb version, and it is <vocabulary>to arrest</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to capture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also be helpful to know the word <jp>逮捕</jp> already as well.
Context 1-EN: If you don’t leave now, I’ll arrest you for violating laws against interfering with a public servant in the line of duty.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし今この場を去らなければ、公務執行妨害で逮捕するぞ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tighten</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to tighten</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You go <vocabulary>to tighten</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to tie</vocabulary> your captive up, and you realize you don't have anything to do it with. Then you see a sheep standing nearby. Okay. You take the <reading>shee</reading>p (<jp>し</jp>), pull its wool, and tie the sheep and your captive up together around a tree. Problem solved!
Context 1-EN: Did you tightly turn off the gas?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ガスの元栓、ちゃんと締めた？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've been led <kanji>astray</kanji> and you've been <kanji>misguided</kanji>. What a <vocabulary>trouble</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>annoyance</vocabulary> all this is.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I am bad at Japanese, so I might be an inconvenience to you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本語が下手なので、あなたに迷惑をかけてしまうかもしれません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Medicine</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>s are <vocabulary>medicines</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>drugs</vocabulary>. Try not to take too many of these, now!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi screamed, "Stop doing drugs right now!" and pointed at Viet's nose with his index finger.
Context 1-JP: <jp>「今すぐ薬物をやめろ！」とさけびながら、コウイチはビエトの鼻を人さし指で指した。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet made a clean break from both the yakuza world and drugs.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトは、ヤクザの世界からも、薬物からも、完全に足をあらった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Have you ever had an allergic reaction to any medicines?
Context 3-JP: <jp>今までに何か薬物によってアレルギー反応が引き起こされたことはありますか？</jp>

Meaning: To Get Lost,To Go Astray,To Waver,To Hesitate,To Wander
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>astray</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to go astray</vocabulary> (because you don't just "to astray" now do you?). You can use it if you ever decide <vocabulary>to get lost</vocabulary>. I'm not sure why you'd do that on purpose, but I don't judge.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you are going to go astray, one way to do it would be to eat wayyyy too much mayo (まよ). I can't think of a worse way to go astray, personally.
Context 1-EN: I’m not sure if I should buy unsweetened coffee.
Context 1-JP: <jp>無糖珈琲を買おうかどうか迷っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: From <kanji>foreign</kanji> lands it has <kanji>come</kanji>. How would you describe that item? Simply by calling it <vocabulary>imported</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>foreign</vocabulary>. This word is also used in hospitals for <vocabulary>outpatient clinic</vocabulary>. That's pretty good to know if you plan on going to the hospital to get checkups in Japan.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Imported words are written with katakana.
Context 1-JP: <jp>外来の言ばは、カタカナでかきます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm worried because the patient who would come to the outpatient clinic every day stopped coming.
Context 2-JP: <jp>毎日外来に来ていたかんじゃさんが、来なくなったので心ぱいしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m really interested in foreign things because they’re so different from what’s in Japan.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本のものと全然違うので、私はとても外来品に興味がある。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Hung,To Get Hung,To Hang
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>掛ける</jp> is "to hang something." This is the version where something hangs by itself. At some point someone decided for it <vocabulary>to be hung</vocabulary> and now it's hanging there. You know this because there is a <reading>car</reading> (<jp>かる</jp>) hanging there on the wall. How silly, you certainly didn't hang it, that would be impossible. It's just hanging by itself.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>掛ける</jp>, so as long as you know that you know this too.
Context 1-EN: When I went to the Louvre, the Mona Lisa was hanging crooked.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ルーヴル美術館に行った時、モナリザが曲がって掛かっていた。</jp>

Meaning: To Urge,To Coerce,To Press,To Draw Near
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>urge</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Are you trying <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary> me to do that? Are you trying <vocabulary>to coerce</vocabulary> me to do that? Which one is it? It's all <reading>sema</reading>ntics (<jp>せま</jp>)!
Context 1-EN: I pressed him to pay back the money, but he ran away.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼に金を返すよう迫ったが、逃げられてしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: There’s a cafe on the tip of the cape.
Context 1-JP: <jp>岬の突端にカフェがあるんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>pain</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>painful</vocabulary>. It's also when you say <vocabulary>ow</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ouch</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: An <reading>eate</reading>r (<jp>いた</jp>) is someone who eats. But, the eater hurt his mouth. So now it's <vocabulary>painful</vocabulary> to eat.
Context 1-EN: Our company should designate an outdoor smoking area because the smoke gets in my eyes in this room and it hurts.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この部屋じゃ煙が目に入って痛いので、会社は屋外に喫煙場所を指定するべきだと思うね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
Grab your noodle pole and let's make some noodles. What's a noodle pole? It's a rolling pin!

You use your rolling pin to flatten out the noodle dough before you slice it into noodles. That's why a rolling pin is so important to make noodles.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. So just keep rolling.
Context 1-EN: Where did you buy that rolling pin?
Context 1-JP: <jp>その麺棒、どこで買ったの？</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you're looking for a rolling pin, it's in that drawer.
Context 2-JP: <jp>麺棒ならあそこの引き出しに入ってるよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A large number of rolling pins have been brought in from China.
Context 3-JP: <jp>大量の麺棒が中国から持ち込まれている。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Misguided,To Be Led Astray,To Be Perplexed,To Be Puzzled
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>misguided</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be misguided</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you are going <vocabulary>to be misguided</vocabulary> you're going to be <reading>mad</reading> (<jp>まど</jp>) about it, most likely. Nobody likes to be misguided, so imagine how mad you feel when you are.
Context 1-EN: The perplexed deer was spinning in circles, so we shot it in the neck.
Context 1-JP: <jp>惑う鹿がぐるぐる回っていたので、首を銃で撃ち抜いた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>vein</kanji>s are all the veins you have going out to all the different people you know. These are your <vocabulary>personal connections</vocabulary>, your <vocabulary>network</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Networking is a very important skill for most business people, but it’s especially true for entrepreneurs.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人脈作りは、ビジネスに関わる殆ど全ての人にとってとても重要なスキルですが、事業家にとっては殊更です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>sell</kanji>ing that you've raised (<jp>上げ</jp>) is the <vocabulary>amount sold</vocabulary> or number of <vocabulary>sales</vocabulary>. Think of a graph going upward, where it's rising as you sell more things.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>売</jp> is the one you learned with <jp>売る</jp>. The reading for <jp>上げ</jp> is the same as the reading for <jp>上げる</jp>, a word you learned previously. If you know those two separate things, you should be able to combine them into one awesome vocab thing.
Context 1-EN: Sales gradually decreased.
Context 1-JP: <jp>だんだん売り上げがへってきた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The DVD of the Hollywood movie in which a popular American actor played the main character has sold eight million copies in Japan alone.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アメリカ人人気はいゆうが主えんしたハリウッドえいがのDVDは、日本だけで売り上げが八百万まいになった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Sales have decreased rapidly because of that sexist advertisement.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの性差別の広告のせいで、売り上げが激減した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This word is made up of a single kanji all alone, but it uses the on'yomi reading. This is probably because you'll usually see this word attached to other things, like numbers. This shows the edition or number of an item. So, even though it's alone, it's usually used like jukugo, which is why the reading for this one is the same as the reading you learned when you learned the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Which train car are you going to ride in?
Context 1-JP: <jp>なん号車にのるよていですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The first fortune-telling robot with 100% accuracy was made by a genius scientist and a genius engineer.
Context 2-JP: <jp>天才かがくしゃと天才こうがくしゃの手によって、われわれのみらいを百パーセントよそうてきちゅうできるうらないロボットだい一号がかんせいしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In Japan, we usually hand out an extra issue of the newspaper for free.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本では新聞の号外は大抵無料で配られます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>promise</kanji>, but the meaning of this word is <vocabulary>about</vocabulary>, which is a little different. Just think about promises. When you promise something you really need to follow through... but only about as much as you need to for the other person to be happy. Someone asks for a puppy for Christmas, and you get them a stuffed animal puppy. It's <vocabulary>approximately</vocabulary> the promise you made. Close enough. *wink*
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. See? I <kanji>promise</kanji>d this one would be easy and it was.
Context 1-EN: Burdocks grow approximately two meters above the ground.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ゴボウは地上約２メートルまでのびます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Before that, I had about three years of experience in the stock trading field.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その前に、約三年間かぶしきとり引の分野で働いていた経験があります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: About a million people have liked Tofugu’s Facebook page so far.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今までで、約百万人の人がTofuguのフェイスブックページに「いいね」をした。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Pickled,To Be Well Seasoned,To Be Submerged,To Be Soaked
Meaning Mnemonic: You already learned that <jp>漬ける</jp> means "to pickle," so this means "to be pickled."
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned <jp>漬ける</jp>, so you should be able to read this one too.
Context 1-EN: I soaked and relaxed in the onsen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>温泉に漬かってゆっくりした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>obstruct</kanji>, so what is the verb vocab version? It's <vocabulary>to obstruct</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You try to obstruct a woman coming your way (see kanji). As she gets close, she roars, "I am Sama(n)tha!" (さまた) You shall let me pass!" You don't argue with Samanthas. Get out of her way!
Context 1-EN: I heard that company is trying to hamper Tofugu's success.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの会社は、トーフグの成功を妨げようとしているらしい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You should get rid of things that obstruct productivity.
Context 2-JP: <jp>生産性を妨げるものは、すててしまった方がいいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I don’t understand why people try preventing aliens from reaching the earth.
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうして人々は宇宙人が地球にやってくる事を妨げようとするのか理解できません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>愛</jp> means <kanji>love</kanji>. So, when you add <jp>する</jp> to it you make it a verb. Now it means <vocabulary>to love</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Koichi loves Tofugu very much and often murmurs things like, "Oh my dear Tofugu-chan."
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチはトーフグのことをとても愛していて、「ぼくの愛するトーフグちゃん」とかってよくつぶやいています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I hurt the person I love.
Context 2-JP: <jp>愛する人をきずつけてしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My husband loved our son, but never showed him any affection. I don't think he knew how.
Context 3-JP: <jp>主人は息子のことは愛していましたが、愛情を示したことは一度もありませんでした。きっと、どうすれば良いのか分からなかったんだと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>giant</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>giant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: "What are you guys doing?" "We are watching Attack on Titan. Oops. I totally missed the last subtitle. Can you rewind it a bit?" "OK. Just tell me when to stop." "Stop!"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「何してるの？」「俺達、進撃の巨人を見てるんだよ。って、あぁ、しまった。最後の字幕見逃しちゃった。ちょっと巻き戻してくれない？」「了解。ストップって言ってね。」「ストップ！」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji as well. Lucky! <kanji>Reverse</kanji> face time!
Context 1-EN: I like hotdogs, and the reverse is also true. I was told by a hotdog that they like me very much the other night in my dream.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私はホットドッグのことが好きで、逆もまた同じ。こないだ夢であるホットドッグに’好きだ’ってちゃっかり言われちゃったんだから。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>aunt</kanji> on your <kanji>mother</kanji>'s side is still your <vocabulary>aunt</vocabulary>. This aunt always has to be younger than her though.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the <jp>伯母</jp> which means aunt too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one aunt, you know them all!
Context 1-EN: My aunt is a school teacher.
Context 1-JP: <jp>叔母は学校の先生をしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>give up</kanji> or <kanji>abandon</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to give up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to abandon</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Just before you're ready to give up on something, you yell, "AKIRA (あきら)!" You don't know anyone named Akira, you just saw it in a movie once and it made sense, you know? So now when you've tried really hard on something, but you have to abandon it anyway, you shout AKIRA into the sky.

I just did it while trying to write this mnemonic!
Context 1-EN: Even if you die, don't give up on learning kanji!
Context 1-JP: <jp>死んでも漢字の勉強を諦めないで！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi finally abandoned his dream of becoming a Pokemon master.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチはついにポケモンマスターになる夢を諦めた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Doing a mountain of reviews without giving up or resetting—it's a difficult choice.
Context 3-JP: <jp>山のようなレビューを諦めずにやるかリセットするかは、とても難しい選択です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: You'll remember this kanji to the <vocabulary>extent</vocabulary> that you study it. If you study it like <reading>Hodo</reading>r (<jp>ほど</jp>) would study it, you won't learn it at all. You would only be able to say "hodor, hodor," over and over again, which isn't helpful at all.
Context 1-EN: It was still an hour before dawn, but a guy with startling blue eyes already had gotten up and was making coffee.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まだ夜明けまでは一時間程あったが、驚く程青い目をした男は既に起床し、珈琲を作り始めていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>giant</kanji> <kanji>big</kanji> thing is something that is <vocabulary>huge</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>gigantic</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I strongly suggest that you schedule the appointment with him well in advance because he is the president of an enormous company and he is very, very busy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼はとっても忙しい巨大企業の社長さんなんだから、アポの約束は絶対に早目に取っておいた方がいいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Wander</kanji> from <kanji>stream</kanji> to stream and you'll get really used to <vocabulary>wandering</vocabulary>. You'll love it so much that you'll convert to <vocabulary>nomadism</vocabulary>. The open sky is your home!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That doesn’t mean all Gypsies are poor, nomadic people.
Context 1-JP: <jp>全てのジプシーが貧しい流浪の民というわけではない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>hop</kanji> and <kanji>leap</kanji> into the air, you probably are doing a <vocabulary>jump</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>leap</vocabulary> into the air.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This lesson is aimed at improving students’ leaping, jumping, and hopping skills.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この授業は、生徒たちの跳躍力を伸ばすことを目的としています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Prosperity</kanji> in <kanji>piles</kanji> is a lot of <vocabulary>prosperity</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Which state is the most prosperous in the U.S.?
Context 1-JP: <jp>アメリカで最も隆盛を極めて入る州は何州ですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji>, which comes out to <vocabulary>same day</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings follow the regular jukugo rules (on'yomi reading) but take note that <jp>日</jp> is read as <jp>じつ</jp>, the alternate on'yomi reading. You've been seeing this reading a lot lately, so hopefully you know it by now and it's easy!
Context 1-EN: Those were launched on the same day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それらは、同日にはつばいされました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The bands I like have concerts in different music clubs on the same day and I'm really not sure which one I should go to.
Context 2-JP: <jp>すきなバンドのライブがちがうはこで同日にかぶっていて、どれにいこうかちょうぜつまよっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: On the same day of my father’s death, Apollo 11 succeeded in landing on the moon’s surface.
Context 3-JP: <jp>父の死と同日に、アポロ11号が月面着陸に成功した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Surpass</kanji> the <kanji>extent</kanji>... okay, what does that even mean? You figure out the extent of your abilities, and then you surpass them to get better. You have to do this over and over again in order to keep getting better. It's a <vocabulary>process</vocabulary> that must be accomplished if you ever hope to get better than you are now.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Can you explain the process of how an average housewife ended up being a psychopath who sent out a bunch of threatening letters to random people?
Context 1-JP: <jp>普通の主婦が無差別に脅迫状を送りつける気違いに成り下がった過程を説明してもらえますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>beach</kanji> <kanji>area</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>beach</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic:
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 辺 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Beach starts with be. Be is べ! (I mean, it's pronounced differently, but they're spelled the same!) When you think of the beach, think of べ!
Context 1-EN: Shall we take a walk on the beach together?
Context 1-JP: <jp>一緒に浜辺を散歩しないか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Shift</kanji> the <kanji>peoples</kanji> of that country into this country. <vocabulary>Immigration</vocabulary> nation!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I confessed my secret that I’m an illegal immigrant to her.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は、自分が違法移民であるという秘密を彼女に告白した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>gambling</kanji> <kanji>hit</kanji> can be multiple things. One type of gambling in Japan that was popular in the day involved betting these awesome wooden block things. You'd gamble by hitting them down on the ground, making a nice thunk sound. Another way to think about it is like blackjack. You want a card? You hit! Either way, it's <vocabulary>gambling</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is weird on this one, but gambling is weird, I guess. <jp>はく</jp> goes to <jp>ばく</jp>, maybe because you're playing some gambling <reading>back</reading>gammon. The <jp>ち</jp> can be <reading>chea</reading>ting, where you cheat at this gambling backgammon. So, you're <reading>back</reading>gammon <reading>chea</reading>ting (<jp>ばくち</jp>), you big cheater.
Context 1-EN: Gambling is illegal in Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>博打を打つことは日本では違法です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>amazing</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>amazing</vocabulary>! Or <vocabulary>terrible</vocabulary>. This word can be both good and bad, it really depends on the context, because what is amazing is usually also a little awful. You know?
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The most amazing and terrible thing you've ever seen is Suit Godzilla (すご). Godzilla was wearing a nice suit (amazing!) but also destroying your home, your friends, and your family (terrible!).
Context 1-EN: It's amazing that he was able to speak half a year after he was born!
Context 1-JP: <jp>生後半年で話せるようになったなんて、凄い！</jp>
Context 2-EN: The rain is awful, isn't it?
Context 3-EN: That's wonderful that you got accepted by Tokyo University!
Context 3-JP: <jp>東大に受かったなんて、凄いじゃないですか！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends in an う sound, you know this word is a verb. More specifically, this verb ends in まる, and most verbs with this ending are intransitive, meaning the action or change happens on its own.

The kanji 温 means warm. So this verb means to get warm or to warm up. To help you distinguish this from 温める, you could think of a circle (まる) rolling down a hill all by itself, and getting warmer and warmer as it picks up speed.
Reading Mnemonic: The kanji reading is the same as <jp>温かい</jp> and <jp>温める</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Until the shower water warms up, I'll wait here.
Context 1-JP: <jp>シャワーの水が温まるまで、ここで待ちます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: With this heater, it takes so much time for the room to get warm.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このヒーターだと、部屋が温まるのにかなり時間がかかる。</jp>
Context 3-EN: After running 1km, my body's getting warmed up.
Context 3-JP: <jp>一キロ走って、体が温まってきた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Anti</kanji> <kanji>aggression</kanji> is when you receive some aggression, then respond to it with anti aggression, aka your <vocabulary>counterattack</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Do you remember when and who Oda’s army started the counterattack against?
Context 1-JP: <jp>いつ誰に対して織田軍が反攻を開始したのか覚えてる？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Shift</kanji> the person and <kanji>defer</kanji> him/her somewhere else. This is a <vocabulary>transfer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>assignment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The principal doesn’t want to transfer his authority to someone else.
Context 1-JP: <jp>校長が権力を他の人に移譲したがらないんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>dangerous</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>dangerous</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is in danger! It's poor old <reading>abe</reading> (<jp>あぶ</jp>) Lincoln. You try to save him, yelling out <jp>危ないよ！！！！</jp>, but he gets shot in the back of the head anyways.
Context 1-EN: It's dangerous, so just leave loading the baggage into the car to Viet, who's strong.
Context 1-JP: <jp>危ないから、車に荷物をつむのは力の強いビエトにやってもらおう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: They say if you find a four-leaf clover, you'll have good luck, but I got in a dangerous situation instead.
Context 2-JP: <jp>四つ葉のクローバーを見つけたら幸運がおとずれるって言うけど、ぎゃくに危ない目にあっちゃったよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t believe no one opposed getting involved in the risky plan of such a risky company.
Context 3-JP: <jp>危ない会社のこんなに危ない計画に巻き込まれることに、誰も反対しなかったなんて信じられないよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>look for</kanji> and the verb version of the kanji is <vocabulary>to look for</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You are looking for a <reading>sagger</reading> (<jp>さが</jp>) amongst the products you're shipping off overseas. The saggers are the boxes that have weird lumps sagging out of them, which means they broke and are getting things wet. So, find the saggers. Go <vocabulary>to search for</vocabulary> them, because they could ruin the whole shipment.
Context 1-EN: A three legged dog walked into a bar and said, "I’m searching for the man who shot my paw. He looks like half fugu and half tofu."
Context 1-JP: <jp>三本足の犬がバーにやって来てこう言った。「俺の足を打った男を探しているんだ。半分河豚で半分豆腐みたいな男なんだが。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>specialty</kanji>, which you focus on with <kanji>aggression</kanji>, is your <vocabulary>major</vocabulary> in college (your <vocabulary>college major</vocabulary>). Study hard, young grasshopper.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m majoring in fine art.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私はファイン・アートを専攻しています。</jp>

Meaning: To Become Hollow,To Be Dented,To Sink,To Collapse
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hollow</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to become hollow</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to sink</vocabulary>
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You feel like you've started to become hollow when you have a head cold (へこ). You may be all stuffed up, but it's making you so sad that you feel hollow somehow.
Context 1-EN: I’m sinking in unrequited love.
Context 1-JP: <jp>失恋で凹んでいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm super sad because I made a dent on my new car already.
Context 2-JP: <jp>早速新車を凹ませてしまって、凹んでいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When <kanji>hope</kanji> has <kanji>died out</kanji>, you have no more hope, only <vocabulary>despair</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The other team is fifteen goals ahead of us, so we are in a pretty hopeless situation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>相手チームに15点差で負けているので、かなり絶望的な状況です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you eat <kanji>vegetable</kanji> <kanji>food</kanji> you practice <vocabulary>vegetarianism</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Does anyone else agree that vegetarians tend to be hypocrites?
Context 1-JP: <jp>菜食主義者の人は偽善者が多いっていう意見に賛成してくれる人はいますか。</jp>

Meaning: To Rejoice,To Become Happy,To Be Glad
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rejoice</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rejoice</vocabulary>. Though <vocabulary>to become happy</vocabulary> probably sounds a little more natural.
Reading Mnemonic: You start <vocabulary>to rejoice</vocabulary> by saying, "<reading>Yo, rock on</reading> (<jp>よろこ</jp>)!" Now you know how to rejoice from now on. At church or temple? "Yo, rock on!" Perfect.
Context 1-EN: My son was very happy when he finally hit the ball with the center of the racket.
Context 1-JP: <jp>やっとラケットの真ん中にボールを当てることができて、息子はとても喜んでいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My mom dyed her gray hairs for the first time, and now she thinks she looks at least ten years younger, so she is rejoicing.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うちの母、初めて白がぞめをしたんだけど、十才はわか返って見えるって言って、本人はすごく喜んでるよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We were so pleased to hear that studying Japanese is your only joy in life. We’d be happy to offer you some tips, so feel free to ask us any questions at anytime.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本語を勉強することがあなたの人生で唯一の喜びだと聞いて、私達はとても嬉しく思っています。喜んでアドバイスするので、質問があればいつでも聞いてくださいね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>despise</kanji> this one guy so much that you want to <kanji>humiliate</kanji> him so you <vocabulary>insult</vocabulary> him in public. That wasn't very nice, but it did seem to embarrass him. I guess you won.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Are you telling me to stay quiet and just accept the insults?
Context 1-JP: <jp>こんな侮辱を受けて、黙っていろというのか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>eyebrows</kanji> <kanji>interval</kanji> is that place between your eyebrows called the <vocabulary>brow</vocabulary>. The technical term for this interval between your brows is the <vocabulary>glabella</vocabulary>, but I bet you never use that word. Unless you're... an eyebrow doctor?
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, but it uses the slightly less common けん reading for 間. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

You stare at the beautiful brow on your Ken (けん) doll, completely mesmerized. You wish your brow looked as perfectly groomed as his... le sigh~
Context 1-EN: The company president said, "Who wrote these documents?" while furrowing his brow.
Context 1-JP: <jp>社長は眉間にシワを寄せながら「この資料は誰が書いた？」と言った。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You know, my pug's most attractive feature is the lines on his brow after all.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私のパグのチャームポイントはやはり眉間のシワです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Please fill in your brow with black marker.
Context 3-JP: <jp>眉間を黒いマジックで塗りつぶしてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Untie</kanji> and <kanji>scatter</kanji> everything. This will cause a <vocabulary>breakup</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>dissolution</vocabulary> of whatever is being untied then scattered.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What are the advantages and disadvantages of dissolving the House of Representatives?
Context 1-JP: <jp>私達にとって、衆議院を解散するメリットとデメリットは何ですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
If you're going to abduct some noodles, make sure it's everybody's favorite noodles, ramen! The other meaning of the first kanji actually makes more sense here though, because you pull the dough to stretch it when you make ramen noodles. Choose whichever meaning helps you remember it best!

This word is mostly written in kana, usually as ラーメン, but sometimes らーめん. You'll see the kanji version pretty often on packaging and menus, though, so it's worth knowing! The word is also occasionally written as らー麺.
Reading Mnemonic: Both of these kanji take the on'yomi, but the first one has a slightly irregular reading, because it's based on the modern Chinese reading. To remember that it's a long <jp>らー</jp>, just think how excited you are about these ramen! <reading>Raaaaaa</reading>! Raaaamen! So exciting!
Context 1-EN: This is my first time eating salmon ramen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>鮭拉麺なんて初めて食べるよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What small companies need in order to grow is ramen.
Context 2-JP: <jp>小さな会社が成長するのに必要なのは、拉麺です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I spilled ramen soup on my crotch.
Context 3-JP: <jp>股間に拉麺の汁をこぼしてしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you treat someone in a <kanji>lowly</kanji> manner because you think they're <kanji>inferior</kanji> to you then you're a <vocabulary>mean</vocabulary> person. Plain and simple.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You played a mean trick!
Context 1-JP: <jp>卑劣な手段を使いやがって。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>energy</kanji> of the <kanji>climate</kanji> is the <vocabulary>climate</vocabulary>. High energy? Climate. Low energy. Climate.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I got off to a good start with my new job, considering the threatening climate.
Context 1-JP: <jp>気候は荒れ模様だが、新しい仕事ではいいスタートが切れた。</jp>

Meaning: School Grade,Grade In School,School Year,Year In School
Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> is kind of like the years you've studied. Where do you study? School. What is a year of study in a school? It's your <vocabulary>school grade</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He is in the same year as my older brother.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かれは、兄と同じ学年です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu not only has fans in early elementary school, but also elderly fans over 100 years old.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグには、小学こうてい学年のファンもいれば、１００才をこえるファンもいる。</jp>
Context 3-EN: One third of the third grade threw up after school lunch.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの給食の後、三年生の学年の三分の一が吐いた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It's the <kanji>side</kanji> of the <kanji>beach</kanji>! Well, wait, what is it? This will make better sense when you look at the reading for the word, since it's a place: <vocabulary>Yokohama</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>横</jp> and <jp>浜</jp> put together into one nice word, <reading><jp>よこはま</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: "Thank you so much for giving me a lift from Yokohama all the way to Osaka." "Don’t mention it!"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「横浜から大阪までずうっと乗せてくれて、本当に有難うございます。」「どういたしまして！」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What is the "<kanji>industry</kanji> of <kanji>make</kanji>"? Well, it's when you industriously make things, obviously. That can only be <vocabulary>handicraft</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crafts</vocabulary>! This can also mean <vocabulary>maneuvering</vocabulary>, in the sense of pulling strings behind the scenes.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Handicraft is not my strong point.
Context 1-JP: <jp>工作はとくいではありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I failed to set up a reasonable alibi.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アリバイ工作にしっぱいした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When I was in elementary school, I made a machine that makes ice cream for my school craft project over summer break.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は小学生の頃、夏休みの自由工作の宿題で、アイスクリームを作る機械を作った。</jp>

Meaning: To Stress,To Stress Out,To Be Nervous
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>緊張</jp> is <vocabulary>stress</vocabulary>. So, the verb version is <vocabulary>to stress out</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I was nervous during delivery because I knew my baby was going to be a breech birth.
Context 1-JP: <jp>赤ちゃんが逆子で産まれてくるって分かってたので、出産時は緊張しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>frozen</kanji>, so the vocab version is <vocabulary>to freeze</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading actually comes from the word <reading><jp>氷</jp></reading>, which means "ice." You can kind of see where the origins of these words come from, now... really cold frozen things. So, think back to <jp>こおり</jp>, then change the <jp>り</jp> to a <jp>る</jp> and put it outside the kanji. That makes the reading for this <jp>こおる</jp>, in all (or most) of <jp>氷</jp>'s glory.
Context 1-EN: Have you ever made ice cubes by freezing orange juice?
Context 1-JP: <jp>オレンジジュースを凍らせて氷を作ったことはありますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Things that are <kanji>target</kanji>ed as <vocabulary>Japanese</vocabulary> are more than just Japanese, they are <vocabulary>very Japanese</vocabulary>. This word may be hard to understand at first, but there are many things the Japanese consider to be Japanese-only. These theories range from reasonable to ridiculous, but either way, you'll see them described as <jp>日本的</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know how to read <jp>日本</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: I yearn for a Japan-style life.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本的なくらしにあこがれています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This anime is very Japanese, yeah?
Context 2-JP: <jp>このアニメはとても日本的ですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Fugu found a very Japanese gentleness in Salmon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグは、サーモンの中に「日本的な優しさ」を見出した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: There is a <kanji>reason</kanji> for this <kanji>fee</kanji> that you have to pay to get in here. We are doing <vocabulary>cooking</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>cuisine</vocabulary> for you to eat while you're watching the show. If we weren't doing cooking, we probably wouldn't charge you this fee!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: There's a lot of fish on the menu. What is everyone getting?
Context 1-JP: <jp>メニューには魚料理がたくさんございますが、みなさんどれになさいますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Mami mistook the cauliflower for white broccoli and cooked it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>マミは、カリフラワーを白いブロッコリーだとかんちがいして料理しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can only cook simple cuisine.
Context 3-JP: <jp>簡単な料理しかできません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>circumference</kanji> that <kanji>surround</kanji>s us is the <vocabulary>perimeter</vocabulary> of the area. Do not cross it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: There are always yakuza-type men surrounding that lady.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの女性の周囲にはいつもヤクザ風の男がいる。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi went into a black building, cautious of his surroundings.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは周囲の目をけいかいしながら黒いたて物に入っていきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was told that Mt. Fuji’s crater is about three kilometers around and two hundred and thirty-seven meters deep.
Context 3-JP: <jp>富士山の火口の周囲は約三キロメートルで、深さは二百三十七メートルだと聞きました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>flock</kanji> that has <kanji>gather</kanji>ed is a <vocabulary>crowd</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>multitude</vocabulary>. Because, well, lots of things gathering.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The crowd broke out in laughter when the little boy started imitating Justin Bieber.
Context 1-JP: <jp>小さな男の子がジャスティン・ビーバーの物真似をし出したので、群集は大笑いをしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the kun'yomi reading you learned for the kanji, meaning you should know both!
Context 1-EN: It snowed a lot this winter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ことしの冬は、ゆきがたくさんふりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's an illustration I drew last winter.
Context 2-JP: <jp>きょねんの冬にかいたえです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t make light of winter or you’re sure to have a painful experience.
Context 3-JP: <jp>冬をなめるといたい目にあうぞ！</jp>

Meaning: By The End Of The Year,Before The End Of This Year,Within The Year
Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Inside</kanji> the <kanji>year</kanji> means <vocabulary>by the end of the year</vocabulary>. In other words, <vocabulary>before the end of this year</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>within the year</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It should be complete within the year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>年内には、かんせいするはずです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm aiming to reach 100,000 followers by the end of this year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>年内にフォロワー10万人目ざします。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The assassination must be carried out before the year is over.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この暗殺は、年内に遂行されなくてはならない。</jp>

Meaning: Head Of Household,Husband,Head Of A Household,Head Of The Household,Landlord,Master
Meaning Mnemonic:
The master person isn't just a master. You have to think back to when they were making these kanji. Who was the master? It was the head of household. This head of household probably told servants what to do and was all bossy and stuff. He was the master person.

Also, this often means husband. Because, I guess the head of household back in the day was the husband. Those sexist ancient people!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Did you and your husband go somewhere yesterday?
Context 1-JP: <jp>きのう、ご主人とどこかへいきましたか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm afraid you bought too many of them, master.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ご主人さま、それは少しかいすぎではないでしょうか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My husband is a politician who doesn’t have any conviction.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の主人は何の信念も無い政治家なんです。</jp>

Meaning: Critical Condition,Critical Illness,On The Verge Of Death
Meaning Mnemonic: If someone is so <kanji>dangerous</kanji> that they <kanji>deliberately</kanji> hurt you, you're going to end up in <vocabulary>critical condition</vocabulary>. This wasn't an accident, they knew what they were doing and they didn't miss. Now you're <vocabulary>on the verge of death</vocabulary>. Hold on, kiddo.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: There was a call saying dad was in critical condition.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父が危篤だという電話がありました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word is pretty weird. It has two distinct sort of meanings. One is the "not so good" meaning, and the other is the "delicate" meaning. Lately the "not so good" meaning has taken priority, I think, so let's focus on that for now. Something is both <kanji>delicate</kanji> and <kanji>strange</kanji>. This delicate strange thing really is just <vocabulary>not so good</vocabulary>. It's not terrible, but it's not great either. It's just not so good. Why? Because if you touch it too hard, it will break. Also, it's not that normal either, so it's not helpful to you. Imagine a thing that could be like this, then think: Is this good? <vocabulary>not really</vocabulary>. It's <vocabulary>not so good</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Well... I have mixed feelings.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うーん…なんとも微妙な感じですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Change</kanji> and <kanji>transition</kanji> mean <vocabulary>change</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>transition</vocabulary>! Nifty.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Let’s look at the changes in the top 20 Japanese language learning sites between 1996 and 2013.
Context 1-JP: <jp>1996年から2013年までのトップ日本語学習サイト20の変遷を見てみましょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading. The "Virtue River" isn't some virtuous river, it's in fact the <vocabulary>Tokugawa</vocabulary> family name, also known as the <vocabulary>Tokugawa Shogun</vocabulary>. They ran Japan for a while, you know?
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are <jp>徳</jp> and the vocab <jp>川</jp> put together into one word. Once you can read this, you'll know the meaning too, so focus on the reading for this one.
Context 1-EN: She likes Japanese history and is very familiar with the Tokugawa Shogunate.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は歴女で、徳川幕府にはとても精通しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>flower</kanji> <kanji>powder</kanji> <kanji>symptom</kanji>s are when you start sneezing from flower powder, aka pollen that comes from all sorts of flowers, which is pretty much all plants. This word, however, refers to the most common version of this sickness, which is <vocabulary>hay fever</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is all on'yomi readings, which you learned for all but <jp>花</jp>. Instead, <jp>花</jp> is <jp>か</jp>, and to remember that you can think about how the only way to escape the <vocabulary>hay fever</vocabulary> is to jump in your <reading>ca</reading>r and turn on the filter. Sweet, sweet relief.
Context 1-EN: I heard that propolis extract is good for hay fever.
Context 1-JP: <jp>プロポリスが花粉症に効くって聞いたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Extinction</kanji> will happen as you go <kanji>versus</kanji> extinction. It will happen <vocabulary>absolutely</vocabulary>. It will happen <vocabulary>without fail</vocabulary>. There's nothing you can do to stop extinction.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful though, <jp>絶</jp> is normally read as <jp>ぜつ</jp>, but in this case it is shortened to <jp>ぜっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: You can’t go out on a school night. If I say it’s no good, it’s absolutely no good!
Context 1-JP: <jp>学校のある夜は、外出できないって言ってるでしょ。だめだと言ったら絶対にだめだからね！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>dark</kanji> <kanji>reef</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>reef</vocabulary>. It's just really deep underwater so it's kinda dark under there. Because of that it can also be called a <vocabulary>sunken reef</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The captain told me to be careful of reefs and then left the steering to me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>船長は、暗礁に気をつけてと言って、僕に操縦を任せた。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>捜査は暗礁に乗り上げてしまったな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji it uses the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, you learned this reading with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: It hasn’t rained yet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>雨はまだふっていません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Unfortunately, I was born prince of a country that has rain all year long.
Context 2-JP: <jp>一年中雨がふるくにの王子として生まれたことをくいています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I like the smell of rain and you smell like it. That’s why I love you.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は雨の臭いが好きで、あなたはそんな臭いがする。だからあなたのことが大好きなの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>ring</kanji> of gum (<jp>ゴム</jp>) (which is what Japanese people call rubber quite often) is a ring of rubber. What is a ring of rubber that people use often? It's a <vocabulary>rubber band</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>輪</jp> is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which is <jp>わ</jp>, making this word <reading><jp>わゴム</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: This elastic band is very durable.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この輪ゴムはとても丈夫です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: They suspected I was the rubber band robber, but I've now been cleared of all charges.
Context 2-JP: <jp>輪ゴムどろぼうのうたがいをかけられていたが、ついに晴れの身となりました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh my God, I just totally love your dress! So many colorful rubber band pictures printed on it, eh? I’ve never seen a dress like this before.
Context 3-JP: <jp>わぁ！そのワンピマジで可愛い！カラフルな輪ゴムの絵がたくさんプリントしてあるんだね！そんなワンピ初めてみたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I need to <kanji>consult</kanji> you on this <kanji>problem</kanji>, if I could. I have a <vocabulary>question</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>enquiry</vocabulary> I'd like to ask you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The Council on Economic and Fiscal Policy plans to hold a meeting on the same day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その日は経済財政諮問会議が開催される予定です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>look up to</kanji> someone... twice. That's too many times that you're looking up to someone. They must be pretty amazing for that to happen. Really, though, you're being fooled. This person is <vocabulary>pompous</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>exaggerated</vocabulary>. So you think they're cool, but really they're pretending to be more than they are.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, x2 with a <jp>しい</jp> added on for good measure.
Context 1-EN: I hate people who use pompous wording.
Context 1-JP: <jp>仰々しい言葉遣いをする人は嫌いです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you follow the <kanji>circumference</kanji> of a <kanji>period of time</kanji>, you end up back at the beginning and it makes a full <vocabulary>cycle</vocabulary>. Events in history always repeat, right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I await your response regarding the cycle of a pendulum.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ふり子の周期についてのお返事、お待ちいたしております。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Actually, I've been practicing a song called "The Moon Cycle" because I wanted to play it for you, Kristen.
Context 2-JP: <jp>実はさぁ、クリステンにきいてもらいたくて、「月の周期」っていう曲を練習してるんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Tohoku’s weather changes in short cycles.
Context 3-JP: <jp>東北の天気は短い周期で変わる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It is <kanji>reverse</kanji> to the <kanji>theory</kanji>! What is going on? Things aren't right. There must be some kind of <vocabulary>paradox</vocabulary> going on, where all theories are reversed! D:
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It may sound paradoxical, but many long-married old people admit that some differences can spice up a relationship.
Context 1-JP: <jp>逆説的に聞こえるかもしれないが、長い結婚生活を送ってきた年配の人達は、ちょっと違ったことに取り組むことは夫婦関係の刺激になると認めている。</jp>

Meaning: To Sever,To Cut Off,To Abstain From
Meaning Mnemonic: This one is a little bit off and will take a little extra remembering. The kanji means <kanji>extinction</kanji> or <kanji>die out</kanji>, but the verb version here is <vocabulary>to sever</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary>. The ideas are pretty similar, but the wording isn't the same. Just think, when you put something to extinction, you have <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary> that thing from your life. Put it in extinction. You have <vocabulary>to sever</vocabulary> it.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

In terms of things you need to sever, tacos (た) are #1 on your list. No more tacos for you, going to cut those off from my diet.
Context 1-EN: Can you promise me you’ll abstain from alcohol?
Context 1-JP: <jp>酒を絶つことが約束できますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>delicate</kanji>, and the vocab has this meaning too. It's that kind of "subtle" delicate, not so much that something will break (like it is with the kanji). Something that is a bit <vocabulary>faint</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>indistinct</vocabulary> is going to be delicate in this sense, perhaps, too.
Reading Mnemonic: If you're going to <reading>cuss</reading> (<jp>かす</jp>) up a storm, that's not really being <vocabulary>delicate</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: I got strangely excited by the faint smell of her perfume.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女の微かな香水の香りに、妙に興奮してしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>untie</kanji> a <kanji>theory</kanji> for someone, you're taking it apart and making it more understandable to them. You are doing an <vocabulary>explanation</vocabulary> of something for them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The teacher’s explanation is really easy to understand.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの先生の解説はとても分かり易いね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When someone asks you <jp>何故</jp>, or "why," you did something, you respond with, "<jp>何故なら</jp> blah blah blah." That makes it mean <vocabulary>because</vocabulary>. Why did you do that? Because I was mad! Why did you dance? Because I was happy!
Reading Mnemonic: This reading is an exception but you learned them already because they're the same as the word <jp>何故</jp>, which you learned a few levels ago. It just has some kana attached to it!
Context 1-EN: Because, he was a wizard!
Context 1-JP: <jp>何故なら、彼は魔法使いだったのです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>笑う</jp> is "to laugh." This is the noun version, because the <jp>う</jp> in <jp>笑う</jp> turns to <jp>い</jp> (so don't confuse this as an adjective). What is the noun version of "to laugh"? It's <vocabulary>a laugh</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>笑う</jp>, so just make sure you know that so you can know this as well.
Context 1-EN: Everybody laughed for some reason when I said that people eat KFC for Christmas dinner in Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本ではクリスマスディナーにケンタッキーを食べると言ったら、なぜか笑いが起きました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I feel like he probably doesn't even know what he's laughing at anymore, but he just can't help it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>もうかれ自身多分何を笑ってるのか分からないけどただ笑いが止まらないっていうじょうたいなんだと思うよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s not like you to cry at movies. You always laugh really hard when there are any serious scenes in them.
Context 3-JP: <jp>映画を見て泣くなんて、お前らしくないじゃないか。いつもどの映画のどんな深刻なシーンにも大笑いしてるのに。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Chastity</kanji> is always in <kanji>season</kanji> so it's always cool to try to keep your <vocabulary>chastity</vocabulary>. Spring, summer? Doesn't matter. Your decision to stay that way is fine no matter what time of year it is.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: She protected her chastity until the end.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は最後まで貞節を守ったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>兄弟</jp> means "siblings?" Well when they're siblings you have to <kanji>obey</kanji> they're not your brother or sister, they're your <vocabulary>cousin</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The entire reading for this is an exception. Sorry about that. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

What are the two defining traits your cousin has? They're good and a child. いいと子, or いとこ for short. Just remember your good, kid cousin. Your いとこ cousin.
Context 1-EN: Cousins can get married?!
Context 1-JP: <jp>従兄弟同士は結婚できるんだぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This may look like a verb at first, but it's actually the adverb version of the adjective <jp>凄い</jp>. When something is <kanji>awful</kanji> it's usually <vocabulary>awfully</vocabulary> awful.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned this reading already, so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Vietnamese coffee was very sweet. I was surprised!
Context 1-JP: <jp>ベトナムのコーヒー、凄く甘くて驚きました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The teacher's health condition got awfully bad today, so class was canceled.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日は、先生の気分が凄く悪くなったため授業が中止になった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want these rain boots so bad. Do you think ordering them from Amazon Prime Now is worth it?
Context 3-JP: <jp>この長靴が凄く欲しいんだけど、Amazon Prime Nowでオーダーする価値あるかな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This has the same meaning as the kanji, specifically the <vocabulary>how many</vocabulary> meaning. You know this because you ask "how many" and they answer "<reading><jp>つ</jp></reading>." This can also be used to ask <vocabulary>how old</vocabulary> someone is, but generally only for children's ages.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from what you learned in the kanji, nice job.
Context 1-EN: Can you count how many apples there are in that parcel?
Context 1-JP: <jp>その小づつみの中にリンゴが幾つ入っているか数えてもらえる？</jp>
Context 2-EN: How many mics do you know of that are adequate for recording?
Context 2-JP: <jp>録音に適したマイクを幾つ知っていますか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How old are you, little girl?
Context 3-JP: <jp>おじょうちゃんは幾つかな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>increase</kanji>, so the vocabulary verb version means <vocabulary>to increase</vocabulary>. This is when something is just increasing on its own, and you're not doing the increasing. You know this because you like to <reading>err</reading> (<jp>える</jp>) on the side of caution and not touch anything when it's increasing, therefore you're not doing any of the increasing yourself (it's just happening).
Reading Mnemonic: It would be <reading>foo</reading>lish (<jp>ふ</jp>) of you to touch anything while things are increasing anyways. You don't want to mess up a good thing, do you? Don't be a fool.
Context 1-EN: Over the past five years, Viet’s daily amount of alcohol has been increasing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここ5年間、ビエトの一日当たりの飲酒量が増えてきています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>創造</jp> is <kanji>creation</kanji> and you add <kanji>power</kanji> to it, you have <vocabulary>creative power</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well!
Context 1-EN: I’m so excited to work with a creative person like you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたのような創造力のある人と仕事ができることを、とても楽しみにしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: With <jp>故</jp> meaning "reason" if you head towards that reason, you transition towards it. To say that in words, you might say <vocabulary>therefore</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>consequently</vocabulary>. You stated your case and ideas, then in order to go towards reason we use these words to transition towards it.
Reading Mnemonic: By knowing the word <jp>故</jp> you'll know the reading for this word too!
Context 1-EN: I was repeatedly late without permission and consequently my vacation days were cut short.
Context 1-JP: <jp>度重なる無断遅刻故に、 休暇日数が減らされてしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>pure</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>pure</vocabulary>. People like this are also usually really <vocabulary>gracious</vocabulary> to others. This type of pure heart would even be a gracious loser.
Reading Mnemonic: Oh man, the reading for this is... like... crazy. First part can be something like <reading>it's soggy</reading> (<jp>いさぎ</jp>)... then the second part is like the word <jp>良い</jp> (good). So, you can think of a pure hearted person eating soggy cereal. He/she is so pure hearted that it doesn't matter to them how soggy it is. In fact, they seem to enjoy it! They keep saying "<reading>it's soggy, good!"</reading> over and over again while eating the terribly soggy food.
Context 1-EN: Wish I had a pure heart like yours.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺にもお前みたいな潔い心があればいいんだがな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>占い</jp> is "fortune telling." <kanji>Star</kanji> <kanji>fortune</kanji> telling is when you use the stars for fortune telling. That's known as <vocabulary>astrology</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>horoscope</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the words <jp>星</jp> and <jp>占い</jp> put together into one. Did you foresee that one coming?
Context 1-EN: Today’s horoscope says I should be careful of getting a bump on my head.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日の星占いで、頭にたんこぶができないように気をつけた方がいいと出ていたの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>borrow</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to borrow</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Dude, can I borrow your <reading>ca</reading>r (<jp>か</jp>)? Please?
Context 1-EN: I want to skim the scum off the top, so can I borrow your ladle for a second?
Context 1-JP: <jp>アクを取りたいので、ちょっとお玉を借りてもいいですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I borrowed one of your loose‐leaf sheets of paper, Kristen.
Context 2-JP: <jp>クリステンのルーズリーフ、一枚借りたよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I’m sorry I lost the romance novel I borrowed from you." "Don’t worry about it. I won’t need it anymore anyway. I have a girlfriend now."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ごめんね。君から借りていた恋愛小説をなくしちゃったんだ。」「気にしないでいいよ。それはもう必要ないから。彼女ができたんだ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When something is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>equal</kanji> it suffers from <vocabulary>inequality</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi doesn't want to distribute Tofugu's profits unevenly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、トーフグの利えきを不等に分配するのがいやなんだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do you know the formula to find the area of a scalene triangle?
Context 2-JP: <jp>不等辺三角形の面せきを求める公式を知っていますか？</jp>
