Context 3-EN: I’m pretty good at simultaneous inequalities.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は連立不等式が得意です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
A person who wanders because their lord was killed, is known as a ronin, or a masterless samurai. Now they're just like the rest of us, but they can't stop wandering because they have nowhere they belong.

In modern times, ronin refers to those who failed their university entrance exams, waiting until for another chance to take the test again.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I failed the exam and entered the life of a failed student.
Context 1-JP: <jp>受験に失敗し、浪人生活に突入しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We are unable to comply with the request of a masterless samurai like you.
Context 2-JP: <jp>お前みたいな浪人の要求には応じられないな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: One of the meanings is the same as the kanji, <vocabulary>previously</vocabulary>, but it can also mean <vocabulary>already</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is different from what you learned with the kanji. But as I told you <vocabulary>already</vocabulary>, I'll be there on <reading>Su-day</reading> (<jp>すで</jp>). It's like Sunday, but not quite the same. Imagine your confusion when someone says this over and over, but you don't know what Suday is.
Context 1-EN: He had already left his office when I called him.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私が電話した時、彼は既に退社してしまってました。</jp>

Meaning: To Get Mixed Up In,To Get Mixed,To Be Mixed
Meaning Mnemonic: This one is a little strange. You have <jp>混む</jp> (To Be Crowded), <jp>混ぜる</jp> (to mix), <jp>混ざる</jp> (to get mixed), and now this: <jp>混じる</jp>, <vocabulary>To Get Mixed Up In</vocabulary>. It makes sense because it has to do with mixing, but how to differentiate from the rest? Well, for this one just imagine <reading>Je</reading>sus (<jp>じ</jp>) getting mixed up in a pot of soup. He's getting mixed up in this giant pot of soup because someone thinks that if they eat him, they'll gain his powers.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as (almost) all the other <jp>混</jp> verbs. All about mamamamama!
Context 1-EN: The message from the demon is a lie, but he will mix lies with the truth to confuse us.
Context 1-JP: <jp>悪魔からのメッセージは偽りだが、我々を混乱させるために嘘と真実が入り混じっている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji itself means <kanji>participate</kanji>, so you'd think this word would mean "to participate" but it doesn't (sorry!). It's a little more complex. Think of it as "to participate" but where you have <vocabulary>to come</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to go</vocabulary> in order to do it. This is the humble way to say those things, so you're going to these places with your tail between your legs, just happy you can participate more than anything.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You get <vocabulary>to come</vocabulary> to participate! "It's <reading>my</reading> (<jp>まい</jp>) lucky day!" you exclaim.
Context 1-EN: Let's go!
Context 1-JP: <jp>いざ、参らん！</jp>
Context 2-EN: This weekend I'm planning to visit my mom's grave.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今週末は、母のおはかに参るつもりです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I visit a Shinto shrine every day.

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>call</kanji> someone by <kanji>scream</kanji>ing, you're probably trying to <vocabulary>summon</vocabulary> them like a magician would. Magicians have to scream their spells out in order for them to work. So you have to scream out their name when you call them if you want to summon someone.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I summoned a magician.
Context 1-JP: <jp>魔法使いを召喚しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>hit</kanji>. What is one hit? It is <vocabulary>one strike</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>one stroke</vocabulary>, or simply <vocabulary>one hit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The ball landed on the green in one stroke.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ボールは、一打でグリーンにのりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In tennis, a shot to start a point is called "service."
Context 2-JP: <jp>テニスでは、さいしょの一打を「サービス」とよびます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Just one hit would turn the tables in our favor.

Meaning: To Approach,To Visit,To Drop In,To Stop By
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means approach, and the verb version is to approach, to visit, to drop in and to stop by.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you're too shy to approach people just learn how to use a yo-yo (よ)! Then people will approach you to compliment you on your sick skills. You won't have to do it yourself!
Context 1-EN: When I come home from school I plan on dropping by the library.
Context 1-JP: <jp>学校の帰りに、図書館に寄るつもりです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This <kanji>fever</kanji> is <kanji>violent</kanji>. This is the feeling you get when you have crazy <vocabulary>passionate enthusiasm</vocabulary>, aka you are <vocabulary> impassioned</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: She seems to be a passionate fan of yours.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女はどうやらお前の熱烈なファンみたいだな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>の</jp> particle makes it so the <jp>人</jp> belongs to the <jp>男</jp>. Basically, this literally means "a man person" or "a person of man." It's a more polite way to say plain old <vocabulary>man</vocabulary>, though, so all you have to remember is that.
Reading Mnemonic: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). That being said, in level 4 you learned about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.
Context 1-EN: Ah! Is that guy Suzuki?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ああ！この男の人が、すず木さんですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The lady next to the foreign guy standing over there is THE famous Kazuyo Matsui.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あそこに立っている外人の男の人のとなりにいる女の人があのゆう名なまつい一代さんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The tall guy is wearing a T-shirt and the short guy is wearing a sweater.
Context 3-JP: <jp>背の高い男の人はTシャツを着ていて、背の低い男の人はセーターを着ています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I'm going to <kanji>cut off</kanji> the part of me that I'm trying to <kanji>diagnose</kanji>... well, not literally cut off, but cut off my diagnosing. I have come to a conclusion. A <vocabulary>diagnosis</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My son was diagnosed with asthma when he was four.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の息子は四歳の時に喘息だと診断されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Pickle</kanji>d <kanji>thing</kanji>s are <vocabulary>Japanese pickled vegetables</vocabulary>! Or <vocabulary>tsukemono</vocabulary> if you've already been eating yummy pickled ginger, daikon, and umeboshi!
Reading Mnemonic: You already learned <jp>漬ける</jp> meaning "to pickle" so just take the <jp>る</jp> off there shove the <jp>け</jp> into the kanji. You read it still, but it's hiding. It probably shrunk in the pickling process. Stick some things (<jp>もの</jp>) on there are you know the reading! Not bad! By the way, sometimes you'll see this word spelled like <jp>漬け物</jp> too.
Context 1-EN: Who pickled these tsukemono?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この漬物は誰が漬けたんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Navigation</kanji> in the <kanji>sky</kanji> is <vocabulary>aviation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>flight</vocabulary>. Vroom vroom sky flying!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That airline company is adding a new route in April.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの航空会社は四月に新路線を増やす予定だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that a <jp>郵便</jp> is the <kanji>mail</kanji> and that a <jp>番号</jp> is a <kanji>number</kanji>. So a "mail number," what is that? Usually refers to your <vocabulary>post number</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>postal code</vocabulary>. It is also often referred to with a symbol, which is <jp>〒</jp>, so look out for that.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I haven’t memorized my new postal code yet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まだ新しい郵便番号を覚えていません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>cabinet</kanji> <kanji>colleague</kanji>s are the <vocabulary>cabinet ministers</vocabulary>. They're the people in the Cabinet that are all colleagues with each other. They just happen to be known as ministers.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He pretended that he was a cabinet minister, but it was such an obvious lie.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は閣僚のふりをしたが、嘘丸出しだった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Even something <kanji>dry</kanji> will <kanji>dry up</kanji> more if it's got <vocabulary>dehydration</vocabulary>. There's a lot of <vocabulary>dryness</vocabulary> going on here.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m wearing a mask to counter the dryness.
Context 1-JP: <jp>乾燥対策でマスクをつけています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>reef</kanji> in the shape of a <kanji>loop</kanji> is an <vocabulary>atoll</vocabulary>. If you don't know what that is, it's a <vocabulary>circular coral reef</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The Japanese tuna boat "S.S. Lucky Dragon 5" accidentally sailed around Bikini Atoll and the crew was exposed to radiation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その時、日本のマグロ漁船「第五福竜丸」がたまたまビキニ環礁を航行しており、乗組員が被ばくしてしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>normal</kanji> <kanji>steps</kanji> are the ones that are totally <vocabulary>usual</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ordinary</vocabulary>, unlike those weird not usual steps.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I apologized to my mother for not calling her more regularly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は普段殆ど電話をしないことを、母に謝りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You saw <jp>締める</jp>, which means "to tighten." So when things tighten, and then they get <kanji>cut</kanji> off, it's when you've reached the <vocabulary>deadline</vocabulary>. You know that feeling? When you get close, you feel a tightening in your stomach. The deadline is near! But, then when your tightening gets cut off completely, it's because you've reached the end. The <vocabulary>deadline</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>締める</jp> and <jp>切る</jp> put together. Notice how the hiragana bits get pushed into the kanji though, that's the interesting part, but also the part that's hard to remember. It's probably because this is a short version of <jp>締め切り</jp>, but you'll see <jp>締切</jp> more often.
Context 1-EN: Did you have any luck with putting the deadline off till tomorrow?
Context 1-JP: <jp>うまく締切を明日まで延ばせたの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Conserve</kanji> those letters with <kanji>abbreviation</kanji> and it's... an <vocabulary>abbreviation</vocabulary>! By using <vocabulary>omission</vocabulary> you were able to abbreviate that word into a smaller word.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I have to omit the details for now due to time constraints, but I’ll explain it to you later.
Context 1-JP: <jp>時間の都合上、今は詳細については省略せざるを得ませんが、また後ほどご説明させて頂きます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Seven ships are stopped in this harbor.
Context 1-JP: <jp>港には、七隻の船が止まっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Corner</kanji> <kanji>corner</kanji>s are still <vocabulary>corners</vocabulary>. Sometimes they're the corners TO corners, so they're the little <vocabulary>nooks</vocabulary> and crannies that are hard to get at.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice, with the second one rendaku'd. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Today I cleaned every nook and cranny of my room.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は部屋を隅々まで掃除しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>congratulate</kanji> someone and <kanji>celebrate</kanji> by saying <vocabulary>congratulation</vocabulary>s and having a <vocabulary>celebration</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: To show our congratulations, a toast!
Context 1-JP: <jp>慶祝の意を表して、乾杯！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: In order to <kanji>diagnose</kanji> a patient, you must first go <vocabulary>to examine a patient</vocabulary>. When you examine them you know what's wrong with them and then you can diagnose them, which is why this verb is <vocabulary>to examine</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>見る</jp>, which you have to do when you are examining a patient. So, you look and see all you can about the patient while you examine them, making this reading <reading><jp>み</jp></reading> as well.
Context 1-EN: I want a doctor to examine my baby to see if she’s growing well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>赤ちゃんがちゃんと育っているのか、お医者さんに診てもらいたいんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>select</kanji> to talk to <kanji>nothing</kanji> but <kanji>sand</kanji> for a really long time, you're <vocabulary>neglecting to contact</vocabulary> anyone else. Your relatives miss you! Stop talking to sand and call them!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I haven’t seen you in so long.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ご無沙汰しております。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The best way to <kanji>describe</kanji> your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s is with <vocabulary>lyricism</vocabulary>. Making a clear <vocabulary>description of feelings</vocabulary> is difficult, but it will make you feel better.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m studying to be able to cleverly describe my feelings.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うまく叙情できるよう勉強しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>南極</jp> is <kanji>Antarctica</kanji>, then the Antarctica <kanji>Range</kanji> is the area that makes up Antarctica. That's the <vocabulary>Antarctic Circle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Are there any animals other than penguins in the Antarctic Circle?
Context 1-JP: <jp>南極圏にはペンギン以外にも動物はいるんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>hard</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>hard</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to cut something that's extremely <vocabulary>hard</vocabulary> so you pull out your diamond <reading>cutter</reading>s (<jp>かた</jp>). Go ahead and imagine yourself cutting this ridiculously hard thing. Good thing you have diamond cutters, though.
Context 1-EN: The building the Tofugu office is in was built on solid ground.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグオフィスの入ったビルは、固い地ばんにたてられています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I chewed the tough beef, for some reason I realized just how insignificant I am and tears came to my eyes.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その固い牛肉をかんだ時、なぜか、自分がとてもちっぽけなそんざいであることを思い知って、なみだがこみ上がってきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'm telling this to you because you are a tight-lipped man, but I saw Aya touching Kinnikuma’s washboard stomach and rock-hard pecs.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたは口が固いから教えてあげるけど、私、アヤがキンニクマの洗濯板のような腹筋と岩のように硬い胸筋を触っているのを見ちゃったんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you're very tired and very giggly, you'll try to say your friend's name but start laughing right away so it ends up sounds like, "Hannah ha ha ha (はなは)."
Context 1-EN: If that sort of thing is true, I’m very sorry.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのようなことが事実だとすれば、甚だ遺憾である。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>worship</kanji> someone who is so <kanji>high</kanji> above you that you can't help but be in awe of their <vocabulary>loftiness</vocabulary>. Their <vocabulary>nobility</vocabulary> is the reason you feel like you should worship them in the first place.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was deeply moved by the noble beauty of nature.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自然の崇高な美しさに感動しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>ability</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is what you can do. This is your <vocabulary>ability</vocabulary>. It is also your <vocabulary>capability</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I have the ability to use Google very efficiently.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしには、グーグルをとてもこうりつてきに使う能力があります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The ability to write weird sentences is required to create WaniKani example sentences.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ワニカニの例文作りには、へんな文章をかく能力が求められる。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m a native English speaker, but my telepathic abilities are in Japanese.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は英語のネイティブスピーカーだが、日本語でテレパシーをする能力がある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Let me <kanji>transmit</kanji> to you a <kanji>theory</kanji>... a theory that perhaps a great <vocabulary>legend</vocabulary> is true.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You just have to remember that <jp>伝</jp> is read as <jp>でん</jp> in this case. Just imagine yourself sitting in your <reading>den</reading> (<jp>でん</jp>) as you get cozy and listen to this theory about a great <vocabulary>legend</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: When you hear "a legendary Irish hero," who comes to mind?
Context 1-JP: <jp>アイルランドの伝説の英ゆうと言われれば、だれを思いうかべますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Girls love you, man. You are legendary, seriously!
Context 2-JP: <jp>お前めちゃくちゃモテるな！マジで伝説的だよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: According to a legend, there is a fugu that eats tofu in this ocean.
Context 3-JP: <jp>伝説によると、この海には豆腐を食べるフグが住んでいるそうです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>How many</kanji>? <kanji>What</kanji>? In this area of <kanji>study</kanji>, you ask these questions a lot. This area of study is <vocabulary>geometry</vocabulary>, because you have to ask how many sides and how much the area is or something (can you tell I don't remember any maths?).
Reading Mnemonic: The <jp>学</jp> is read correctly, in terms of what you learned. The <jp>幾</jp> and <jp>何</jp> is weird, though. Just think how when you're asking a question in Japanese, you end the sentence with <jp>か</jp>. So, it's like, "<jp>何か</jp>????" and that's why it becomes <jp>か</jp>. Then, for <jp>幾</jp> think about how the <reading>key</reading> (<jp>き</jp>) to answering geometry questions correctly is figuring out "how many" sides something has. So, "do you have the <reading>key</reading><reading><jp>か</jp></reading>?"
Context 1-EN: Did you get an A+ on the geometry test? That’s amazing, you did really well!
Context 1-JP: <jp>幾何学のテストでAプラス取ったの？すごいじゃん、よくやったね！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Lightweight</kanji> <kanji>scorn</kanji>, no matter how light, is still <vocabulary>scorn</vocabulary>. Those feelings are pretty strong no matter what.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 軽 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have more scorn and disdain for the KKK (けい) than any other group in the whole world. And I'm not going to argue with you, they're pretty hatable.
Context 1-EN: I despise them.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私、あの人のこと軽蔑しているの。</jp>

Meaning: To Remain Behind,To Remain,To Stay Behind
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>remainder</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is "to remainder." Let's make that sound better: <vocabulary>to remain behind</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide <vocabulary>to remain behind</vocabulary>. Everyone else leaves, and you think you're alone. Then, someone <reading>knock</reading>s (<jp>のこ</jp>) on the door. Your heart jumps in your throat. They knock again.
Context 1-EN: Please stay behind if you think you're mysterious.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分がミステリアスだと思う人は、ここに残ってください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We left for Portland, but Koichi remained behind in Japan.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私たちはポートランドに向けて出発したが、コウイチはまだ日本に残っていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This will go down in history as the best Japanese learning material ever.
Context 3-JP: <jp>これは、今までにない最高の日本語学習教材として、歴史に残るでしょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: They <kanji>warn</kanji> you and they <kanji>guess</kanji> when you've done something wrong (with evidence, of course!). They are the <vocabulary>police</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The smell of umeshu hit my nose as I entered the police station.
Context 1-JP: <jp>警察署に入ると、梅酒のにおいが鼻をついた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That police officer sneered at Viet's warning, so he later found himself in a miserable situation.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その警察は、ビエトの警告をあざ笑ったため、後からひどい目にあいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: One hour after meeting at the police station, the police officer and the robber had completely hit it off.
Context 3-JP: <jp>警察署での出会いから一時間後、その警察官と泥棒はすっかり意気投合した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>cup of liquid</kanji> is equal to <vocabulary>one cup</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>one cup of liquid</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that <jp>一</jp> becomes <jp>いっ</jp>, and <jp>杯</jp> becomes <jp>ぱい</jp>.
Context 1-EN: "Let’s go for a drink." "Sounds like a plan."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「ちょっと一杯飲みに行かない？」「いいね。」</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I was a child, I watched a movie called "One Cup of Soba Noodles in Broth" just once.
Context 2-JP: <jp>子供の時に「一杯のかけそば」という映画を一度だけ観たことがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My mind was so full of the following year's budget that I didn't feel like having even one drink that night.
Context 3-JP: <jp>次年度の予算のこととで頭が一杯な状態だったので、その夜は一杯もお酒を飲む気にはなれなかった。</jp>

Meaning: Probably,Perhaps,Likely,I Dare Say,Maybe,As Likely As Not
Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fear</kanji> rock (<jp>らく</jp>) will <vocabulary>probably</vocabulary> come straight at your face. It's pretty <vocabulary>likely</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: The criminal is probably lurking in this area.
Context 1-JP: <jp>犯人は恐らくこの辺りに潜んでいるのでしょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> <kanji>letter</kanji> what do you have? Here's a hint, there's one kanji in this word that consists of one writing letter (aka a <vocabulary>straight line</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The girl got angry and her mouth pursed into a straight line.
Context 1-JP: <jp>女の子は、おこって口を一文字にむすびました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: After wiping moisture off the fish with paper towels, score the skin straight across.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ペーパータオルでさかなの水気をふきとったら、かわに一文字の切り目を入れてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The swans flew in a straight line from our bathtub to the lake.
Context 3-JP: <jp>白鳥たちは、うちの風呂場からその湖へ、真一文字になって飛んでいった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has <jp>曜日</jp> in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>water</kanji> day of the week is where the water flows from. Think of your entire week as a big hill, with Wednesday (hump day) being in the middle. This hump is a hill. What originates from hills? Water! That's why Water day is <vocabulary>Wednesday</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word <jp>曜日</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: We can split up what we have to do on Wednesday into three, big things.
Context 1-JP: <jp>水曜日にするべきことは、大きく分けて三つあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Every Wednesday after school I go to the pool and swim.
Context 2-JP: <jp>毎週水曜日は、学校の後プールに行って泳いでいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He got drunk out of his mind Wednesday night and was run over by a truck.
Context 3-JP: <jp>水曜日の夜、彼はかなり酔っていて、トラックに轢かれてしまったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Stone</kanji>s that form in your <kanji>guts</kanji> are <vocabulary>gallstones</vocabulary>. Sometimes you have to get them surgically taken out. Scary!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: With inflammation of the gallbladder, the most likely cause is gallstones.
Context 1-JP: <jp>胆嚢炎は、ほとんどの場合、胆石が原因です。</jp>

Meaning: To Work As,To Serve As,To Be Employed As
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>task</kanji> so what's the verb vocab version? Well, when you do a task, you are going <vocabulary>to work as</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to serve as</vocabulary> something to do that task.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

To work as my secretary, you will have to complete a task. A task where you bring me two toes (つと)! Don't ask me why! You want to serve as my assistant, right? Just get me those two toes then!
Context 1-EN: My father worked as a police officer for forty years until last year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父は去年まで四十年間警察官を務めました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi served an important role of taking care of aliens from various planets.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは色々な星からやってきた宇宙人をお世話するという大役を務めた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Mr. Tamura was employed as Ms. Tanaka’s private secretary for one year, but it didn’t really work out.
Context 3-JP: <jp>田村さんは田中さんの個人秘書を一年間務めたんだけど、あまりうまくいかなかったんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Remember the movie "<reading>Tonari</reading> (<jp>となり</jp>) no Totoro"? That is the Tonari.
Context 1-EN: We raised our children in a neighboring town, then my husband and I moved to this town after they grew up.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子育ては隣町でしてたんですが、子どもたちがみんな大きくなったので主人と私はこの町に越して来たんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>element</kanji> of <kanji>clear up</kanji> (like the sky clearing up!) is so <vocabulary>wonderful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>splendid</vocabulary>. Sort of a weird word, but very useful. Just think of that wonderful feeling you get when the sun breaks and things clear up and it's awesome.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird, too. Luckily, you've learned both of them already. <jp>晴れる</jp> is <jp>はれる</jp>. That's the reading you use here, though <jp>は</jp> goes to <jp>ば</jp>.
Context 1-EN: "Don’t sell yourself short like that. You’re a magnificent woman."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「そんな風に自分を安売りしないで。君は素晴らしい女性だよ。」</jp>

Meaning: To Get Dry,To Become Dry,To Be Dried
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dry</kanji>. This verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to get dry</vocabulary>. You're not doing the drying, it's just happening. That's <reading>coo</reading>', you say, things can get dry.
Reading Mnemonic: The <reading><jp>川</jp></reading> (<jp>かわ</jp>) has started <vocabulary>to get dry</vocabulary>. Need to use less water around here otherwise it'll become completely dry.
Context 1-EN: Our laundry hasn’t dried yet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>洗濯物はまだ乾いていません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>fear</kanji>? <vocabulary>Scary</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>frightening</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>I'm afraid</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>I'm scared </vocabulary> too.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You know what's really scary? Koalas (こわ). Have you ever heard one of those things? They're super scary, don't go near them.
Context 1-EN: My mother is the scariest in the world.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺の母親は世界で一番恐い。</jp>

Meaning: To Sleep,To Go To Bed,To Lie Down
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lie down</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to lie down</vocabulary>, but what you're really doing is trying <vocabulary>to sleep</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. So, you can go ahead and lie down for a moment before moving on to the next item.
Context 1-EN: Alright, I’m gonna go to bed. Sleep well. See you in the morning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>よし、そろそろ寝るね〜。おやすみ〜。また明日〜。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>detach</kanji>, but what happens when something detaches? It causes it <vocabulary>to separate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to leave</vocabulary>. This refers to when something separates on its own. You aren't doing the separating. You know this because it's <reading>rare</reading> (<jp>れる</jp>) to see things separate, but sometimes you do see them. Also, whenever you see <jp>れる</jp> usually it's a safe bet that you're not the one doing the action, right? Think about it.
Reading Mnemonic: For the reading, think about what is separating. It's quite sad, because all of the <reading><jp>花</jp></reading>s (<jp>はな</jp>) are separating from their stems and falling on the ground, and nobody knows why. Just falling off and being sad.
Context 1-EN: Being away from my parents and living by myself was easier than I thought.
Context 1-JP: <jp>親元から離れて一人暮らしをすることは思っていたよりも簡単でした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Who do you know that will <kanji>use</kanji> a <kanji>pole</kanji> to stop someone from breaking your <kanji>heart</kanji>? Your <vocabulary>bodyguard</vocabulary>! He's there to make sure no one hurts you, and for some reason he really likes using a pole to do it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Will you work as my bodyguard?
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の用心棒をしてくれない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also mean <vocabulary>flour</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You have this great ice cream... that is, until your cone (こな) turns to powder, and your ice cream falls to the ground. A sonic boom powdered your ice cream cone, and left you very messy.

You can also use こ for this kanji. Just imagine that the powder breaks down even further, and all that is left of the reading is こ. This reading feels a bit older, but it's still a-okay.
Context 1-EN: I’ve been eating too many flour-based foods lately.
Context 1-JP: <jp>最近私は粉ものを食べ過ぎています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What is a <kanji>skill</kanji>? It's something you can do, and do quite well. It is a <vocabulary>technique</vocabulary> that you can make happen with ease.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You do your <vocabulary>technique</vocabulary> on a bad guy, coming at you. You flip him over and knock him out. He <reading>was</reading> (<jp>わざ</jp>) a threat, but now he's not. You look closer at the bad guy. Turns out it's <reading>Woz</reading>, the Apple Co-founder. He was just trying to hand you an iPhone12, not grab your wrist. Whoops!
Context 1-EN: You've mastered tricky art like that one, have you?
Context 1-JP: <jp>これはまたきわどい技をマスターしたね！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Is Koichi teaching Nikka a new trick?
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチはニッカに新しい技を仕こんでいるんですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: In judo, technique is more important than strength.
Context 3-JP: <jp>柔道では力より技のほうが大切であります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Thing</kanji>s with <kanji>value</kanji> have <vocabulary>prices</vocabulary>. This is just the general prices of things. In other words, the <vocabulary>prices of commodities</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cost of living</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>ぶつ</jp> changes to <jp>ぶっ</jp>, though, so hopefully that doesn't change the price you're willing to pay for this vocab? Right? Please give me your money.
Context 1-EN: In Japan, it seems that prices have begun to go up.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本では、物価が上がり始めたようだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It's <kanji>possible</kanji> to <kanji>love</kanji> this thing. It's so gosh darn <vocabulary>cute</vocabulary>! Any really cute thing is possible to love.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is screwed up, though if we're lucky, you already know the word for cute. It seems to have injected itself into American and English culture a decent amount, anyways. If you are one of the lucky ones, you'll know that this word is read as <reading><jp>かわいい</jp></reading>. If you're not, think of the cute thing being a cow. Then you say, "that <reading>cow</reading>" (<jp>かわい</jp>), or "that cow is good" because it's so cute.
Context 1-EN: Koichi speaks in a cute voice, don't you think?
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチって可愛い声で話すよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Who does this cute baby belong to?
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの可愛い赤ちゃんはだれの子ですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Fugu: S-Salmon...? Wow what a, what a cute name. Salmon: You think so? I’ve always kinda hated it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグ: サ…サーモンっ？へーっ...す、すっごく可愛い名前だね。 サーモン: そう思う？ 私はずっと自分の名前があまり好きじゃないんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>guts</kanji> feel like they're <kanji>fall</kanji>ing when you experience a lot of <vocabulary>discouragement</vocabulary>. You know that sinking feeling you get in the pit of your stomach? That's your guts falling!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My son failed an exam and is discouraged.
Context 1-JP: <jp>息子は、受験に失敗して落胆しているんだ。</jp>

Meaning: Japan And South Korea,South Korea And Japan,Japan And Korea,Korea And Japan
Meaning Mnemonic: With the <jp>日</jp> of <jp>日本</jp>, the <jp>日</jp> means <kanji>Japan</kanji>. Then, you add <kanji>Korea</kanji> into the mix and you have Japan + Korea. This word means <vocabulary>Japan and South Korea</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>South Korea and Japan</vocabulary> (depending on where you're from, I guess).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This custom is frequently seen in both Japan and Korea.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この風習は日韓両国でよく見られます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading here is the same as the kanji reading!
Context 1-EN: Last night, I just about died on blowfish poison.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨日の晩はフグの毒にあたって死ぬところでした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi has appeared in my dreams every night for the last three days, and he whispers in my ear that I will be unhappy if I don't purchase WaniKani.
Context 2-JP: <jp>三日前の晩から毎晩コウイチがゆめに出てきてわたしにWanikaniを買わない不こうになると耳打ちするんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Hey, why don’t we go for a drink tonight?" "Sorry, I’m staying sober now."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「よお！今晩、飲みに行かないか？」「ごめん。今、禁酒中なんだよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>inside</kanji> <kanji>ditch</kanji> is the inner ditch, or, if you make it awesome enough, the <vocabulary>inner moat</vocabulary>. If they get through the outer moat, we have the inner one, at least!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi / vocab readings of these kanji. <jp>内</jp> + <jp>堀</jp> added into one word.
Context 1-EN: I stepped aside to let him pass through to the inner moat.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は彼を内堀に通すために道をあけた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The process of <kanji>reject</kanji>ing <kanji>water</kanji> and letting it go somewhere else is called drainage.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I dropped the commemorative coin down the drain.
Context 1-JP: <jp>記念硬貨を排水溝に落っことしちゃった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>ditch</kanji> is the ditch around our town that's on the outside (not the inside ditch, which is the inner moat). This is the <vocabulary>outer moat</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the same readings from the previous vocabulary except that <jp>堀</jp> gets rendakued - don't forget!
Context 1-EN: I’ve changed my mind, I don’t think we need an outer moat.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちょっと気が変わって、外堀は必要がないようと思うようになりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you are saying <kanji>congratulation</kanji>s and also giving your <kanji>condolence</kanji>s then they are <vocabulary>congratulations and condolences</vocabulary>. Pretty easy, right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Do you have ceremonial dress for celebration and condolences?
Context 1-JP: <jp>慶弔用の礼服は持っているのか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If a <kanji>parent</kanji> is <kanji>friendly</kanji> enough you can form a <vocabulary>friendship</vocabulary> with them, not just a kid/parent bond.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We are preparing for a party to strengthen our friendship.
Context 1-JP: <jp>親睦を深めるためのパーティーを準備しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>surprised</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be surprised</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: What are you so surprised by? Your friend's <reading>odor</reading> (<jp>おどろ</jp>). Think of a friend that you wouldn't expect to be so smelly. Then, be surprised by the odor. Eww, bro, you have to take a shower.
Context 1-EN: "Fugu? Is that you, Fugu?" "Salmon? I’ll be damned. I haven’t seen you since high school. How are you?"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「フグ？お前、フグか？」「サーモンか？こいつは驚いた。高校以来だね。元気かい？」</jp>

Meaning: To Shake,To Shiver,To Quake,To Tremble,To Quaver,To Quiver
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>earthquake</kanji> so the verb means <vocabulary>to shiver</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary>, like you would if there was an earthquake happening right now.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You start to shake in an earthquake because you're really full (ふる) from eating lunch. Now your full belly is shaking and quaking with the ground! Ahh it's awful! You never want to be full again!
Context 1-EN: My alcoholic father’s hands always shake.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アル中の父の手は、いつも震えていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A person <kanji>request</kanji>s something, so you are the one <vocabulary>to take</vocabulary> it. You're really nice <vocabulary>to accept</vocabulary> their request. What a nice person you are!
Reading Mnemonic: What's another word for "to accept" or "to receive"? How about <jp>受ける</jp>? They share a reading!
Context 1-EN: I only took this job so that you could save face.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お前の顔を立てるためだけにこの仕事を請けたんだからな。</jp>

Meaning: To Wake Someone Up,To Wake Up,To Wake Someone
Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen <jp>起きる</jp> which is "to wake up." This is similar, except you are doing the waking up, which makes the meaning of this word <vocabulary>to wake someone up</vocabulary>. How do you differentiate between this and <jp>起きる</jp>? Because of the <jp>す</jp> on the end. You wake someone up violently, wrenching their neck. They turn around and <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) you, making you wish you never woke them up.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>起きる</jp>, so as long as you know that word you should be able to read this one. Of course, you can also imagine them yelling "OH!" when you shake them awake too, if that helps.
Context 1-EN: I tried really hard to wake you up, but it didn't work.
Context 1-JP: <jp>折角起こしてあげたのに、意味なかったね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We don't want to wake our sleeping baby, so please don't buzz the intercom.
Context 2-JP: <jp>赤ちゃんを起こしたくないので、インターホンは鳴らさないでください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You are absolutely correct, Viet! We should definitely wake Koichi up right now!
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビエットが100%正しいよ。今すぐコウイチ起こすべきだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: To remember this reading, just think about what your mommy did for you when you were little and you got yourself a <vocabulary>wound</vocabulary>... she would <reading>kiss</reading> (<jp>きず</jp>) the wounds better. Of course, that never worked and was a total farce, but try to forgive mommy this one time, okay?
Context 1-EN: I got a scratch on my ukulele.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ウクレレに傷がついちゃったんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You have your bow and you use it to shoot things, sure, but you've also covered it in candy so you can eat it when you're waiting out in the woods waiting for a buck to come by. You lick your candy bow and say: "<reading>yummy</reading>!" (<jp>ゆみ</jp>). Imagine the taste of your bow. What taste would make you say yummy?
Context 1-EN: We can't find Koichi's bow anywhere.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチの弓がどこにも見当たらないんだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You have to stabilize your upper body to draw the bow.
Context 2-JP: <jp>弓を引くには、まず上半身を安定させなくてはいけません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Yeah, Lawson is open 24/7, but, you know, I don’t think they carry bows and arrows.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うん、ローソンは確かに二十四時間営業だよ。でもさぁ、あのー、多分弓と矢は置いてないと思うよ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>view</kanji> of you is your <vocabulary>external appearance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I like the outward appearance of this apartment.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このアパートメントの外観が好きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is my <kanji>territory</kanji>. This is my <kanji>region</kanji>. This is my <vocabulary>domain</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Everyone has to take a step into unknown territory to progress.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰でも、前進するためには未知の領域に足を踏み入れなくてはいけない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stuffed</kanji>, this word means <vocabulary>to stuff in</vocabulary>, as in you're doing the stuffing. You know that this is the case because when it comes to the <reading>mail</reading> (<jp>める</jp>), you stuff that mail into the garbage as hard as you can (it's all junk).
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should have no troubles here.
Context 1-EN: Can you put some rice in my bento box for me?
Context 1-JP: <jp>お弁当にご飯を詰めといてくれない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>scary</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>scary</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You know what's really <vocabulary>scary</vocabulary>, like double scary (because kanji and vocab both mean scary)? How about your <reading>cowo</reading>rkers (<jp>こわ</jp>). They are all insane, and you know it. Absolute nutjobs they are.
Context 1-EN: It seems that a magnitude 7 earthquake occurred on Mars. Scary!
Context 1-JP: <jp>火星でマグニチュード7の地震が起きたんだってさ。怖いね！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>迷う</jp> means "to go astray" or "to get lost?" Well when you feel like you're about to go astray or get lost it causes <vocabulary>hesitation</vocabulary>. You end up with a lot of <vocabulary>doubt</vocabulary> about where to go or what to do. It's a natural progression.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned this reading already when you learned <jp>迷う</jp>! Just swap the <jp>う</jp> for an <jp>い</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I managed to get rid of my hesitation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>なんとか迷いを断ち切りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>compose</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to compose</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You want to compose a poem but all you have for inspiration is what's in your pocket. You reach in and find a yo-yo (よ). Ah yes, this will do. So you compose a poem about your yo-yo:

One string to rule them all, One string to find them, One string to- hey wait a minute...
Context 1-EN: People who compose haiku are called haijin.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俳句を詠む人のことを俳人と呼びます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>pray</kanji> and <kanji>request</kanji>. This is your <vocabulary>prayer</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I'm praying for my visa to be issued without any issues.
Context 1-JP: <jp>無事にビザが取れるよう、祈願しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi can do the war dance of the Martians.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、火星人の戦勝祈願のおどりをおどることができます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "May Salmon’s surgery go well," Fugu prayed to God.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「サーモンの手術が上手くいきますように！」と、フグは神様に祈願した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is put on people's names, though most likely you'll only see this when someone is being sarcastic or if you're watching a samurai TV show. "<jp>おはようございます！こういち殿！</jp>"
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Who is your great <vocabulary>lord</vocabulary>? Imagine it being someone named <reading>Don</reading> (<jp>どの</jp>). If you know a Don, that's great, imagine that person. If you don't, think of a famous Don that's out there.
Context 1-EN: Please tell Lord Nobunaga.
Context 1-JP: <jp>信長殿にお伝え頂きたい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>gallop</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to gallop</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We burst out laughing when we saw the teacher dashing down the hallway with his arms folded.
Context 1-JP: <jp>先生が腕を組んだまま廊下を駆けて行くのを見て、大笑いしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>resident</kanji> <kanji>detain</kanji>ed in a location who is in the <kanji>army</kanji> is a member of the <vocabulary>stationed troops</vocabulary> at this location. They could also be the <vocabulary>occupying troops</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Is there a laundry service for the stationed troops?
Context 1-JP: <jp>駐留軍向けの洗濯サービスとかはありますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>普遍</jp> means "universal?" Well when you add <kanji>like</kanji> it's still <vocabulary>universal</vocabulary>! Easy!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I think it’s a really universal theme.
Context 1-JP: <jp>とても普遍的なテーマだと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What's that feeling when your <kanji>belly</kanji> <kanji>stands</kanji> up? It's that feeling where something jumps up into your throat (in this case your belly) and you get all pissed off. This word means <vocabulary>to get mad</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are <jp>腹</jp> plus <jp>立つ</jp> put together. The <jp>たつ</jp> becomes <jp>だつ</jp>, though.
Context 1-EN: It makes me so mad. They are in the way of our practice!
Context 1-JP: <jp>本気で腹立つんだけど。練習のジャマだわ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>merchandise</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> <kanji>street</kanji> is a street with all kinds of shops and merchandise on it. Sounds like a lot of shopping goes on here in this <vocabulary>shopping district</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My brother is a complete moron. Yesterday, he went out to get some milk in the shopping district so he could try and drink milk with his nose, but he got lost there and ended up not buying it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の弟は正真正銘の馬鹿だよ。昨日、鼻で牛乳を飲んでみたかったみたいで、商店街に牛乳を買いに行ったんだけど、そこで道に迷って結局牛乳買わずじまいだったんだから。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>go beyond</kanji> so the verb vocab version is also <vocabulary>to go beyond</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading can come from <jp>越える</jp>. So if you know that you know this too!
Context 1-EN: How can I be taller than 6.5 feet like NBA players? I’m 6 feet now and I want to surpass that.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうすればNBA選手のように身長が6.5フィートを越すのでしょうか。今、6フィートなのですが、6.5を越したいのです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dye</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to dye</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You need <vocabulary>to dye</vocabulary> something that you just <reading>sew</reading>ed (<jp>そ</jp>) together. It's all sewed and looks like a shirt, but it's colorless. That's where the dying comes in.
Context 1-EN: I’m wondering what color to dye my hair.
Context 1-JP: <jp>髪を何色に染めるか迷っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen that <jp>旅行</jp> is "trip." So who is <kanji>someone</kanji> who goes on trips? That is a <vocabulary>tourist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>traveler</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the reading of <jp>旅行</jp> already.
Context 1-EN: At first, I thought the traveler was unsociable, but when I tried talking to her, I discovered she was actually very interesting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>最初、ぶあい想な旅行者だなぁと思ったんだけど、話をしてみると意外におも白い人だったのよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Normally we would not do this, but since you are a tourist, we'll comply with your request.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ふだんはこういった対おうはいたしませんが、旅行者でいらっしゃるということですので、今回は特別に対おうさせていただきます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey, look, look. Don’t you think that tourist is wearing clothes that are completely unsuitable for her age?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ねぇ、見て見て。あの旅行者の服装、全然年相応じゃないと思わない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A young <kanji>woman</kanji> who is planting rice from <kanji>early</kanji> morning into the <kanji>latter</kanji> evenings is a <vocabulary>rice planting girl</vocabulary>. You'll see them out there all day long, from dawn till dusk, planting, taking care of, and picking rice.
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a really weird exception, sorry. You've kind of learned these reading, but they're like... weird variations of them.

Take the さ from 早速, the おつ becomes おと, and then the 女 kun'yomi め (hey that one's normal!). And you get さおとめ. You might need to just memorize this one.
Context 1-EN: Long ago, women who planted rice seedlings were called Saotome or Ueme.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昔は稲の苗を水田に植えつける女性のことを「早乙女」や「植女」と呼んでいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Okay, only <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>response</kanji> for that, and that is that <vocabulary>tentatively</vocabulary> we have an agreement... <vocabulary>for now</vocabulary>. Just think of the one response you have, and that one response is to just get everyone off your back, so you agree with them... for now.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: For now I made a backup of all the data on this hard drive, just in case.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一応念のため、全データのバックアップをこのハードディスクに取っておきました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>secrecy</kanji> <kanji>transport</kanji> is when you transport something in secrecy. If you don't want people to know what you're transporting, you'll have to resort to <vocabulary>smuggling</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was asked to smuggle narcotics once.  Of course I refused.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺は一度麻薬の密輸をする話を持ちかけられたことがあるよ。もちろん断ったけどね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>test</kanji> that tries to find <kanji>truth</kanji> is an <vocabulary>experiment</vocabulary>. This is because you don't know the truth, so the only way to find it is to try things out and test them. Thus, experiment!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Take note that the <jp>つ</jp> in <jp>じつ</jp> is turned into a small <jp>っ</jp>, though.
Context 1-EN: I borrowed a car for an experiment.
Context 1-JP: <jp>実験のために、車を一台借りました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We experimented to find out what things we could say to make Viet angry.
Context 2-JP: <jp>どんなことを言ったらビエトがおこるのか、実験してみた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Who wants to be a guinea pig for the experiment for our new fugu flavored tofu project?
Context 3-JP: <jp>私達の新製品「フグ風味の豆腐」の実験台になりたい人はいますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: A person who entices or lures another person is called decoy in English, sakura in Japanese, and troll on the internet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>相手の気を引いたりうまく釣ったりする人のことを英語ではデコイと言うが、日本語では桜、ネット用語では釣りと言う。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Preface</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is the <vocabulary>preface</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I usually skip a book’s preface.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私はいつも本の序文は飛ばします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A person whose <kanji>idea</kanji>s are <kanji>ground</kanji>ed in <kanji>evil</kanji> is a <vocabulary>malicious</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>mean</vocabulary> <vocabulary>jerk</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This reading is a combination of the on'yomi readings for <jp>意</jp> and <jp>地</jp>, and the kun'yomi reading for <jp>悪</jp>. You've learned them all already, so this should be cake!
Context 1-EN: Don't waste your precious time on such a jerk.
Context 1-JP: <jp>折角の時間をあんな意地悪なやつのためにむだにするなんてもったいないよ。</jp>

Context 3-EN: Why are you so mean to my little sister?!
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうして妹に意地悪ばっかりするの！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Secret</kanji> and <kanji>secrecy</kanji>. Combine the two and you have quite the <vocabulary>secret</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Your secret is safe with me. My lips are sealed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>秘密は誰にも言わないよ。ちゃんと、口にチャックしておくよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You'll have to learn this word in two parts. You already know the meaning of <jp>今</jp> because of the kanji, which means "now." The <jp>すぐ</jp> part, however, is a new word, meaning "soon." The two words even start with the same "soo" sound. If you put these two together, you get "now soon." Put in better English, that's <vocabulary>at once</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>right now</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since you already know the vocab word <jp>今</jp> (read <jp>いま</jp>), you should be able to read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: Let's go meet them right away.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今すぐ、会いに行きましょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You can read season 1 of TextFugu right now for free.
Context 2-JP: <jp>テキストフグのシーズン１なら、むりょうで今すぐよめますよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Be quiet and come over at once!
Context 3-JP: <jp>いいから黙って今すぐ来い!</jp>

Meaning: Reason For Living,Something Worth Living For
Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>甲斐</jp> is "effect" or "worth." So, the "worth for being alive" is your <vocabulary>reason for living</vocabulary>. It gives life worth. It's your reason for living.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>甲斐</jp> and <jp>生き</jp>, so if you know those you may have a <vocabulary>reason for living</vocabulary>, or at least a reason for doing your kanji study.
Context 1-EN: Rock climbing is what I live for.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ロッククライミングは私の生き甲斐です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>bee</kanji>'s <kanji>honey</kanji> is its <vocabulary>honey</vocabulary>, honey.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: She took a bite of my honey pudding.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は私の蜂蜜プリンを一口味見しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>invade</kanji>d and <kanji>damage</kanji>d me. You are doing <vocabulary>infringement</vocabulary> on my territory. This is a <vocabulary>violation</vocabulary> of me.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Banning facial hair is a human rights violation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>髭を禁止することは人権侵害です。</jp>

Meaning: Government Management,Government Operation,Run By The Government,Government Run
Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Manage</kanji>d by the <kanji>government</kanji>? Then it is run by <vocabulary>government management</vocabulary> or it is a  <vocabulary>government operation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Context 1-JP: <jp>日本郵政をどうして官営から民営に変える必要があったのか、未だに分かりません。</jp>

Meaning: To Panic,To Hurry,To Rush,To Be Upset
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>confused</kanji> or <kanji>bewildered</kanji> but this is usually just used when someone starts <vocabulary>to panic</vocabulary>. They're so confused and bewildered that they try <vocabulary>to hurry</vocabulary> through things.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Whenever you start to panic you can't help but blurt out, "A wha- (あわ)?" to everything people say and ask. For example, "Would you like a mint?" "A WHA?!" Yeah, you really do sound upset.
Context 1-EN: Please don't rush—just drive safely.
Context 1-JP: <jp>慌てないで、安全運転をお願いします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I panicked, thinking there was a fire, and threw some water, but it was just a candle.
Context 2-JP: <jp>火事だと思い、慌てて水をかけたら、ただのロウソクだった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>和</jp> represents Japan? Now, take that and add <kanji>translate</kanji> to it. With that, you have <vocabulary>Japanese translation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Aside from some minor mistakes, I think your Japanese translation was pretty good.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いくつか小さな間違いはあるものの、うまく和訳できていると思いますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>company</kanji> <kanji>expense</kanji> is a <vocabulary>company expense</vocabulary>. These are nice, by the way, if you can get them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m studying Japanese at my company’s expense.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は社費で日本語を勉強させてもらっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>surpass</kanji> the <kanji>past</kanji> then you're going backwards in time (at least if you're coming from the "present.") If this is the case, then you are definitely in the <vocabulary>past</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My eyes have never watered from onions before.
Context 1-JP: <jp>玉ねぎが目にしみたことは過去に一度もありません。</jp>

Meaning: Move The Capital,Transfer The Capital,Relocation Of The Capital
Meaning Mnemonic: If you want to <kanji>transition</kanji> the <kanji>capital</kanji> to a new, better place, you need to <vocabulary>move the capital</vocabulary>. This used to happen a lot way back in Japanese history. It's actually pretty interesting so you might want to read up on it!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Next year an event is being held for the 1500 year anniversary of the relocation of the capital.
Context 1-JP: <jp>来年は、遷都1500年記念のイベントが開催されます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you make a <kanji>duplicate</kanji> <kanji>copy</kanji> you are <vocabulary>copying</vocabulary> things. You are making a <vocabulary>duplication</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You can keep the original, but we’ll take a copy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一枚目はお手元にお持ちください。私達は複写の方を頂きますね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fur</kanji> <kanji>cloth</kanji> isn't something you'd just throw away. You'd probably turn this warm fur cloth into a nice <vocabulary>blanket</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My mom reminded me not to forget my blanket.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母が、毛布を忘れないようにすることを思い出させてくれました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Can you put the blanket in the cardboard box?
Context 2-JP: <jp>その毛布、ダンボール箱に入れてもらっていい？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t imagine myself washing one hundred blankets every day.
Context 3-JP: <jp>毎日毛布を百枚も洗うなんて想像もつかないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
Remember how 嫌い is to dislike? When that dislike is big, you really dislike it. That means you hate (or really hate) it.

As with 嫌い, a more literal translation is detestable.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the reading for <jp>大</jp>, and the reading for <jp>嫌い</jp> is like the one you learned with <jp>嫌い</jp> in level 20.
Context 1-EN: What food do you really hate?
Context 1-JP: <jp>大嫌いな食べ物は何ですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that there are some people in the world who hate Tofugu.
Context 2-JP: <jp>世の中には、トーフグのことが大嫌いな人もいるらしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Mr. Viet will meet with you instead of Mr. Koichi because Mr. Koichi really hates you.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチはあなたのことが大嫌いなので、彼に代わってビエトがお会いします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>凹凸</jp> means "uneven?" Well spin something uneven around and it's still <vocabulary>uneven</vocabulary>! Just kinda backwards, just like this word!
Word Type: noun,する verb,な adjective,の adjective
Reading Mnemonic:
However, just because the meaning stays the same when you flip it, doesn't mean the reading does. Doing that actually made the reading change from on'yomi to kun'yomi readings! You haven't learned either of these yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you have the convex parts first and the concave parts second in something uneven is ends up looking like a deco box (でこぼこ). An art deco box that is. They have lots of stuff stick out of them on the outside, but you can open them up and put stuff on the inside.
Context 1-EN: I’m worried that the floor is a little uneven.
Context 1-JP: <jp>床がちょっと凸凹しているのが気になるね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>idea</kanji> of <kanji>sincerity</kanji> is <vocabulary>sincerity</vocabulary>. It's also to have <vocabulary>good faith</vocabulary> in others.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: After hearing her sincere explanation, I decided to give her the benefit of the doubt this time around.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誠意のこもった説明が聞けたので、今回は彼女の言い分を聞いて上げることにしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What's the verb form of <kanji>request</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>to request</vocabulary>. It also is for when you want something (<vocabulary>to want</vocabulary>), because when you request something you probably want it.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What is it that you want? You want a <reading>moat</reading> (<jp>もと</jp>) around your home. Your neighbor's cats keep pooping on your lawn, but if you had a moat they wouldn't be able to get to your lawn in the first place, since cats hate water (and alligators). You request a moat!
Context 1-EN: Tofugu wants a person who has a poker face.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグは、ポーカーフェイスができる人を求めています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Sometimes we get emails requesting refunds.
Context 2-JP: <jp>時々、返金を求めるメールがとどきます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Increasingly, Tofugu clients are demanding environmentally friendly Japanese learning products.
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguの顧客は、ますます環境に優しい日本語学習製品を求めるようになってきている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You are <kanji>float</kanji>ing above everything, at least that's how your <kanji>spirit</kanji> feels. You're having an <vocabulary>affair</vocabulary>, and feel like nothing will catch you but... wait, what's that? Is that your wife? Oh no... not floating anymore, you're not.
Reading Mnemonic: This kanji uses the kun'yomi read for the first kanji, and the on'yomi reading for the second. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too.
Context 1-EN: "So he had an affair and then blamed it on you for not having a cellphone?" "That about sums it up."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「彼は浮気をして、それを携帯電話を持っていないあなたのせいにしたってこと？」「要約するとそんなところね。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Self</kanji> <kanji>defense</kanji> is when you protect yourself. It's <vocabulary>self defense</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Is it legal to murder someone in self defense?
Context 1-JP: <jp>自衛のための殺人は合法なのでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Warm</kanji> <kanji>warm</kanji> is <vocabulary>warm</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This winter is unusually cold and we have had tons of snow, so is the earth really getting warmer?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今年の冬は例年よりも寒くて雪も凄く降ったけど、本当に地球は温暖化してるのかね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It's <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>again</kanji>? Well, if it's already now, then it's <vocabulary>now</vocabulary>. It's also <vocabulary>too late</vocabulary> to do what you want to do... if it was the past, then maybe it would have been okay.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the vocab words <jp>今</jp> and <jp>更に</jp>'s <jp>更</jp> put together.
Context 1-EN: It may be a little late, but I started carrying around my own pair of chopsticks.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今更ですが、マイ箸を持ち歩き始めました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>illuminate</kanji> and then <kanji>bake</kanji> some food. To illuminate it, you put on some shiny sauce. Then, you cook it. Sound familiar, in terms of a type of food? This is <vocabulary>teriyaki</vocabulary>, though I have to warn you it's quite different from what you get at "teriyaki shops" in the west.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>照る</jp> and <jp>焼く</jp>. Put them together and you have something delicious.
Context 1-EN: "Have you got everything, Koichi?" "Yes, mom." "Oh, wait. I forgot to put the teriyaki salmon in your bento box." "What! Hurry, mom!"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「コウイチ、忘れ物は無い？」「無いよ。」「あ、ちょっと待って。あんたのお弁当に照り焼きサーモン入れるの忘れてたわ。」「ええっ！母さん、早くしてよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Clothes</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> are still <vocabulary>clothes</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You stole your girlfriend’s clothes, didn’t you?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたが彼女の衣服を盗んだんですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>eternity</kanji> that is <kanji>far</kanji> away is not really an eternity, it just feels like it. It's <vocabulary>forever</vocabulary>, but not the real kind of forever that's actually forever. That's <jp>永久</jp>, which is a real forever, this is more like "whoa, I haven't eaten sushi in forever" (actually, you have).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Will you never come back to Japan again?
Context 1-JP: <jp>もう永遠に日本には帰ってこないの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: If I won the lottery, I would build my own castle in the back yard.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし宝くじが当たったら、裏庭に自分のお城を建てるね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Halt</kanji> and <kanji>stop</kanji>. When something does this, it's in a <vocabulary>stoppage</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My brother once went into cardiopulmonary arrest, but his heart started beating again after the surgeon performed a cardiac massage.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の兄は一度心肺停止にまで至ったんですが、外科医が心臓マッサージを施した後に、心臓が再び脈動しだしたんです。</jp>

Meaning: To Get Dirty,To Get Polluted,To Become Dirty
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dirty</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to get dirty</vocabulary>. You know you're not doing the dirtying, because it's <reading>rare</reading> (<jp>れる</jp>) for you to get anything dirty, though things do get dirty on their own.
Reading Mnemonic: Things seem <vocabulary>to get dirty</vocabulary> easily around here, which is why <reading>you go</reading> (<jp>よご</jp>) to great lengths to keep things clean.
Context 1-EN: I don’t recommend white controllers because they get dirty easily.
Context 1-JP: <jp>汚れやすいので白いコントローラーはお勧めしません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>push</kanji> things to make them <kanji>enter</kanji> the <vocabulary>closet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cupboard</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>押し</jp> (push the <jp>し</jp> inside the <jp>押</jp>) plus <jp>入れる</jp>'s reading.
Context 1-EN: I’ve done nothing but think about her since the day I kidnapped her and locked her up in my closet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女を誘拐して押入れに閉じ込めたあの日から、僕はずっと彼女のことばかり考えているんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you tasted the air at a <kanji>recital</kanji> the <kanji>flavor</kanji> would taste like <vocabulary>scrutiny</vocabulary>. That's really what everyone is doing when they watch. They don't really want to hear you, they just want to judge you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I want to decide on a spouse after a lot of careful investigation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>結婚相手はよく吟味してから決めたい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Things you <kanji>sell</kanji> that <kanji>pass through</kanji> the world to get to you are probably <vocabulary>mail order</vocabulary>. You order them and they get zoomed off to you, passing through all kinds of space to arrive at your door.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’ve never bought anything through mail order before, but I’ll give it a shot.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今まで通販で買い物したことないけど、ちょっとやってみるよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Happy,To Be In High Spirits,To Be Elated
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>浮く</jp> means "to float," and <jp>浮かれる</jp> draws on that metaphor of "floating" to mean <vocabulary>to be happy</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be in high spirits</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be elated</vocabulary>. We have the same metaphor in English — think of being "on cloud nine."
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>浮く</jp>, so if you know that you' are going <vocabulary>to be happy</vocabulary> and you won't have a <reading>care</reading> (<jp>かれる</jp>) in the world!
Context 1-EN: Many people get too carried away by the olympics.
Context 1-JP: <jp>たくさんの人がオリンピックに浮かれすぎている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>become</kanji> <kanji>exploits</kanji>... as in, your exploits become a thing you can actually see, and you can see them in the form of <vocabulary>grades</vocabulary>. Ouch, some of your exploits weren't all that amazing...
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My grades have gotten a lot better thanks to my personal tutor.
Context 1-JP: <jp>家庭教師の先生のお陰で、成績がグンと上がりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>individual</kanji> <kanji>peoples</kanji> <kanji>party</kanji> is the political group that believes in each individual of the people (or something?). The translation doesn't really get hinted at in this meaning, but this group is the <vocabulary>Liberal Democratic Party</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>LDP</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Our Liberal Democratic Party is hot stuff this year. Nobody would call us the Loopy Democratic Party anymore.
Context 1-JP: <jp>我らが自民党が今年は熱いな。もう誰も我々のことを「愚民党」なんて呼ぶことはないだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>East</kanji> <kanji>Asia</kanji> is <vocabulary>East Asia</vocabulary>! That's where Japan is!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why is the Pacific War called The Greater East Asian War?
Context 1-JP: <jp>太平洋戦争のことを、大東亜戦争と呼ぶのは何故ですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>挙がる</jp>, which means "to rise"? Well, this word means <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to elevate</vocabulary>, and this time you're the one doing the raising.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>挙がる</jp>, so if you know that reading you should know this one as well.
Context 1-EN: I held my wedding ceremony in city hall, but I’m not ashamed of that.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は結婚式を市役所で挙げましたが、そのことを恥ずかしいとは思っていません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The prime minister's (<jp>総理</jp>) <kanji>government</kanji> is where he does all his governmenting. It's where the <vocabulary>Prime Minister's office</vocabulary> is located as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know <jp>総理</jp> beforehand as well.
Context 1-EN: I knew nothing about her except that she worked in the prime minister’s office.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女のことについては、総理府で働いているという以外には何も知らなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>excel</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to excel</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.
