You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "<reading>He-e</reading> (<jp>ひい</jp>) is going <vocabulary>to excel</vocabulary>," you stutter. "He-e is!"
Context 1-EN: The only thing I excel at is picking my nose. In fact, I have never made my nose bleed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は鼻くそをほじくることだけには秀でています。実際、鼻血を出すはめになったこともありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
You should congratulate a person who speaks lots of dialects because they have to be a really strong person, just like Mr. Benkei was. You think learning Japanese is hard now, just wait till you hear Osaka-ben and Hokkaido-ben. It takes a really strong person — a Benkei — to learn all those dialects, so congratulate them and tell them how strong they are!

弁慶 is the name of a Japanese historical figure who was really strong, so Benkei is the Japanese equivalent of Hercules or Achilles in Western languages.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Benkei and Ushiwakamaru fought at Kiyomizu Temple.
Context 1-JP: <jp>弁慶と牛若丸は清水寺で戦いました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: A person who is arrogant at home but submissive outside the home is called an "uchi-benkei".
Context 2-JP: <jp>家では威張っているが、外では従順になる人のことを「内弁慶」と言う。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The shin is known as "Benkei's weeping spot" because, if you hit it, it hurts so much that even someone as strong as Benkei would shed tears.
Context 3-JP: <jp>むこうずねは、ぶつけると弁慶ほど強い人でも涙を流すほど痛いことから、「弁慶の泣き所」といわれています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen <jp>動く</jp> hopefully, and know it means <vocabulary>to move</vocabulary>. This is similar to that, but now you're moving something else. You know this because as you go <vocabulary>to move something</vocabulary> the thing you're moving starts to <reading>cuss</reading> (<jp>かす</jp>) you out because it's angry.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this can come from <jp>動く</jp>. If you know that word, you know how to read this word!
Context 1-EN: Almost all of my friends can push and move a truck with their hands.
Context 1-JP: <jp>友だちのほとんどが、トラックを手でおして動かすことができるよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi suddenly got up, started sleepwalking, and tried to move the massive grand piano.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチったら、急にむくっと起き上がって、ねぼけてあのきょ大なグランドピアノを動かそうとしだしたんだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t move my legs anymore because of that motorcycle accident.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あのバイク事故のせいで、もう脚を動かすことができなくなっちゃったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sick</kanji>ness that can <kanji>transmit</kanji> and then <kanji>dye</kanji> into you (aka get inside you and infect you, via transmission) is a <vocabulary>contagious disease</vocabulary>. Everyone cover their mouths when they cough and sneeze, and please wash your hands, okay?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What is the most dangerous infectious disease in the world?
Context 1-JP: <jp>世界で一番危険な伝染病は何ですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>follow</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to follow</vocabulary> (it's also <vocabulary>to chase</vocabulary>, because when you follow something you are chasing it too).
Reading Mnemonic: You've learned this reading already, so you should know how to read this word!
Context 1-EN: In Japan, there is a proverb that says, "If you chase after two hares, you will catch neither."
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本には、二とを追うものは一とをもえず、ということわざがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi is always following the latest trends.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、いつも最新のりゅう行を追っている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I will keep following my dreams, no matter how hard it gets.
Context 3-JP: <jp>どんなに大変でも、私は自分の夢を追い続けるつもりなの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>電</jp> is what powers electric things. Many times, these electric things light up (especially back in the day, when electricity did this a lot more than other things). So, you have "lighting." Then, you have <kanji>decorate</kanji>. So, if you decorate with lighting, you have <vocabulary>decorative lighting</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I heard that you use power strips for decorative lighting to eliminate wasted energy, but you might overload the circuits so it’s dangerous.
Context 1-JP: <jp>省エネのために電飾にOAタップを使ってるって聞いたんだけど、タコ足配線にするのは危ないわよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>child</kanji> <kanji>servant</kanji> is a <vocabulary>child</vocabulary>. Children are basically like little servants anyways, what else are they good for?
Reading Mnemonic:
The readings for this one are the kun'yomi readings of each kanji. 子 is just こ, like the individual vocab word. 供 is ども, however. Remember this by thinking how much children love domo-kun.

Also, 子ども is kind of more "politically correct" with the kana hanging off there. 子供 is still used in a lot of situations, usually stiff ones. The second kanji means servant, and some people don't like that. The second version pops up a decent amount, so it's good to be familiar with that as well.
Context 1-EN: Your child is way too good looking, I can hardly believe he’s your kid.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お前の子供、イケメンすぎて、お前の子供だとは思えねーよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>What</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji>? This doesn't make any sense. One thing you'll notice with Japanese and kanji is that <jp>何</jp>, when added to other things, often means "how many _____" rather than "what ____." Just something you have to know and experience a bit to catch on to, but you will, I believe in you. So, for this one it's <vocabulary>how many times</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word with a slightly unique reading, where the first kanji uses the kun'yomi reading and the second uses the on'yomi reading. You've seen these readings before, so you should be able to read this alright.
Context 1-EN: Including this time, how many times have you come to Japan?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本へ来るのは、今回で何回目ですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This video is so funny that I have to watch it a bunch of times.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このビデオ、おもしろすぎて何回も見てしまうわ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How many times do we have to have this conversation until it finally sinks in? I am not Luke Skywalker. I played him in a movie. My name is Mark. I live in Chicago.
Context 3-JP: <jp>事をはっきりさせるまでに、いったい何回この会話を繰り返さないといけねえんだよ？だから俺はリューク・スカイウォーカーじゃねえんだよ。映画でその役を演じただけだっつーの。俺の名前はマークだ。シカゴに住んでる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Let's <kanji>departure</kanji> on our <kanji>dig</kanji>ging up of this site. It is more than just digging, we're going somewhere and learning new things with this dig. This is an <vocabulary>excavation</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the <jp>発</jp> getting shortened.
Context 1-EN: Would you like to do a part-time job in fossil excavation? It'll be fun!
Context 1-JP: <jp>化石発掘のバイトをしてみませんか。楽しいですよ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Until about 30 years ago, iron ore could be found in this mine.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この鉱山では三十年ほど前まで鉄鉱石が発掘できました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The talent was discovered through a star search audition.
Context 3-JP: <jp>そのタレントはスター発掘オーディションで発掘されました。</jp>
Context 4-EN: One day, he excavated a large number of old Greek treasures while digging for gold.
Context 4-JP: <jp>ある日、金を求めて穴を掘っていると、大量の古代ギリシャのお宝を発掘しました。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Lit,To Be Ignited,To Be On,To Come On
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji 点 means point, but this verb actually means to be lit or to be ignited. Think of it this way, when a flashlight turns on, it points a beam, of light.

You already learned 点ける, which is for when you turn something on. 点く, on the other hand, is an intransitive verb. That means it happens by itself. Like, "Oh look! The lights came on! That's cool (く)!"
Reading Mnemonic:
You already learned this reading when you learned 点ける but here's a mnemonic just in case:

Every time you count to two (つ) a light comes on. How cool (く) that it does it all by itself!!
Context 1-EN: The TV turned on by itself.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ひとりでにテレビが点いた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The lighter wouldn't ignite and it irritated me!
Context 2-JP: <jp>中々ライターが点かなくて、イライラした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My motorcycle light comes on now.
Context 3-JP: <jp>バイクのライトが点くようになった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>cable</kanji> but this word refers to more of a <vocabulary>rope</vocabulary>, which is pretty similar.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading used here is the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Have you heard of the guy who walked a tightrope between two hot air balloons?
Context 1-JP: <jp>二つの気球の間を綱渡りした男の人の話はもうお聞きになりましたか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Every</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is <vocabulary>daily</vocabulary> (or just <vocabulary>every day</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I study every day at a Japanese language school.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは日本ご学こうで、毎日べんきょうしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm commuting from Nagoya to Americamura in Osaka every day.
Context 2-JP: <jp>名古やから、大さかにあるアメリカ村に毎日かよっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I eat anywhere between 17-21 cheeseburgers every day.
Context 3-JP: <jp>毎日17から21個のチーズバーガーを食べます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>最新</jp> is, as you can probably guess, "the newest." So, the newest <kanji>sharp</kanji> thing, is the <vocabulary>cutting edge</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>state of the art</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Once, a little while ago, 3D printers were cutting edge machines.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かつて、少し前までは、3Dプリンタは最新鋭の機械でした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>decorate</kanji> your <kanji>spirit</kanji> with a bunch of pretty things like streamers and balloons, people will think you're just <vocabulary>showing off</vocabulary>. Yes, you know your spirit is awesome, but everyone else doesn't want it pushed in their face with your over the top decorations.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since the first part of this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned how to read the かざ part already with the 飾る vocabulary.

The second kanji uses the on'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading for 気 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

At the height of showing off, you bend one arm to your hip and the other out in the air. You pretend to be a kettle (け). You show off your spirit to all your friends singing "I'm a little ke-ttle, short and stout. Here is my handle, here is my spout. EVERYONE LOOK HOW GREAT I AM!" Your kettle dance is sure to impress them.
Context 1-EN: She’s a really plain woman.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつは本当に飾り気のない女だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji, so it has the same meaning, basically. You can say this is <vocabulary>the most</vocabulary> or just <vocabulary>most</vocabulary>. You can also use it as <vocabulary>extremely</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji (the kun'yomi reading). To learn it, let's look at a mnemonic.

Think of the most ridiculous motto (もっと) you've ever heard. Now imagine a motto that's even more ridiculous. Here are some actual totally real mottos that are the most ridiculous: "What Can Brown Do for You?" "It's Not for Women" "If It Doesn't Get All Over the Place, It Doesn't Belong in Your Face" and of course, "Why Not Enjoy the Go?"
Context 1-EN: The summer solstice is the shortest night of the year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>げしとは、一年で最も夜がみじかくなる日のことだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Mt. Fuji is the tallest mountain in Japan.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ふじ山は日本で最も高い山です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you know what he ate tonight? He went to an all you can eat yakiniku restaurant. We’d better prepare for the smelliest farts imaginable. Better safe than sorry.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼、今日の夜何食べたか知ってる？焼き肉食べ放題に行ったんだよ。最も臭いおならに備えておいた方が身のためだよ。用心に越したことはないんだから。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>cherry blossom</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is what color? Kind of a <vocabulary>pink</vocabulary>, wouldn't you say? Also, pink can be <jp>ピンク</jp>, if you want it to be.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the readings for <jp>桜</jp> and <jp>色</jp> combined.
Context 1-EN: I saw a picture of me in a full-fledged pink tux when I was two or three years old.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分が二歳か三歳の頃に、一丁前に桜色のタキシードを着てる写真を見ました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>present time</kanji>, but you can't "to present time." If you try to do present time, the best you can do is try <vocabulary>to show</vocabulary> it. Kind of a weird connection, but if you think through it a couple times it might get better.
Reading Mnemonic: Do you remember learning <jp>現れる</jp>? This has the same exact pronunciation!
Context 1-EN: I knew that she would show her true colors in the end.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は最後には本性を現すと思ってたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>consolation</kanji> of a <kanji>problem</kanji> is when I show my <vocabulary>condolences</vocabulary>. It is my <vocabulary>sympathy call</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We visit a nursing home with therapy dogs every Sunday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私達は毎週日曜日、セラピー犬たちと一緒に老人ホームを慰問します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>consolation</kanji> so now you can <kanji>relax</kanji>. What a great feeling this is. You now have <vocabulary>solace</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>relaxation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Our company has a mandatory recreation trip every year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの会社では、毎年強制参加の慰安旅行があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>courteous</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji> is a <vocabulary>friendly chat</vocabulary>. We all know that "friendly chats" are never what they seem, though... right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We are holding a friendly get together for the apartment residents on October 22.
Context 1-JP: <jp>来る10月22日に、マンションの住人の皆様との懇話会を予定しております。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word takes the <kanji>reason</kanji> meaning of the kanji, making it <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary>. What's the reason for it having two meanings? You've got me, I have no clue.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What's your reason to wake (わけ) up this morning? Think about it. Now think of your reason to wake up tomorrow. What is it?
Context 1-EN: Can you tell me the reason why you tried doing a handstand over the toilet?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして便器の上で逆立ちをしようとしたのか訳を聞かせてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who <kanji>float</kanji>s and <kanji>wander</kanji>s from place to place is a <vocabulary>vagrant</vocabulary>. They don't really have a home, but they keep hanging around yours. It's kind of annoying. (This word has a negative connotation, you wouldn't use it for someone who is just homeless, unless you're really mean.)
Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 浮 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

All the vagrants you know are fools (ふ). They just left their homes and now they float around your city for no reason. You ask them why and they shrug. You've never seen a better definition of a fool before in your life!
Context 1-EN: 70% of vagrants do some kind of work and earn a daily cash income.
Context 1-JP: <jp>浮浪者でも7割の人は何らかの仕事をして日銭を稼いでいる。</jp>

Meaning: To Follow,To Stick With,To Stick To,To Go Through
Meaning Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>貫く</jp> meaning "To Go Through" and <jp>通す</jp> meaning "To Let Pass." So when you're trying to go through an area and also let someone pass with you, you start <vocabulary>to follow</vocabulary> them. Not intentionally, but you're both trying to go through at the same time so you decide <vocabulary>to stick with</vocabulary> them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of two words you already know, so you should already know this too!
Context 1-EN: He stuck to his beliefs until the end.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は最後まで自分の信念を貫き通しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>part</kanji> <kanji>split</kanji> is when things split into two parts. This is a <vocabulary>split</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>division</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I thought the political party was split three ways, but it was actually split four ways.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その政党は三派に分裂したと思っていたんだけど、実際は四派に分裂していたんだね。</jp>

Meaning: Year After Next,The Year After Next
Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>next year</kanji> (<jp>来年</jp>), but then you do a year <kanji>again</kanji>. That's the <vocabulary>year after next</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We should propose a two-year contract that lasts until the year after next.
Context 1-JP: <jp>再来年まで継続する二年契約を提案するべきではないでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>courteous</kanji> <kanji>parent</kanji> is a parent who knows when a kid needs a friend. Then, they set their kid up with you so that you can have a <vocabulary>friendship</vocabulary>. What a nice parent the other person is!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: There will be a friendly reunion after the company’s stockholders’ meeting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その会社の株主総会の後には、懇親会があります。</jp>

Meaning: For The Time Being,First Of All,At Once,Immediately
Meaning Mnemonic: If you only <kanji>take</kanji> <kanji>daring</kanji> and you don't have any yourself, you only have it <vocabulary>for the time being</vocabulary>. It will go away if you can't make it yourself.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for the kanji. You learned both of these already, so you should be able to read this with no problems!
Context 1-EN: Edamame and beer for now please.
Context 1-JP: <jp>取り敢えず枝豆とビールをください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>If</jp> <jp>冷やす</jp> is "to chill something," then this would be the version where something is just chilled. You're not doing the action of chilling anything, it's just that way. You know this because if you get involved, there's always some kind of chilling <reading>err</reading>or (<jp>える</jp>). So, you step back and let the fridge do its job without messing.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>冷やす</jp>. Know that and you know this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m really sensitive to the cold, especially my feet which are always cold.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は冷え性で、特に足がいつも冷えています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how you learned that <jp>惜しむ</jp> means "to be sparing?" Well if you make that negative with <jp>ない</jp>, then you're doing it <vocabulary>without sparing</vocabulary> anything instead.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, so you should be able to read this already too!
Context 1-EN: I think it’s important to spare no effort in fulfilling your goals.
Context 1-JP: <jp>目的を成し遂げるには、努力を惜しまないことが大切だと思います。</jp>

Meaning: To Catch Fire,To Catch On Fire
Meaning Mnemonic: When something <kanji>attach</kanji>es a <kanji>burn</kanji> to something that something is about <vocabulary>to catch fire</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is the readings of <jp>燃える</jp> and <jp>付く</jp> put together.
Context 1-EN: My bangs caught fire during a chemistry experiment.
Context 1-JP: <jp>化学の実験をしている最中に、前髪に火が燃え付いた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>instant</kanji> <kanji>interest</kanji> in something you didn't have interest in before? Well, time for some <vocabulary>improvisation</vocabulary>, because you're going to have to pretend you have interest in it (since you don't actually).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening of <jp>そく</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Everyone told him that his impromptu poem was great, but it was obviously just lip service.
Context 1-JP: <jp>みんなは彼が即興で作った詩をすごいねと褒めたが、口先だけなのは見え見えでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

It is I! Due to my ego, I love the Wii and no other gaming device. I love playing all the Wii-ware (われ) that's available, and everything else sucks.
Context 1-EN: I hate how he acts as if he doesn’t care.
Context 1-JP: <jp>我関せずって感じのアイツの態度、超嫌なんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <jp>軍艦</jp> is a <kanji>battleship</kanji>, and <jp>島</jp> is an island. Welcome to... <vocabulary>Battleship Island</vocabulary> (go Jurassic Park music).
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi readings for <jp>軍</jp> and <jp>艦</jp>, and the kun'yomi reading for <jp>島</jp>. You learned all of them, so you should know the reading already! Oh, but watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: He isn’t interesting at all. All he talks about is the urban legend of Battleship Island.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アイツはぜんぜん面白くないな。話題といったら軍艦島の都市伝説だけだし。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>漏れる</jp> is "to leak," then this is when you do the leaking yourself. The reason this thing is leaking, though (and it shouldn't be), is because you <reading>rush</reading>ed (<jp>らす</jp>) the job (because you did it yourself), which is why you know this is <vocabulary>to leak something</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>漏れる</jp>, so if you know that, you know this! Don't let that memory leak from your head.
Context 1-EN: Bloody hell! I’m just totally fed up with your behavior, Fugu. Why do you wet your pants all the time? Oh, don’t tell me again that you are from the ocean. I’ve heard enough of the same excuses.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もう限界だ！君の行動にはうんざりだよ、フグ。どうしていつも小便を漏らすんだ？ああ、また海出身だからなんて言わないでくれよ。君のお決まりの言い訳はもう聞き飽きているからね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I will <kanji>chastise</kanji> you and give you <kanji>penalty</kanji>. I do this as a <vocabulary>discipline</vocabulary>. A <vocabulary>punishment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Violators will receive punishment.
Context 1-JP: <jp>違反者には懲罰が与えられる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It is <kanji>alone</kanji> and <kanji>special</kanji>. Nothing is like it. It is very <vocabulary>unique</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: These spices have a unique aroma.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この香辛料は独特の香りがする。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is different from the one you learned (this is kun'yomi). There's an easy way to remember it, though. <jp>一人</jp> and <jp>独り</jp> share the same readings and mean almost the same thing. Just try to remember that this <jp>ひとり</jp> is used to emphasize solitude and independence.
Context 1-EN: He lives alone.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は独り住居だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>運動</jp> means "exercise?" When you <kanji>meet</kanji> with a bunch of other people to exercise it's called <vocabulary>Sports Day</vocabulary>! This is a day at schools in Japan where everybody does physical stuff together! It's fun and also very tiring!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The bad weather spoiled Sports Day, which we had really been looking forward to.
Context 1-JP: <jp>悪天こうで、折角楽しみにしていた運動会が中止になってしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I hope it’s sunny on the day of the sports festival.
Context 2-JP: <jp>運動会の日、晴れるといいですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We were surprised that on the morning of Sports Day, there were parents asking if we could change it to tomorrow just because they couldn't make it that day.
Context 3-JP: <jp>運動会の日の朝に、今日は都合が悪いから運動会を明日に変えることはできないかって聞いてきた親がいて、びっくりしたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.
Context 1-EN: You have to cut the grass soon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そろそろ草をからなくてはなりません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I don't have money, so I live by eating grass.
Context 2-JP: <jp>お金がないから草をたべて生きています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Why does my neighbor have such green grass? And why is his house so big?
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうして隣の人の草はあんなに青いんだろう。どうして彼の家はあんなに大きいんだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>drawing</kanji> <kanji>corridor</kanji> is a corridor in which there are drawings hanging up on the wall. This is a <vocabulary>picture gallery</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: She opened her own picture gallery.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は自分の画廊を開いた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>ゆ</jp> comes from <jp>湯</jp>, which is "hot water." So a "hot water <kanji>egg</kanji>" Is a <vocabulary>boiled egg</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji.
Context 1-EN: If you think I stole your boiled egg, you’re barking up the wrong tree.
Context 1-JP: <jp>僕が君のゆで卵を盗んだと思っているのなら、とんだお門違いだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have to pay a <kanji>fee</kanji> for the <kanji>material</kanji> you use to make food. Those are the <vocabulary>ingredients</vocabulary> you're paying for! Imagine making a list of all of the materials you need to make a stew, then making sure you have enough to pay the fees, so you'll have all the ingredients you need to make it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He's the person in charge of material prep.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かれが材料調たつのたん当者です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please pour two parts water for one part of the ingredient.
Context 2-JP: <jp>材料の二倍の水を入れてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My favorite food is udon noodles and the ingredients are just wheat flour, salt, and water.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の好きな食べ物は饂飩ですが、麺の材料は、小麦粉と塩と水だけなんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>scold</kanji> and the verb vocab version also means <vocabulary>to scold</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: When I got double eyelid surgery done, I was harshly scolded by my parents because I hurt the face I inherited from them.
Context 1-JP: <jp>二重瞼の整形手術をした時、親から貰った顔に傷をつけたと両親からこっぴどく叱られました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Mail</kanji> (or <kanji>post</kanji>) has <kanji>convenience</kanji> because it is sent for you in the <vocabulary>mail</vocabulary> (or the <vocabulary>post</vocabulary>!).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading of <jp>便</jp> (<jp>びん</jp>) in this vocabulary is an exceptional reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. You get a lot of junk mail so you throw it in the waste <reading>bin</reading> (<jp>びん</jp>). The waste bin is where junk mail goes.
Context 1-EN: Madam, we have mail for you!
Context 1-JP: <jp>おくさーん、郵便ですよー！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Efficiency and speed are everything in mail service.
Context 2-JP: <jp>郵便業においては、効率とスピードが全てだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I wonder if I should ship this by airmail or sea mail.
Context 3-JP: <jp>こう空郵便で送るか、船便で送るかまよっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>過ぎる</jp> is to surpass... <jp>過ごす</jp> is <vocabulary>to spend time on</vocabulary>... for some reason. I suppose if you surpass something or someone, you must spend time to do it.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>過ぎる</jp>. Time to surpass this kanji? Or, maybe it's time <vocabulary>to spend time on</vocabulary> it instead.
Context 1-EN: Our electricity stopped because we fell three months behind on our utility bill, so we had to spend the hot day without an air‐conditioner.
Context 1-JP: <jp>電気料金の支払いが三ヶ月遅れて電気を止められちゃって、あのクソ暑い日をエアコン無しで過ごさなきゃならなかったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>world</kanji> of <kanji>acting</kanji> <kanji>ability</kanji> is the world of <vocabulary>showbusiness</vocabulary>. Save yourself some letters, honey, and call it <vocabulary>showbiz</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I went all the way to Tokyo, but I couldn't get in to the showbiz industry.
Context 1-JP: <jp>折角東京まで行ったのに、芸能界には入れなかった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My daughter tends to make decisions on the fly, and now she's saying that she wants to work in show business.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしのむすめは思いつきで物事を決めがちなんですが、今度は芸能界で働きたいって言い出してるんですよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m not interested in the gossip of the world of show business. I couldn’t care less.
Context 3-JP: <jp>芸能界のゴシップなんて全然興味ねーよ。どうでもいいっつーの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>push</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to push</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, actually!
Context 1-EN: I’m sorry, I forgot to punch my timecard this morning. What should I do?
Context 1-JP: <jp>すみません。今朝タイムカードを押し忘れちゃったんですが、どうすればいいですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The most important part of your <kanji>military</kanji> <kanji>attire</kanji> are your <vocabulary>arms</vocabulary> (not the ones attached to your body, your guns and stuff). Arms are what make you a real military person.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It seems that they were attacked by armed insurgents.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうやら、武装勢力に襲われたようだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're so <kanji>healthy</kanji> it puts you at <kanji>ease</kanji>. That's your <vocabulary>health</vocabulary>! So healthful, go you!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Is company-paid health insurance included in the fringe benefits?
Context 1-JP: <jp>会社側が負担する健康保険は、諸手当の中に含まれているのでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>puzzle</kanji> <kanji>puzzle</kanji> is a <vocabulary>puzzle</vocabulary>, but it's also a <vocabulary>riddle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>enigma</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Pretty much all kids like solving riddles, right?
Context 1-JP: <jp>子どもはみんな謎々遊びをするのが好きだろう。</jp>

Meaning: To Despise,To Disdain,To Make Light Of
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>despise</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to despise</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Think of all the things you start to despise and to disdain. Now come up with some anecdotes (あなど) for each one of those things. Be sure to think in your head, "I'm coming up with anecdotes for things I disdain, why am I coming up with anecdotes?"
Context 1-EN: You shouldn’t make light of it just because it’s a child.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子供だからといって侮らない方がいい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Constant</kanji> <kanji>example</kanji>s that you use all the time end up becoming part of an <vocabulary>established practice</vocabulary>. You constantly use them so it just stays that way after a while.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It is an established practice at my company to have a Christmas party every year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの会社では、毎年恒例のクリスマス会があるんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>livelihood</kanji>. The verb version is <vocabulary>to live</vocabulary>. It's not really "to live" literally, though. It's more like <vocabulary>to live one's life</vocabulary>, rather than just to live.
Reading Mnemonic: If anyone is going <vocabulary>to live one's life</vocabulary>, it's gotta be the great <reading>Ku</reading>blai Khan (<jp>く</jp>). He conquered most of the world and was super badass.
Context 1-EN: He is living a happy life now, but he actually experienced a lot of hardships.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は今は幸せに暮らしているが、ああ見えて苦難を経験してるんだぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>hair</kanji> <kanji>model</kanji> is how you model your hair. It's your <vocabulary>hairstyle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hairdo</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the vocab readings of the individual kanji. For <jp>髪</jp> that's no problem. For <jp>型</jp> just remember that it's the individual vocab reading. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: Your hairstyle looks like the Beatles’.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビートルズみたいな髪型だね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Settle in</kanji> to the <kanji>business</kanji>. You've been here a while and you have <vocabulary>employment</vocabulary> now.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We meet on a monthly basis to discuss employment regulations.
Context 1-JP: <jp>就業規則についての話し合いをするために、 私たちは月一のペースで会っている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>効果</jp> means "effect"? Add <kanji>~like</kanji> to that and it's <vocabulary>effective</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Performance based salaries are the most effective and fairest ways to attract good workers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>成果主義の給与制度は、良い社員を引き込む最も効果的で公平な方法である。</jp>

Meaning: To Investigate,To Examine,To Research,To Look Into,To Search
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>investigate</kanji> so the vocab verb version means <vocabulary>to investigate</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You are hired to investigate someone's wife. It is said that she loves (しら) another man... but you need to investigate her to find out if that's true, for her husband of course.
Context 1-EN: This afternoon, I looked up things about the war at the library.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日の午後は、としょかんでせんそうについて調べました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When the police investigated inside Koichi's car, a drunken blowfish came out.
Context 2-JP: <jp>けいさつがコウイチの車の中を調べると、中から酒によったフグが出てきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Can you research capybaras and see if they are edible?
Context 3-JP: <jp>カピバラが食べられるのかどうか、ちょっと調べてくれない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What do people usually <kanji>scatter</kanji> in a rush (<jp>らし</jp>)? <vocabulary>Leaflet</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>flyer</vocabulary>s. Handing them out takes way too much time, so if you just scatter them all over the place your job will be done so much faster!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the <jp>散る</jp>, so you should be able to read it already!
Context 1-EN: Don’t you leave supermarket fliers here?
Context 1-JP: <jp>スーパーの散らし、ここに置いてなかった？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>お</jp> just makes the word more polite. Since tea is so important in Japan, it gets the <jp>お</jp>. Otherwise, you should be able to figure out the meaning as it's the same as the kanji.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi reading, just like you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I didn’t drink tea.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしはお茶をのみませんでした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I want to eat bacon rice covered in tea before I die.
Context 2-JP: <jp>死ぬ前に、ベーコンのお茶づけが食べたい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t drink tea anymore because it makes me fart.
Context 3-JP: <jp>何故かおならがしたくなるので、もうお茶を飲むことはできない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: How much can you hold in this <kanji>ladle</kanji>? Why, exactly <vocabulary>eighteen liters</vocabulary> of course! Eighteen is your favorite number, how convenient.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Do you have a bag of 18 liters of rice?
Context 1-JP: <jp>一斗のお米が入った袋は置いてますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be used to refer to a <vocabulary>noble girl</vocabulary> as well, as in a girl of the noble family.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Okay, so from now on we have to call her Princess Aya?
Context 1-JP: <jp>わかったわ。じゃあ、これからはアヤのこと、アヤ姫って呼ばないといけないの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When something is <kanji>hand</kanji> <kanji>made</kanji>, it is <vocabulary>handmade</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. Just think of this word as two separate words put together (<jp>手</jp> and <jp>作る</jp>). The <jp>る</jp> in <jp>作る</jp> gets changed to <jp>り</jp> because it's an adjective, and the <jp>つ</jp> in <jp>つくり</jp> gets changed to <jp>づ</jp> because of the way the words are combined with each other. You should know most of the reading that is in this word, though it will probably take a little bit of thinking to sort out the little changes in those readings.
Context 1-EN: This table was handmade by Hayashi.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このテーブルは、林さんの手作りです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I try to have a homemade, well-balanced diet every day.
Context 2-JP: <jp>毎日手作りのバランスのいい食じをとるようにしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Handmade presents are pretty scary because they reveal that you have too much free time.
Context 3-JP: <jp>手作りのプレゼントは、どれだけ暇な時間があるかってことがバレてしまうので、結構怖い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

You may have the ability to taste things now, but just wait until you get up there in age (あじ). You'll find that the tastes and flavors you once liked will become bland, and you'll need a lot of Sriracha to make things taste better.
Context 1-EN: I hope the flavor will suit your tastes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>味がお口に合うといいんですが。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's past the expiration date, so it might not taste the same, but I think it's still edible.
Context 2-JP: <jp>しょう味きげんをすぎたから、味はちょっとかわってるかもしれないけど、まだ食べられると思うよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This blowfish sashimi tastes is amazing! Just what I wanted!
Context 3-JP: <jp>このフグの刺し身の味、最高だよ！まさにこれだって感じだね！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>How many</kanji> <kanji>occurence</kanji>s is just another way of asking <vocabulary>how many times</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.
Context 1-EN: Even though he failed many times, he didn’t give up.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は、幾度失敗しても、諦めなかった。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Added To,To Join In
Meaning Mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji 加 means add, and this verb means to be added to or to join in.

It is an intransitive verb, like most verbs ending in わる. That means that it happens by itself, or at least the cause of the adding is not you. Something gets added to something else, perhaps by magic?
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 加える. To help you distinguish between the two, remember that most verbs ending in わる are intransitive.
Context 1-EN: A new character will be added soon!
Context 1-JP: <jp>もうすぐ新しいキャラクターが加わるよ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: A monkey joined in the volleyball match.
Context 2-JP: <jp>サルがバレボールの試合に加わった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The cost of advertising will be added to the ten million yen for the ingredients.
Context 3-JP: <jp>材料の一千万円に、さらに広告のコストが加わる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>cave in</kanji> where everyone <kanji>die</kanji>s is still a <vocabulary>cave in</vocabulary>, just a really sad one.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It looks like that highway over there collapsed from the earthquake.
Context 1-JP: <jp>地震であそこの道路が陥没したそうです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have a <kanji>rest</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> you have a <vocabulary>holiday</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the <jp>日</jp> reading is the alternate reading, <jp>じつ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I watched a bunch of movies over the holiday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>休日は、えいがを見ることがおおいです。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>たのしい休日をすごしてくださいね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I spent the holiday in my tree house.
Context 3-JP: <jp>休日をツリーハウスで過ごした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cry</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to cry</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. If you remember the kanji reading you'll have no problem with this word.
Context 1-EN: Aww. I'm so happy I'm about to burst into tears!!
Context 1-JP: <jp>ヤバイ。うれしすぎて、泣きそう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's shameful that I cried onstage in public.
Context 2-JP: <jp>情けないことに、晴れのぶ台で泣いてしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m crying because my salary was cut. I want to transfer to a higher paying job.
Context 3-JP: <jp>減給になっちゃって泣いてます。もっと給料のいい会社に移りたいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You are doing a <kanji>set up</kanji> of something. It's a nice little noun sort of situation, where the word doesn't make too much sense. So, you set yourself up. To do this, you set up a <vocabulary>stance</vocabulary> to fight your opponent.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is like <jp>構う</jp>, so as long as you know that you know this too.
Context 1-EN: In Muay Thai, your battle stance is the most important thing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ムエタイではあなたの打撃の構えが最も重要な事である。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you can't (<kanji>not</kanji>) <kanji>believe</kanji> in someone, it's because you <vocabulary>distrust</vocabulary> them. Maybe someone <vocabulary>discredit</vocabulary>ed them and now you <vocabulary>mistrust</vocabulary> everything they say.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That oddball is giving me a distrusting stare.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの変人が不信の目でおれのことを見てくるんだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: WaniKani users' distrust of Tofugu just keeps getting stronger.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ワニカニユーザーのトーフグへの不信はつのるばかりだった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t you think that only partial release of the new Japanese learning material may feed suspicion that our company is covering up some facts?
Context 3-JP: <jp>新しい日本語学習教材を部分的に公開することは、我々の会社が何か事実を隠蔽しようとしているとの不信を招くかもしれないじゃないですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>closed</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is when a store's status is <vocabulary>store closed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>closed store</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: "What are your business hours?" "We are open from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「営業時間は何時から何時までですか？」「午前10時開店で、午後8時閉店となります。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Dedicate</kanji> your life to what you <kanji>believe</kanji> in and you'll have really strong <vocabulary>belief</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>faith</vocabulary> in whatever that thing is. Just try to dedicate yourself to something nice.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I think all Japanese citizens should believe in Shinto.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は日本国民全員が神道を信奉すべきだと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

A star is just a whole sheep (ほし) floating in the sky. If it wasn't a whole sheep, it wouldn't shine so brightly and you wouldn't be able to see it from Earth. Don't let anyone tell you stars are made of gas. The whole thing is sheep, okay?
Context 1-EN: That night the stars were really pretty.
Context 1-JP: <jp>夜には、星がとてもきれいでした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I hope we can see a lot of shooting stars tonight.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今夜はたくさんながれ星が見れるといいんですが。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Dad, why are you wearing star-shaped glasses today?
Context 3-JP: <jp>お父さん、どうして今日は星型の眼鏡をかけているの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>left</kanji> <kanji>arm</kanji> is your <vocabulary>left arm</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading can either be a combination of the kun'yomi readings (more common) or the on'yomi readings (pretty uncommon, and only used to talk about sports players, especially baseball). That being said, you've seen all of these readings except <jp>わん</jp>. If you want to remember <jp>さわん</jp> just think: I have just <reading>one</reading> (<jp>わん</jp>) left arm!
Context 1-EN: My left arm is broken.
Context 1-JP: <jp>左腕を骨折しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

You cut yourself and there's blood everywhere. You need to stop the bleeding with something, but the only thing nearby is a block of cheese. You grab the cheese and stuff it into your gash, but the blood comes out the holes (it is Swiss cheese, blargh!). Imagine this in great detail to be able to remember it well.
Context 1-EN: There is blood on your shirt.
Context 1-JP: <jp>シャツに血がついていますよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why does my bum bleed when I poop?
Context 2-JP: <jp>うんちをするときにおしりから血が出るのはなぜなんだ！</jp>
Context 3-EN: I like steak when it still has lots of blood in it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>血が滴るぐらいのステーキが好きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>go beyond</kanji>, the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to go beyond</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <vocabulary>to go beyond</vocabulary> <reading>child</reading> (<jp>こ</jp>) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in the USA, and 20 years old in Japan.
Context 1-EN: In Japanese, the song "I’ve Been Working on the Railroad" begins with, "the railroad continues forever, over fields, mountains, and valleys."
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本語では、線路は続くよどこまでもの歌は、「線路は続くよどこまでも、野を越え山越え谷越え」という感じで始まります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This almost shares the meaning with the kanji. It's essentially the same thing, though when it's alone it refers to a specific <vocabulary>piece of music</vocabulary> (aka a <vocabulary>tune</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well, so you should be able to read it.
Context 1-EN: What was the name of that song?
Context 1-JP: <jp>その曲の名まえ、何だったっけ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Are there any songs you would recommend?
Context 2-JP: <jp>何かおすすめの曲はありますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: He played a tune for us on the piano, but for some reason, the piano sounded like a guitar.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼がピアノで一曲弾いてくれたんですが、何故かそのピアノはギターの様な音がしたんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji's reading.
Context 1-EN: Working too much is harmful to your body.
Context 1-JP: <jp>働きすぎは体に毒ですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet is hiding a poison arrow in his desk drawer so that he can assassinate Koichi any time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトのつくえの引き出しには、コウイチをいつでも暗殺できるように毒の矢が仕こんである。</jp>
Context 3-EN: While puffer fish is very delicious and provides a deeply satisfying culinary experience, it also carries a deadly poison.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグはとても美味しく、食べる人の心を豊かにしてくれますが、一方で猛毒も持っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>visit</kanji> <kanji>problem</kanji> is when someone makes <vocabulary>a visit</vocabulary>, because you're the type of person who doesn't like visitors, since they're usually so inconsiderate and you have to feed them. That's why <vocabulary>a visit</vocabulary> is a visit problem.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: In Japan, you usually can’t go to the dentist and get everything done in just one visit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本では、通常歯医者に一回の訪問で治療を済ませてもらうことはできません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Small</kanji> <kanji>wheat</kanji> <kanji>powder</kanji> is <vocabulary>wheat flour</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>flour</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of all three kanji. The <jp>小</jp> and the <jp>粉</jp> both use kun'yomi that you haven't learned yet, but luckily they are both the same! Just think about how "small" things are like "children" (<jp>子</jp>), and "powder" is also small. So both <jp>小</jp> and <jp>粉</jp> are read <reading><jp>こ</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: Add three times more flour than water.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お水の三倍の量の小麦粉を入れてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is a sweet that is made by kneading flour.
Context 2-JP: <jp>これは小麦粉を練って作ったお菓子です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh no. I left the expensive flour I just bought on the train.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うわっ最悪。さっき買った高級小麦粉、電車に忘れちゃった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, at least on the <kanji>tendon</kanji> side of things.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You get a horrible tendon injury, making it so you can't walk anymore. You're so upset that you blame it on Jesus. So, you go and sue Jesus for this tendon injury, and win in court, amazingly.
Context 1-EN: I strained my leg when I was running.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ジョギングをしてる時に足の筋を痛めちゃってさ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I shall finally make beef tendon stew today.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日は久々に牛筋のに込みでも作ってみますか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Look, isn't it because you didn't cut the tendons before you fried it that the meat shrunk?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ほら、肉を焼く前にちゃんと筋を切っておかなかったから焼いたら縮んじゃったでしょ？</jp>

Meaning: To Enjoy,To Enjoy Oneself,To Have Fun
Meaning Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen the word <jp>楽しい</jp>, which means "fun." Now you're going to figure out the verb version (ends in an <jp>う</jp> sound, right?) of it. That would be <vocabulary>to enjoy</vocabulary>. Speaking of which, I hope you're enjoying WaniKani so far!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word <jp>楽しい</jp>, so be sure to know that word and you'll be able to apply it over here.
Context 1-EN: You can enjoy the beautiful ocean view from the window.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まどから、海の美しいけ色を楽しむことができます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We are having a lot of fun with this project.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このプロジェクト、みんなすごく楽しみながらやってます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Snap out of it, Usagi. Forget Tuxedo Mask and enjoy your life!
Context 3-JP: <jp>うさぎちゃん、いい加減目を覚ましなって。タキシード仮面のことなんか忘れて、うさぎちゃんはうさぎちゃんの人生を楽しんだらいいんだよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>action</kanji> that takes place that could <kanji>change</kanji> the locale or even the world has got to be a big <vocabulary>incident</vocabulary>. You'll sometimes see this on the ends of "incident" names, like the "Manshuu Jihen" (<jp>満州事変</jp>), aka the "Manshuu Incident." You know that it isn't an unusual or strange incident (like <jp>変事</jp>) because the "strange" kanji (<jp>変</jp>) doesn't come first with this word. Instead, it comes after and means "change" in this case.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What year did Shanghai Incident occur?
Context 1-JP: <jp>上海事変は何年に起こりましたか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I was looking for an example sentence with the word incident, I came across a band called Tokyo Incident.
Context 2-JP: <jp>事変という言葉を使った例文をさがしていたら、東京事変というバンドがあることを知りました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Can you explain what the Manchurian Incident is?
Context 3-JP: <jp>満州事変について説明をしてもらえますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>table</kanji> is a <vocabulary>calculator</vocabulary>. Why is this? You can think about it in a couple of different ways. Maybe in the past, a calculator (aka abacus) would take up a whole table, making this "electric" version a calculator. Or, maybe it can be used to solve tables. Wrong kind of table, but should help you to remember the meaning of this word.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Please stop drumming on the calculator. You’re driving me crazy!
Context 1-JP: <jp>頼むから電卓を叩くのをやめてくれ。気が狂いそうになるだろ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>field</kanji> of <kanji>livelihood</kanji> is so lively! Look at everything jumping around. It is so fresh and new and awesome! That being said, being so lively and fresh and new, it's pretty <vocabulary>unrefined</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rustic</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Our school is so stupid that they ban the use of social media by students.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの学校は本当に野暮だから、生徒たちのソーシャルメディアの利用を禁止してるんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

Tell me about your country. Now imagine your country covered in raccoons (くに), taking up every inch of the ground. In your country you have to walk on top of them there are so many. That's why your country is known as "(rac)coon country."
Context 1-EN: Which country are you from?
Context 1-JP: <jp>お国はどちらですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I thought this country was safe, but now I'm disappointed.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この国は安全だと思っていたのに、がっかりです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In my country, there is a shop that sells apple pies made by a cat.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の国には、猫が焼くアップルパイのお店がある。</jp>

Meaning: To Harden,To Solidify,To Become Firm,To Become Certain
Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen how <jp>固める</jp> means "to make hard." This word means that something hardened by itself, it means <vocabulary>to harden</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to solidify</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: Why are you guys packed into the corner like this?
Context 1-JP: <jp>みんな何でそんなすみっこに固まってるの？</jp>
Context 2-EN: My decision to quit Tofugu finally solidified.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ようやくトーフグをやめる決心が固まりました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think the pudding will finally harden soon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>そろそろプリンが固まる頃かしら。</jp>

Meaning: To Grow,To Spring Up,To Sprout,To Come Out
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. Remember how <jp>生きる</jp> means "to live?" Well this is what happens right after it starts to live. It begins <vocabulary>to grow</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When something starts to grow it also learns to laugh. Imagine a little plant growing out of the ground laughing. "Ha (は) ha ha ha!" it says, as it sprouts out of the ground.
Context 1-EN: My beard grows quickly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あごひげがよく生えます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: "Weeds grow," is Japanese Internet slang used when you think something's funny. It started because "w" (lol) looks like weeds.
Context 2-JP: <jp>「くさ生える」とは、おもしろいとおもったときにつかう日本のネットスラングで、「w」をくさに見立てたことからつかわれはじめました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do mushrooms grow in places like this?
Context 3-JP: <jp>こんなところにキノコが生えるのかね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>hunt</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a person who hunts. A <vocabulary>hunter</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned the reading of <jp>狩</jp> when you learned the kanji, but the reading for <jp>人</jp> is totally irregular. Just imagine that you're hunting a reindeer named <reading>Rudo</reading>lph (<jp>りゅうど</jp>). He has an unusually red nose, which makes him easy to spot and puts him at a bit of a disadvantage.
Context 1-EN: I didn’t know the hunters used the five-day workweek system.
Context 1-JP: <jp>狩人が週休二日制だってのは初耳だな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cloudy</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to get cloudy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to become cloudy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. It also happens to be the same as <jp>雲</jp>, which has a very similar meaning (clouds).
Context 1-EN: I don’t like it when my glasses get cloudy from ramen steam.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ラーメンの湯気で眼鏡が曇っちゃうのが好きじゃないんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>文化</jp> means "culture?" Well add <kanji>festival</kanji> to it and you end up with a <vocabulary>culture festival</vocabulary>! These happen all the time at Japanese schools, so sometimes they're called <vocabulary>school festival</vocabulary>s too.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned all of these readings already, good for you!
Context 1-EN: Please come visit my school’s culture festival!
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの学校の文化祭にもあそびに来てくださいね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: "What time should we start the school festival rehearsal?" "I'm available all day long, so anytime that suits you best."
Context 2-JP: <jp>「文化祭の練習、何時にする？」「おれは一日中ひまだから、そっちの都合の良い時なら何時でもいいよ。」</jp>
Context 3-EN: We've assessed administrative and overhead fees at about 35 percent of the total culture festival costs.
Context 3-JP: <jp>文化祭の管理諸経費は全体の約三十五パーセントになると見積っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>strange</kanji> <kanji>death</kanji> is one that doesn't seem right. It's an <vocabulary>unnatural death</vocabulary>, and probably an <vocabulary>accidental death</vocabulary> (ie wasn't caused by natural causes).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The police are investigating Koichi's unnatural death.
Context 1-JP: <jp>けいさつは、コウイチの変死についてちょうさしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: "You look upset. Is everything alright?" "I just heard that Koichi died an accidental death and Tofugu went bankrupt. It’s a nightmare."
Context 2-JP: <jp>「なんかパニクってるけど、どうしたの？」「コウイチは変死して、トーフグがとうさんするって聞いたんだよ。最悪だよ。」</jp>
Context 3-EN: The news that Koichi met a mysterious and unnatural death shocked the nation.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチが謎の変死を遂げたというニュースは、全国民を震撼させた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji it uses the kun'yomi reading. You've already learned this reading with the kanji, though, so you should be able to read this.
Context 1-EN: Every morning I walk in the forest.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎あさ、林をさんぽしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I happened to catch Mrs. Hayashi speed walking in the woods.
Context 2-JP: <jp>林先生が早足で林をあるいているのを見ちゃった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I couldn’t wait until I got to the house, so I left my wet socks in the woods.
Context 3-JP: <jp>家に帰るまで待てずに、林の中に濡れた靴下を残した。</jp>
